Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bowoto v. Chevron Texaco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Typical acts of parent corporation officers which are within the bounds of corporate formalities and do not warrant veil-piercing include: supervising the acts of the subsidiaries; receiving regular reports from the subsidiaries; creating general policies and procedures which the subsidiaries must follow; and overseeing the financial management of the subsidiaries.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether to pierce corporate veil on ratification theory was triable fact issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bowoto v. Chevron Texaco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Appropriate corporate parental involvement, which does not warrant veil-piercing, includes: monitoring of the subsidiary's performance, supervision of the subsidiary's finance and capital budget and articulation of general policies and procedures.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether to pierce corporate veil on ratification theory was triable fact issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bowoto v. Chevron Texaco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: There are no inflexible tests by which courts determine when to hold corporations liable for the acts of their subsidiaries; generally, the corporate separateness is respected unless to do so would work an injustice upon innocent third parties, but each case must be considered on its own facts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether to pierce corporate veil on ratification theory was triable fact issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bowoto v. Chevron Texaco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: In addition to the need for a close relationship or domination between the parent and subsidiary, agency liability also requires a finding that the injury allegedly inflicted by the subsidiary, for which the parent is being held liable, was within the scope of the subsidiary's authority as an agent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether to pierce corporate veil on ratification theory was triable fact issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bowoto v. Chevron Texaco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Test for whether subsidiaries and parent corporations are alter egos requires a determination whether: (1) there is such a unity of interest between the corporate personalities that they do not function as separate personalities and (2) failure to disregard the separate nature of the corporate entities would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether to pierce corporate veil on ratification theory was triable fact issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Parkinson v. Guidant Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: It is only where the parent corporation dominates a subsidiary to such a degree that the subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of the parent or amounts to a sham corporation that the corporate existence of the subsidiary may be disregarded under Pennsylvania law.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Unavoidably Unsafe Products. Prescription medical device was unavoidably unsafe product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Enic, PLC v. F.F. South & Co., Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fifth District.
Headnote: The parent corporation, to be liable for its subsidiary's acts under the agency theory, must exercise control to the extent the subsidiary manifests no separate corporate interests of its own and functions solely to achieve the purposes of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Personal jurisdiction was not established over subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Richmond v. Indalex Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina "mere instrumentality rule," used as test for disregarding the corporate veil, a corporation which exercises actual control over another, operating the latter as a mere instrumentality or tool, is liable for the torts of the corporation thus controlled, and in such instances, the separate identities of parent and subsidiary or affiliated corporations may be disregarded.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent companies' alleged control of an employer would not permit piercing corporate veil for employee's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Richmond v. Indalex Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under Delaware law, facts demonstrating parent companies' complete domination and control of subsidiary must be alleged to the point that subsidiary no longer has legal or independent significance of its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent companies' alleged control of an employer would not permit piercing corporate veil for employee's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Nobles v. Rural Community Ins. Services
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, subsidiary's parent corporation could not be held liable for subsidiary's actions, absent evidence that parent so controlled the operation of the subsidiary as to make it a mere adjunct, instrumentality, or alter ego of the parent.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Amended complaint adding new defendants did not relate back to filing of original complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: O'Brien v. Watco Contract Switching, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate ownership of a subsidiary and overlapping offices and directorates are not, without more, sufficient to impose liability on the parent for conduct of the subsidiary under a statute that does not itself pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Transportation Workers. Employer was not a common carrier under FELA as to worker employed in switching operation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Managed Care Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida, Miami Division.
Headnote: Direct liability for alleged wrong is imposed on parent corporation when parent has forced the subsidiary to take complained-of action in disregard of subsidiary's distinct legal personality.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Health care providers' contract-based claims against managed care insurers were not preempted by ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Luc v. Krause Werk GMBH & Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: In evaluating whether to disregard a corporate entity based on finding that a subsidiary is the alter ego for its parent corporation, the court considers whether: (1) parent corporation owns all or a majority of subsidiary's capital stock; (2) corporations have common directors or officers; (3) whether parent finances subsidiary; (4) parent subscribed to all of subsidiary's capital stock or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent, or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent corporation; (8) papers of parent and statements of its officers refer to subsidiary as such or as a department or division; (9) directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take direction from parent; and (10) formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Subsidiary manufacturer was alter ego of foreign parent company for purposes of personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Neilson v. Union Bank of California, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Mere fact that parent corporation owns stock of subsidiary will not suffice to prove that two entities are alter egos of one another, for purpose of imposing personal liability upon shareholders under California law for corporations' actions; rather, evidence must show that wholly-owned subsidiary is merely conduit for, or is financially dependent on, parent corporation.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Fraud. Investors sufficiently alleged that banks aided and abetted Ponzi scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: To determine whether parent corporation may be bound by agreement entered into by its subsidiary, factors to consider include whether: (1) parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent and subsidiary have common business departments; (4) parent and subsidiary file consolidated financial statements; (5) parent finances subsidiary; (6) parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary operated with grossly inadequate capital; (8) parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (9) subsidiary receives no business except that given by parent; (10) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (11) daily operations of the two corporations are not kept separate; (12) subsidiary does not observe corporate formalities; (13) directors of the subsidiary act in the primary and independent interest of the parent; (14) others pay or guarantee debts of the subsidiary; and (15) alleged parent deals with the subsidiary corporation at arms length.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Non-signatory Turkmenistan government could not be compelled to arbitrate a contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Langford Tool & Drill Co. v. Phenix Biocomposites, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: A subordinate corporation which has no purpose or existence apart from the operation of its cooperative owners may be considered merely an agency or arm of the parent.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Liens. Project was abandoned for purposes of subsequent mortgage priority over mechanic's lien.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Zamarron v. Shinko Wire Company, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: An alter ego relationship between parent and subsidiary corporations is not established merely by showing one hundred percent stock ownership, commonality of officers and directors, and an exercise of control derived from stock ownership; rather, proof of control by the parent over the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary must be shown to fuse the two corporations for jurisdictional purposes.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked general or specific jurisdiction over Japanese corporation in tort action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: M & A Oasis, Inc. v. MTM Associates, L.P
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Allegations that two subsidiaries dominated parent corporation and used their control to perpetrate a fraud upon plaintiff and that parent did not observe proper corporate formalities were sufficient to state claim seeking to pierce parent's corporate veil to reach the subsidiaries.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Two-year discovery statute of limitations applied to prospective purchaser's fraud claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Petition of Garcia Avila
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil or establish alter ego liability under New York law, creditor must show domination and control by the shareholder or parent, the use of that position to commit a wrong or perpetrate a fraud, and injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Foreign debtors were entitled to injunctive relief preventing interference with bond proceeds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Petition of Garcia Avila
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Mere domination and control, or a parent-subsidiary relationship, is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil or establish alter ego liability under New York law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Foreign debtors were entitled to injunctive relief preventing interference with bond proceeds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: IGEN Intern., Inc. v. Roche Diagnostics GmbH
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, the act of one corporation is not regarded as the act of another merely because the first corporation is a subsidiary of the other, or because the two may be treated as part of a single economic enterprise for some other purpose; rather, to pierce the corporate veil based on an agency or "alter ego" theory, the corporation must be a sham and exist for no other purpose than as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Continuation of suit against licensor was not sham, so licensee was immune from tort liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Reeves v. Mohawk Factoring, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: A subsidiary is generally considered under law to be a separate legal entity from its parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether subsidiary could recover debt owed to parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Diamond Chemical Co., Inc. v. Atofina Chemicals, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: To establish that subsidiary is alter ego of its parent, also referred to as "piercing the corporate veil," courts look to whether there is unity of ownership and interest.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Conspiracy. Clayton Act case against French corporation was not dismissed for lack of personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. Public Interest Research Group v. Atlantic Salmon of Maine, LLC.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maine.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced and parent held liable for subsidiary corporation's conduct when corporate form would otherwise be misused to accomplish certain wrongful purposes, most notably fraud, on parent's behalf.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Contempt. Salmon farm operator's use of wholly-owned subsidiary to stock smolt warranted contempt sanctions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Chrysler Corp. (Delaware) v. Chaplake Holdings, Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court of Delaware.
Headnote: In the parent-subsidiary context, it is appropriate to consider the extent of control exercised by the parent over the subsidiary in order to determine the scope of the agency relationship.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Pleading. Plaintiff could alternatively plead promissory estoppel and contact theories of liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Chrysler Corp. (Delaware) v. Chaplake Holdings, Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court of Delaware.
Headnote: Under the agency theory, the court may attribute the actions of a subsidiary company to its parent where the subsidiary acts on the parent's behalf or at the parent's direction.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Pleading. Plaintiff could alternatively plead promissory estoppel and contact theories of liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Ski Train Fire In Kaprun, Austria on Nov. 11, 2000
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under California law, a parent corporation is the alter ego of its subsidiary if it controls the subsidiary to such a degree as to render it the mere instrumentality of the parent.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Interests of justice required transfer of wrongful death lawsuit to Colorado federal court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Epps v. Stewart Information Services Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Arkansas law, parent corporation is not liable for debts of its subsidiary merely because parent holds controlling interest or because two are managed by same officers, rather, it is only when privilege of transacting business in corporate formhas been illegally abused to injury of third person that the corporate entities should be disregarded, and corporate veil pierced.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. Due process did not support exercise of personal jurisdiction over holding company in RESPA action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Precision, Inc. v. Kenco/Williams, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Delaware and Michigan courts will pierce the corporate veil and hold the parent company liable for acts of a subsidiary when there is such a complete identity between the defendant and the corporation as to suggest that one was simply the alter ego of the other; also, there must be evidence that the use of the corporation was improper.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not alter ego of its subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cuiksa v. Hallmark Hall of Fame Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: In determining whether subsidiary was "alter ego" of parent, under Kansas law, courts consider: (1) whether parent owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary, (2) whether corporations have common directors or officers, (3) whether parent finances subsidiary, (4) whether parent subscribed to all of capital stock of subsidiary or other wise causes its incorporation, (5) whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, (6) whether parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary, (7) whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent, (8) whether in papers of the parent, and in statements of its officers, subsidiary is referred to as such or as department or division, (9) whether directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take direction from parent, and (10) whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed; no single factor is conclusive.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Fact questions precluded summary judgment in injured worker's negligence action against film company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cuiksa v. Hallmark Hall of Fame Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Ultimate test in determining "alter ego" status, under Kansas law, is whether, from all of the facts and circumstances, it is apparent that relationship between parent and subsidiary is so intimate, parent's control over subsidiary is so dominating, and business and assets of two are so mingled that recognition of subsidiary as distinct entity would result in injustice to third parties.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Fact questions precluded summary judgment in injured worker's negligence action against film company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Orenbuch v. North Shore Health Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the corporate veil may be pierced either to prevent fraud or other wrong, or where a parent dominates or controls a subsidiary.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Debt collector's nondisclosure of relationship with affiliated organizations did not violate FDCPA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Firstar Bank, N.A. v. Faul Chevrolet, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois courts will only find that piercing of corporate veil is proper where failure to do so would: (1) unfairly enrich one of parties; (2) allow parent corporation to escape responsibility where it had created subsidiary's liabilities and was cause of subsidiary's inability to meet those liabilities; (3) allow former partners to ignore obligations; or (4) uphold corporate arrangement to keep assets in liability-free corporation while placing liabilities on asset-free corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Automobile dealership's creditor was not entitled to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Ascension Technology Corp. v. McDonald Investments, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Vermont.
Headnote: In cases where the parent so dominates and controls the subsidiary that the subsidiary's separate entity is essentially disregarded, the parent may be held legally accountable for the actions of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Investor failed to state claim for piercing corporate veil of parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under the Fletcher test used in determining whether a corporate veil should be pierced under Delaware law, plaintiff must show (1) that the parent and the subsidiary, in a parent corporation/subsidiary corporation context, operated as a single economic entity, and (2) that an overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Trustee failed to prove that debtor-subsidiary's corporate veil should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under the first prong of the Fletcher test used when undertaking, in a parent corporation/subsidiary corporation context, a corporate veil-piercing analysis under Delaware law, factors considered by the court include whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking, whether the corporation was solvent, whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed, whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds, and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Trustee failed to prove that debtor-subsidiary's corporate veil should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Fraud or injustice sufficient to pierce the corporate veil of a subsidiary or subsidiaries exists if a parent drains assets out of the same.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Trustee failed to prove that debtor-subsidiary's corporate veil should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Fraud or injustice sufficient to pierce the corporate veil of a subsidiary under Delaware law exists if a parent misuses the corporate form/veil of such subsidiary.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Trustee failed to prove that debtor-subsidiary's corporate veil should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: American Heritage Bancorp v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: Generally, a parent corporation is not liable for the acts of its subsidiaries, even where the directors of the parent corporation and the subsidiary are the same; however, a parent corporation may be held liable under both state and federal common law if it abuses the corporate form to accomplish wrongful purposes, such as fraud on the corporate parent's behalf.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - False Claims. Statute of limitations was not was not applicable to special plea in fraud counterclaim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Reiss v. Societe Centrale du Groupe des Assurances Nationales
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In general, a subsidiary-parent relationship is not sufficient to prove a principal-agent relationship.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Evidentiary hearing was required to determine jurisdiction under the FSIA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Union Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate form typically protects shareholders, directors and officers from personal liability for the acts of the corporation, even where there is a parent-subsidiary relationship between two corporations.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Past and current owners of contaminated site were responsible parties under CERCLA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Union Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Equity requires that courts pierce the corporate veil where necessary to prevent fraud, illegality, or injustice, or when recognition of the corporate entity would defeat public policy or shield someone from liability for a crime, or when the parent so dominated the subsidiary that it had no separate existence.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Past and current owners of contaminated site were responsible parties under CERCLA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Union Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Finding of liability against parent corporation for acts of a subsidiary does not require that all of the elements for piercing the corporate veil be satisfied, but rather, that under a totality of the circumstances, the evidence demonstrate that the parent exercised such pervasive control over the subsidiary that the subsidiary was merely the alter ego of the parent.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Past and current owners of contaminated site were responsible parties under CERCLA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: VanStelle v. Macaskill
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Absent some abuse of corporate form, parent and subsidiary corporations are presumed to be separate and distinct entities.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Malpractice. Hospital was not liable for alleged malpractice by physician under ostensible agency doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: DVI, Inc. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: A parent company's ownership or control of a subsidiary corporation does not, without more, subject the parent corporation to the jurisdiction of the state where the subsidiary does business.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Foreign parent corporation of subsidiary was not subject to general jurisdiction in California.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: DVI, Inc. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: A parent holding company may be subject to general jurisdiction in a state where a subsidiary does business only under limited circumstances, which includes an alter ego relationship or the parent's exercise of such a degree of control of the subsidiary as to reflect the parent's purposeful disregard of the subsidiary's independent corporate existence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Foreign parent corporation of subsidiary was not subject to general jurisdiction in California.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: DVI, Inc. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: General jurisdiction over a parent corporation may exist in an action against a subsidiary when evidence establishes the parent and the subsidiary are alter egos; the party asserting alter ego liability must establish such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist and an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Foreign parent corporation of subsidiary was not subject to general jurisdiction in California.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: DVI, Inc. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: If a foreign parent corporation exercises such a degree of control over its subsidiary corporation that the subsidiary can legitimately be described as only a means through which the parent acts, or nothing more than an incorporated department of the parent, the subsidiary will be deemed to be the agent of the parent in the forum state and jurisdiction will extend to the parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Foreign parent corporation of subsidiary was not subject to general jurisdiction in California.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Acree v. McMahan
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Sole ownership of corporation by one person or another corporation is not a factor in determining whether to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Issue of whether shareholder breached buyout agreement by failing to make payments was for jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hazard Coal Corp. v. Kentucky West Virginia Gas Co., L.L.C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, separate corporate interests, including subsidiaries and affiliates, are separate legal entities and must be recognized and treated as such unless there is some reason to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Oil and Gas. Mineral rights owner, its lessee, and coal mining company had to pay for relocation of gas pipelines.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Greene v. New Dana Perfumes Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Delaware courts are very cautious about imputing even the acts of wholly-owned Delaware subsidiaries to parent corporations without an analysis of whether corporate veil should be pierced or whether parent corporation actively employed subsidiary as its mere agent or instrumentality.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Jurisdiction. Court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over foreign subsidiary on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Sunbeam Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, corporate veil can be pierced when there is fraud, or when subsidiary is in fact mere instrumentality or alter ego of owner.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transactions could not be collapsed for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Sunbeam Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To establish "alter ego" liability under Delaware law, plaintiff must show (1) that parent and subsidiary operated as single economic entity; and (2) that overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transactions could not be collapsed for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Sunbeam Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Among factors which a Delaware court considers in deciding whether parent and subsidiary operated as a single economic entity, such that it would be inequitable to uphold legal distinction between them, are as follows: (1) whether corporation was adequately capitalized for corporate undertaking; (2) whether corporation was solvent; (3) whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and (5) whether, in general, corporation simply functioned as facade for dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transactions could not be collapsed for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Sunbeam Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to support claim for alter ego liability under Delaware law, and to establish that corporate subsidiary was mere facade for dominant parent, it is not sufficient to show mere domination and control of the subsidiary by parent; rather, domination shown must be complete domination concerning the transaction at issue; extent of domination and control must preclude the controlled entity from having legal or independent significance of its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transactions could not be collapsed for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hersey v. Lonrho, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Where corporate formalities are substantially observed and the parent does not dominate the subsidiary, a parent and a subsidiary are two separate entities and the acts of one cannot be attributed to the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil properly was not pierced for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Interfaith Community Organization v. Honeywell Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Generally, it is deeply ingrained in our economic and legal systems that a parent corporation is not liable for the acts of its subsidiaries; however, where the parent/subsidiary relationship appears to be a facade created merely to perpetrate a fraud or evade the law, veil-piercing is permitted and shareholders, or parent corporations, may be found liable for the actions of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Factors weighted against piercing veil to make parent corporation liable for CERCLA cleanup costs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Interfaith Community Organization v. Honeywell Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Veil piercing is proper when a subsidiary is an alter ego or instrumentality of the parent corporation.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Factors weighted against piercing veil to make parent corporation liable for CERCLA cleanup costs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Feinberg v. Katz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a parent corporation may not pierce the corporate veil it set up for its own benefit in order to advance the claims of its subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Purchasing shareholder had standing to recover for pre-sale acts of mismanagement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Feinberg v. Katz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a parent corporation cannot create a subsidiary and then ignore its separate corporate existence whenever it would be advantageous to the parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Purchasing shareholder had standing to recover for pre-sale acts of mismanagement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: APS Sports Collectibles, Inc. v. Sports Time, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce veil between parent corporation and subsidiary under Illinois law, plaintiff must make substantial showing that one corporation is really dummy or sham for another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Officers and shareholders were not liable for corporation's alleged unlawful transfer of assets.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Praseuth v. Newell-Rubbermaid, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Factors considered under integrated enterprise test for determining parent corporation's liability for acts of subsidiary are: (1) interrelation of operations, (2) centralized control of labor relations, (3) common management, and (4) common ownership or financial control.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Parent corporation was not liable to employee of subsidiary for subsidiary's alleged discrimination.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: OTR Associates v. IBC Services, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Basic finding that must be made to enable the court to pierce the corporate veil is that the parent so dominated the subsidiary that it had no separate existence but was merely a conduit for the parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil was properly pierced to hold parent corporation liable for leasing subsidiary's debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: OTR Associates v. IBC Services, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil in regard to parent corporation and its subsidiary, court must find, beyond parent's domination of subsidiary, that parent has abused the privilege of incorporation by using the subsidiary to perpetrate a fraud or injustice, or otherwise to circumvent the law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil was properly pierced to hold parent corporation liable for leasing subsidiary's debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: BMC Software Belgium, N.V. v. Marchand
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: A subsidiary corporation will not be regarded as the alter ego of its parent merely because of stock ownership, a duplication of some or all of the directors or officers, or an exercise of the control that stock ownership gives to stockholders.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court did not have jurisdiction over foreign subsidiary of Houston based corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re U-Haul Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: For the purposes of legal proceedings, subsidiary corporations and parent corporations are separate and distinct "persons" as a matter of law and the separate entity of corporations will be observed by the courts even where one company may dominate or control, or even treat another company as a mere department, instrumentality, or agency.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Sanctions. Manufacturer and insurer were not on business enterprise, and thus discovery sanctions were not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Minton v. Ralston Purina Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: A parent corporation may be liable for the acts of a wholly owned subsidiary when state law supports piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Claimant's recovery was limited to workers' compensation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Minton v. Ralston Purina Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and find a parent corporation liable, the party seeking relief must show that there is an overt intention by the corporation to disregard the corporate entity in order to avoid a duty owed to the party seeking to invoke the doctrine.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Claimant's recovery was limited to workers' compensation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Minton v. Ralston Purina Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: Generally, to pierce the corporate veil and find a parent corporation liable for the acts of a subsidiary, a party must show that the corporation manipulated the entities in order to avoid the legal duty.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Claimant's recovery was limited to workers' compensation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Scandinavian Satellite System, AS v. Prime TV Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: The law sometimes disregards the separate corporate forms of parent and subsidiary corporations to hold one accountable for the actions of another, especially when a failure to do so would work fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. Contract defense did not preclude district court jurisdiction over copyright claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Scandinavian Satellite System, AS v. Prime TV Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: Before it can be found that a parent and subsidiary corporation are one entity in the eyes of the law, it must first be determined whether the subsidiary is in fact controlled by the parent.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. Contract defense did not preclude district court jurisdiction over copyright claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Scandinavian Satellite System, AS v. Prime TV Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: Whether a parent and subsidiary corporation have a unity of interest, such that one may be held accountable for the actions of the other, cannot be determined without an examination of the control exercised by the parent over the subsidiary.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. Contract defense did not preclude district court jurisdiction over copyright claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Wady v. Provident Life and Accident Ins. Co. of America
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be directly involved in financing and macro-management of its subsidiaries without exposing itself to charge that each subsidiary is merely its alter ego.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Parent holding company could not be held liable for insurer's actions under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Wady v. Provident Life and Accident Ins. Co. of America
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Financial transactions between parent and subsidiary do not make the parent liable for subsidiary's debts, under alter ego theory, unless parent attempts to liquidate the subsidiary for purpose of avoiding its liabilities.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Parent holding company could not be held liable for insurer's actions under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Eure v. Norfolk Shipbuilding & Drydock Corp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Before the corporate entity may be properly disregarded and the parent corporation held liable for the acts of its subsidiary, it must be shown not only that undue domination and control was exercised by the parent corporation over the subsidiary, but also that this control was exercised in such a manner as to defraud and wrong the complainant, and that unjust loss or injury will be suffered by the complainant as the result of such domination unless the parent corporation is held liable.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Agreement was ambiguous as to continuation of officers' medical expense reimbursement plan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Milford v. Commercial Carriers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Florida law permits courts to pierce the corporate veil if a subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of the parent and there is some form of improper conduct.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unemployment Compensation. Dual personality exception to exclusive remedy provision of Illinois Workers Compensation Act applied to employee's tort claim against his employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: E.E.O.C. v. Preferred Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Indianapolis Division.
Headnote: To hold parent corporation liable for act of its affiliate, plaintiff must show that parent took some action so as to forfeit its separate and independent status.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. EEOC's investigation of alleged religious discrimination did not violate establishment clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: E.E.O.C. v. Preferred Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Indianapolis Division.
Headnote: Three sorts of actions qualify to establish liability in parent corporation for acts of its affiliates: (1) actions that would traditionally permit court to pierce corporate veil, (2) action for express purpose of avoiding liability under discrimination laws, or (3) where parent corporation might have directed discriminatory act, practice, or policy of which employee of its subsidiary was complaining.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. EEOC's investigation of alleged religious discrimination did not violate establishment clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bagel Bros. Maple, Inc. v. Ohio Farmers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, party seeking to pierce the veil between a corporate parent and its subsidiary must show: (1) that subsidiary is mere instrumentality of parent, and (2) that subsidiary is being used by parent in order to commit or conceal fraud or other wrongdoing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Veil Piercing. Debtor-corporation could not be held liable for related corporate entities' debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Minnesota ex rel. Hatch v. Fleet Mortg. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Except in unusual circumstances, courts will not disregard the separate identities of a parent and its subsidiary, even a wholly-owned subsidiary.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Industry Regulation. Bank subsidiary was subject to FTC's telemarketing sales rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Motorsport Engineering, Inc. v. Maserati, S.p.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Generally, under Massachusetts law, sibling corporations do not share their liabilities absent unusual circumstances, even when owned by a holding company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Creation of successor corporation did not result in successor assuming predecessor's liabilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Binder v. Bristol-Myers Squibb, Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, two general theories of liability exist under which parent corporation may be held responsible for obligations of its subsidiaries: alter ego and agency principles.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Corporation which purchased manufacturer of mammary prostheses did not assume its liabilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Binder v. Bristol-Myers Squibb, Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Alter ego relationship, under which parent corporation may be held responsible for obligations of its subsidiaries under Delaware law, might exist where corporate parent exercises complete domination and control over its subsidiaries.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Corporation which purchased manufacturer of mammary prostheses did not assume its liabilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Binder v. Bristol-Myers Squibb, Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation may be deemed alter ego of its corporate parent, permitting parent to be held responsible for obligations of subsidiary under Delaware law, where there is lack of attention to corporate formalities, such as where assets of two entities are commingled, and their operations intertwined.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Corporation which purchased manufacturer of mammary prostheses did not assume its liabilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Binder v. Bristol-Myers Squibb, Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Fraud, or something like it, is required before subsidiary corporation may be deemed alter ego of its corporate parent, permitting parent to be held responsible for obligations of subsidiary under Delaware law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Corporation which purchased manufacturer of mammary prostheses did not assume its liabilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Binder v. Bristol-Myers Squibb, Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Liability for activities of subsidiary will attach to parent corporation pursuant to agency theory, under Delaware law, only if parent dominates those activities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Corporation which purchased manufacturer of mammary prostheses did not assume its liabilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Binder v. Bristol-Myers Squibb, Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Factors to consider in determining whether parent corporation dominates activities of subsidiary, as required to hold parent responsible for obligations of subsidiary pursuant to agency theory under Delaware law, include stock ownership, officers and directors, financing, responsibility for day-to-day operations, arrangements for payment of salaries and expenses, and origin of subsidiary's business and assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Corporation which purchased manufacturer of mammary prostheses did not assume its liabilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Heslop v. UCB, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Fact that one corporation is parent of another is not sufficient to warrant treating two corporations as one, under Kansas law, without showing that one exercises undue control over internal affairs of other.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Pleading. Terminated employee failed to state claim for fraudulent misrepresentation against employers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Heslop v. UCB, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, where it is apparent relationship between parent corporation and its subsidiary is so intimate, the parent's control over the subsidiary is so dominating, and business and assets of the two are so mingled that recognition of distinct entity would result in injustice to third persons, courts will look through legal fiction of separate entities and treat them as justice requires.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Pleading. Terminated employee failed to state claim for fraudulent misrepresentation against employers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Heslop v. UCB, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Guidelines considered under Kansas law for determining alter ego status include: (1) whether parent owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary, (2) whether corporations have common directors or officers, (3) whether parent finances subsidiary, (4) whether parent subscribed to all of the capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, (5) whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, (6) whether parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary, (7) whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent, or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent, (8) whether in papers of parent, and in statements of its officers, subsidiary is referred to as such or as a department or division, (9) whether directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take direction from parent, and (10) whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are observed.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Pleading. Terminated employee failed to state claim for fraudulent misrepresentation against employers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Sun Trust Bank v. Sun International Hotels, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under Florida law, and impute subsidiaries' activities directly to parents, plaintiffs must allege (1) that subsidiaries are mere instrumentalities of parent, and (2) that defendants engaged in improper conduct in formation or use of corporations.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Forum-selection clause on preprinted hotel registration form was unenforceable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Wilkins v. North American Const. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego doctrine applies when there is such unity between parent corporation and its subsidiary that the separateness of the two corporations has ceased and holding only subsidiary corporation liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - False Claims. Allegations of hidden costs did not meet requirements of False Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Wilkins v. North American Const. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, twelve factors to be assessed when determining whether a subsidiary is the alter ego of its parent are: (1) parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent and subsidiary have common business departments; (4) parent and subsidiary file consolidated financial statements and tax returns; (5) parent finances subsidiary; (6) parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital; (8) parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (9) subsidiary receives no business except that given by parent; (10) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (11) daily operations of the two corporations are not kept separate; and (12) subsidiary does not observe basic corporate formalities, such as keeping separate books and records and holding shareholder and board meetings.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - False Claims. Allegations of hidden costs did not meet requirements of False Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: UST Corp. v. General Road Trucking Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: If the circumstances of the case show that a parent-subsidiary relationship existed between corporations and it was demonstrated that the parent dominated the finances, policies, and practices of the subsidiary, then a court should pierce the corporate veil and hold the parent liable as an alter ego for the subsidiary's breach of contract.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Joint venturer was entitled to a new trial to determine its lost profits from breach of the agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: UST Corp. v. General Road Trucking Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: If the totality of circumstances surrounding a corporate parent-subsidiary relationship indicates that one of the corporations is so organized and controlled, and its affairs are so conducted, as to make it merely an instrumentality, agency, conduit, or adjunct of one or more other entities, then a court should pierce the corporate veil and hold these other entities liable.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Joint venturer was entitled to a new trial to determine its lost profits from breach of the agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Russell v. Enterprise Rent-A-Car Co. of Rhode Island
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: To determine whether parent corporation and its subsidiary maintained separate corporate identities for alter ego analysis, district court examines factors that demonstrate whether corporate formalities have been observed, including whether parent corporation and its subsidiary were separately incorporated, had separate boards of directors, maintained separate financial records, and had separate facilities and operating personnel.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employer's non-resident parent corporation was not subject to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Jacobs v. Felix Bloch Erben Verlag fur Buhne Film und Funk KG
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a corporate entity is considered to be a "mere department" of a parent company only where the control of the lesser entity is pervasive enough that the corporate separation is more formal than real.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. German producers were not doing business in New York.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Jacobs v. Felix Bloch Erben Verlag fur Buhne Film und Funk KG
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Test under New York law for evaluating whether one corporation is a mere department of another involves consideration of four factors: (1) proof of nearly identical ownership interests is essential to a finding that one corporation is a mere department of another; (2) financial dependency of the subsidiary on the parent corporation; (3) the degree to which the parent interferes in the selection and assignment of the subsidiary's executive personnel and fails to observe corporate formalities; and (4) the extent of the parent's control over the subsidiary's marketing and operational policies.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. German producers were not doing business in New York.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Great Neck Plaza, L.P. v. Le Peep Restaurants, LLC
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. I.
Headnote: The corporate veil may be pierced where the subsidiary is merely an alter ego of the principal.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Attachment and Garnishment. Alter ego and fraudulent transfer could be litigated in garnishment proceeding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
