Title: Great Neck Plaza, L.P. v. Le Peep Restaurants, LLC
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. I.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard the corporate entity, court may consider certain factors, not all of which must be shown, including: (1) parent corporation owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent finances the subsidiary; (4) parent subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) parent pays salaries, expenses, or losses of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; (8) in parent's papers and in statements of its officers, "the subsidiary" is referred to as such or as department or division; (9) directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take direction from parent; and (10) formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Attachment and Garnishment. Alter ego and fraudulent transfer could be litigated in garnishment proceeding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Smotherman v. Texaco Exploration and Production, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: Factors to consider in applying alter ego doctrine to subsidiary corporation include: (1) common stock ownership; (2) common directors or officers; (3) common business departments; (4) filing of consolidated financial and tax statements; (5) parent finances subsidiary; (6) parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital; (8) parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (9) subsidiary receives no business except that given to it by parent; (10) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (11) daily operations of two corporations are not kept separate; (12) subsidiary does not observe basic corporate formalities, such as keeping separate books and records and holding shareholder and board meetings; or (13) directors and officers of subsidiary act independently in the interest of that company, or whether they take their orders from parent and act in parent's interest.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Texas corporation was fraudulently to destroy diversity jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Graham Graphics, Inc. v. Baer Marketing Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: The notion of separate corporate existence of parent and subsidiary or affiliated corporations will not be recognized where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its business conducted in such a manner as to make it merely an agency, instrumentality, adjunct, or alter ego of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Successor parent corporation was liable for subsidiary's debt to printer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Graham Graphics, Inc. v. Baer Marketing Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil between a parent and a subsidiary, a plaintiff must show more than the mere sharing of services between the two corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Successor parent corporation was liable for subsidiary's debt to printer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Graham Graphics, Inc. v. Baer Marketing Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Fact that successor parent corporation was not yet in existence when contract for printing services was made by subsidiary did not preclude it from being held liable for subsidiary's debt to graphics company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Successor parent corporation was liable for subsidiary's debt to printer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: "Alter ego doctrine" is applied to disregard the corporate fiction when there is such unity between a corporation and its subsidiary that the separateness of the latter has ceased, and holding only the subsidiary liable would lead to injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Evidence that a subsidiary is not reasonably capitalized in light of the nature and risk of its business is a factor which weighs in favor of corporate veil-piercing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Control is part of the normal framework of a parent/subsidiary relationship, and a blending of corporate activities is insufficient to show that the subsidiary is an alter ego of the parent, as will permit the corporate veil to be pierced.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Courts will usually decline to hold that a subsidiary is the alter ego of a parent unless the corporate entity of the subsidiary is a sham being used to commit a fraud, avoid financial responsibility, or break the law, and exceptional circumstances are required to invoke this remedy.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: ORI, Inc. v. Lanewala
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, alter ego relationship exists between parent and subsidiary where totality of circumstances shows that separation of two entities has not been maintained and injustice would occur to third parties if separate entity were recognized.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Employer did not suffer any damages by employee's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Carballo-Rodriguez v. Clark Equipment Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Generally, parent corporation is not liable for acts of its subsidiaries.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Parent corporation was not liable for subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Starner v. Guardian Industries
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Generally, a parent corporation is not liable for the actions of its subsidiary, even if the subsidiary is wholly owned by the parent corporation; however, under certain circumstances, corporate entity may be disregarded and a parent corporation and its subsidiary may be treated as a single entity.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employee did not establish sex discrimination claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Shelley v. Flow Intern. Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: For a subsidiary corporation to be considered the alter ego of the parent corporation, there must be direct intervention by the parent in the management of the subsidiary to such an extent that the subsidiary's paraphernalia of incorporation, directors and officers' are completely ignored.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Contractors and Developers. General contractor on highway project was not liable for injuries suffered by subcontractor's employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Doe v. Unocal Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: To demonstrate that parent and subsidiary are not really separate entities and satisfy alter ego exception to general rule that subsidiary and parent are separate entities, plaintiff must make out prima facie case: (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of entities no longer exist; and (2) that failure to disregard their separate identities would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Burmese plaintiffs did not show personal jurisdiction over French corporate defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Doe v. Unocal Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be directly involved in financing and macro-management of its subsidiaries without exposing itself to charge that each subsidiary is merely its alter ego.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Burmese plaintiffs did not show personal jurisdiction over French corporate defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Doe v. Unocal Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: References in parent's annual report to subsidiaries or chains of subsidiaries as divisions of parent company do not establish existence of alter ego relationship.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Burmese plaintiffs did not show personal jurisdiction over French corporate defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Wausau Business Ins. Co. v. Turner Const. Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts may pierce the veil cloaking a parent corporation from liability for the conduct of its subsidiary if necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Intermingling of funds and sharing of officers raised fact issue on whether to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Wausau Business Ins. Co. v. Turner Const. Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, whether a subsidiary is an alter ego of its corporate parent is a fact-intensive inquiry that must take into consideration a variety of factors: (1) failure to observe corporate formalities; (2) undercapitalization; (3) intermingling of corporate funds; (4) overlap in corporate officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) the amount of business discretion exercised by the subsidiary corporation; (7) whether the two companies deal with each other at arm's length; (8) whether the corporations exist as independent sources of profit; (9) the guarantee of the subsidiary's debts by the parent; and (10) common use of corporate property.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Intermingling of funds and sharing of officers raised fact issue on whether to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Wausau Business Ins. Co. v. Turner Const. Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, no single one of the multiple factors to be considered in determining whether a subsidiary is an alter ego of its corporate parent is dispositive; liability is imposed to reach an equitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Intermingling of funds and sharing of officers raised fact issue on whether to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Pearson v. Component Technology Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Parent corporations may be directly liable for their subsidiaries' actions when the alleged wrong can seemingly be traced to the parent through the conduit of its own personnel and management, and the parent has interfered with the subsidiary's operations in a way that surpasses the control exercised by a parent as an incident of ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. Secured creditor was not liable under WARN for employer's unnoticed plant closure.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Real Estate Investors Four, Inc. v. American Design Group Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: To determine whether one corporation completely controls another, for purposes of piercing corporate veil, court considers whether (1) parent owns all or most of subsidiary's stock, (2) corporations have common directors or officers, (3) parent finances subsidiary, (4) parent causes incorporation of subsidiary, (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, (6) parent pays subsidiary's expenses or losses, (7) subsidiary lacks its own substantial business or assets, (8) parent's corporate papers describe subsidiary as department or division, (9) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own, (10) subsidiary's directors or executives take orders from parent in parent's interest, or (11) subsidiary fails to observe legal formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual occupant of premises leased to corporation was liable to lessor under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gagliardi v. Universal Outdoor Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: General rule that parent corporation is not responsible for liabilities of subsidiary does not apply where parent and subsidiary are so interconnected that they are one and the same, or "alter egos" of one another.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Jurisdiction was lacking over corporations not named in EEOC charge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gagliardi v. Universal Outdoor Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Criteria court must use to evaluate whether parent and subsidiary corporations are related, so as to impose alter ego liability, are: (1) interrelation of operations, (2) centralized control of labor relations, (3) common management, and (4) common ownership or financial control.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Jurisdiction was lacking over corporations not named in EEOC charge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gammill v. Lincoln Life and Annuity Distributors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Jackson Division.
Headnote: Factors in whether corporate veil may be pierced under Mississippi law include whether: (1) parent owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent finances subsidiary; (4) parent subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; (8) in papers of parent corporation and in statements of its officers "subsidiary" is referred to as such or as department or division; (9) subsidiary's directors or executives do not act independently in subsidiary's interest but take direction from parent; and (10) formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Mere fact of parent-subsidiary relationship was insufficient to establish alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Nichols v. Pabtex, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: While limited liability remains the norm in American corporation law, an exception exists where a parent company totally dominates and controls its subsidiary, operating the subsidiary as its business conduit or agent.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Employee, who already received worker's compensation benefits, was not precluded from recovering under FELA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Commerce Bank, N.A. v. Liebau-Woodall & Associates, L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: The factors to assess the unity of interest of separate legal entities, under corporate alter ego doctrine, are: (1) whether the parent owns all or a majority of the capital stock of the subsidiary; (2) whether the organizations have common directors or officers; (3) whether the parent finances the subsidiary; (4) whether the parent subscribed to all of the capital stock of the subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) whether the subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) whether the parent pays the salaries or expenses or losses of the subsidiary; (7) whether the subsidiary has substantially no business except with the parent, or no assets except those conveyed to it by the parent; (8) whether in the papers of the parent, and in the statements of its officers, the subsidiary is referred to as such or as a department or division; (9) whether the directors or executives of the subsidiary do not act independently in the interest of the subsidiary but take direction from the parent; and (10) whether the formal legal requirements of the subsidiary as a separate and independent organization are not observed.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Remand was required to determine if liquidation trustee for securities firm was necessary party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Soerries v. Dancause
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, sole ownership of a corporation by one person or another corporation is not a factor, and neither is the fact that the sole owner uses and controls it to promote his ends, but rather there must be evidence of abuse of the corporate form, and plaintiff must show that the defendant disregarded the separateness of legal entities by commingling on an interchangeable or joint basis or confusing the otherwise separate properties, records or control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to support verdict piercing corporate veil in dramshop case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Amsellem v. Host Marriott Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In order for the subsidiary's activities to warrant the exercise of jurisdiction over the parent, the parent company's degree of control over the subsidiary's activities must be so complete that the subsidiary is, in fact, merely a department of the parent.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Discovery was required to determine if foreign hotel operator was subject to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rodriguez v. Riddell Sports, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, a court will not disregard the corporate fiction of a parent company and hold it liable for the obligations of its subsidiary except where it appears that the corporate entity of the subsidiary is being used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, to avoid liability, to avoid the effect of a statute, or in other exceptional circumstances.
Document Preview: TORTS - Emotional Distress. Mother of injured high school football player could not recover damages as a bystander.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: PayPhone LLC v. Brooks Fiber Communications of Rhode Island
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Separate corporate identities of a parent and subsidiary are entitled to recognition as long as the two corporations observe corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation could not pierce own veil for jurisdiction purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Linko v. Indemn. Ins. Co. of N. Am.
Court: Supreme Court of Ohio.
Headnote: While a parent corporation may have a close relationship with its subsidiary, the two remain separate and distinct legal entities.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Automobile. Each separately incorporated named insured must be listed on UM/UIM rejection form.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. CMC Steel Fabricators, Inc. v. Harrop Const. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Corpus Christi Division.
Headnote: Texas law honors the distinction between corporations and their subsidiaries unless the parent manipulates the relationship between itself and its subsidiary to such degree that the lines of distinction between the two corporations are blurred and the protection of the parent would work an injustice on those injured by the parent.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Supplier was not liable for consequential damages caused by breach of contract and fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Caligiuri v. First Colony Life Ins. Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Sixth Division.
Headnote: Stock ownership alone in one corporation by another is common in a parent-subsidiary relationship and does not create the relation of principal and agent or alter ego between the two.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Arbitration. Subsidiary was not broker-dealer's agent entitled to invoke arbitration clause in cash management account agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rebh v. Rotterdam Ventures Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show complete domination and control of the subsidiary by the parent and also that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff that resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent's acquisition of subsidiary's assets at foreclosure sale did not warrant veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: T & S Products, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: A parent corporation and a subsidiary are in law separate and distinct entities, and under ordinary circumstances a contract in terms and in name with one corporation cannot be treated as that of both, and a parent will not be liable for the obligations of its subsidiaries.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS - Bidding. Contracting agency could consider parent company's promised resources in evaluating bid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund v. Reimer Express World Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Where corporate formalities are substantially observed and parent does not dominate the subsidiary, parent and subsidiary are two separate entities and the acts of one cannot be attributed to the other.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Federal statute that premises liability on corporate affiliation will not confer personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gabriel Capital, L.P. v. NatWest Finance, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, corporate veil may be pierced under alter ego rationale when parent and subsidiary operated as single economic entity and overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Claim that Thailand steel mill would be first class was actionable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Dews v. Ratterree
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Because the cardinal rule of corporate law is that a corporation possesses a legal existence separate and apart from that of its officers and shareholders, the mere operation of corporate business does not render one personally liable for corporate acts, and in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, sole ownership of a corporation by one person or another corporation is not a factor, and neither is the fact that the sole owner uses and controls it to promote his ends, but instead there must be some evidence of abuse of the corporate form, and the plaintiff must show that the defendant disregarded the separate entities by commingling on an interchangeable or joint basis or confusing the otherwise separate properties records or control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Question of whether corporate veil of garage door company should be pierced in tort action was for jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: MeterLogic, Inc. v. Copier Solutions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: In order for parent corporation to be liable for its subsidiary's acts under agency theory, under Florida law, parent must exercise control to extent subsidiary manifests no separate corporate interests of its own and functions solely to achieve purposes of parent corporation
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court lacked jurisdiction over corporate parents in contract case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Greater Hammond Community Services, Inc. v. Mutka
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Distinct corporations, even parent and subsidiary corporations, are presumed separate; to overcome this presumption, plaintiff must show that one corporation dominated another to the extent that the subordinate was the mere instrumentality of the dominant corporation, that the dominant corporation employed the subordinate to perpetrate a fraud, or that the capital placed in the subordinate was illusory or trifling compared to the business to be done and the risks of loss, and also must demonstrate that the defalcation of the corporations, for example, fraud, was the proximate cause of the injury sustained.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Immunity. Regional community services organization was not protected by Tort Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Sonora Diamond Corp. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Parent corporation is not exposed to liability for the obligations of a subsidiary pursuant to alter ego doctrine when the parent contributes funds to the subsidiary for the purpose of assisting the subsidiary in meeting its financial obligations, and not for the purpose of perpetrating a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Canadian parent corporation of Nevada subsidiary was not subject to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Computer Engineering Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil may be pierced either to prevent fraud or other wrong, or where a parent dominates and controls a subsidiary.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Joint deposit arrangement was not absolute transfer of debtor-contractor's interest in payments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Medina v. Four Winds Intern. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Under Wyoming law, parent company can be held liable for acts of its subsidiary where it assumed some independent legal duty by retaining or exercising control over some aspect of operation of subsidiary corporation that was involved in incident resulting in plaintiff's injuries.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parties injured in traffic accident could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Medina v. Four Winds Intern. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Under Wyoming law, parent becomes liable for acts of its subsidiary only where it exercises control over aspect of subsidiary's operation that caused plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parties injured in traffic accident could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Medina v. Four Winds Intern. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Under Wyoming law, parent corporation and subsidiary's unity of ownership and interlocking directorates, standing alone, are not sufficient basis upon which to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parties injured in traffic accident could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Medina v. Four Winds Intern. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Beyond mere unity of ownership, Wyoming law requires higher showing of unfairness and will disregard separate corporate identities only where doing so will prevent fraud, injustice or wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parties injured in traffic accident could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Backuswalcott v. Common Ground Community HDFC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts apply the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil reluctantly and only when the subsidiary is so dominated by the parent company that it is merely an instrumentality of the parent.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Not-for-profit corporation fell within FDCPA's affiliate exemption.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: S & Davis Intern., Inc. v. The Republic of Yemen
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Relationship of principal and agent does not obtain unless the alleged principal has manifested its desire for subsidiary to act upon its behalf, unless subsidiary has consented so to act, unless alleged principal has right to exercise control over subsidiary with respect to matters entrusted to it, and unless alleged principal exercises its control in manner more direct than by voting majority of stock in the subsidiary or by making appointments to subsidiary's board of directors.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Foreign Sovereigns. Foreign sovereign did not impliedly waive its immunity by agreement to arbitrate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Kneepkins v. Gambro Healthcare, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Ownership, even total ownership, of a corporation does not by itself impart the corporation's liabilities to the owner, and that rule is not abated simply because the owner happens to be another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not accountable for alleged Medicare fraud of subsidiary's predecessor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Kneepkins v. Gambro Healthcare, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under certain circumstances, the corporate veil may be pierced and an owner or parent may be held accountable for a corporation's liabilities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not accountable for alleged Medicare fraud of subsidiary's predecessor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Kneepkins v. Gambro Healthcare, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under federal law, corporate veil may be pierced to hold parent corporation accountable for subsidiary's liabilities only if the parent and subsidiary lacked independence, the principals conducted their affairs with a requisite degree of fraudulent intent, and failure to pierce the veil would work substantial injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not accountable for alleged Medicare fraud of subsidiary's predecessor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: McConkey v. McGhan Medical Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Breast implant recipient failed to make a showing that former parent company controlled former subsidiary at time subsidiary manufactured recipient's implants, despite loan made by parent company to subsidiary, and therefore could not pierce the corporate veil, as prerequisite to imposing liability under Tennessee law on theories of instrumentality, alter ego, or parent/subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Breast implant recipient failed to make showing that former parent company controlled former subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Kayser-Roth Corp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Under Rhode Island law, corporate veil may be pierced if it is demonstrated that parent dominated finances, policies and practices of subsidiary, or when corporate form is misused to accomplish wrongful purposes, including fraud, on shareholders' behalf.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Parent was operator under CERCLA due to amount of control over environmental operations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Daimler-Benz Aktiengesellschaft v. Olson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Courts must examine all relevant circumstances to determine whether parent and subsidiary should be considered separate or joined; some factors that may be considered include whether distinct and adequately capitalized financial units are maintained, whether daily operations are separate, whether formal barriers between management of the two entities are erected, whether consolidated tax returns are filed, whether operating capital is financed by parent or borrowed from other sources, whether subsidiary's stock is owned by parent, whether the two share common officers and directors, extent to which separate books and accounts are kept, whether both have common departments of businesses, whether they have separate meetings of shareholders and directors, whether officer or director of one corporation is permitted to determine policies of the other, whether those with whom corporation comes into contact are apprised of their separate identity, and extent to which contracts between parent and subsidiary favor one over the other.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Texas court had personal jurisdiction over German car manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Karo Marketing Corp., Inc. v. Playdrome America
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: When a corporate entity is a mere instrument of a parent corporation so dominated that it has no separate existence and the subsidiary is used to perpetuate a fraud or injustice, or otherwise to circumvent the law, then the corporate veil may be pierced.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Terminating contract with company to make it judgment proof and creating new company was creditor fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Anthem Ins. Companies, Inc. v. Tenet Healthcare Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Contacts of a subsidiary may be aggregated with the contacts of the parent to achieve personal jurisdiction over the parent, but only in narrow instances where a parent utilizes its subsidiary in such a way that an agency relationship can be perceived or the parent has greater control over the subsidiary than normally associated with common ownership and directorship or where the subsidiary is merely an empty shell. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Appellate review of exercise of personal jurisdiction presented question of law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mid-Missouri Telephone Co. v. Alma Telephone Co.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: As a general rule, two separate corporations are to be regarded as distinct legal entities, even if the stock of one is owned partly or wholly by the other.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Right of first refusal did not apply to proposed sale of parent company of cellular phone company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mid-Missouri Telephone Co. v. Alma Telephone Co.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Ownership of capital stock in one corporation by another does not itself create identity of corporate interest as between the two.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Right of first refusal did not apply to proposed sale of parent company of cellular phone company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mid-Missouri Telephone Co. v. Alma Telephone Co.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Normally, a parent corporation is not responsible for the acts of its subsidiary corporation, but where circumstances exist that would allow a wronged party to pierce the corporate veil, a parent corporation could then incur liability, thus losing the parent/subsidiary distinction.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Right of first refusal did not apply to proposed sale of parent company of cellular phone company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mid-Missouri Telephone Co. v. Alma Telephone Co.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Circumstances allowing piercing of the corporate veil to make a parent corporation responsible for its subsidiary are present only where there is such dominion and control that the controlled corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own and is but an alter ego for its principal; absent such control, there can be no principal-agent relationship between corporate entities.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Right of first refusal did not apply to proposed sale of parent company of cellular phone company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Oxford Capital Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether assets of parent corporation may be levied upon to satisfy tax liabilities of subsidiary, factors to consider include: (1) parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent and subsidiary have common business departments; (4) parent and subsidiary file consolidated financial statements; (5) parent finances subsidiary; (6) parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary operated with grossly inadequate capital; (8) parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (9) subsidiary receives no business except that given by parent; (10) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (11) daily operations of the two corporations are not kept separate; (12) subsidiary does not observe corporate formalities. 26 U.S.C.A. § 7426.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. Judge failed to apply proper burden-shifting analysis to levy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cotracom Commodity Trading AG v. Seaboard Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Circumstances justify disregard of separate corporate status, under Kansas law, if separation of parent and subsidiary has not been maintained and injustice would occur to third parties if separate entity were recognized. K.S.A. 60-308(b).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. long-arm statute did not confer jurisdiction over subsidiaries and affiliates.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re SunSport, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Case of two affiliated corporations, such as a parent-subsidiary relationship, presents a common situation ripe for piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Successor liability would be imposed on company that acquired Chapter 7 debtor's assets prepetition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Paul v. Genesee & Wyoming Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: As a rule, parent corporations are not liable for the debts or actions of their subsidiaries.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION - Railroads. Railroad employee injured while inspecting railcar could not hold employer strictly liable for FSAA violations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Manufacturers Consolidation Service, Inc. v. Rodell
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: Theory of "piercing the corporate veil" permits a court to disregard a corporate entity in order to impose liability against a related entity, such as a parent corporation or a controlling shareholder, where the two entities are in fact identical or indistinguishable and where necessary to accomplish justice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Parties. Conditioning shareholder's intervention upon posting $1.6 million bond was not an abuse of discretion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Dewhurst v. Telenor Invest AS
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Inadequate funding is a factor to consider in assessing the independent corporate status of a subsidiary.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Foreign Sovereigns. Corporation that was wholly owned subsidiary of Norway was a foreign state under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act (FSIA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Transamerica Leasing, Inc. v. La Republica de Venezuela
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: Question of how much control is required before parent and subsidiary corporations may be deemed principal and agent defies resolution by mechanical formulae, for the inquiry is inherently fact-specific, but, at a minimum, the relationship of principal and agent does not obtain unless the parent has manifested its desire for the subsidiary to act upon the parent's behalf, the subsidiary has consented so to act, the parent has the right to exercise control over the subsidiary with respect to matters entrusted to the subsidiary, and the parent exercises its control in a manner more direct than by voting a majority of the stock in the subsidiary or making appointments to the subsidiary's board of directors. Restatement (Second) of Agency § 1.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Foreign Sovereigns. Exceptions to foreign state's sovereign immunity not established.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Automated Salvage Transport, Inc. v. NV Koninklijke KNP BT
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be held liable for actions of subsidiary, under theories of agency law, without piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. There was fact issue regarding agency status of waste paper buyer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Retzler v. Pratt and Whitney Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fifth Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, it requires a strong case to induce a court to consider two corporations as one, and disregard corporate fiction, on account of one owning all the capital stock of the other.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION - Aviation. Federal Aviation Act did not bar state personal injury claims against lessor of commercial airplane.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Colon v. Chart House Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Fact that a parent corporation owns all of the stock of the subsidiary does not justify ignoring the separateness of the two entities for jurisdictional purposes.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Employee satisfied prima facie burden of showing personal jurisdiction over nonresident defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: De Castro v. Sanifill, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Parent corporation's mere ownership of the two subsidiaries would not establish a measure of control over them sufficient for court to reject their own corporate identity, nor would the fact that the officers and directors of the subsidiaries were also officers and directors of the parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Piercing corporate veil not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: De Castro v. Sanifill, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard the corporate form, courts normally conduct a highly fact-specific inquiry, including, inter alia, consideration of: the extent to which a subsidiary may have disregarded corporate formalities; the degree of control exercised by the parent over the day-to-day operations of the subsidiary; overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; and whether the subsidiary was adequately capitalized, and adequacy of capital is determined within the context of the relevant corporate purposes and activities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Piercing corporate veil not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Lewis v. Central Oklahoma Medical Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 1.
Headnote: In determining whether one corporation is simply the instrumentality of another corporation and should be treated as one corporation for the purpose of tort law, court considers whether: (1) the parent corporation owns most or all of the stock, (2) the corporations have common officers or directors, (3) the parent provides financing to the subsidiary, (4) the dominant corporation subscribes to all the other's stock, (5) the subordinate corporation is under capitalized, (6) the parent pays the salaries, expenses or losses of the subsidiary, (7) a great deal of business is with parent corporation or assets of the former were conveyed to the other corporation, (8) the parent refers to the subsidiary as a division or department, (9) the subsidiary follows directions from the parent's officers or directors, (10) legal formalities for keeping the entities separate are observed.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Malpractice. Fact questions precluded summary judgment for health maintenance organization (HMO) and its parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mertz v. Seibel Realty, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: For two corporations to constitute alter egos, there must be direct intervention by the parent in the management of the subsidiary to such an extent that the subsidiary's paraphernalia of incorporation, directors, and officers are completely ignored.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Corporations which shared officers and were in landlord-tenant relationship were not alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Velazquez v. P.D.I. Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Fraud, as required to support piercing of corporate veil, can be proven by some cognizable showing that the parent corporation maintained the subsidiary to avoid its statutory responsibilities, acted in a blameworthy manner, looted the subsidiary, or so undercapitalized the subsidiary that the latter could not reasonably have been expected to meet its obligations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to support legitimacy of corporate structure, preventing piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Land Ocean Logistics, Inc. v. Aqua Gulf Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, even in the case of a parent corporation and its wholly-owned subsidiary, limited liability normally will not be abrogated.
Document Preview: Transportation broker brought suit in state court against freight forwarders, alleging breach of contract. After action was removed, and order was entered with respect to discovery disputes, 181 F.R.D. 229, defendants moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Arcara, J., adopted the report and recommendation of Foschio, United States Magistrate Judge, which held that: (1) fact that transportation broker had failed to obtain license from Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) to perform brokering services did not render agreement unenforceable; (2) fact issues as to whether contractual agreement existed, and if so, nature of relationship created, precluded summary judgment; and (3) broker failed to establish basis to pierce corporate veil of forwarder which was not party to agreement. Report and recommendation adopted, and motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Land Ocean Logistics, Inc. v. Aqua Gulf Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, courts may pierce the corporate veil by finding that a subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of the parent corporation; application of this principle depends on a finding that the parent so dominated the subsidiary that it had no separate existence, but was merely a conduit for the parent.
Document Preview: Transportation broker brought suit in state court against freight forwarders, alleging breach of contract. After action was removed, and order was entered with respect to discovery disputes, 181 F.R.D. 229, defendants moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Arcara, J., adopted the report and recommendation of Foschio, United States Magistrate Judge, which held that: (1) fact that transportation broker had failed to obtain license from Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) to perform brokering services did not render agreement unenforceable; (2) fact issues as to whether contractual agreement existed, and if so, nature of relationship created, precluded summary judgment; and (3) broker failed to establish basis to pierce corporate veil of forwarder which was not party to agreement. Report and recommendation adopted, and motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Land Ocean Logistics, Inc. v. Aqua Gulf Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether a subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of the parent corporation, as will allow corporate veil to be pierced under New Jersey law, courts apply the traditional common law factors, including the presence in both corporations of the same officers, directors, and shareholders, financial support of the subsidiary's operations by the parent, whether the property of the subsidiary is used by the parent corporation as its own, the failure of a subsidiary to observe the formal requirements attributable to its operation, and the involvement of the parent's corporate officers in the day-to-day business of the subsidiary.

Title: Land Ocean Logistics, Inc. v. Aqua Gulf Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Even in the presence of corporate dominance, liability is imposed against parent under New Jersey law only when the parent has abused the privilege of incorporation by using the subsidiary to perpetrate a fraud or injustice, or otherwise to circumvent the law.

Title: ESI, Inc. v. Coastal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil will be pierced for jurisdictional purposes only when the subsidiary is acting as an agent for the parent, or the parent's control is so complete that the subsidiary is a mere department of the parent; jurisdiction over the foreign subsidiary will be found only when the activities of the parent show a disregard for the separate corporate existence of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Project director of electrical generating power plant built in El Salvador sued developers and El Salvador host company, seeking a declaratory judgment as to parties respective ownership interests in power plant and the income from the plant. Numerous counterclaims and cross-claims were asserted. Upon various motions principally seeking dismissal of the various claims on grounds of lack of personal jurisdiction, forum non conveniens and failure to state a claim upon which relief may be granted, the District Court, William C. Conner, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) affiliates were subject to personal jurisdiction pursuant to doing business jurisdictional statute because they were acting as mere departments of parent corporations which were present in New York; (2) affiliates transacted business in New York within the meaning of New York's long-arm statute; (3) action would not be dismissed on the ground of forum non conveniens; (4)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: ESI, Inc. v. Coastal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors to aid in determining whether, under New York law, subsidiary is the "mere department" of parent, as would allow corporate veil to be pierced, for jurisdictional purposes are: (1) common ownership, (2) financial dependency of the subsidiary on the parent, (3) the degree to which the parent interferes in the selection of the subsidiary's executive personnel and fails to observe corporate formality, and (4) the degree of the parent's control over the subsidiary's marketing and operational policies; first factor, common ownership, is essential to the assertion of jurisdiction over a foreign related corporation, while the other three factors are "important."

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: ESI, Inc. v. Coastal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: For purposes of determining whether, under New York law, subsidiary is the "mere department" of parent, as would allow corporate veil to be pierced for jurisdictional purposes, financial dependency of the subsidiary on the parent corporation exists where the parent provides no- or low-interest loans to the subsidiary or extends credit on terms not otherwise available, guarantees the subsidiary's obligations, or provides and pays for insurance coverage or other necessities on behalf of the subsidiary; courts also inquire whether the subsidiary retains its own profits or whether they are received by and reported on the financial statements of the parent but issuance of consolidated financial statements is not dispositive if the parent company is merely complying with SEC requirements.

Title: ESI, Inc. v. Coastal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In examining interference with executive personnel and failure to observe corporate formalities, courts attempting to determine whether, under New York law, subsidiary is the "mere department" of parent, as would allow corporate veil to be pierced, for jurisdictional purposes, look to, inter alia, whether the parent shares officers with the subsidiary and shifts executives among its subsidiaries, whether the parent pays the executives' salaries, and whether the subsidiary holds separate meetings of its board of directors.
