Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gardemal v. Westin Hotel Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine applies under Texas law when there is such unity between the parent corporation and its subsidiary that the separateness of the two corporations has ceased and holding only the subsidiary corporation liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: Guest at hotel in Mexico sued corporate manager and its parent corporation for negligence in connection with drowning death of her husband. In accordance with recommendations of magistrate judge, the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Orlando L. Garcia, J., dismissed action. Appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, DeMoss, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) liability was not imputable to parent corporation under either the alter ego or single business enterprise doctrine, and (2) district court had neither specific nor general jurisdiction over hotel's corporate manager. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gardemal v. Westin Hotel Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, degree of control necessary for finding parent corporation is alter ego of subsidiary is not mere majority or complete stock control but such domination of finances, policies and practices that the controlled corporation has, so to speak, no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal; thus, one-hundred percent ownership and identity of directors and officers are, even together, an insufficient basis for applying the alter ego theory to pierce the corporate veil
Document Preview: Guest at hotel in Mexico sued corporate manager and its parent corporation for negligence in connection with drowning death of her husband. In accordance with recommendations of magistrate judge, the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Orlando L. Garcia, J., dismissed action. Appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, DeMoss, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) liability was not imputable to parent corporation under either the alter ego or single business enterprise doctrine, and (2) district court had neither specific nor general jurisdiction over hotel's corporate manager. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Manchester Equipment Co., Inc. v. American Way
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate form will be disregarded only if form has been used to achieve fraud or parent exercises such extreme dominion and control over subsidiary as to render corporate form a sham.
Document Preview: Seller of computer equipment brought state court action against parent of storage company for negligently delivering goods to unknown persons. Following removal, parent moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Wexler, J., held that: (1) parent was not liable for subsidiary's negligent security, and (2) subsidiary did not have apparent authority to act on behalf of parent. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Manchester Equipment Co., Inc. v. American Way
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, parent company liability will be found if: (1) parent exercised such control that subsidiary has become mere instrumentality of parent, which is real actor; (2) control has been used to commit fraud or other wrong; and (3) fraud or wrong results in unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: Seller of computer equipment brought state court action against parent of storage company for negligently delivering goods to unknown persons. Following removal, parent moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Wexler, J., held that: (1) parent was not liable for subsidiary's negligent security, and (2) subsidiary did not have apparent authority to act on behalf of parent. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: People ex rel. Vacco v. World Interactive Gaming Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate form, there must be some proof that the parent company dominates or controls the daily activities of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Computers and Online Services. Offshore Internet casino site violated state and federal gambling laws.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Garden State Tanning, Inc. v. Mitchell Mfg. Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporate subsidiary is an alter ego of parent, under Pennsylvania law, court should look to factors such as whether there is intermingling of funds, insufficient capitalization, nonfunction of officers and directors, failure to observe corporate formalities, failure to pay dividends, and the existence of a corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: Creditor of corporate subsidiary sued parent, seeking to recover under guaranty and for alleged fraudulent transfer of assets of subsidiary to third party. Parent moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Katz, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) there were fact questions regarding scope of guaranty precluding recovery on breach of contract, unjust enrichment and quantum meruit theories; (2) transfer of assets was not fraudulent under Michigan statutes; (3) transfer was not fraudulent under Pennsylvania common law; (4) transfer was not fraudulent under Michigan common law; and (5) creditor failed to establish that subsidiary was alter ego of parent, under laws of Michigan or Pennsylvania. Motion granted in part, denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Material Supply Intern., Inc. v. Sunmatch Industrial Co ., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In determining whether a subsidiary corporation is the alter ego of its parent, the court must undertake a two-pronged analysis to determine whether the subsidiary retained a corporate personality distinct from the parent's: (1) whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporations no longer exist; and (2) whether an inequitable result will follow if the court treats the subsidiary's allegedly wrongful acts as those of the subsidiary alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Evidence was insufficient to establish that subsidiary was alter ego of parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Material Supply Intern., Inc. v. Sunmatch Industrial Co ., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: To assess whether there is a unity of interest and ownership between a parent corporation and its subsidiary, so as to make the parent liable for the subsidiary's acts, the court may consider the nature of the corporate ownership and control; failure to maintain corporate minutes or records; failure to maintain corporate formalities; commingling of funds and assets; diversion of one corporation's funds to the other's uses; and use of the same office or business location.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Evidence was insufficient to establish that subsidiary was alter ego of parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Material Supply Intern., Inc. v. Sunmatch Industrial Co ., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: To assess whether a parent corporation so controlled its subsidiary as to render it a mere instrumentality, the court will consider whether parent and subsidiary have common business departments; whether the parent finances the subsidiary; whether the parent incorporated the subsidiary; whether the subsidiary is inadequately capitalized; whether parent and subsidiary file consolidated financial statements and tax returns; whether they have a joint accounting and payroll system; whether the subsidiary is operated as a mere division of the parent; whether the subsidiary depends on the parent for substantially all of its business; whether the subsidiary's obligations are assumed to be those of the parent; whether the subsidiary's property is used by the parent as its own; and whether the subsidiary is operated exclusively in the interest of the parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Evidence was insufficient to establish that subsidiary was alter ego of parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Material Supply Intern., Inc. v. Sunmatch Industrial Co ., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: When assessing whether a parent corporation so controlled its subsidiary as to render it a mere instrumentality, it is not relevant that the parent ultimately benefitted from the activities of the subsidiary or that the subsidiary's supervisors reported to the parent's officers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Evidence was insufficient to establish that subsidiary was alter ego of parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Material Supply Intern., Inc. v. Sunmatch Industrial Co ., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Bare allegations of agency are insufficient to establish that a subsidiary corporation is an alter ego of its parent, nor is agency established by showing merely that parent and subsidiary are in the same business and have worked together in the past.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Evidence was insufficient to establish that subsidiary was alter ego of parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Material Supply Intern., Inc. v. Sunmatch Industrial Co ., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: A subsidiary corporation is an agent of its parent if the parent's ownership of the subsidiary was not a mere investment, but rather an alternative means of transacting business by the parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Evidence was insufficient to establish that subsidiary was alter ego of parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Taeger v. Catholic Family and Community Services
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1, Department A.
Headnote: Unity of control, as element of alter ego theory, is shown where the parent corporation exercised substantially total control over the management and activities of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Adoption. Agency may have had fiduciary relationship with adoptive parents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Taeger v. Catholic Family and Community Services
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1, Department A.
Headnote: To be held responsible for actions of its subsidiary, the parent must actually exercise substantially total control so that the subsidiary becomes a mere instrumentality.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Adoption. Agency may have had fiduciary relationship with adoptive parents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Ocala Breeders' Sales Co. v. Hialeah, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Florida law, it must be shown not only that the wholly-owned subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of the parent corporation but also that the subsidiary was organized or used by the parent to mislead creditors or to perpetrate a fraud upon them.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Pierce of corporate veil was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Ocala Breeders' Sales Co. v. Hialeah, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: In determining whether the corporate veil should be pierced, the relationship between the parent corporation and its subsidiary must be examined.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Pierce of corporate veil was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hefner v. Dausmann
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District. Division One.
Headnote: A parent corporation is not responsible for the acts of its subsidiary except where the wronged party pierces the corporate veil.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Plaintiffs could not pierce corporate veil to bring action against hospital affiliated with medical clinic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hefner v. Dausmann
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District. Division One.
Headnote: Absent evidence that a controlled corporation has no separate mind, will or existence of its own, the parent corporation is not liable for the acts of the subsidiary, or the affiliated corporation.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Plaintiffs could not pierce corporate veil to bring action against hospital affiliated with medical clinic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hefner v. Dausmann
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District. Division One.
Headnote: The control a parent corporation must have over its subsidiary to be held liable for the subsidiary's actions must include control over finances and over the policy and business practice with respect to the particular transaction at issue.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Plaintiffs could not pierce corporate veil to bring action against hospital affiliated with medical clinic.

Title: Securities Investor Protection Corp. v. Stratton Oakmont, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: "Veil piercing" is term used most often with respect to subsidiary-parent paradigm where court seeks to impose liabilities of subsidiary on the parent because the latter completely dominates the former and has used that control for an improper purpose.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Securities Investor Protection Corp. v. Stratton Oakmont, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil, be it backwards or forwards, is not, in and of itself, an independent cause of action, but is a procedural device through which plaintiff may assert facts and circumstances to persuade court to impose the parent corporation's obligation on the subsidiary or vice versa.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. SIPA trustee's reverse veil-piercing theory survived dismissal motions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Securities Investor Protection Corp. v. Stratton Oakmont, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: "Reverse veil piercing" typically arises when plaintiff seeks to hold corporate entity accountable for the actions of its shareholders, or, similarly, to hold subsidiary liable for debts of its parent.

Title: Securities Investor Protection Corp. v. Stratton Oakmont, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil generally requires a showing that parent corporation dominates subsidiary to such an extent that the latter is really an agent for or instrumentality of the former and that parent corporation used that control to commit fraud or some other wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. SIPA trustee's reverse veil-piercing theory survived dismissal motions.

Title: Brown v. Vitelcom, Inc.
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Thomas and St. John.
Headnote: Under "agency test" for determining whether to pierce corporate veil, plaintiff must demonstrate that parent corporation exerted significant control over subsidiary's decision-making process.
Document Preview: Employee, a black woman from Dominica, brought action against employer, its parent corporation, and other subsidiary corporations, alleging discrimination and retaliation based on race or national origin, under Title VII and §1981. On cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Moore, Chief Judge, held that: (1) fact issues existed on Title VII and §1981 claims, and (2) parent corporation was properly named defendant. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Brown v. Vitelcom, Inc.
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Thomas and St. John.
Headnote: Under "integrated enterprise test," to determine whether allegedly independent corporations constitute single employer, liability hinges on all circumstances surrounding parent-subsidiary relationship, including: (1) whether subsidiary's corporate operations were merged, integrated, or interrelated with parent corporation; (2) whether parent corporation exercised centralized control of subsidiary's labor relations; and (3) whether subsidiary and parent corporations were commonly owned and managed.
Document Preview: Employee, a black woman from Dominica, brought action against employer, its parent corporation, and other subsidiary corporations, alleging discrimination and retaliation based on race or national origin, under Title VII and §1981. On cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Moore, Chief Judge, held that: (1) fact issues existed on Title VII and §1981 claims, and (2) parent corporation was properly named defendant. Motions denied.

Title: Magnus v. Fortune Brands, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, courts may pierce the corporate veil upon a finding that: (1) the parent so dominated the subsidiary that it had no separate existence but was merely a conduit for the parent; and that (2) the parent has abused the privilege of incorporation by using the subsidiary to perpetrate a fraud or injustice, or otherwise to circumvent the law.
Document Preview: Cigarette smokers and smoker's survivor brought products liability action against cigarette manufacturers, their parent corporations, and tobacco industry-related trade and research associations. The District Court, Gershon, District Judge, held that: (1) smokers' claim that manufacturers breached special duty to protect public by providing information about effects of tobacco use was not preempted by Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act; (2) smokers' fraud and deceit claims were not preempted by Act; (3) smokers' breach of implied warranty claims were not preempted by Act; (4) smokers' complaint sufficiently specific to state alter ego claim against manufacturers' parent corporations; (5) trade and research associations could not be held liable to smokers under failure to warn, negligent and defective design, or strict products liability theories; (6) smokers could bring fraud action against trade and research associations; (7) New Jersey smoker's common law claims for...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Conservatorship of Prom v. Sumitomo Rubber Industries, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Mere existence of a parent-subsidiary relationship between two corporations is not sufficient to provide a court which has jurisdiction over one of the two corporations with jurisdiction over the other; rather, record must establish that the parent corporation had control over the subsidiary corporation.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Process. Japanese corporation did not transact business in Wisconsin, for purposes of process statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Conservatorship of Prom v. Sumitomo Rubber Industries, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Factors considered in determining if parent corporation controls subsidiary to such an extent that separate corporate identity of subsidiary should be disregarded are (1) common stock ownership, (2) overlapping directors and officers, (3) combined use of corporate offices, (4) capitalization of subsidiary by parent, (5) financing of subsidiary by parent, (6) control of subsidiary's stock by parent, (7) use of the subsidiary's property by parent, (8) intercorporate loans, (9) parental incorporation of subsidiary, (10) consolidated tax returns, (11) independent decision making by subsidiary, (12) independent decision making by directors of subsidiary, (13) observance of formal corporate legal requirements, (14) contracts between subsidiary and parent, and (15) fraud or injustice to third parties.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Process. Japanese corporation did not transact business in Wisconsin, for purposes of process statute.

Title: Eclipse Medical, Inc. v. American Hydro-Surgical Instruments, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, parent corporation will not be held liable for actions of its subsidiary unless subsidiary is deemed to be mere instrumentality of parent.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Distributors failed to establish fraud claim against supplier.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Ritter v. BJC Barnes Jewish Christian Health Systems
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: In a parent-subsidiary relationship, the parent corporation is ordinarily not liable for tortious acts of the subsidiary corporation, unless there is evidence to support a finding which would pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Hospital's parent corporation was not liable for hospital's allegedly negligent medical care.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Shelton Wholesale, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Saint Joseph Division.
Headnote: A strict adherence to common law principles is not required in the determination of whether a parent should be held for the acts of its subsidiary, where strict adherence would enable the corporate device to be used to circumvent the policy of the statute.
Document Preview: Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) brought action against fireworks importers for alleged violations of Federal Hazardous Substances Act (FHSA). In separate action, importers sought declaratory and injunctive relief. Following trial on both actions, the District Court, Sachs, J., held that: (1) importers received adequate due process; (2) CPSC's methods and procedures for testing fireworks were reasonable; (3) importers' violations of FHSA were knowing; and (4) fine of $100,000 was warranted. Judgment rendered for CPSC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Shelton Wholesale, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Saint Joseph Division.
Headnote: Where a violation of law is perpetrated through a corporate entity, the courts will intercede to hold the shareholder or parent corporation liable.
Document Preview: Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) brought action against fireworks importers for alleged violations of Federal Hazardous Substances Act (FHSA). In separate action, importers sought declaratory and injunctive relief. Following trial on both actions, the District Court, Sachs, J., held that: (1) importers received adequate due process; (2) CPSC's methods and procedures for testing fireworks were reasonable; (3) importers' violations of FHSA were knowing; and (4) fine of $100,000 was warranted. Judgment rendered for CPSC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Johnson Enterprises of Jacksonville, Inc. v. FPL Group, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil and hold parent corporation liable for actions of its subsidiary must prove: (1) that subsidiary was mere instrumentality of parent, and (2) that parent engaged in improper conduct through its organization or use of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Contractor sued cable television company and its parent company, alleging breach of contract for construction of cable television systems and fraud, racketeering, and tortious interference. Alaimo, J., granted defendants judgment as a matter of law on several claims, but entered judgment for contractor on contract claims against both defendants and for contractor on tortious interference claim against parent. Both parties appealed. The Court of Appeals, Tjoflat, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) alleged mileage guarantee was barred by parol evidence rule and was unsupported by consideration; (2) contract was not subject to Uniform Commercial Code's (UCC) duty of good faith; (3) contractor was not fraudulently induced to enter contract; (4) there was no evidentiary basis for racketeering claims; (5) corporate veil of parent would not be pierced to hold it liable for breach of contract...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Laird v. Capital Cities/ABC, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: To establish a parent corporation's liability for acts or omissions of its subsidiary on an agency theory, a plaintiff must show more than mere representation of the parent by the subsidiary in dealings with third persons; the showing required is that a parent corporation so controls the subsidiary as to cause the subsidiary to become merely the agent or instrumentality of the parent.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Parent corporation was not liable for discrimination perpetrated against employee of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Laird v. Capital Cities/ABC, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: To justify piercing the corporate veil on an alter ego theory in order to hold a parent corporation liable for the acts or omissions of its subsidiary, a plaintiff must show that there is such a unity of interest and ownership between the two corporations that their separate personalities no longer exist, and that an inequitable result would follow if the parent were not held liable.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Parent corporation was not liable for discrimination perpetrated against employee of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Laird v. Capital Cities/ABC, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: To justify piercing the corporate veil on an alter ego theory in order to hold a parent corporation liable for the acts or omissions of its subsidiary, the plaintiff must show specific manipulative conduct by the parent toward the subsidiary which relegates the latter to the status of merely an instrumentality, agency, conduit or adjunct of the former.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Parent corporation was not liable for discrimination perpetrated against employee of subsidiary.

Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: Veil piercing is proper when a facility is pervasively controlled by its parent corporation for a sufficiently improper purpose.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Doe v. Unocal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: To demonstrate that parent and subsidiary are not really separate entities and satisfy alter ego exception to general rule that subsidiary and parent are separate entities, plaintiff must make out prima facie case: (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of entities no longer exist; and (2) that failure to disregard their separate identities would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Burmese citizens brought class action asserting various claims against United States oil corporation and French corporation. On French Corporation's motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, the District Court, Paez, J., held that: (1) claimants effected proper service of process over French corporation; (2) claimants, who did not serve process pursuant to Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), could not rely on corporation's national contacts under RICO to establish personal jurisdiction; (3) corporation's direct contacts with California were insufficient to warrant exercise of personal jurisdiction; and (4) contacts of corporation's subsidiaries could not be imputed to corporation to establish minimum contacts. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Doe v. Unocal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be directly involved in financing and macro-management of its subsidiaries without exposing itself to charge that each subsidiary is merely its alter ego.

Title: AT & T Global Information Solutions Co. v. Union Tank Car Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the corporate form of a subsidiary will be disregarded when it is so dominated and controlled that it has no more than a paper existence.
Document Preview: Potentially responsible parties (PRPs) who entered consent order with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) concerning cleanup of solvent reclamation site brought contribution action under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) against subsidiary and grandparent corporations concerning alleged disposal of subsidiary's waste at site. On motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Holschuh, J., held that: (1) evidence that subsidiary created toxic waste and had it deposited at site supported imposition of arranger liability against subsidiary under CERCLA; (2) Ohio law would apply to issue of piercing corporate veil of grandparent company; and (3) evidence that grandparent company exercised dominion and control over subsidiary, that piercing of corporate veil was necessary to prevent injustice, and that subsidiary would have been liable in CERCLA contribution action if subsidiary had not been dissolved by grandparent, supported piercing...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Townley v. Emerson Elec. Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Monroe County, New York.
Headnote: On occasion, courts will disregard the separate legal personality of corporation, and assign liability to its owners where necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity; however, such liability can never be predicated solely upon fact of a parent corporation's ownership of a controlling interest in shares of its subsidiary, and at the very least, there must be direct intervention by parent in management of subsidiary to such an extent that subsidiary's paraphernalia of incorporation, directors, and officers are completely ignored.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. Parent of manufacturing subsidiary was equitably estopped from denying that it manufactured product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Townley v. Emerson Elec. Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Monroe County, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced (1) to achieve equity, even absent fraud, where officers and employees of parent corporation exercise control over daily operations of subsidiary corporation and act as true prime movers behind subsidiary's actions, and/or (2) where parent corporation conducts business through subsidiary which exists solely to serve parent.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. Parent of manufacturing subsidiary was equitably estopped from denying that it manufactured product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Townley v. Emerson Elec. Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Monroe County, New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil between parent corporation and subsidiary, parent must exercise complete domination and control in the matter; stock control, interlocking directors, and interlocking officers are in and of themselves insufficient facts to justify imposition of such liability on parent, but control by parent over subsidiary's everyday operations will render parent liable for subsidiary's acts.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. Parent of manufacturing subsidiary was equitably estopped from denying that it manufactured product.

Title: Seminole Pipeline Co. v. Broad Leaf Partners, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation will not be regarded as the alter ego of its parent merely because of stock ownership, a duplication of some or all of the directors or officers, or an exercise of control that stock ownership gives to stockholders.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Damages. Statute capped award of punitive damages against each defendant rather than total punitive damages.

Title: Shapiro, Lifschitz & Schram, P.C. v. Hazard
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Considerations of justice and equity justify piercing corporate veil and finding corporation's officers or shareholders to be alter egos of corporate entity when there is a unity of ownership and interest, which can be demonstrated by showing domination and control of corporation, as in parent-subsidiary relationship or in closely held corporation.

Harris, J., held that: (1) evidentiary hearing on jurisdiction issue was warranted to resolve law firm's alter ego theory; (2) suit would not be transferred to California; (3) clients could not recover attorney's fees incurred in defending action or prosecuting their claims; (4) clients failed to state claims based on law firm's allegedly excessive fees; (5) allegation that law firm unilaterally refused to represent clients stated claims for professional malpractice and breach of fiduciary duty; and (6) retainer agreement was not subject to rescission as illegal contract. Motion to dismiss for lack of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gruca v. Alpha Therapeutic Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In Illinois, a corporation's veil may be pierced to assert personal jurisdiction over parent based on activities of subsidiary only if (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the subsidiary no longer exist; and (2) adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Mother filed action on behalf of herself, her two minor children, and the estate of her late husband, against subsidiary and Japanese parent corporation alleging negligence in collecting plasma and manufacturing plasma-derived product. Upon parent's motion to dismiss, the District Court, Gottschall, J., held that court lacked jurisdiction over Japanese parent corporation based on subsidiary's activities. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gruca v. Alpha Therapeutic Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To determine if there is a sufficient "unity of interest and ownership" between two corporations to justify piercing veil for purpose of asserting personal jurisdiction in Illinois over parent based on activities of subsidiary, courts look to four factors: (1) the failure to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities, (2) the commingling of funds or assets, (3) undercapitalization, and (4) one corporation treating the assets of another as its own.
Document Preview: Mother filed action on behalf of herself, her two minor children, and the estate of her late husband, against subsidiary and Japanese parent corporation alleging negligence in collecting plasma and manufacturing plasma-derived product. Title: George Hyman Const. Co. v. Gateman
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: A circumstance strongly suggesting veil piercing under Massachusetts law is a case of financial misconduct of the subsidiary involving such manipulation as asset-stripping or asset-siphoning, which depletes the resources of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: General contractor brought action against demolition subcontractor, which did not pay its vendors, and subcontractor's shareholders. Shareholders filed counterclaim for unfair and deceptive trade practices. The District Court, Saris, J., held that: (1) shareholders could not be held liable for corporate debts by virtue of piercing the corporate veil; (2) general contractor failed to state claim for fraud; (3) shareholders' conduct in transferring money from subcontractor to related corporation was not an unfair and deceptive business practice; and (4) general contractor's suit was not baseless, so as to constitute an unfair and deceptive trade practice. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Broussard v. Meineke Discount Muffler Shops, Inc.
