Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Satellite Cable Services, Inc. v. Northern Electric Co-op., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Mere fact that one corporation owns all or a majority of the stock of another, or that two corporations have common officers or directors, will not render a parent automatically answerable for acts of its subsidiary.
Document Preview: City's community antenna television system (CATV) provider brought action against rural electric cooperative and its subsidiary, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief and damages for interference with contractual and prospective contractual relations. The Circuit Court, Fifth Judicial Circuit, Day County, Myles J. DeVine, J., enjoined electric cooperative and subsidiary from offering cable television service, and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Konenkamp, J., held that: (1) amendment removing statutory restrictions on electric cooperatives' competition with CATV providers in municipalities required injunction be set aside; (2) electric cooperative was entitled to be member of cooperative formed to bring television signals to rural areas and small towns; (3) electric cooperative could not offer television service, under former statutory scheme, by merely creating another cooperative singly consisting of its own subsidiary; and (4) to extent rural electric cooperative was...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Pirelli Armstrong Tire Corp. v. Titan Tire Corp.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, despite common officers and common address, corporate veil of subsidiary would not be pierced to reach parent company, where subsidiary observed corporate formalities, maintained appropriate corporate records, maintained arm's length relationship with parent company, and was adequately capitalized.
Document Preview: Tire manufacturer brought action against buyer of its plant and buyer's parent company alleging violations of federal trademark laws and Illinois Uniform Deceptive Trade Practices Act, deceptive trade practices, unfair competition, and breach of asset purchase and intellectual property agreements. On parties' cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) piercing of corporate veil was not warranted; (2) trademarks were valid; (3) manufacturer's claims were not barred by doctrines of estoppel or laches; (4) defendant infringed and diluted manufacturer's trademarks; (5) defendant unlawfully passed off its tires as those of manufacturer; and (6) defendant breached asset purchase and intellectual property agreements. Judgment for tire manufacturer against competitor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Jean Anderson Hierarchy of Agents v. Allstate Life Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Liability may be imposed on a stockholder or corporate parent for the wrongful acts or contractual obligations of corporation, where the shareholder or parent so dominates activities of corporation that it is necessary to treat the dominated corporation as an agent or "alter ego."
Document Preview: Former executive sales director of insurance company brought action challenging company's alleged discriminatory conduct regarding the payment of commissions and earned persistency bonuses.  On motion to dismiss for failure to state claim, the District Court, Joyner, J., held that: (1) allegations in former sales director's complaint were not sufficient to state claim against insurance company's sister or parent corporations or against the parent's corporate parent; (2) allegations were sufficient to state claim against insurer under the Fair Labor Standards Act/Equal Pay Act and under Title VII; and (3) allegations were not sufficient to state a claim under Pennsylvania law for the intentional infliction of emotional distress or for punitive damages. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rivera Rojas v. Loewen Group Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: As long as parent and subsidiary have maintained corporate formalities such as separate books, taxes, minute books, bank accounts, and facilities, corporate veil should not be pierced.
Document Preview: Sellers of funeral home business brought breach of contract action against corporate buyer for alleged mismanagement of company, onerous loan agreement, and misappropriation of profits.  Buyer moved to dismiss for failure to join its subsidiary, allegedly a necessary party.  The District Court, Laffitte, J., held that: (1) subsidiary was an indispensable party, and (2) subsidiary was not alter ego of buyer. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rivera Rojas v. Loewen Group Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Mere fact that parent corporation exerts high degree of control over its subsidiary will not be sufficient to pierce corporate veil; even though parent may "call the shots" with subsidiary, their corporate identities should remain separate if corporate formalities have been followed.
Document Preview: Sellers of funeral home business brought breach of contract action against corporate buyer for alleged mismanagement of company, onerous loan agreement, and misappropriation of profits.  Buyer moved to dismiss for failure to join its subsidiary, allegedly a necessary party.  The District Court, Laffitte, J., held that: (1) subsidiary was an indispensable party, and (2) subsidiary was not alter ego of buyer. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Docudata Records Management Services, Inc. v. Wieser
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Parent corporation and its subsidiaries are distinct legal entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Neither transfer of corporation's stock to new holding company nor merger of wholly-owned subsidiary into corporation constituted sale of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Feszczyszyn v. General Motors Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: In order for vicarious liability of parent corporation to exist, parent must exercise complete dominion and control over subsidiary's daily operations.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Limitations. Japanese automobile corporation and its American subsidiary were not united in interest for limitations purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: State v. American Tobacco Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: As to control element of agency relationship, the amount of control the parent corporation exercises must be very significant. West's F.S.A. § 48.193.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Parent corporations of tobacco companies did not exercise sufficient control over subsidiaries to justify personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Daley v. American Drug Stores, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Before court will pierce corporate veil of subsidiary corporation, it must be shown that one corporation so controls affairs of another that the other is mere instrumentality or dummy and that, under circumstances, observance of fiction of separate corporate existence will sanction fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Liquor. Plain language of municipal ordinance imposing moratorium on issuance of new liquor licenses prohibited transfer of license between wholly owned subsidiaries of same corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Harwood Tire-Arlington, Inc. v. Young
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Alter ego applies when there is such unity between parent corporation and its subsidiary that separateness of the two corporations has ceased and holding only subsidiary corporation liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to disregard corporate fiction and hold parent liable for injuries suffered by employee of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Harwood Tire-Arlington, Inc. v. Young
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Unity between parent and subsidiary corporations, for purposes of alter-ego doctrine is shown from total dealings of parent corporation and its subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to disregard corporate fiction and hold parent liable for injuries suffered by employee of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Expediters Intern. of Washington, Inc. v. Direct Line Cargo Management Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: In order for parent corporation to be liable for contracts made by subsidiary, as agent, not only must arrangement exist between two corporations so that one acts on behalf of other and within usual agency principles, but arrangement must be relevant to plaintiff's claim of wrongdoing.
Document Preview: Complainant who was purported holder of rights to copyrighted computer program, obtained from Taiwan corporation with which it was affiliated, sued competitor formerly affiliated with Taiwan corporation, alleging violation of Copyright Act, trade secret misappropriation, and breach of contract. Competitor moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pisano, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) material issues of fact, precluding summary judgment, existed as to whether competitor authorized foreign affiliates to utilize program after license agreement expired, so as to be primarily liable for violation of Copyright Act; (2) provision of Copyright Act, allowing for copying of computer programs, did not apply to facts of case; (3) state trade secret claim was not preempted by Copyright Act; (4) there was fact issue whether competitor could be found liable for breach of confidentiality agreements between complainant and foreign corporations using programs;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Status Intern. S.A. v. M & D Maritime Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Ownership by a parent of all its subsidiary's stock is an insufficient reason in and of itself to disregard distinct corporate entities; actual domination, rather than the opportunity to exercise control, must be shown.
Document Preview: Vessel owner brought suit against subcharterer and its agent, and another subcharterer, to enforce a maritime lien on certain subfreights and demurrage.  Subcharterer moved to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, and vessel owner moved for partial summary judgment on its claim against subcharterer.  The District Court, Scheindlin, J., held that: (1) where defendants contended that court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because complaint does not state sufficient facts to support the enforcement of a maritime lien, motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction had to be treated as motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim, and (2) vessel owner failed to state a claim for subfreights owed by subcharterers. Motion to dismiss granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Saint Joseph Hosp. v. Berks County Board of Assessment Appeals
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where parent corporation dominates subsidiary corporation to degree that it is a mere instrumentality or sham corporation, corporate existence of subsidiary may be disregarded.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Real Property. Hospital was purely public charity entitled to exemption from real estate taxes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Schmitt v. Beverly Health and Rehabilitation Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Critical inquiry for determining if parent corporation would be held liable for decision made by subsidiary regarding employees of subsidiary, is whether parent exercised control over significant aspects of complaining employee's terms and conditions of employment or parent dominated subsidiary's operations to such degree that two corporations were in reality single entity.
Document Preview: Terminated employee of subsidiary corporation sued parent, alleging wrongful discharge.  Parent moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Earl E. O'Connor, J., held that: (1) employee failed to make necessary showing that parent controlled subsidiary to degree that they were effectively one corporation, as required for parent to have liability; (2) employee failed to establish parent's liability under state law claims of retaliatory discharge for filing workers' compensation claim and for whistle-blowing, and, on motion to alter judgment or in alternative for relief from judgment (3) parent was not equitably estopped from denying employment relationship; and (4) leave to amend complaint to add subsidiary as employer, following grant of summary judgment to parent, would not be granted. Summary judgment granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Maltz v. Union Carbide Chemicals & Plastics Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, liability of parent corporation can never be predicated solely upon fact of parent corporation's ownership of controlling interest in shares of subsidiary; at very least, there must be direct intervention by parent in management of subsidiary to such extent that subsidiary's paraphernalia of incorporation, directors, and officers are completely ignored.
Document Preview: Marble care franchisees brought action against franchisor, franchisor's parent and grandparent corporations, and various officers, directors and employees, alleging various tort and contract violations.  On defendants' motion to dismiss, the District Court, Kimba M. Wood, J., on report and recommendation of Katz, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) law of state in which franchises were located applied to their tort claims, and New York law applied to their contract claims; (2) allegations were sufficient to state claim for alter ego liability against parent under New York law; (3) warranty disclaimer in chemical purchase agreement was sufficiently conspicuous and specific to be enforceable under New York law; (4) franchisees' allegations were sufficient to state fraud claim; (5) allegations were sufficient to state negligent misrepresentation claim; (6) allegations were sufficient to state civil conspiracy claim; (7) allegations were sufficient to state claim for...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Alexander v. CIGNA Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, parent and subsidiary corporations are distinct legal entities and courts are extremely reluctant to pierce corporate veil between the two absent compelling circumstances; parent corporation will not be held liable for acts of its subsidiary unless parent has abused privilege of incorporation by using subsidiary to perpetrate fraud or injustice or otherwise to circumvent the law.
Document Preview: Independent insurance agents sued defendant insurance company and its subsidiaries for fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, promissory and equitable estoppel, negligent misrepresentation, and breach of contract in connection with exclusive representation agreement.  On defendants' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Greenaway, J., held that: (1) it was manifestly unreasonable for agents to assert that they reasonably relied on any alleged statements concerning lifetime or perpetual duration of exclusive representation agreements with company; (2) representations by company with respect to lifetime tenure for agents were insufficient to create binding obligation by company to retain agents until death or retirement; and (3) evidence of general promotional tape and alleged fraudulent statements made by corporate officer did not amount to requisite minimum contacts needed to exercise specific jurisdiction over company. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Regency Holdings (Cayman), Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent and subsidiary corporations are, as a rule, separate entities, having separate assets and liabilities.
Document Preview: Avoidance. Chapter 11 debtor's corporate control over subsidiary and over subsidiary's subsidiary did not permit it to recover, for benefit of its own creditors, preferential or fraudulent transfers of subsidiaries' assets.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Regency Holdings (Cayman), Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation's ownership of all shares of subsidiary does not make subsidiary's assets those of parent.
Document Preview: Avoidance. Chapter 11 debtor's corporate control over subsidiary and over subsidiary's subsidiary did not permit it to recover, for benefit of its own creditors, preferential or fraudulent transfers of subsidiaries' assets.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: F.D.I.C. v. Refco Group, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, factors that courts apply in deciding whether to disregard the separate nature of corporation and corporate subsidiary, not all of which must be present for corporate veil to be pierced, are: (1) whether parent corporation owns all or a majority of capital stock of subsidiary; (2) whether parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) whether parent finances subsidiary; (4) whether parent subscribes to all the capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) whether parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; (8) whether subsidiary' is referred to as such in papers of parent corporation and in statements of its officers; (9) whether directors or executives of subsidiary fail to act independently in interests of subsidiary; and (10) whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are disregarded.
Document Preview: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), in its capacity as bank's receiver, brought suit against securities broker and its related corporate entities, seeking to hold them liable for broker's alleged role in Ponzi scheme perpetrated upon bank by its investment advisor/manager.  On cross-motions for summary judgment or partial summary judgment, to bifurcate alter ego claims, to impose Rule 11 sanctions, and to authorize calling of fact witness, the District Court, Kane, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) material fact questions precluded entry of summary judgment on proximate cause and damages issues, on securities fraud and racketeering claims, and on false representation and other common law claims; (2) prior determination, in lawsuit to impose constructive trust on funds which investment advisor/manager had caused to be transferred to customer from its securities brokerage account, that investment advisor was agent authorized to transfer funds and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Brooklyn Navy Yard Cogeneration Partners, L.P. v. Superior Court (Parsons Corp.)
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: In order to establish that subsidiary corporation is alter ego of parent, (1) there must be such unity of interest that separate personalities of corporations no longer exist, and (2) inequitable results must follow if corporate separateness is respected.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Attorneys' representation of subsidiary did not bar representation adverse to parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: DaSilva v. American Tobacco Co.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Protection afforded separate corporate entities can be overcome only by showing that parent has exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Pleading. Products liability complaint against cigarette manufacturers was deficient in failing to identify brand or brands of cigarettes smoked by each plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Audre, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Absent illegitimate purposes, the separate existence of subsidiary corporation will be recognized, unless: (a) the business transactions, property, employees, bank and other accounts and records of corporation and subsidiary are intermingled; (b) formalities of separate corporate procedures for each corporation are not observed; (c) subsidiary corporation is inadequately financed as separate unit from the point of view of meeting its normal obligations; (d) respective enterprises are not held out to the public as separate enterprises; and (e) policies of subsidiary corporation are not directed to its own interests primarily, but rather to those of parent corporation.
Document Preview: Claims - Rooker-Feldman doctrine applied to prevent bankruptcy court from disallowing claim that was based on state court judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Air-Sea Forwarders, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: Corporation is considered "alter ego" of another where such unity of interest, ownership, and control exists between the two, generally parent corporation and its subsidiary, that their separate personalities no longer exist.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS - Performance and Breach. Freight forwarder's alleged oral contract with CIA cover corporation was for secret services and, thus, was unenforceable under Totten doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Circle Land and Cattle Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: When parent and subsidiary corporations are focus of alter ego charge, Kansas courts consider ten factors in deciding whether corporate veil should be pierced: (1) whether parent corporation owns all or a majority of capital stock of subsidiary; (2) whether corporations have common directors or officers; (3) whether parent corporation finances subsidiary; (4) whether parent corporation subscribed to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise caused its incorporation; (5) whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) whether parent corporation pays the salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation; (8) whether in the papers of parent corporation, and in statements of its officers, subsidiary is referred to as such or as department or division; (9) whether directors or executives of subsidiary act independently in interest of subsidiary or take direction from parent corporation; and (10) whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are observed.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Veil-piercing factors alleged by creditor did not warrant substantive consolidation of Chapter 11 debtor with alleged corporate alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Valero South Texas Processing Co. v. Starr County Appraisal Dist.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: For purposes of legal proceedings, subsidiary corporations and parent corporations are separate and distinct "persons" as matter of law; separate entity of corporations will be observed by courts even in instances where one may dominate or control, or may even treat it as mere department, instrumentality, or agency of other.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Real Property. County appraisal review board's notice of issuance of order to protesting taxpayer was insufficient under statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cable & Connector Warehouse, Inc. v. Omnimark, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Mere fact that two corporations are affiliated in some way, such as parent-subsidiary, does not mean that a contract with one of those corporations is a contract with the other.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Liens. Supplier to supplier did not have claim under Private Works Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rothstein v. Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York.
Headnote: Courts will pierce corporate veil to prevent fraud or other wrongdoing, or where parent entity dominates and controls subsidiary.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. Corporation that purchased rights to manufacture line of radioactive contrast dyes could be liable, under product line exception to rule against holding successor liable for predecessor's torts, for death attributed to dye.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rothstein v. Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York.
Headnote: In determining whether parent entity is an alter ego of subsidiary, courts examine following factors: failure to adhere to corporate formalities, day-to-day control of subsidiary by parent, subsidiary's capitalization, comingling of assets, and/or use of subsidiary for fraudulent or unjust purposes.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. Corporation that purchased rights to manufacture line of radioactive contrast dyes could be liable, under product line exception to rule against holding successor liable for predecessor's torts, for death attributed to dye.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rothstein v. Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York.
Headnote: Imposition of liability upon corporate parent for acts of subsidiary can never be predicated solely upon fact of parent corporation's ownership of controlling interest in shares of its subsidiary.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. Corporation that purchased rights to manufacture line of radioactive contrast dyes could be liable, under product line exception to rule against holding successor liable for predecessor's torts, for death attributed to dye.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kindle Bldg. Co. v. Ford Motor Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Although no precise standard exists to pierce corporate veil, plaintiff must show that parent corporation: (1) dominates and controls subsidiary so that it has no mind, will or existence of its own; (2) used that domination to commit fraud, wrong, or other dishonest or unjust acts; and (3) injured plaintiff.
Document Preview: Lessor brought action against parent corporation of dissolved corporate lessee, alleging damages caused when lessee installed defective underground storage tank on lessor's property. Parent moved for summary judgment, and lessor moved to amend complaint. The District Court, Carr, J., held that: (1) allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil, and (2) court would not grant lessor's motion for leave to amend complaint to include statutory charges. Judgment as ordered. Affirmed,  F.3d .

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kindle Bldg. Co. v. Ford Motor Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: To establish that parent corporation used domination over subsidiary to commit fraud, as would warrant piercing corporate veil, plaintiff would have to prove that parent personally or through others, intentionally caused misrepresentations or nondisclosures, and that those misrepresentations or nondisclosures were intended by parent to deceive plaintiff.
Document Preview: Lessor brought action against parent corporation of dissolved corporate lessee, alleging damages caused when lessee installed defective underground storage tank on lessor's property. Parent moved for summary judgment, and lessor moved to amend complaint. The District Court, Carr, J., held that: (1) allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil, and (2) court would not grant lessor's motion for leave to amend complaint to include statutory charges. Judgment as ordered. Affirmed,  F.3d .

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kindle Bldg. Co. v. Ford Motor Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: To establish that parent corporation used domination over subsidiary to commit wrong or other dishonest or unjust acts, as would warrant piercing corporate veil, plaintiff would have to prove either that parent disregarded corporate entity or plaintiff suffered extraordinary injustice.
Document Preview: Lessor brought action against parent corporation of dissolved corporate lessee, alleging damages caused when lessee installed defective underground storage tank on lessor's property. Parent moved for summary judgment, and lessor moved to amend complaint. The District Court, Carr, J., held that: (1) allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil, and (2) court would not grant lessor's motion for leave to amend complaint to include statutory charges. Judgment as ordered. Affirmed,  F.3d .

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Abdel-Fattah v. Pepsico, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Exception to rule that parent corporation has no duty to control its subsidiaries applies when there is some basis for piercing corporate veil and treating two corporations as one entity.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer Torts. Parent's 100% ownership of subsidiary's stock corporation did not make it liable for subsidiary's alleged negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Arch v. American Tobacco Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Possibility that plaintiff may have difficulty enforcing judgment against subsidiary corporation is not enough to justify piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs commenced state court action against tobacco manufacturers and distributors and a foreign holding company whose subsidiary was a manufacturer.  Action was removed, and holding company filed motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The District Court, Newcomer, J., held that: (1) holding company did not have sufficient minimum contacts with Pennsylvania so as to establish personal jurisdiction, and (2) jurisdictional contacts of holding company's subsidiary could not be imputed to holding company. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Jeanneton v. Hilton Intern.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico's "single entity" or "common control" doctrine, parent corporation and its subsidiary will only be regarded as one for purposes of finding the former liable if it is determined that: (1) their operations are significantly interrelated; (2) there is common management; (3) there is joint control over labor relations; and (4) there is joint proprietorship or financial control.
Document Preview: Hotel employee brought action against hotel and its parent corporation alleging, inter alia, breach of employment contract.  On motion by hotel and parent corporation for partial summary judgment, the District Court, Casellas, J., held that parent corporation could not be held liable for hotel's alleged breach of employment contract. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re American Honda Motor Co., Inc. Dealerships Relations Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Corporate parent cannot be held liable for subsidiary's wrongful acts solely by virtue of its ownership of and control over subsidiary, unless corporate veil can be pierced under conventional doctrines because of inadequate capitalization of subsidiary, gross disregard of corporate formalities, and the like.
Document Preview: Multiple actions arose in which automobile dealers alleged that automobile manufacturer and law firm were liable for purported scheme under which manufacturer's distribution subsidiary gave illegal kickbacks to other dealers.  Actions were consolidated by order of judicial panel on multidistrict litigation. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Conner v. ContiCarriers and Terminals, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: If parent and subsidiary maintain separate and distinct corporate entities, presence of one corporation in forum state may not be attributed to other. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: CIVIL PROCEDURE - Jurisdiction. Barge operator did not have continuous and systematic contacts necessary to maintain general personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >

Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Before alter-ego jurisdiction may attach, court must determine that parent so controls or dominates subsidiary as to disregard corporate formalities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kissun v. Humana, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: Parent/subsidiary relationship does not in and of itself establish subsidiary as either alter ego of parent, or as parent's actual or apparent agent; however, mere fact that one corporation is subsidiary of another does not alone serve to insulate parent where evidence can establish legal requirements of actual or apparent agency relationship between the two corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Agency. Parent corporation may be found liable for acts or omissions of wholly-owned subsidiary corporation under theories of apparent agency or joint venturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Yoder v. Honeywell Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Determination under Colorado law of whether subsidiary is mere instrumentality of parent includes evaluation of whether parent owns all or majority of subsidiary's capital stock, corporations have common directors or officers, parent finances subsidiary, parent subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, parent pays salaries, expenses, or losses of subsidiary, subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent, subsidiary is referred to as such or as department or division in papers of parent or statements of officers, directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently but take direction from parent, and formal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.

Title: Classic Communications, Inc. v. Rural Telephone Service Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Parent corporation has discrete corporate existence and is treated independently of its subsidiaries in absence of extraordinary circumstances.

Brown does not apply...

Title: McClaran v. Plastic Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, parent corporation of subsidiary formed to acquire different company's boat division was not subsidiary's alter ego; no evidence showed that parent knew kayak designer would not consent to assignment of his contract with acquired division to subsidiary and created subsidiary to avoid liability to designer, no abuse of corporate form between parent and subsidiary existed, despite common officers and directors and some blurring of corporate identities, and nothing indicated that subsidiary was undercapitalized at outset or that financial accounting of two companies were commingled or manipulated.
Document Preview: Kayak designer sued manufacturer for breach of contract, based on its assignment of nonassignable license agreement.  Designer also sued assignee and its parent corporation for inducement to breach contract and trademark infringement.  After dismissing parent corporation, the United States District Court for the District of Idaho, Marion J. Callister, Senior District Judge, found in favor of designer on breach of contract, inducement to breach, and trademark infringement claims, ordered remittitur of award against assignee, and imposed direct liability on parent corporation for inducement to breach damages.  Parties cross-appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Wiggins, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) manufacturer breached contract; (2) damage award to designer for lost royalties was too speculative; (3) under Tennessee law, parent was not assignee-subsidiary's alter ego; (4) due process barred entry of judgment against parent, inasmuch as parent was dismissed...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Association of Mill and Elevator Mut. Ins. Co. v. Barzen Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil between parent corporation and subsidiary there must be a "a number" factors such as insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation as merely facade for individual dealings, and there must also be element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: Unsecured creditors of subsidiary corporation brought suit against parent and subsidiary, seeking to recover amounts due from subsidiary.  The District Court, Chisago County, Linn Slattengren, J., entered judgment for creditors, allowing for piercing of corporate veil, and denied recovery on theories of agency or promissory estoppel.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Klaphake, J., held that: (1) corporate veil should not have been pierced, even though parent had provided capital infusions for subsidiary, subsidiary had been insolvent at time of its dissolution, and parent had taken management role (albeit not a dominant role) in latter days of corporation; (2) parent had not breached fiduciary duty, if any, toward creditors by paying down line of credit held by bank as preferred creditor; (3) alleged oral promises to pay debts owing to unsecured creditors was unenforceable. Affirmed in part; reversed in part.

Title: Giuliano v. Nations Title, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Massachusetts law did not permit the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts to pierce corporate veil of California parent corporation so that district court could assert jurisdiction over California parent corporation, even though there was intermingling of corporate officers and some evidence that parent corporation had considerable control over its subsidiary, where there was no adequate showing of "pervasive control" by officers of parent corporation and no evidence that parent corporation's participation produced fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against title insurance company and its California-based parent, alleging breach of contract, unfair and deceptive trade practices and conversion.  Parent moved to dismiss.  The District Court, Young, J., held that: (1) there was no basis for assertion of direct jurisdiction over parent, based on parent's doing business in Commonwealth, and (2) corporate veil would not be pierced, even though there were indications that officers of parent had exercised some control over subsidiary's activities. Motions granted.

Title: Union Carbide Corp. v. Montell N.V.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, where subsidiary is in fact mere instrumentality or alter ego of its owner, court can pierce corporate veil.

Defendants moved to dismiss portions of complaint. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re American Honda Motor Co., Inc. Dealerships Relations Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard corporate form, court will consider amount of respect given to separate identity of subsidiary by parent, fraudulent intent of incorporators, and degree of injustice which will result if two companies are treated as separate entities.

Title: In re American Honda Motor Co., Inc. Dealerships Relations Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Intercorporate agency can be established for some purposes, such as service of process, by showing that subsidiary is completely controlled by parent or that separately incorporated subsidiary is only conduit for that which parent would otherwise have to do for itself, but such a showing falls short of the fraudulent intent or gross inequity required to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Alabama Power Co. v. Tennessee Valley Authority
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, in general, mere ownership of capital stock of one corporation by another does not create identity of corporate interest.
Document Preview: Power companies with exchange power arrangements with Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) brought action against TVA, respecting statutory eligibility of electric utility's nonregulated power marketing affiliate to purchase surplus power from TVA.  TVA moved to dismiss or for summary judgment, and power companies and affiliate moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Propst, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) power companies had standing to bring action; (2) it was not required to simply defer to ipse dixit arguments of TVA as litigant; and (3) affiliate was not organization for statutory exemption purposes within meaning of statute limiting area for TVA power sales and, under exemption, allowing TVA to make exchange power arrangements with power-generating organizations with which TVA had such arrangements on 1957 grandfathered date, such as utility. Power companies' motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Perry v. Household Retail Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Mere fact that one corporation owns all the stock of another corporation does not destroy the separate corporate identities.
Document Preview: Consumer who financed purchase of satellite television dish sued retail dealer, distributor, issuers of private label credit cards, and issuers' parent corporation for alleged violation of the Truth-in-Lending Act (TILA), the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), and Alabama and Illinois statutory and common law.  Corporation moved to dismiss and for summary judgment.  The District Court, De Ment, J., held that: (1) corporation's objections to service of process and venue were without merit; (2) genuine issues of material fact existed as to whether corporation and subsidiary engaged in civil conspiracy or were otherwise joint tort-feasors, and thus whether corporate veil should be pierced; and (3) Illinois Consumer Fraud Act was not limited in scope to the protection of Illinois residents. Motions denied. See also 953 F.Supp. 1370.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Perry v. Household Retail Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: In assessing the indicia of control necessary to establish that one party is the alter ego of another party, or to pierce the corporate veil, court considers, among other factors, whether parent corporation owns all or most of subsidiary's capital stock, whether parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers, whether parent finances subsidiary, whether parent subscribes to all the subsidiary's capital stock or otherwise causes its incorporation, whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, whether parent pays salaries and other expenses or losses of subsidiary, whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent, whether in papers of parent or in statements of its officers subsidiary is described as department or division of parent or its business or financial responsibility is referred to as parent's own, whether parent uses property of subsidiary as its own, whether subsidiary's directors or executives do not act independently in the interest of the subsidiary but take their orders from parent in latter's interest, and whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary are not observed.
Document Preview: Consumer who financed purchase of satellite television dish sued retail dealer, distributor, issuers of private label credit cards, and issuers' parent corporation for alleged violation of the Truth-in-Lending Act (TILA), the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), and Alabama and Illinois statutory and common law.  Corporation moved to dismiss and for summary judgment.  The District Court, De Ment, J., held that: (1) corporation's objections to service of process and venue were without merit; (2) genuine issues of material fact existed as to whether corporation and subsidiary engaged in civil conspiracy or were otherwise joint tort-feasors, and thus whether corporate veil should be pierced; and (3) Illinois Consumer Fraud Act was not limited in scope to the protection of Illinois residents. Motions denied. See also 953 F.Supp. 1370.

Title: Marzano v. Computer Science Corp. Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Court may not depart from New Jersey principle of limited liability of parent corporation and pierce corporate veil of parent unless it finds that a subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of parent corporation; requisite finding is that parent so dominated subsidiary that it had no separate existence but was merely a conduit for parent.
Document Preview: Female former employee brought action in state court against former employer alleging unlawful discrimination on basis of pregnancy in violation of New Jersey Law Against Discrimination, unlawful interference with her rights under New Jersey Family Leave Act, and breach of implied-in-fact employment contract.  Case was removed.  The United States District Court for the District of New Jersey, Clarkson S. Fisher, J., granted summary judgment for former employer.  Former employee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Sarokin, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether division in which employee worked was appropriate work unit for determining whether there was a reduction-in-force and whether a reduction-in-force occurred, precluding summary judgment on pregnancy discrimination claim; (2) district court applied wrong test to reduction-in-force claim and application of wrong test was reversible error; (3) genuine issues of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: F.D.I.C. v. First Interstate Bank of Denver, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: If parent corporation used corporate entity to perpetuate fraud or wrong on another, equity will permit plaintiff to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) as receiver for bank, brought suit in state court against securities firm and others, alleging fraudulent scheme among defendants and investment advisor.  Action was removed to federal district court where defendants moved to dismiss and FDIC moved to strike designation of nonparty liability by defendants.  The District Court, Babcock, J., held that: (1) complaint made prima facie showing of jurisdiction over defendants under alter-ego theory of liability; (2) complaint stated claim for primary violation of Colorado Organized Crime Control Act (COCCA); (3) as a matter of first impression, aiding and abetting liability is viable claim under COCCA; (4) complaint stated claim for aiding and abetting COCCA violation; (5) respondeat superior is proper basis for claim under COCCA; (6) complaint stated claim for conspiracy to violate COCCA; (7) complaint stated claim under Colorado...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Freeman v. Complex Computing Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts will pierce the corporate veil in two broad situations: to prevent fraud or other wrong, or where parent dominates and controls a subsidiary.
Document Preview: Salesperson for computer software company brought action against company, successor corporation, and university student, who developed computer software but was prohibited by university policy from serving as officer, director or stockholder in a corporation marketing software and thus had a corporation organized to get around policy, alleging breach of contract and tortious interference with contract. Salesperson moved to compel arbitration. The District Court, Kaplan, J., held that: (1) salesperson's commencement of breach of contract action was not a default in proceeding with arbitration and did not preclude him from seeking order compelling arbitration; (2) salesperson did not waive right to arbitrate by commencing action; (3) claim against university student was arbitrable, although he was not a party to any arbitration clause; and (4) successor corporation was not subject to arbitration agreement. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Gundle Lining Const. Corp. v. Adams County Asphalt, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether subsidiary is alter ego of parent, under Texas law, court considers whether: parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership, parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers, parent and subsidiary have common business departments, parent and subsidiary file consolidated and financial statements and tax returns, parent finances subsidiary, parent caused incorporation of subsidiary, subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital, parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary, subsidiary receives no business except that given to it by parent, parent uses subsidiary's property as its own, and daily operations of the two corporations are not kept separate.

Hughes, J., granted summary judgment to surety, and third-party defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Robert M. Parker, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court had jurisdiction over contractor; (2) jurisdiction was lacking as to other third-party defendants; (3) district court properly denied contractor's motion to transfer venue; and (4) surety paid subcontractor's claim against payment bond in...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rolls-Royce Motor Cars, Inc. v. Schudroff
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To establish that subsidiary corporate entity is alter ego of its parent owners for purposes of piercing corporate veil under New York law, plaintiff must allege and prove that parent exercised such complete domination in respect to transaction attacked that subsidiary had at that time no separate will of its own, and that this domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff.
Document Preview: Automobile manufacturer brought action against car dealership and its owners, corporate successor, corporate parent, and accountants alleging numerous contract, tort, and Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) claims regarding transactions involving 15 automobiles. The District Court, Mukasey, J., held that: (1) plaintiff sufficiently alleged alter ego theory for piercing corporate veil; (2) defendants could not be held liable for fraud or negligent misrepresentation; (3) plaintiff had right to enforce checks against dealership; (4) plaintiff failed to establish continuity of criminal activity as required for RICO claims; (5) plaintiff stated claim for trademark infringement and unfair competition; and (6) defendants could be held for fraudulent conveyance upon proof of actual intent. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rolls-Royce Motor Cars, Inc. v. Schudroff
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under alter ego theory according to law of New York, it is sufficient to prove that complete domination of parent over subsidiary was used to commit fraud or wrong; thus, veil-piercing claimant can prevail against parent without proving fraud if claimant can identify some nonfraudulent "wrong" attributable to parent's complete domination of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Royal Industries Ltd. v. Kraft Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation can commission its subsidiary to act as parent's agent and, if such agency arrangement is alleged, plaintiff need not also allege domination and intent to defraud, as required to pierce corporate veil, in order for claim against parent to survive; parent should not be allowed to escape liability simply because it owns stock in subsidiary/agent but, rather, as in any agency case, issue should be whether subsidiary had authority, actual or apparent, to act on parent's behalf.
Document Preview: Marshall Islands distributor of food products to Russian customers brought action for breach of purchase contract against Delaware manufacturer of food products, an unincorporated New York division of which was responsible for handling manufacturer's end of the deal.  On manufacturer's motion to dismiss for failure to join indispensable party and on ground of forum non conveniens, and distributor's cross-motion for partial summary judgment, the District Court, Haight, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) there was genuine issue of material fact as to existence of agency relationship between manufacturer and its subsidiary; (2) subsidiary was not necessary or indispensable party; and (3) dismissal on ground of forum non conveniens was not warranted, particularly as New York law, rather than law of Russia, governed. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Royal Industries Ltd. v. Kraft Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: When parent corporation is sued on agency theory, claim against parent is premised on view that subsidiary had authority to act, and was in fact acting, on parent's behalf, i.e., in name of parent, while when parent is sued on theory of piercing corporate veil, plaintiff does not dispute that underlying obligation belongs to subsidiary, but seeks to hold parent liable on theory that parent fraudulently induced subsidiary to incur obligation. Restatement (Second) of Agency § 14M Appendix.
Document Preview: Marshall Islands distributor of food products to Russian customers brought action for breach of purchase contract against Delaware manufacturer of food products, an unincorporated New York division of which was responsible for handling manufacturer's end of the deal.  On manufacturer's motion to dismiss for failure to join indispensable party and on ground of forum non conveniens, and distributor's cross-motion for partial summary judgment, the District Court, Haight, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) there was genuine issue of material fact as to existence of agency relationship between manufacturer and its subsidiary; (2) subsidiary was not necessary or indispensable party; and (3) dismissal on ground of forum non conveniens was not warranted, particularly as New York law, rather than law of Russia, governed. Motions denied.

Title: Great West Cas. Co. v. Travelers Indem. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Western Division.
Headnote: Under South Dakota law, parent corporation is liable for acts of subsidiary when parent controls subsidiary to such a degree as to render the latter a mere instrumentality of the former, and when adherence to rule of corporate separateness would produce injustices and inequities.
Document Preview: Creditors of insurance agency which had filed for Chapter 7 relief brought adversary proceeding against corporate lender which had financed management's acquisition of stock of agency, seeking to hold corporate lender liable for agency's debts on corporate instrumentality theory. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Great West Cas. Co. v. Travelers Indem. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Western Division.
Headnote: Under South Dakota law, factors which trial court considers in deciding whether to hold parent corporation liable for acts of its subsidiary include: whether parent owns most of capital stock of subsidiary; whether parent and subsidiary corporations have common directors or officers; whether parent finances subsidiary; whether parents subscribed to all the capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise caused its incorporation; whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; whether parent pays salaries and other expenses and losses of subsidiary; whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; whether subsidiary is described in papers of parent corporation or in statements of its officers as mere department or division of parent; whether parent uses property of subsidiary as its own; whether directors or executives of subsidiary act independently in interest of subsidiary or simply take their orders from parent; and whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary are observed.

Title: Great West Cas. Co. v. Travelers Indem. Co.

Headnote: Under South Dakota law, dominant corporation may be held liable for debts of subservient corporation on instrumentality theory, where dominant corporation misuses subservient corporation by treating it, and by using it, as mere business conduit for purposes of dominant corporation.

Title: Great West Cas. Co. v. Travelers Indem. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Western Division.
Headnote: Under South Dakota law, three elements must be present for dominant corporation to be held liable for debts of subservient corporation on instrumentality theory: control by dominant corporation; proximate cause through misuse of control; and fraud or injustice resulting from that use of control.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Great West Cas. Co. v. Travelers Indem. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Western Division.
Headnote: Under South Dakota law, "control" required for dominant corporation to be held liable for debts of subservient corporation on instrumentality theory amounts to total dominion of subservient corporation, such that subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its one and functions solely to achieve purposes of dominant corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Orlando Regional Healthcare System, Inc. v. Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division. .
Headnote: Florida courts may pierce subsidiary's corporate veil only upon showing that parent corporation used subsidiary as mere instrumentality and that this was done for improper purpose.
Document Preview: Plaintiff hospital system brought suit, alleging that defendant hospital system breached its joint venture agreement with plaintiff by not offering it the opportunity to purchase defendant's interest in hospital the parties operated in a joint venture. The District Court, G. Kendall Sharp, J., held that defendant breached provision of joint venture agreement entitling plaintiff to purchase defendant's interest in the venture if defendant received purchase offer from certain enumerated companies or their affiliates. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: American Psych Systems, Inc. v. Options Independent Practice Ass'n, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Westchester County, New York.
Headnote: Parent and subsidiary corporation are generally presumed to be two distinct legal entities; however, this distinction may be called into question by showing of control by parent.
Document Preview: Disqualification. Disqualification of plaintiff's counsel was warranted by its prior representation of defendant's parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Sims v. Western Waste Industries
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Parent and subsidiary corporations, absent exceptional circumstances and when it is in the interest of equity to do so, are not held accountable for the acts of the other; this is primary motivation for incorporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Law does not permit parent corporation to assert alter ego theory of piercing the corporate veil of subsidiary and thereby assert workers' compensation immunity as defense to suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Wallace
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation will be held derivatively liable for acts of its subsidiary only upon factual determination that corporate formalities should be disregarded and corporate veil pierced.
Document Preview: Federal and state governments filed separate actions under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) concerning cleanup of waste treatment and disposal facility, and cases were consolidated. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Wallace
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded in interest of public convenience, fairness and equity, but courts generally limit veil piercing to situations in which corporate subsidiary is established to perpetrate fraud, its shareholders drain corporation's assets, or subsidiary is totally dominated and controlled by parent corporation as its business conduit or alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Wallace
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under general corporate law principles, relevant inquiry into control issue in determining whether parent corporation is alter ego of subsidiary focuses on relationship between parent and subsidiary at time acts complained of took place.
Document Preview: Federal and state governments filed separate actions under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) concerning cleanup of waste treatment and disposal facility, and cases were consolidated.
