Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Crain
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Domination of subservient corporation is indicated when corporation maintains no separate and distinct corporate bank account, when corporation and personal funds are intermingled or corporate funds are used for personal purposes, or when individual drains funds from corporation.
Document Preview: Involuntary Petitions. Creditor that filed involuntary petition against alleged debtor was not disqualified as petitioning creditor by debtor's postpetition payment of debt, even though debtor alleged payment created voidable transfer that disqualified creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Joiner v. Ryder System Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: In general, parent corporation may not be held to account for liabilities of subsidiary unless legal separateness of parent and subsidiary has been disregarded in wide range of corporate matters.
Document Preview: Worker brought strict products liability and negligence action to recover for injuries sustained when he attempted to remove skids located at rear of automobile transport trailer.  Parent company of trailer's manufacturer moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) parent company did not exert improper control over subsidiaries so as to support argument that parent was alter ego of trailer manufacturer; (2) parent company did not hold itself out as manufacturer of trailer, for purposes of liability under apparent manufacturer doctrine; and (3) assuming parent company was aware prior to injuries in question that trailer was unsafe, parent did not have duty to order subsidiary to redesign trailer. Motion for summary judgment allowed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Joiner v. Ryder System Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Party seeking to show unity and interest and ownership between parent corporation and subsidiary, for purposes of piercing corporate veil under alter ego doctrine, must show degree of control by parent corporation by presenting evidence of misrepresentation, commingling of funds, assets, or identities, undercapitalization of subsidiary, failure to operate at arms length, and failure to comply with corporate formalities.
Document Preview: Worker brought strict products liability and negligence action to recover for injuries sustained when he attempted to remove skids located at rear of automobile transport trailer.  Parent company of trailer's manufacturer moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) parent company did not exert improper control over subsidiaries so as to support argument that parent was alter ego of trailer manufacturer; (2) parent company did not hold itself out as manufacturer of trailer, for purposes of liability under apparent manufacturer doctrine; and (3) assuming parent company was aware prior to injuries in question that trailer was unsafe, parent did not have duty to order subsidiary to redesign trailer. Motion for summary judgment allowed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Humana, Inc. v. Kissun
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil it must be shown that parent's disregard of corporate entity made subsidiary mere instrumentality for transaction of parent's affairs, that there was such unity of interest in ownership that separate personalities of subsidiary and parent no longer exist, and that to adhere to doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: Corporations. Corporate veil of subsidiary could not be pierced in malpractice case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Humana, Inc. v. Kissun
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Standing alone, lawful uses of subsidiary corporation by its parent corporation cannot support claim against parent under theory of apparent agency or joint venturer; such claims must rest upon factors other than those which law contemplates and approves.
Document Preview: Corporations. Corporate veil of subsidiary could not be pierced in malpractice case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Satcorp Intern. Group v. China Nat. Import & Export Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Financial dependency of subsidiary on parent, supporting assertion of jurisdiction over parent on theory that subsidiary is its alter ego, may be established where parent makes no-interest loan to subsidiary, where it controls subsidiary's finances, or where it finances subsidiary's inventory.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor of Chinese subsidiary corporation brought suit against Chinese parent corporation, seeking to collect on default judgment.  On Chinese parent's motion to dismiss for lack of in personam jurisdiction, and judgment creditor's motion to strike jurisdictional defense and impose discovery sanctions, the District Court, Kaplan, J., held that: (1) failure of Chinese parent corporation to comply with court's order to respond to discovery request for correspondence with its wholly owned American subsidiary warranted sanctions of attorney fees and striking of parent's jurisdictional defense, and (2) court had personal jurisdiction over parent corporation on alter ego theory. Plaintiff's motion granted and defendant's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Manhattan Woods Golf Club, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, court may not pierce corporate veil to hold parent corporation liable for acts of subsidiary unless parent corporation has exercised such control over subsidiary that subsidiary has become mere instrumentality of parent, which is the real actor, unless such control has been used to commit fraud or other wrong, and unless fraud or wrong results in unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: Corporations. corporate subsidiary's former officers and directors could not engage in reverse veil-piercing to hold subsidiary liable on their agreements with corporate parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Sonnenblick-Goldman Co. v. ITT Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under Delaware law, if there is no fraud, plaintiff must show that parent and subsidiary operated as single economic entity and that overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: Licensed real estate broker brought action against corporation in New York County Supreme Court, alleging that corporate executive vice-president and chief financial officer of corporation's subsidiary, on behalf of corporation and its subsidiary, breached agreement to pay brokerage fees.  Corporation removed, then moved to dismiss.  Broker cross-moved to remand to state court.  The District Court, Batts, J., held that: (1) under Delaware law, broker's pleadings were insufficient as a matter of law to show that corporation and its subsidiary were single economic unit, for purpose of piercing corporate veil in order to bring breach of brokerage agreement action against corporation, and (2) broker's complaint, alleging that corporation was involved in fraudulent scheme to avoid paying broker, failed to plead elements of fraud with required amount of specificity. Broker's motion denied; corporation's motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kasprzak v. American General Life & Acc. Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: As general rule, court will not disregard corporate fiction and hold corporation liable for obligations of its subsidiary except where it appears corporate entity of subsidiary is being used as sham to perpetrate fraud, to avoid liability, to avoid effect of statute, or in other exceptional circumstances when corporate form has been used as part of basically unfair device to achieve inequitable result.
Document Preview: Insureds brought state-court action against life insurer and its corporate parent, alleging misrepresentation in sales of policies issued by insurer. Defendants removed. On insureds' motion to remand for lack of diversity, the District Court, Cobb, J., held that clear and convincing evidence showed that insureds fraudulently joined parent in effort to defeat diversity as jurisdictional basis for removal, and thus removal was proper, where there was no evidence to support disregarding corporate separateness of insurer and parent. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kasprzak v. American General Life & Acc. Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: There must be something more than mere unity of financial interest, ownership and control for court to treat corporate subsidiary as alter ego of parent and make parent liable for subsidiary's actions.
Document Preview: Insureds brought state-court action against life insurer and its corporate parent, alleging misrepresentation in sales of policies issued by insurer. Defendants removed. On insureds' motion to remand for lack of diversity, the District Court, Cobb, J., held that clear and convincing evidence showed that insureds fraudulently joined parent in effort to defeat diversity as jurisdictional basis for removal, and thus removal was proper, where there was no evidence to support disregarding corporate separateness of insurer and parent. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kasprzak v. American General Life & Acc. Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: Merely showing blending of activities between corporate parent and subsidiary, such that they may have had some or all of same directors or officers, filed consolidated income tax returns, shared same corporate logo, conducted intercorporate business, or officed in same building, is not alone sufficient to make parent liable.
Document Preview: Insureds brought state-court action against life insurer and its corporate parent, alleging misrepresentation in sales of policies issued by insurer. Defendants removed. On insureds' motion to remand for lack of diversity, the District Court, Cobb, J., held that clear and convincing evidence showed that insureds fraudulently joined parent in effort to defeat diversity as jurisdictional basis for removal, and thus removal was proper, where there was no evidence to support disregarding corporate separateness of insurer and parent. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Grease Monkey Intern., Inc. v. Godat
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Trial court erred in imposing lien on property for conduct of subsidiary of property owner; placing a lien on the property had the effect of making the parent company liable for debt of subsidiary without an opportunity to be heard.
Document Preview: REAL ESTATE - Specific Performance. Sales contract was incomplete and therefore not subject to specific performance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Grease Monkey Intern., Inc. v. Godat
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Normally, a parent corporation is not responsible for acts of its subsidiary corporation except where wronged party pierces the corporate veil.
Document Preview: REAL ESTATE - Specific Performance. Sales contract was incomplete and therefore not subject to specific performance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Powers v. Fox Television Stations, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors relevant in determining whether subsidiary is merely "alter ego" of its parents include (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, such as issuance of stock, election of directors, and keeping of corporate records, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group, and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of corporations as if it were its own. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1332(c)(1).
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought suit in state court, alleging that defendant corporation terminated his employment in violation of New York State human rights law and New York City Administrative Code, and defendant removed case to federal court based on diversity.  On plaintiff's motion to remand, the District Court, Scheindlin, J., held that: (1) defendant carried its initial burden of demonstrating that California was its principal place of business, and (2) plaintiff failed to prove that defendant was alter ego of its New York parent companies, and thus that New York should be defendant's imputed location for jurisdictional purposes. Motion to remand denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Catfish Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Delta Division.
Headnote: When party alleges that corporate form of subsidiary should be disregarded as limitation upon liability of parent corporation under "alter ego" theory, that party in essence charges that parent corporation totally dominates and controls subsidiary, operating subsidiary as its business conduit or agent.
Document Preview: Food distributors brought antitrust action against catfish processors, alleging conspiracy to fix prices of catfish products.  On processors' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Davidson, J., held that: (1) fact issues as to whether defendants fraudulently concealed price fixing conspiracy so as to toll Clayton Act's statute of limitations precluded summary judgment on limitations grounds; (2) evidence raised genuine issue of material fact as to whether plaintiffs suffered actual damages, precluding summary judgment; (3) evidence raised genuine issue of material fact as to whether parent corporation was responsible for its subsidiary's antitrust liability; (4) evidence raised fact issue as to whether subsidiary withdrew from alleged conspiracy; and (5) evidence raised fact issue as to whether parent exercised sufficient control over subsidiary to disregard corporate form of subsidiary. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Catfish Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Delta Division.
Headnote: Amount of control required of parent corporation to disregard corporate form of subsidiary is that which amounts to total domination of subservient corporation, to extent that subsidiary corporation manifests no separate corporate interest of its own and functions solely to achieve purposes of dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Food distributors brought antitrust action against catfish processors, alleging conspiracy to fix prices of catfish products.  On processors' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Davidson, J., held that: (1) fact issues as to whether defendants fraudulently concealed price fixing conspiracy so as to toll Clayton Act's statute of limitations precluded summary judgment on limitations grounds; (2) evidence raised genuine issue of material fact as to whether plaintiffs suffered actual damages, precluding summary judgment; (3) evidence raised genuine issue of material fact as to whether parent corporation was responsible for its subsidiary's antitrust liability; (4) evidence raised fact issue as to whether subsidiary withdrew from alleged conspiracy; and (5) evidence raised fact issue as to whether parent exercised sufficient control over subsidiary to disregard corporate form of subsidiary. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Catfish Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Delta Division.
Headnote: To determine whether sufficient domination and control are present, as required to disregard corporate form of subsidiary, fact finder must consider totality of the circumstances.
Document Preview: Food distributors brought antitrust action against catfish processors, alleging conspiracy to fix prices of catfish products.  On processors' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Davidson, J., held that: (1) fact issues as to whether defendants fraudulently concealed price fixing conspiracy so as to toll Clayton Act's statute of limitations precluded summary judgment on limitations grounds; (2) evidence raised genuine issue of material fact as to whether plaintiffs suffered actual damages, precluding summary judgment; (3) evidence raised genuine issue of material fact as to whether parent corporation was responsible for its subsidiary's antitrust liability; (4) evidence raised fact issue as to whether subsidiary withdrew from alleged conspiracy; and (5) evidence raised fact issue as to whether parent exercised sufficient control over subsidiary to disregard corporate form of subsidiary. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Doughty v. CSX Transp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: In absence of fraud or other invidious and vitiating circumstances, fact that one corporation is instrumental in formation of another corporation and owns nearly all of the stock of latter corporation does not have legal effect of making parent corporation liable for debts of subsidiary corporation.
Document Preview: Employee of subsidiary corporation brought Federal Employers' Liability Act (FELA) action against parent corporation for injuries he sustained while employed by subsidiary, alleging that parent was alter ego of subsidiary.  The Wyandotte District Court, Bill D. Robinson, Jr., J., entered summary judgment for parent.  Employee appealed.  The Supreme Court, Lockett, J., held that facts that the two corporations had stockholders or officers in common, that one was parent of the other, that parent selected from its own directors and officers the majority of directors of the other, and that parent financed subsidiary were, without more, insufficient to warrant treating them as one. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Doughty v. CSX Transp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Mere fact that subsidiary corporation was organized for avowed purpose of avoiding liability on part of holding company does not in itself constitute fraud justifying disregard of corporate entity of subsidiary.

The Supreme Court, Lockett, J., held that facts that the two corporations had stockholders or officers in common, that one was parent of the other, that parent selected from its own directors and officers the majority of directors of the other, and that parent financed subsidiary were, without more, insufficient to warrant treating them as one. Affirmed.

Title: Doughty v. CSX Transp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Ultimate test for imposing alter ego status on corporation is whether, from all facts and circumstances, it is apparent that relationship between parent and subsidiary is so intimate, parent's control over subsidiary is so dominating, and business and assets of the two are so mingled that recognition of subsidiary as distinct entity would result in injustice to third parties; in addition to factors used to determine corporate alter ego status, plaintiff must show that allowing legal fiction of separate corporate structure would result in injustice toward plaintiff.

The Wyandotte District Court, Bill D. Robinson, Jr., J., entered summary judgment for parent.  Employee appealed.  The Supreme Court, Lockett, J., held that facts that the two corporations had stockholders or officers in common, that one was parent of the other, that parent selected from its own directors and officers the majority of directors of the other, and that parent financed subsidiary were, without more, insufficient to warrant treating them as one. Affirmed.

Title: Mark Six Realty Associates, Inc. v. Drake
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Although great caution should be exercised in piercing the corporate veil, that is, disregarding or going behind the corporate entity, it may be done when the subsidiary is shown to be the alter ego or business conduit of the parent.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employment Contract. Real estate brokerage retained sufficient control over agent's duties to make her employee not independent contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Yoder v. Honeywell Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, whether parent corporation should be held liable for acts of its subsidiary based on alter ego doctrine, involves considering whether parent corporation owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary, parent and subsidiary corporations have common directors or officers, parent corporation finances subsidiary, parent corporation subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, parent corporation pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary, subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent corporation, in papers of parent corporation, and in statements of its officers, subsidiary is referred to as such or as department or division, directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take direction from parent corporation, formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: Worker brought products liability action against corporation, and corporation's former subsidiary that manufactured computer keyboard, for injuries suffered from use of allegedly defective keyboard, corporation moved for summary judgment, and former subsidiary moved for dismissal.  The District Court, Babcock, J., held that: (1) corporation was not alter ego of former subsidiary; (2) corporation was not manufacturer of keyboard; and (3) worker's action against former subsidiary accrued when she knew she was injured and knew cause of her injury. Motions granted.

Title: Yoder v. Honeywell Inc.

Headnote: Under Colorado law, unity of interest, from one corporation owning 100 percent of stock of subsidiary corporation, is insufficient to find that personalities of corporation and its subsidiary are not distinct.
Document Preview: Worker brought products liability action against corporation, and corporation's former subsidiary that manufactured computer keyboard, for injuries suffered from use of allegedly defective keyboard, corporation moved for summary judgment, and former subsidiary moved for dismissal.  The District Court, Babcock, J., held that: (1) corporation was not alter ego of former subsidiary; (2) corporation was not manufacturer of keyboard; and (3) worker's action against former subsidiary accrued when she knew she was injured and knew cause of her injury. Title: Fletcher v. Atex, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To prevail on alter ego claim under Delaware law, plaintiff must show (1) that parent and subsidiary operated as single economic entity, and (2) that overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.

Cabranes, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under New York law, New York state court's previous determination that issues of fact existed as to whether manufacturer was dominated by its parent corporation did not preclude relitigation of alter ego issue under doctrine of collateral estoppel; (2) under Delaware law, manufacturer was not alter ego of its parent corporation; (3) under New York law, manufacturer did not have...

Title: Fletcher v. Atex, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: For purposes of alter ego claim against parent corporation under Delaware law, factors to be considered in determining whether subsidiary and parent operate as single economic entity are whether subsidiary was adequately capitalized for corporate undertaking; whether subsidiary was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether parent siphoned subsidiary's funds; and whether, in general, subsidiary simply functioned as facade for parent.

Title: Thomson-CSF, S.A. v. American Arbitration Ass'n
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Courts will pierce corporate veil to prevent fraud or other wrong, or where parent dominates and controls subsidiary.
Document Preview: Corporate parent, which had recently purchased subsidiary, brought action against subsidiary's supplier, seeking declaration that it was not bound by arbitration clause in agreement between subsidiary and supplier, and seeking injunction prohibiting further proceedings against it under agreement. Supplier cross-moved to compel arbitration with parent.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, John F. Keenan, J., 1994 WL 593805, denied parent's request for declaratory and injunctive relief and granted supplier's motion to compel arbitration.  Corporate parent appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Altimari, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) parent did not assume obligation in agreement between subsidiary and supplier to arbitrate disputes with supplier, even though parent was aware that agreement purported to bind parent to agreement as an affiliate of subsidiary; (2) corporate parent could not be bound to arbitration...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Seasword v. Hilti, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Separate corporate entities will be respected, and law presumes that absent some abuse of corporate form, parent and subsidiary corporations are separate and distinct entities; presumption, often referred to as "corporate veil," may be pierced only where otherwise separate corporate existence has been used to subvert justice or cause result that is contrary to some other clearly overriding public policy, and subsidiary must become mere instrumentality of parent before its separate corporate existence will be disregarded.
Document Preview: Corporations. Michigan declines to adopt apparent manufacturer doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: McCabe v. Henpil, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: In essence, alter ego theory merely allows plaintiff to hold shareholder or parent corporation liable under Texas law for actions of subsidiary corporation, but this mechanism establishes liability in only one direction, and, while parent corporation can be held liable for acts of subsidiary corporation under alter ego theory, subsidiary corporation is not liable for acts of parent or shareholder merely on basis of alter ego.
Document Preview: Employee brought state court action against employer and employer's subsidiary, alleging tort claims related to employee's work-related accident. Suit was removed to federal court.  On plaintiff's motion to remand, the District Court, Schell, Chief Judge, held that: (1) negligence and strict liability claims were not subject to Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) preemption; (2) intentional infliction of emotional distress and mental anguish claim related to employer's occupational injury and disease benefits plan; (3) defendants did not establish that benefit plan fell outside of workers' compensation exception to ERISA preemption; but (4) subsidiary was fraudulently joined to destroy diversity, and diversity jurisdiction existed. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Dean Operations, Inc. v. One Seventy Associates
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Under circumstances where corporate entity is disregarded, parent corporation may be held liable for acts of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Parent corporation, which had purchased loan to partnership in which its subsidiary was managing partner, brought action to foreclose on loan. The Wyandotte District Court, Philip L. Sieve, J., granted partial summary judgment for other partner, finding that managing partner was alter ego of its parent.  The Court of Appeals granted parent's application for interlocutory appeal, and the Supreme Court granted parent's motion to transfer.  The Supreme Court, Lockett, J., held that parent was alter ego of subsidiary. Affirmed.

Title: Natl. City Bank v. The Plechaty Cos.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Parent corporation is not liable for debts of subsidiaries, absent proof that parent exercised complete dominion and control over subsidiary and such control was used to commit fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Loan Guaranties. For purposes of determining deficiency sale price of collateral was $275,000, not $1.6 million, where $1.6 million note given in sale was payable only if $275,000 were not paid.

Title: Elgin Sweeper Co. v. Melson Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Initially, some proof of fraud, whether actual or intended, must be offered before court can pierce the corporate veil, and the next step in determining appropriateness of piercing corporate veil is to analyze the following factors: ownership of stock, commonality of directors and officers, financial relationships between entities, and independence of subsidiary's directors or executives.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Evaluation of corporate control claims cannot disregard fact that, no different from other stockholders, parent corporation is expected-indeed, required-to exert some control over its subsidiary.
Document Preview: Products liability action was brought against sole shareholder of major supplier of breast implants.  Shareholder, which had never itself manufactured or distributed breast implants, moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pointer, Chief Judge, held that genuine issues of material fact precluded summary judgment on corporate control and direct liability claims. Motion denied.

Title: In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Totality of circumstances must be evaluated in determining whether subsidiary may be found to be alter ego or mere instrumentality of parent corporation, and whether corporate veil may thus be pierced.
Document Preview: Products liability action was brought against sole shareholder of major supplier of breast implants.  Shareholder, which had never itself manufactured or distributed breast implants, moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pointer, Chief Judge, held that genuine issues of material fact precluded summary judgment on corporate control and direct liability claims. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether subsidiary may be found to be alter ego or mere instrumentality of parent corporation, court considers, inter alia, whether: parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; parent and subsidiary have common business departments; parent and subsidiary file consulted financial statements and tax returns; parent finances subsidiary; parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital; parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; subsidiary receives no business except that given to it by parent; parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; daily operations of two corporations are not kept separate; subsidiary does not observe basic corporate formalities, such as keeping separate books and records and holding shareholder and board meetings.
Document Preview: Products liability action was brought against sole shareholder of major supplier of breast implants.  Shareholder, which had never itself manufactured or distributed breast implants, moved for summary judgment. Title: Watkins v. Black & Decker (U.S.), Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Galveston Division.
Headnote: Generally, parent corporation has separate legal existence from its subsidiaries under Texas law, and parent and subsidiary corporations should be treated separately unless circumstances suggest that distinction between corporate entities should be disregarded. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, arts. 5.06, subd. A(3), 5.10, subd. B(2).
Document Preview: Following accidental gun discharge, product liability action based on strict liability in negligence was brought against numerous corporations that were related as result of mergers.  Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Kent, J., held that: (1) sale of corporate division that manufactured guns did not absolve selling corporation from liability, and (2) genuine issue existed as to whether successor corporation could be held accountable for tort liability incurred by its fully owned subsidiary. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Watkins v. Black & Decker (U.S.), Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Galveston Division.
Headnote: Alter ego exists, and corporate shell may be pierced under Texas law, where corporation is operated and organized as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation; making alter ego determination, court may look at total dealings of corporation, such as amount of financial interest, ownership, and control parent has over subsidiary.

Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Kent, J., held that: (1) sale of corporate division that manufactured guns did not absolve selling corporation from liability, and (2) genuine issue existed as to whether successor corporation could be held accountable for tort liability incurred by its fully owned subsidiary. Motion denied.

Title: Watkins v. Black & Decker (U.S.), Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Galveston Division.
Headnote: When management or operations of subsidiary are controlled by parent corporation, such constitutes evidence of alter ego relationship under Texas law.

Title: In re TMJ Implants Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota, Third Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, corporation's separate identity will only be disregarded where subsidiary has become mere instrumentality of its parent or parents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Doney v. TRW, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Sixth District, California.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be deemed alter ego of its subsidiary corporation only if there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of subsidiary and parent no longer exist, and it appears that, if acts are treated as those of subsidiary alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: Wrongful Death. Parent corporation was not liable for murders of subsidiary's employees, where subsidiary had secured payment of workers' compensation benefits.

Title: American Eagle Ins. Co. v. United Technologies Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, there is generally no vicarious liability if parent and subsidiary corporations are entirely separate entities and there is no showing of fraud.
Document Preview: Owner of airplane brought action for negligence and violation of Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act (DTPA) against manufacturer of airplane engine and its parent corporation. Owner appealed, and the Court of Appeals, Benavides, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Texas law, cause of action for negligence is not recognized where only loss is economic; (2) damage to hull of aircraft did not constitute damage to other property and did not allow recovery in strict liability action; (3) damage to third party's property for which owner of plane subsequently became liable was not damage to other property of owner and did not create liability on part of manufacturer; (4) claim for breach of implied warranty under DTPA was not time barred; (5) fact issue...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Murray v. Miner
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Delaware courts will allow shareholder of parent corporation to maintain double derivative action even if he does not own any shares of the subsidiary, effectively breaching the corporate veil that separates the two.
Document Preview: Following bankruptcy filings by their employer and its successor, former employees brought suit against successor's controlling shareholders, seeking to hold them liable, under single employer doctrine, for contractual obligations of their employer and its successor.  On plaintiffs' motion to amend complaint to add claims of piercing the corporate veil, and defendants' motion to dismiss complaint for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted, the District Court, Robert P. Patterson, Jr., J., held that: (1) there was no basis for holding controlling shareholders liable under single employer doctrine, and (2) alter ego claim belonged to bankruptcy trustee. Plaintiffs' motion denied and defendants' motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Calvert v. Huckins
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: In order to find one corporation is alter ego of another, parent must control subsidiary to such degree as to render the latter the mere instrumentality of the former, and there must be enough evidence to support finding that failure to look past the corporate entity would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: In action to quiet title to roadway, parent and grandparent corporations of defendant landowner moved to dismiss claims against them for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The District Court, Shubb, J., held that: (1) general jurisdiction was lacking, and (2) parent's and grandparent's control over subsidiary was insufficient to invoke alter ego jurisdiction. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cooper v. Lakewood Engineering and Mfg. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, application of "instrumentality doctrine" to parent-subsidiary relationship merely refines one requirement for piercing corporate veil-analyzing reality of how corporation functioned and defendant's relation to that operation-by asserting that parent and its subsidiary may be considered one entity if they are sufficiently intertwined.
Document Preview: Wrongful death action was brought against, among others, corporate successor of manufacturer of electric motor used in product that allegedly caused fire.  The United States District Court for the District of Minnesota, Richard H. Kyle, J., 874 F.Supp. 947, granted successor's motion for summary judgment, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Morris Sheppard Arnold, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) there was no express assumption of liability under Minnesota law and terms of assumption of liabilities agreement; (2) successor did not assume liability by implication; and (3) successor could not be held liable under instrumentality doctrine as applied in parent-subsidiary setting. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mutual Holding Co. v. Limbach
Court: Supreme Court of Ohio.
Headnote: Generally, parent and subsidiary are separate and distinct legal entities; this is so even if parent owns all outstanding shares of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Franchise Tax. Wholly owned subsidiary was not asset of insurance company to which other asset exemption from franchise tax could apply.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Goessel v. Club Med Sales, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In absence of clear indication of dominion and control, parent and subsidiary are treated separately and independently for purposes of assigning legal responsibility.
Document Preview: Liability. Local corporations were not liable for injuries sustained in Mexico.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division..
Headnote: Factors court considers in determining whether subsidiary is alter ego of corporate parent, warranting veil piercing, include common stock ownership, directors, and business departments, existence of consolidated financial statements and tax returns, subsidiary's capitalization, whether parent finances subsidiary, parent's use of subsidiary's property, and observation of corporate formalities.
Document Preview: VEIL PIERCING. veil piecing was not warranted absent showing that corporate parent committed misconduct with regard to subsidiary's creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division..
Headnote: In addition to examining issue of control generally, when deciding whether to pierce veil between corporate parent and subsidiary, court must evaluate domination in relation to transaction attacked.
Document Preview: VEIL PIERCING. veil piecing was not warranted absent showing that corporate parent committed misconduct with regard to subsidiary's creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division..
Headnote: When determining whether corporate parent dominates subsidiary to extent warranting veil piercing, court should consider cumulative effect which each aspect of control had in determining overall domination and control exercised by parent.
Document Preview: VEIL PIERCING. veil piecing was not warranted absent showing that corporate parent committed misconduct with regard to subsidiary's creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Jemez Agency, Inc. v. CIGNA Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Court may properly invoke jurisdiction over parent corporation predicated upon acts of its subsidiary, if parent's control of subsidiary goes beyond that normally exercised by majority shareholder, and is so complete as to render subsidiary an instrumentality of the parent, or subsidiary is mere "alter ego" of parent.
Document Preview: Insurance agencies brought suit against insurance companies and their parent companies, arising out of termination of marketing program.  On motion of ultimate parent of the subsidiaries to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, the District Court, Burciaga, Chief Judge, held that subsidiary companies could not be the basis for asserting in personam jurisdiction over parent. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Jemez Agency, Inc. v. CIGNA Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: If subsidiary does an act at direction of parent, or in course of parent's business, court may characterize subsidiary as agent of parent and thereby hold parent answerable as principal. Restatement (Second) of Conflicts of Law § 562 comment.
Document Preview: Insurance agencies brought suit against insurance companies and their parent companies, arising out of termination of marketing program.  On motion of ultimate parent of the subsidiaries to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, the District Court, Burciaga, Chief Judge, held that subsidiary companies could not be the basis for asserting in personam jurisdiction over parent. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Jemez Agency, Inc. v. CIGNA Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Mere control by parent corporation is not enough to warrant piercing corporate veil under New Mexico law; some form of moral culpability attributable to parent, such as use of subsidiary to perpetrate fraud, is required.
Document Preview: Insurance agencies brought suit against insurance companies and their parent companies, arising out of termination of marketing program.  On motion of ultimate parent of the subsidiaries to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, the District Court, Burciaga, Chief Judge, held that subsidiary companies could not be the basis for asserting in personam jurisdiction over parent. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fletcher v. Atex, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, subsidiary possessed sufficient indicia of a separate corporate existence such that corporate veil would not be pierced; subsidiary's participation in parent's cash management system was consistent with sound business practice and did not show undue domination or control, it was appropriate for parent to approve major policies involving subsidiary and for employees of parent and subsidiary to meet periodically to discuss business matters, and three misstatements in promotional literature as to relationship between corporations were too few to infer that they reflected corporations' true state of mind.
Document Preview: Keyboard users sued parent and subsidiary corporations alleging that repetitive stress injuries were caused by keyboards manufactured by subsidiary.  On parent's motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Lasker, J., held that: (1) subsidiary possessed sufficient indicia of a separate corporate existence such that corporate veil would not be pierced; (2) apparent manufacturer doctrine applied only to seller of chattel or party otherwise involved in chain of distribution of product; (3) parent was not liable under concerted action theory; and (4) parent was not liable under agency theory. Motions granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fletcher v. Atex, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, factors to be analyzed in determining whether corporations acted as single entity, for purposes of determining whether corporate veil should be pierced, include whether: subsidiary was adequately capitalized for corporate undertaking, subsidiary was solvent, dividends were paid, corporate records were kept, officers and directors functioned properly, other corporate formalities were observed, dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds, and, in general, corporation simply functioned as facade for dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: Keyboard users sued parent and subsidiary corporations alleging that repetitive stress injuries were caused by keyboards manufactured by subsidiary.  On parent's motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Lasker, J., held that: (1) subsidiary possessed sufficient indicia of a separate corporate existence such that corporate veil would not be pierced; (2) apparent manufacturer doctrine applied only to seller of chattel or party otherwise involved in chain of distribution of product; (3) parent was not liable under concerted action theory; and (4) parent was not liable under agency theory. Motions granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Winkler v. V.G. Reed & Sons, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Just as equity permits piercing of corporate veil to reach assets of individual, it also permits piercing of subsidiary's corporate veil to reach assets of parent to protect innocent third parties from fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Corporations. There was no basis to pierce corporate veil and hold sole shareholder liable for employment contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Winkler v. V.G. Reed & Sons, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Courts are extremely reluctant to disregard corporate entity and mere fact of subsidiary-patient relationship is not, without more, sufficient reason to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Corporations. There was no basis to pierce corporate veil and hold sole shareholder liable for employment contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Campo v. 1st Nationwide Bank
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors considered by courts under New York law, in determining whether parent controls subsidiary corporation for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, stated.
Document Preview: Residential subdivision developer brought action against entities that had agreed to finance purchase of property and to fund construction projects and their parent bank, alleging breach of contract, breach of fiduciary duty, and tortious interference with business and contract relationships.  Defendants moved to dismiss complaint, and developer moved to amend complaint.  The District Court, Bartels, J., held that: (1) developer stated action for breach of contract under New York law against entities; (2) developer stated cause of action for breach of contract against bank under alter ego theory; and (3) developer alleged requisite elements of joint venture under New York law so as to state cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty. Motion to dismiss denied, motion to amend complaint granted in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Horizon Resources Bethany Ltd. v. Cutco Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1, Department D.
Headnote: Parent corporation is responsible for actions of its subsidiary when subsidiary has become mere instrumentality, so overshadowed by parent that separate corporate identity should be disregarded to prevent perpetration of fraud.
Document Preview: Lessor filed suit against corporate parent of lessee for enforcement of lease guaranty agreement.  The Superior Court of Maricopa County, No. CV 9032000, Alan S. Kamin, J., granted summary judgment for corporation, and lessor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Gerber, J., held that: (1) corporation did not bind itself on lease by participating in negotiations on behalf of subsidiary; (2) evidence did not support lessor's claim that subsidiary was mere instrumentality of corporation; but (3) fact issue existed as to whether corporation consented to alteration of lease to allow extensions or consented to exercise of option to renew provided in original lease such that it was estopped from arguing that guaranty did not apply to extended term. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Flynn v. Allis Chalmers Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Before court will pierce corporate veil of subsidiary corporation, it must be shown that one corporation so controls affairs of another that other is mere instrumentality or dummy of another and that, under circumstances, observance of fiction of separate corporate existence will sanction fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Corporations. Refiling complaint against parent corporation after dismissal of complaint against subsidiary not barred by refiling rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Pay Tel Systems, Inc. v. Seiscor Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Mentioning of parent during negotiations with others, sending of communications to and from the parent, references to indirect subsidiary as part of the parent company's family, and similar events are insufficient to make the parent responsible for the indirect subsidiary's contracts; statements which are supported by the appearance of authority to speak for the parent and which specifically purport to commit the parent would be sufficient to do so.
Document Preview: Buyers brought action against sellers to recover profits lost as a result of defective goods.  On pretrial motions, the District Court, Vincent L. Broderick, J., held that: (1) one defendant and one plaintiff were both citizens of Massachusetts; (2) when complete assignment has been made, assignee is the real party in interest and a necessary party; (3) plaintiffs could not recover open-ended damages for lost profits due to the fact that success that they had hoped for when the relevant contracts were entered into did not materialize due to defective goods supplied to them; and (4) warranty purporting to disclaim any unspecified warranty was invalid with respect to consumers insofar as it related to implied warranties of merchantability. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Carey v. Fiberfloat Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Fact that corporation appeared to have exerted considerable control over activities of subsidiary, along with several other factors, warranted piercing veil separating corporation from subsidiary for personal jurisdiction purposes; corporation purchased subsidiary primarily to acquire subsidiary's trade name, subsidiary did not maintain separate payroll, and corporation apparently exercised control over subsidiary's major hiring decisions. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: Delaware boat owner injured in Delaware by electrical discharge allegedly caused by battery charger brought action against New York corporation whose subsidiary allegedly manufactured charger.  On corporation's motion to dismiss, the District Court, Frank A. Kaufman, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) fact that corporation appeared to have exerted considerable control over activities of subsidiary, along with several other factors, warranted piercing veil separating corporation from subsidiary for personal jurisdiction purposes, but (2) court lacked personal jurisdiction over parent corporation. Motion granted.

Title: Sterling v. Interlake Industries Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, to disregard corporate form, that is, to pierce corporate veil, and hold parent company liable for acts of its subsidiary, parent company must essentially have exercised such control over day-to-day operations of subsidiary that subsidiary has become mere instrumentality of parent.

Title: Sterling v. Interlake Industries Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, disregard of corporate form is evidenced by consideration of absence of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, whether funds are transferred to parent or for parent's use, overlap in ownership, common office space, amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated company, whether the corporations deal with each other at arms length, whether allegedly dominated corporation is treated as independent profit center, payment of debts by parent for benefit of subsidiary, and whether subsidiary uses property of parent as if it were its own.
Document Preview: Employee who was injured when storage rack collapsed brought products liability action against purported manufacturer of rack in state court, and action was removed to federal court.  On purported manufacturer's motion for summary judgment, and employee's alternative motion to amend complaint, the District Court, Spatt, J., held that: (1) purported manufacturer was not equitably estopped from asserting that summary judgment should be granted for it on basis that it was not manufacturer of rack; (2) employee failed to meet threshold requirements of rule providing for continuance when party opposing summary judgment could not by affidavit present facts to justify its position; (3) purported manufacturer did not act with flagrant bad faith, so as to justify dismissal of its motion for summary judgment as discovery sanction; (4) corporate formalities between purported manufacturer and successor of actual manufacturer of rack would not be disregarded,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bell Atlantic Business Systems Services v. Hitachi Data Systems Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Fact that parent and subsidiaries were legally incapable of conspiring in violation of federal antitrust laws did not require finding under California law that parent was alter ego of its subsidiaries. Sherman Act, § 1, as amended, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1.
Document Preview: Independent service organization (ISO) servicing high technology computer equipment sued foreign manufacturer of direct access storage devices, company to whom manufacturer exported devices, and ISO's competitor in device service market, alleging conspiracy to restrain trade in violation of Sherman Antitrust Act and state law alter ego claim.  On defendants' motions for dismissal and for judgment on pleadings, as converted to motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Ware, J., held that: (1) importer, as wholly owned subsidiary, could not conspire with manufacturer; (2) manufacturer could not conspire with competitor, over which it had legal control; (3) importer and competitor, as sister subsidiaries, could not conspire with each other; but (4) fact issue as to whether competitor and importer were mere instrumentalities of manufacturer precluded summary judgment on alter ego claim. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bell Atlantic Business Systems Services v. Hitachi Data Systems Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Courts will pierce corporate veil in situations where evidence exists that subsidiary is "mere instrumentality" of parent, or, in other words, parent creates subsidiary to shield it from liability rather than for reasons of business efficiency.
Document Preview: Independent service organization (ISO) servicing high technology computer equipment sued foreign manufacturer of direct access storage devices, company to whom manufacturer exported devices, and ISO's competitor in device service market, alleging conspiracy to restrain trade in violation of Sherman Antitrust Act and state law alter ego claim.  On defendants' motions for dismissal and for judgment on pleadings, as converted to motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Ware, J., held that: (1) importer, as wholly owned subsidiary, could not conspire with manufacturer; (2) manufacturer could not conspire with competitor, over which it had legal control; (3) importer and competitor, as sister subsidiaries, could not conspire with each other; but (4) fact issue as to whether competitor and importer were mere instrumentalities of manufacturer precluded summary judgment on alter ego claim. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Bell Atlantic Business Systems Services v. Hitachi Data Systems Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, necessary elements of alter ego claim are unity of interest and ownership such that separate personalities of two corporations no longer exist, and that inequitable result will occur if corporate veil is not pierced and challenged conduct is treated as that of subsidiary alone.
Document Preview: Independent service organization (ISO) servicing high technology computer equipment sued foreign manufacturer of direct access storage devices, company to whom manufacturer exported devices, and ISO's competitor in device service market, alleging conspiracy to restrain trade in violation of Sherman Antitrust Act and state law alter ego claim.  On defendants' motions for dismissal and for judgment on pleadings, as converted to motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Ware, J., held that: (1) importer, as wholly owned subsidiary, could not conspire with manufacturer; (2) manufacturer could not conspire with competitor, over which it had legal control; (3) importer and competitor, as sister subsidiaries, could not conspire with each other; but (4) fact issue as to whether competitor and importer were mere instrumentalities of manufacturer precluded summary judgment on alter ego claim. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Church of Scientology Intern. v. Eli Lilly & Co.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: As separate corporate entities, advertising agency and public relations firm, who shared single parent corporation, had to be held fully and strictly accountable for their own actions under District of Columbia law; in view of their fierce independent nature and fact they were organized and operated as separate corporate entities, to treat them as one would have undermined concept of corporate structure acting as "fire wall."
Document Preview: Church brought action against public relations firm which had represented it, firm's parent corporation and its chief executive, advertising agency owned by parent, and drug manufacturer represented by agency, alleging breach of contract and of fiduciary duties against firm, inducement of breach of contract against parent, agency, executive, and manufacturer, and intentional interference with business relations against parent, agency, executive, manufacturer and firm.  On defendants' motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Sporkin, J., held that: (1) genuine issues of material fact precluded summary judgment for firm on church's claims for breach of contract and fiduciary duty; (2) firm could not be found to have intentionally interfered with its own business relations with church; (3) genuine issues of material fact, including whether conduct of manufacturer went beyond mere refusal to deal with parent if parent continued to represent church,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bright v. Roadway Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, "piercing of corporate veil" is not favored and this primary exception to rule that parent company is not liable for acts of its subsidiary is "stringently applied."
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against former employer and former employer's parent corporation alleging race discrimination in violation of Title VII, retaliatory discharge, and intentional infliction of emotional distress.  The District Court, Alesia, J., held that: (1) parent corporation did not have notice that it was subject to discrimination action; (2) court had supplemental jurisdiction over state-law claims against parent corporation; and (3) allegations were insufficient to state claim for veil piercing against parent corporation. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Keene Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under doctrine of piercing corporate veil, also known as alter ego liability, creditor can sue parent or shareholder of his debtor if he can establish that parent or shareholder controls or dominates the debtor, the control or domination has been used to commit or perpetuate fraud or wrong, and creditor has suffered injury or loss.
Document Preview: AUTOMATIC STAY. automatic stay precluded asbestos creditors from pursuing claims against debtor's officers who allegedly restructured debtor and transferred assets to defraud creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Stratagem Development Corp. v. Heron Intern. N.V.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether New York court may exercise personal jurisdiction over parent of wholly owned subsidiary present in New York, court considers: common ownership; financial dependency; interference with subsidiary's selection of personnel; disregard for corporate formalities; and control over subsidiary's marketing and operational policies. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
