Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Rehabilitation of Centaur Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Illinois.
Headnote: A corporation's separate and distinct entity will be disregarded, and corporate veil pierced, where subsidiary is so organized and controlled, and its affairs so conducted by a parent, that observance of fiction of separate identities would sanction a fraud or promote injustice under the circumstances.
Document Preview: Insolvent Company. Rehabilitator of insolvent reinsurer did not have standing to assert alter ego action against reinsurer's parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Farley, Inc. v. Chiappetta
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Corporation is not normally liable for another corporation's financial obligations, even if corporations are parent and wholly owned subsidiary with mutual dealings.
Document Preview: CORPORATIONS. vice president of corporation owned by Chapter 11 debtor's principal was entitled to seek stock from debtor based on employment agreement between vice president and corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Buckhead America Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Doctrine of independent legal significance provides that corporate action taken pursuant to one section of Delaware General Corporation Law (DGCL) is legally independent, and its validity is not dependent upon, nor to be tested by requirements of other unrelated DGCL sections under which same final result might be attained by different means.
Document Preview: LEVERAGED BUYOUTS. Chapter 11 debtor's creditors committee stated claims stemming from leveraged buy out of debtors' stock.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Jiffy Lube Intern., Inc. v. Jiffy Lube of Pennsylvania, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, without showing of control, subsidiaries, even if wholly owned, are presumed separate and distinct entities from their parent corporations for purposes of piercing the corporate veil under alter-ego theory of liability.
Document Preview: Automobile lubricating service center franchisor brought action against franchisee, alleging trademark infringement and unfair competition. Franchisee counterclaimed and brought third-party action against second franchisee and motor oil company, alleging, inter alia, fraudulent inducement to enter into franchisor-franchisee relationship, intentional interference with contractual relationship, conspiracy, and racketeering.  Plaintiffs and third-party defendants moved for summary judgment on counterclaim and third-party complaint.  The District Court, Van Antwerpen, J., held that: (1) under Maryland law, franchisee's release of franchisor in asset transfer agreement covered all of franchisee's claims against franchisor and second franchisee; (2) under Pennsylvania law, franchisee failed to show that company was liable for actions of franchisor on alter-ego theory on franchisee's claims for breach of contract, fraud, misrepresentation, and breach of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Global Credit Services, Inc. v. AMISUB (Saint Joseph Hosp.), Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Doctrine of separate corporate existence does not break down merely because corporation is subsidiary, even if wholly owned by the parent.
Document Preview: Company which contracted with hospital for collection of its overdue patient accounts brought action against individual and corporate defendants for breach of contract and for interference with company's business relationship with hospital.  The District Court, Douglas County, Keith Howard, J., granted summary judgment for defendants, and company appealed.  The Supreme Court, Caporale, J., held that company failed to make prima facie case that corporate defendants engaged in joint operation of the hospital. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Global Credit Services, Inc. v. AMISUB (Saint Joseph Hosp.), Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil between parent and subsidiary, plaintiff must show more than mere sharing of services between the two corporations.
Document Preview: Company which contracted with hospital for collection of its overdue patient accounts brought action against individual and corporate defendants for breach of contract and for interference with company's business relationship with hospital.  The District Court, Douglas County, Keith Howard, J., granted summary judgment for defendants, and company appealed.  The Supreme Court, Caporale, J., held that company failed to make prima facie case that corporate defendants engaged in joint operation of the hospital. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Global Credit Services, Inc. v. AMISUB (Saint Joseph Hosp.), Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: For plaintiff to pierce corporate veil between parent and subsidiary, it must show that parent totally dominated subsidiary to such extent that subsidiary had no separate corporate existence and functioned solely to achieve purposes of the parent.
Document Preview: Company which contracted with hospital for collection of its overdue patient accounts brought action against individual and corporate defendants for breach of contract and for interference with company's business relationship with hospital.  The District Court, Douglas County, Keith Howard, J., granted summary judgment for defendants, and company appealed.  The Supreme Court, Caporale, J., held that company failed to make prima facie case that corporate defendants engaged in joint operation of the hospital. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Global Credit Services, Inc. v. AMISUB (Saint Joseph Hosp.), Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Authorization to issue capital stock in subsidiary's charter should not be confused with formal minimum paid-in capital requirements and does not reflect ability of subsidiary to conduct its business for purposes of determining whether corporate veil between parent and subsidiary should be pierced.
Document Preview: Company which contracted with hospital for collection of its overdue patient accounts brought action against individual and corporate defendants for breach of contract and for interference with company's business relationship with hospital.  The District Court, Douglas County, Keith Howard, J., granted summary judgment for defendants, and company appealed. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation (MDL 926)
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Fact that shareholder corporations viewed their formation of corporation as collaborative undertaking, anticipating synergistic benefits from their separate corporations through new corporation and protecting their individual interests in stock structure and that they decided to use corporate form to protect shareholders against potential liabilities from undertaking, did not give rise to inference of improper purpose or intent so as to warrant piercing of corporate veil on theory of inappropriate control and domination by shareholder corporations.
Document Preview: In products liability action involving silicone breast implants, defendant corporations filed motion for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pointer, Chief Judge, held that: (1) plaintiffs were not entitled to pierce corporate veil of implant manufacturer to reach its two parent corporations, and (2) plaintiffs failed to show that parent corporations were liable under theories of fraud, conspiracy, concert of action, aiding and abetting or collective liability due to their own conduct relating to testing, production and distribution of implants. Motions granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Daniels v. Kerr McGee Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Four tests used to determine whether parent corporation should be held liable for acts of subsidiary are "integrated enterprise" test, "agency" theory, alter ego test, and instrumentality test.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against parent corporation based on subsidiary corporation's alleged wrongful conduct in discharging employee.  The District Court, Brimmer, J., held that parent corporation was not liable for alleged wrongful discharge of employee by subsidiary under either alter ego test or integrated enterprise test for imposing liability on parent corporation for acts of subsidiary. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Daniels v. Kerr McGee Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Under integrated enterprise standard for imposing liability on parent corporation for actions of subsidiary corporation, prong of test which requires centralization of control of labor relations is met only if it is shown that parent controlled day-to-day employment decisions of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against parent corporation based on subsidiary corporation's alleged wrongful conduct in discharging employee.  The District Court, Brimmer, J., held that parent corporation was not liable for alleged wrongful discharge of employee by subsidiary under either alter ego test or integrated enterprise test for imposing liability on parent corporation for acts of subsidiary. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Toledo v. Ayerst-Wyeth Pharmaceutical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil of parent corporation, plaintiff must show that parent and subsidiary ignored independence of their separate operations, that some fraudulent intent exists on parent's part, and that substantial injustice would be visited on proponents of veil piercing should court validate corporate shield.
Document Preview: Employee brought action alleging claims of retaliatory discharge under ERISA as well as various state claims.  On defendants' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Gierbolini, Chief Judge, held that: (1) employer's medical benefits and disability plans constituted welfare benefit plan under ERISA and court had subject matter jurisdiction; (2) question of fact existed as to employer's motivation in discharging employee; (3) court would not pierce corporate veil of corporation of which employer was subdivision; and (4) court would assert pendent jurisdiction over state law claims. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Devlin v. WSI Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, parent corporation and its subsidiary are separate corporate entities.

Title: Devlin v. WSI Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be liable for acts of its subsidiary if parent dominates subsidiary in pervasive manner that necessitates treating dominated corporation as agent of principal.
