Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mitchell v. K.C. Stadium Concessions, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Ordinarily, parent corporation is not liable for acts of its subsidiary corporation; exception to this rule occurs in situation where plaintiff pierces corporate veil.
Document Preview: Fire Policy. Fact that lessee and lessor declined to rebuild following fire did not relieve insurer of its obligation to pay replacement costs to lessor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mitchell v. K.C. Stadium Concessions, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Mere fact of complete ownership and control of subsidiary by parent corporation does not, of itself, justify piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: Fire Policy. Fact that lessee and lessor declined to rebuild following fire did not relieve insurer of its obligation to pay replacement costs to lessor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mitchell v. K.C. Stadium Concessions, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Test to determine when to pierce corporate veil and thereby hold parent liable for subsidiary's wrongful acts has two parts: first, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or by another corporation; and second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Fire Policy. Fact that lessee and lessor declined to rebuild following fire did not relieve insurer of its obligation to pay replacement costs to lessor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Paglin v. Saztec Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Circumstances to consider under Missouri law in determining whether parent corporation "controls" subsidiary, for purposes of alter ego liability, are that parent owns all or most of subsidiary's capital stock; parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; parent finances subsidiary; parent subscribes to all of subsidiary's capital stock or otherwise causes its incorporation; subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; parent pays salaries and other expenses or losses of subsidiary; subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; in papers of parent or statements of its officers, subsidiary is described as department, division of parent, or its business or financial responsibility is referred to as parent's own; parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; subsidiary's directors or executives do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take their orders from parent and the latter's interest; and formal legal requirements of subsidiary are not observed.
Document Preview: Acquired corporation and its former president brought action against acquiring corporation, its parent corporation which was also majority shareholder in acquiring corporation, and officers and directors alleging breach of asset purchase agreement and employment agreement, tortious interference with contract, and fraud.  Defendants moved for summary judgment and plaintiffs moved to amend complaint.  The District Court, Stevens, Chief Judge, held that: (1) rule governing voluntary dismissal of an action did not permit plaintiffs to voluntarily dismiss one of several claims; (2) plaintiffs were entitled to amend complaint to dismiss racial discrimination claims; (3) issues of material fact existed as to extent of parent corporation's control over its subsidiary and whether parent exercised control over subsidiary for unlawful purpose, precluding summary judgment on claim to impose alter ego liability; (4) genuine issues of material fact...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Tutu Wells Contamination Litigation
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Thomas and St. John.
Headnote: To warrant disregard of corporate separateness under Virgin Islands law, plaintiff must show more than that parent owns majority or all of stock of subsidiary and more than that officers, directors and managers are identical; there must be showing that parent intended to defraud or to escape liability, or that parent exercised such dominion over finances, policies, and practices that controlled corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a conduit for principal.
Document Preview: Owners and lessees of contaminated water wells brought suit under the Comprehensive Environment Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) and under state law, and various third-party complaints and counterclaims were asserted.  On defense motions for summary judgment and to dismiss, the District Court, Brotman, J., sitting by designation, held that: (1) two-year statute of limitations governed property tort claims; (2) owners and lessees failed to present sufficient facts to warrant disregard of principal of corporate separateness so as to hold parent company liable, but they would be allowed additional time to engage in necessary discovery to supplement their proceedings; (3) owners stated cause of action based on strict liability, under Virgin Islands law; (4) Virgin Islands Solid and Hazardous Waste Management Act (VISHWMA) does not create private cause of action for indemnification and damages; and (5) CERCLA supersedes federal...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Application of CN Carriers, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Separate corporate existence of parent and subsidiary or affiliated corporations will not be recognized when subsidiary is so organized and controlled that its business is conducted in such manner as to make it merely agency, instrumentality, adjunct, or alter ego of another corporation.
Document Preview: Protestors appealed from order of Public Service Commission (PSC) which affirmed PSC's previous order granting application of wholly owned subsidiary of transportation cooperative to transfer common carrier operating rights of third party to wholly owned subsidiary.  The Court of Appeals, Wright, J., held that PSC acted arbitrarily and capriciously in granting application to transfer common carrier authority to wholly owned subsidiary of transportation cooperative that could not hold authority directly where wholly owned subsidiary was not truly separate and distinct from parent. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Frank v. U.S. West, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Colorado law to determine whether parent corporation is liable for acts of its subsidiary, inquiry is whether there is such a close relationship between the two companies that one is, in essence, an instrumentality of the other; relevant factors included, inter alia, parent owns all subsidiary's capital stock, parent finances subsidiary, and parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers.
Document Preview: Employees of telephone company's subsidiaries brought action against parent telephone corporation, alleging employment discrimination based on age and national origin.  The United States District Court for the District of Colorado, Edward W. Nottingham, J., found that parent corporation was not employees' employer.  Employees appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Baldock, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) parent corporation was not liable for subsidiaries' actions under federal law or Colorado law, and (2) lower court properly refused to add subsidiary as defendant. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Carte Blanche (Singapore) Pte., Ltd. v. Diners Club Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Generally, parent corporation and its subsidiary are regarded as legally distinct entities, and contract under corporate name of one is not treated as that of both.
Document Preview: Franchisee brought suit to compel parent corporation of franchisor to satisfy judgment obtained against franchisor for breach of franchise agreement, pursuant to arbitration.  Piercing the corporate veil was denied by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Whitman Knapp, J., 802 F.Supp. 1006, and franchisee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, George C. Pratt, Circuit Judge, held that piercing of corporate veil was appropriate as franchisor had ceased to function as separate entity and its operations and assets had been absorbed into parent, and act constituting breach of franchise agreement was taken in the name of the parent. Reversed and remanded with direction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Carte Blanche (Singapore) Pte., Ltd. v. Diners Club Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: While New York is reluctant to pierce corporate veils, exceptions are made in two broad situations: to prevent fraud or other wrong, or where parent dominates and controls subsidiary.
Document Preview: Franchisee brought suit to compel parent corporation of franchisor to satisfy judgment obtained against franchisor for breach of franchise agreement, pursuant to arbitration.  Piercing the corporate veil was denied by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Whitman Knapp, J., 802 F.Supp. 1006, and franchisee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, George C. Pratt, Circuit Judge, held that piercing of corporate veil was appropriate as franchisor had ceased to function as separate entity and its operations and assets had been absorbed into parent, and act constituting breach of franchise agreement was taken in the name of the parent. Reversed and remanded with direction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Carte Blanche (Singapore) Pte., Ltd. v. Diners Club Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Determining whether parent corporation's control and domination requires court to disregard corporate form, under New York law on piercing corporate veil, requires examination of a number of factors involving interactions between parent and subsidiary, including absence of formalities, inadequate capitalization, overlap in ownership, officers and directors, common office space, whether corporations deal at arm's length and are treated as independent profit centers, and payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group.
Document Preview: Franchisee brought suit to compel parent corporation of franchisor to satisfy judgment obtained against franchisor for breach of franchise agreement, pursuant to arbitration.  Piercing the corporate veil was denied by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Whitman Knapp, J., 802 F.Supp. 1006, and franchisee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, George C. Pratt, Circuit Judge, held that piercing of corporate veil was appropriate as franchisor had ceased to function as separate entity and its operations and assets had been absorbed into parent, and act constituting breach of franchise agreement was taken in the name of the parent. Reversed and remanded with direction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gosconcert v. Hillyer
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, action to pierce corporate veil may be brought where parent corporation has exercised such control that subsidiary has become mere instrumentality of parent, such control has been used to commit fraud or other wrong, and fraud or wrong results in unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: STANDING. alter ego claim should have been asserted by corporation's bankruptcy trustee, and not by individual corporate creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mylan Laboratories, Inc. v. Akzo, N.V.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Maryland "agency" test for deciding whether to pierce veil separating parent corporations from subsidiaries for jurisdictional purposes allows court to attribute actions of subsidiary to foreign parent only if parent exerts considerable control over activities of subsidiary; central to exertion of such control is whether significant decisions of subsidiary must be approved by parent, and other relevant factors include whether parent and subsidiary maintain separate books and records and hold separate director's meetings, and the level of interdependence between them.
Document Preview: Suit was brought seeking damages on various theories for alleged conspiracy to facilitate approval of defendants' abbreviated new drug applications for generic drugs while impeding approval of plaintiff's applications.  Motion of foreign corporate defendant to dismiss was granted by the United States District Court for the District of Maryland, at Baltimore, Norman Park Ramsey, Senior District Judge, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ervin, Chief Judge, held that: (1) district court did not have personal jurisdiction over foreign parent corporation solely because parent's third-tier subsidiary corporation conducted business in Maryland, and (2) there was no abuse of discretion in denying further discovery on personal jurisdiction question. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mylan Laboratories, Inc. v. Akzo, N.V.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, if courts are to refrain from exercising jurisdiction over foreign corporate parent on basis of actions of subsidiary, subsidiary must have some independent reason for its existence other than being under the complete domination and control of another legal entity simply for the purpose of doing its act and bidding, while for court to exercise jurisdiction over parent, court must find that parent knew, or should have known that its conduct would have some impact in Maryland.
Document Preview: Suit was brought seeking damages on various theories for alleged conspiracy to facilitate approval of defendants' abbreviated new drug applications for generic drugs while impeding approval of plaintiff's applications.  Motion of foreign corporate defendant to dismiss was granted by the United States District Court for the District of Maryland, at Baltimore, Norman Park Ramsey, Senior District Judge, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ervin, Chief Judge, held that: (1) district court did not have personal jurisdiction over foreign parent corporation solely because parent's third-tier subsidiary corporation conducted business in Maryland, and (2) there was no abuse of discretion in denying further discovery on personal jurisdiction question. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Newtowne, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the separate identities of parent and subsidiary corporation will not be ignored absent proof that subsidiary was formed for purpose of perpetrating fraud and that domination by parent corporation over its subsidiary was exercised in such manner as to defraud complainant.
Document Preview: FRAUDULENT TRANSFERS. court could not ignore debtor's and sister corporation's separate corporate identities for purpose of deciding whether debtor received reasonably equivalent value for alleged fraudulent transfer in satisfaction of sister corporation's debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Ataka America, Inc.
Court: United States Court of International Trade.
Headnote: In context of parent-subsidiary relationships, court will pierce corporate veil and find parent liable for subsidiary's debts if subsidiary is mere instrumentality which is under complete domination of parent and parent manipulates subsidiary in such a way as to cause unjust loss to plaintiff.
Document Preview: United States sought to recover customs duties from importer's successor and from importer's surety.  On motions for judgment on pleadings and for summary judgment, the Court of International Trade, Restani, J., held that: (1) action against successor was timely; (2) fact issues precluded judgment on pleadings for successor; and (3) action against surety was time barred. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Talkington v. Anchor Gasoline Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Northeastern Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, subsidiary corporation has existence separate and distinct from that of owners or its parent corporation, but separate entity may be disregarded upon showing of special circumstances as that corporation is a puppet, sham, or dummy, or that failure to disregard corporation would result in injustice.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit based on alleged oral promise of employer's president to provide deferred compensation in lieu of company's standard retirement plan. The United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, Morton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) under Tennessee law, equitable estoppel exception to statute of frauds applied where employer misrepresented intention to prepare and sign written memorandum and corporation's intention not to rely on statute of frauds; (2) partial performance exception to Tennessee statute of frauds applied; (3) corporate veil of subsidiary which employed plaintiff could be pierced as mere instrumentality of parent corporation; and (4) employee could bring suit for total amount due under promise, even though installments were contemplated. Judgment for employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Talkington v. Anchor Gasoline Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Northeastern Division.
Headnote: Three elements required under Tennessee law for piercing corporate veil on ground that subsidiary is mere instrumentality for parent are: time of transaction, parent exercises complete dominion and control over its subsidiary in finances, policy, and business practice, so that entity has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; control must be used for wrongful, fraud, unjust act in contravention of third-party rights; and control and breach of duty must proximately cause injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit based on alleged oral promise of employer's president to provide deferred compensation in lieu of company's standard retirement plan. The United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, Morton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) under Tennessee law, equitable estoppel exception to statute of frauds applied where employer misrepresented intention to prepare and sign written memorandum and corporation's intention not to rely on statute of frauds; (2) partial performance exception to Tennessee statute of frauds applied; (3) corporate veil of subsidiary which employed plaintiff could be pierced as mere instrumentality of parent corporation; and (4) employee could bring suit for total amount due under promise, even though installments were contemplated. Judgment for employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Talkington v. Anchor Gasoline Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Northeastern Division.
Headnote: Tennessee law does not require that fraud be proven before corporate veil of subsidiary may be pierced on ground that subsidiary is mere instrumentality for parent; recovery may be made for violation of legal duty, dishonest act, or injustice.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit based on alleged oral promise of employer's president to provide deferred compensation in lieu of company's standard retirement plan. The United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, Morton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) under Tennessee law, equitable estoppel exception to statute of frauds applied where employer misrepresented intention to prepare and sign written memorandum and corporation's intention not to rely on statute of frauds; (2) partial performance exception to Tennessee statute of frauds applied; (3) corporate veil of subsidiary which employed plaintiff could be pierced as mere instrumentality of parent corporation; and (4) employee could bring suit for total amount due under promise, even though installments were contemplated. Judgment for employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hess v. L.G. Balfour Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, parent corporation and its subsidiaries are separate and distinct legal entities.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit against employer and its parent corporation alleging breach of contract, failure to pay wages, unlawful deductions from wages, conversion, and constructive discharge.  Parent corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) employee failed to demonstrate control or malice by parent required under Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under instrumentality test; (2) employee failed to show that parent and subsidiary had same identity as required by Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under identity test; and (3) parent did not dominate or interfere with subsidiary as needed under Connecticut law to impose liability on parent based on agency's principles. Granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hess v. L.G. Balfour Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under Connecticut law using "instrumentality test," plaintiff must prove: control by parent of finances, policies and business practices relating to transactions at issue to such extent that subsidiary at the time had no separate mind, will or existence of its own; that parent used its control over subsidiary for purpose of committing fraudulent, wrongful, or otherwise unlawful act; and that control and breach of duty alleged caused plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit against employer and its parent corporation alleging breach of contract, failure to pay wages, unlawful deductions from wages, conversion, and constructive discharge.  Parent corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) employee failed to demonstrate control or malice by parent required under Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under instrumentality test; (2) employee failed to show that parent and subsidiary had same identity as required by Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under identity test; and (3) parent did not dominate or interfere with subsidiary as needed under Connecticut law to impose liability on parent based on agency's principles. Granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hess v. L.G. Balfour Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Parent corporation must have acted with malice or bad faith to pierce corporate veil under Connecticut law using instrumentality test.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit against employer and its parent corporation alleging breach of contract, failure to pay wages, unlawful deductions from wages, conversion, and constructive discharge.  Parent corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) employee failed to demonstrate control or malice by parent required under Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under instrumentality test; (2) employee failed to show that parent and subsidiary had same identity as required by Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under identity test; and (3) parent did not dominate or interfere with subsidiary as needed under Connecticut law to impose liability on parent based on agency's principles. Granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hess v. L.G. Balfour Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Factors for determining whether parent and subsidiary corporation have same identity, as needed to justify piercing of corporate veil under Connecticut law, include whether business transactions, bank accounts, and records are intermingled, corporations are not observing corporate formalities, subsidiary is inadequately financed, and subsidiary is acting solely for interests of parent.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit against employer and its parent corporation alleging breach of contract, failure to pay wages, unlawful deductions from wages, conversion, and constructive discharge.  Parent corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) employee failed to demonstrate control or malice by parent required under Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under instrumentality test; (2) employee failed to show that parent and subsidiary had same identity as required by Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under identity test; and (3) parent did not dominate or interfere with subsidiary as needed under Connecticut law to impose liability on parent based on agency's principles. Granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hess v. L.G. Balfour Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Parent and subsidiary corporations did not have same identity, as needed to pierce corporate veil under Connecticut law, where subsidiary maintained separate business transactions, bank accounts, and records, parent and subsidiary were incorporated in different states and in different decades, each had its own directors and officers and maintained its own records, subsidiary's financing was not obviously inadequate, and subsidiary was not shown to have acted solely for interests of parent.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit against employer and its parent corporation alleging breach of contract, failure to pay wages, unlawful deductions from wages, conversion, and constructive discharge.  Parent corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) employee failed to demonstrate control or malice by parent required under Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under instrumentality test; (2) employee failed to show that parent and subsidiary had same identity as required by Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under identity test; and (3) parent did not dominate or interfere with subsidiary as needed under Connecticut law to impose liability on parent based on agency's principles. Granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Birmingham Asbestos Litigation
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Parent corporation, even one that owns all stock of subsidiary corporation, is not subject to liability for acts of its subsidiary unless parent so controls operation of subsidiary as to make it mere adjunct, instrumentality or alter ego of parent corporation.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs sought to hold parent corporations liable for activities of their asbestos related subsidiaries.  The Court of Appeals, 966 F.2d 1392, certified question to Alabama Supreme Court.  The Supreme Court, Steagall, J., held that duty to control doctrine may not be applied to hold parent corporation liable for acts of its subsidiary. Question answered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Birmingham Asbestos Litigation
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Plaintiff must first pierce corporate veil before parent corporation's liability may be established.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs sought to hold parent corporations liable for activities of their asbestos related subsidiaries.  The Court of Appeals, 966 F.2d 1392, certified question to Alabama Supreme Court.  The Supreme Court, Steagall, J., held that duty to control doctrine may not be applied to hold parent corporation liable for acts of its subsidiary. Question answered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Birmingham Asbestos Litigation
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Duty to control doctrine may not be applied to hold parent corporation liable for acts of its subsidiary.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs sought to hold parent corporations liable for activities of their asbestos related subsidiaries.  The Court of Appeals, 966 F.2d 1392, certified question to Alabama Supreme Court.  The Supreme Court, Steagall, J., held that duty to control doctrine may not be applied to hold parent corporation liable for acts of its subsidiary. Question answered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Ricoh Co., Ltd. v. Honeywell, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, parent and subsidiary corporations are distinct legal entities, and courts are extremely reluctant to pierce veil between the two absent compelling circumstances.
Document Preview: Patent holder brought infringement action against corporation, and corporation moved for transfer of venue.  The District Court, Lechner, J., held that corporation established that transfer to state in which corporation was located was more convenient for witnesses, parties, and trial. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Marquis Products, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Maine.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, person attempting to pierce corporate veil to reach subsidiary must show that owner has used subsidiary as mere agent and conduit for its own aggrandizement, as when it systematically drains subsidiary of worth for its own enrichment, at expense of those who deal with subsidiary.
Document Preview: FRAUDULENT TRANSFERS. Chapter 11 debtor-in-possession subsidiary was entitled to avoid as fraudulent transfer the mortgage given to parent's creditor to secure parent's line of credit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Undercapitalization of corporation is insufficient in itself to form basis for piercing corporate veil of parent corporation, as Florida law imposes no legal duty on parent to assure continuously adequate capitalization of wholly owned subsidiary where subsidiary was already existing corporate entity when acquired by parent, and was not creation of parent.
Document Preview: DISCOVERY. additional discovery on issue of whether corporate veil could be pierced so as to hold parent of corporation liable to asbestos claimants was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bollwerk v. Susquehanna Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Western Division.
Headnote: Under South Dakota law, plaintiff may disregard corporate structure, under alter ego exception, if subsidiary is acting as mere instrumentality of parent corporation.
Document Preview: Former employee of subsidiary brought suit against parent and subsidiaries, alleging that one or more defendants fraudulently concealed medical information from him during time he was employed at uranium processing mill.  On parent's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Battey, J., held that parent could not be found liable for alleged acts of its subsidiaries. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Stephens v. American Home Assur. Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Failure to pierce corporate veil does not preclude finding of agency whereby corporate parent can be held liable on theory that its subsidiary is its agent.
Document Preview: Actions were brought by liquidator of insolvent reinsurer seeking coverage from certain retrocessionaires and premiums from companies which had ceded insurance risks to reinsurer, and defendants in two of the actions impleaded reinsurer's parent corporation and certain officials of Kentucky Department of Insurance.  On various motions for determination of defenses, for summary judgment, to vacate or to reconsider, and to dismiss, the District Court, Martin, J., held that: (1) New York law applied to determining validity of retrocession agreements though reinsurer was Kentucky corporation and insolvency proceeding was in Kentucky; (2) defense of fraud and remedy of rescission for fraudulent inducement of retrocession contracts were not rendered unavailable as matter of New York law by mere fact of insolvency proceedings; (3) no basis was shown for piercing parent corporation's corporate veil; (4) partial summary judgment granted by state court...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Oxford Furniture Companies, Inc. v. Drexel Heritage Furnishings, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, parent corporation is distinct entity from its subsidiary and is not liable for acts of subsidiary unless the subsidiary is a mere adjunct, instrumentality, or alter ego of the parent.
Document Preview: Former operator of furniture retail stores sued furniture manufacturer and manufacturer's parent company, alleging breach of contract, fraudulent suppression of objections to contract, and tortious interference with contract to open showcase store.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, No. 90G965S, J. Foy Guin, Jr., J., directed verdict against manufacturer on breach of contract claim, denied defendants' motions for directed verdict on fraudulent suppression and tortious interference claims, and entered judgment on plaintiff's verdict for over $1.7 million in compensatory and punitive damages.  Defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Birch, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) manufacturer breached contract to make plaintiff the exclusive area dealer for its furniture when it rescinded its decision to terminate another dealer; (2) whether manufacturer had duty under Alabama...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Radaszewski by Radaszewski v. Telecom Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether subsidiary corporation is undercapitalized, for purposes of piercing corporate veil of parent company, issue is whether subsidiary is financially responsible, whether by means of insurance or otherwise.
Document Preview: Motorist who collided with vehicle driven by subsidiary corporation appealed from order of the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri, Dean Whipple, J., which sustained motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction over parent corporation.  The Court of Appeals, 891 F.2d 672, reversed and remanded.  Following remand, the District Court held that it lacked jurisdiction, and appeal was again taken.  The Court of Appeals, Richard S. Arnold, Chief Judge, held that motorist could not pierce corporate veil and hold parent responsible for conduct of its subsidiary and subsidiary's employee. Affirmed as modified. Heaney, Senior Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Radaszewski by Radaszewski v. Telecom Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Existence of insurance goes directly to question of subsidiary's financial responsibility, for purposes of determining whether corporate veil of parent corporation may be pierced; if parent has established financially responsible subsidiary, then that subsidiary is not undercapitalized and therefore it cannot have been established by parent, either deliberately or recklessly, in effort to avoid obligations or to make them difficult to collect.
Document Preview: Motorist who collided with vehicle driven by subsidiary corporation appealed from order of the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri, Dean Whipple, J., which sustained motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction over parent corporation.  The Court of Appeals, 891 F.2d 672, reversed and remanded.  Following remand, the District Court held that it lacked jurisdiction, and appeal was again taken.  The Court of Appeals, Richard S. Arnold, Chief Judge, held that motorist could not pierce corporate veil and hold parent responsible for conduct of its subsidiary and subsidiary's employee. Affirmed as modified. Heaney, Senior Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Rehabilitation of Centaur Ins. Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Corporate identity of subsidiary will be disregarded, and subsidiary and parent corporations will be treated as one, if adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would endorse fraud upon creditors.
Document Preview: Insolvency. Reinsurer's rehabilitator could not assert claims of policyholder against reinsurer's parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Rehabilitation of Centaur Ins. Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Under alter ego doctrine, subsidiary cannot pierce its own corporate veil to reach a parent corporation; rather, equitable remedy lies with third parties such as creditors.
Document Preview: Insolvency. Reinsurer's rehabilitator could not assert claims of policyholder against reinsurer's parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Loral Fairchild Corp. v. Victor Co. of Japan, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Whether corporate veil should be pierced includes consideration of whether there is gross undercapitalization of subsidiary, siphoning by parent of subsidiary's funds, nonfunctioning of subsidiary's officers and directors, and absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: Corporation brought patent infringement action against manufacturers, marketers and distributors of allegedly infringing products.  One of the defendants, a Japanese corporation, brought motion to dismiss for lack of in personam jurisdiction.  The District Court, Johnson, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support exercise of in personam jurisdiction over Japanese corporation which owned 100% of North Carolina corporation under Virginia long-arm statute providing for exercise of in personam jurisdiction over defendant causing tortious injury in Virginia by act or omission outside Virginia; (2) exercise of in personam jurisdiction could not be based on piercing the corporate veil so as to impute subsidiary's contacts to the Japanese corporation; and (3) exercise of in personam jurisdiction over Japanese corporation comported with due process under stream of commerce theory. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Loral Fairchild Corp. v. Victor Co. of Japan, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Fact that a parent corporation may in fact "control" subsidiary's board does not necessarily create relation of principal and agent between the parent and subsidiary.
Document Preview: Corporation brought patent infringement action against manufacturers, marketers and distributors of allegedly infringing products.  One of the defendants, a Japanese corporation, brought motion to dismiss for lack of in personam jurisdiction.  The District Court, Johnson, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support exercise of in personam jurisdiction over Japanese corporation which owned 100% of North Carolina corporation under Virginia long-arm statute providing for exercise of in personam jurisdiction over defendant causing tortious injury in Virginia by act or omission outside Virginia; (2) exercise of in personam jurisdiction could not be based on piercing the corporate veil so as to impute subsidiary's contacts to the Japanese corporation; and (3) exercise of in personam jurisdiction over Japanese corporation comported with due process under stream of commerce theory. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Celi v. Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, to pierce corporate veil and hold parent corporation liable for acts of subsidiary, plaintiff must show that subsidiary is "mere instrumentality" of parent and that subsidiary is being used by parent in order to commit or conceal fraud.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against former employer and its parent corporations, claiming breach of contract, consequential damages, and promissory estoppel.  Defendants filed motion to dismiss and for summary judgment.  The District Court, Johnson, J., held that: (1) Canadian parent corporation was not subject to Court's in personam jurisdiction; (2) alleged three-year oral employment agreement was unenforceable under New York's Statute of Frauds; (3) allegations that employee had been excluded from obtaining employment in adhesives injury because defendants fraudulently induced him to leave his prior position were barred by New York's one-year limitations period for defamation; and (4) employee's alleged injuries did not arise to level of unconscionable injury required to recover under New York's promissory estoppel doctrine. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Pulte Home Corp., Inc. v. Ply Gem Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, mere ownership by one corporation of all the stock of another corporation is not, in itself, sufficient to warrant disregard of subsidiary's separate existence.
Document Preview: Builder brought action against manufacturers and sellers of allegedly defective plywood used in builder's homes.  On motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Kovachevich, J., held that: (1) fact issues precluded summary judgment on builder's claim for punitive damages; (2) builder had standing to sue defendants for damages; (3) Florida law applied to builder's contract claim; (4) fact issues precluded summary judgment on builder's fraud claim; (5) builder was required to identify source of plywood to recover on strict products liability claim; (6) economic loss doctrine did not preclude builder from recovering on its tort claims; and (7) parent corporation could not be held vicariously liable for actions of subsidiary. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Carte Blanche (Singapore) PTE., Ltd. v. Diners Club Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, parent corporation's mere power to control subsidiary is not enough to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor brought suit to compel parent corporation to satisfy judgment obtained against subsidiary for breach of franchise agreement. Following bench trial, the District Court, Whitman Knapp, Senior District Judge, held that piercing corporate veil was not proper under New York law where subsidiary was properly established and later wound down. Judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Big Apple BMW, Inc. v. BMW of North America, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Statement of subsidiary may be attributed to its corporate parent, consistent with agency theory, where parent dominates activities of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Unsuccessful automobile franchise applicants filed antitrust suit against automobile distributor, also alleging pendent state law claims. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, John P. Fullam, J., granted distributor's motion for summary judgment as to all claims except those under Pennsylvania Board of Vehicles Act.  On cross appeals, the Court of Appeals, Mansmann, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) applicants set forth sufficient evidence of concerted action between distributor and its dealership body to exclude applicant and further produced evidence tending to show that distributor's alleged independent reasons for rejecting applications were pretextual, so summary judgment was inappropriate on Sherman Act count; (2) genuine issues of material fact also precluded summary judgment on state law claims for tortious interference with contract; and (3) applicants had standing under Pennsylvania Board of Vehicles Act....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Foster Wheeler Energy Corp. v. Metropolitan Knox Solid Waste Authority, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, corporate veil doctrine is applied to place liability on stockholders, or in parent-subsidiary relationship, to hold parent liable in spite of subsidiary's independent status.
Document Preview: Contractor sued city and county for breach of contract between contractor and solid waste authority, which was nonprofit corporation created jointly by city and county, neither of whom were equity owners in authority.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee, Robert Leon Jordan, J., denied defendants' motion to dismiss.  Defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Contie, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate veil would not be pierced to hold city and county liable, and (2) Tennessee Interlocal Cooperation Act did not provide for liability of city and county. Reversed and remanded with instructions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Boyle v. Jacor Communications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Under New York law, parent and subsidiary corporations are ordinarily separate personalities that cannot be disregarded.
Document Preview: Former corporate officer and director filed suit against parent corporation, demanding payment and interest on note and consulting agreement with subsidiary.  On plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Spiegel, J., held that: (1) Ohio choice of law rules applied; (2) under New York law, parent corporation's ownership of all of subsidiary's stock did not justify piercing corporate veil, and fact that parent's checks had been used to make recent payments to plaintiff did not unequivocally establish that parent had assumed subsidiary's obligations; and (3) genuine issues of material fact, as to whether parent and subsidiary had operated in such a manner as to justify piercing corporate veil, precluded summary judgment. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Boyle v. Jacor Communications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Under New York law, the following criteria should be examined when question of piercing the corporate veil arises: (1) whether subsidiary is subject to such domination and control by its shareholder that it might be said to have no existence of its own; (2) whether evidence exists of bad faith or fraud of parent or subsidiary; and (3) whether corporation is dummy for its stockholders who are in reality carrying on business in their personal capacities for purely personal rather than corporate ends.
Document Preview: Former corporate officer and director filed suit against parent corporation, demanding payment and interest on note and consulting agreement with subsidiary.  On plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Spiegel, J., held that: (1) Ohio choice of law rules applied; (2) under New York law, parent corporation's ownership of all of subsidiary's stock did not justify piercing corporate veil, and fact that parent's checks had been used to make recent payments to plaintiff did not unequivocally establish that parent had assumed subsidiary's obligations; and (3) genuine issues of material fact, as to whether parent and subsidiary had operated in such a manner as to justify piercing corporate veil, precluded summary judgment. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Ministry of Defense of the Islamic Republic of Iran v. Gould, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation was not "alter ego" of its wholly owned subsidiary, so that there was no justification for piercing corporate veil; corporation and subsidiary had kept corporate officers and finances separate, had balanced profits and losses separately, and had not commingled funds, there was no indication that corporation had fraudulent intent in purchasing or maintaining subsidiary, and there was no indication that subsidiary could not satisfy award against it, even though two documents incorrectly referred to subsidiary as division of corporation, modification to one contract of subsidiary was signed by official of corporation, application for export license for subsidiary was completed by corporation, and corporation and subsidiary were represented by same attorneys.
Document Preview: Corporation brought breach of contract claim against Iran before the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal, and Iran brought counterclaims. The Tribunal ordered award for Iran, and corporation appealed.  After affirmance of its subject matter jurisdiction, 887 F.2d 1357, the United States District Court for the Central District of California, Richard A. Gadbois, Jr., J., affirmed Tribunal's award in part and modified it in part, and both Iran and corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, O'Scannlain, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) parent corporation was not alter ego of wholly owned subsidiary; (2) award was within jurisdiction of Tribunal; (3) Tribunal did not relinquish its authority to make award; and (4) remand to district court was warranted for consideration of proposal to implement portion of award which would violate statute. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Union Pacific Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States Claims Court.
Headnote: For there to be common control between parent corporation and subsidiary, subsidiary must be in position to exercise voting control concerning the affairs of the parent.
Document Preview: Parent corporation operated as management holding company for railroad sought refund of federal taxes paid pursuant to Railroad Retirement Tax Act, subject to offset for taxes under Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) and Federal Unemployment Tax Act.  On corporation's motion for summary judgment and government's motion for summary judgment or partial summary judgment, the Claims Court, Horn, J., held that corporation was not under common control with railroad and thus fell outside scope of term employer as defined in Railroad Retirement Tax Act. Plaintiff's motion granted; defendant's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Union Pacific Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States Claims Court.
Headnote: Holding company is generally held not to be doing or transacting business through its subsidiary where separate corporate entities are maintained.
Document Preview: Parent corporation operated as management holding company for railroad sought refund of federal taxes paid pursuant to Railroad Retirement Tax Act, subject to offset for taxes under Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) and Federal Unemployment Tax Act.  On corporation's motion for summary judgment and government's motion for summary judgment or partial summary judgment, the Claims Court, Horn, J., held that corporation was not under common control with railroad and thus fell outside scope of term employer as defined in Railroad Retirement Tax Act. Plaintiff's motion granted; defendant's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Geyer v. Ingersoll Publications Co.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Court can pierce corporate veil where there is fraud, or where subsidiary is in fact a mere instrumentality or alter ego of its owner.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor filed suit against corporation and corporate director for their alleged fiduciary breaches and fraudulent conveyances.  On defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction and failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted, the Chancery Court, Chandler, Vice Chancellor, held that: (1) corporation is insolvent, such that corporate director will owe fiduciary duties to corporation's creditors, whenever it is insolvent in fact, though no statutory proceedings have been filed against it; (2) Delaware court's exercise of personal jurisdiction over nonresident director of Delaware corporation did not violate due process; and (3) allegations in creditor's complaint were sufficient to state claim against corporation under Fraudulent Conveyances Act. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. Fire Ins. Co. v. Allied Towing Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Any number of considerations, including gross undercapitalization of subservient corporation, siphoning of funds by dominant corporation, failure to observe corporate formalities, and absence of corporate records, may in any given case weigh in favor of piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: In an action arising out of collision involving a tug, a tow, and a Navy ship, owner of tow and its insurance company filed suit against owner of tug and United States.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, Robert G. Doumar, J., found both tug and Navy ship at fault for collision and apportioned liability equally between owner of tug and United States, awarded damages, but declined to award prejudgment interest.  Appeals were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Luttig, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) remand was required to enable district court to make more specific determinations for purposes of determining whether to rely on tow's insured value as measure of value, and (2) identity of officers and directors of tug owner and tow owner was not alone sufficient to permit piercing of corporate veil, and, thus, denial of prejudgment interest was an abuse of discretion. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Chateaugay Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Imposition of alter ego liability of parent corporation for conduct of subsidiary requires showing that subsidiary was operated as mere tool or business conduit of parent and that it was operated in such a manner that respect for corporate shield would deny plaintiff just relief.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtor objected to proofs of claim.  The Bankruptcy Court, Burton R. Lifland, Chief Judge, held that: (1) debtor was not liable for subsidiary's breach of contract, and (2) claims against third party were subject to indemnification by debtor. Motion granted in part and denied in part. See also 126 B.R. 165.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Acapolon Corp. v. Ralston Purina Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, En Banc.
Headnote: Corporation, just as individual, is entitled to benefits of limited liability if it chooses to invest in securities of other corporations, and may exercise control which inheres in stock ownership; it does not lose benefits of limited liability by taking active interest in subsidiary's affairs, by using voting power to elect directors, or by entering contracts with subsidiary, so long as corporate formalities are observed and rules followed.
Document Preview: Guatemala buyer of allegedly defective shrimp feed brought action against Guatemala seller and seller's Missouri parent corporation to recover damages.  The Circuit Court, City of St. Louis, Robert G. Dowd, Jr., J., sustained parent's motion to dismiss under doctrine of forum non conveniens and sustained seller's motion to quash service.  On review, the Court of Appeals reversed and remanded.  Granting transfer, the Supreme Court, en banc, Blackmar, J., held that: (1) action was properly dismissed as to parent on grounds of forum non conveniens, and (2) service upon seller was not effective, despite acceptance of summons and petition by employee of parent. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Nynex Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Alter ego analysis may be used to impose liability on parent corporation for conduct of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Telephone company was charged with criminal contempt for violating consent decree which prohibited it from providing information services.  Company moved to dismiss indictment and for hearing to determine whether defense counsel should be disqualified.  The District Court, Harold H. Greene, J., held that: (1) indictment was not defective, and (2) defense counsel would not be disqualified on ground of potential conflict of interest. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Poulos v. Naas Foods, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, parent corporation may be liable for its subsidiary's delicts if applying the corporate fiction would accomplish some fraudulent purpose, operate as constructive fraud, or defeat some strong equitable claim.
Document Preview: Terminated sales representative brought suit in state court against his former company and its parent corporation under Wisconsin Fair Dealership Law (WFDL). Case was removed following dismissal of parent corporation, a nondiverse party. Former representative moved to remand, and his former company moved to compel production of documents and answers to deposition questions. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin, Robert W. Warren, Chief Judge, 132 F.R.D. 513, denied motions in part and granted them in part. On appeal, the Court of Appeals, Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) case did not become removable upon dismissal of nondiverse defendant as that dismissal was involuntary with respect to plaintiff; (2) nondiverse defendant was fraudulently joined and removal jurisdiction was thus proper; (3) former representative could be compelled to produce his tax returns despite claim of qualified immunity; and (4) dismissal...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Schnoor v. Deitchler
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: Ownership by parent corporation of stock of another corporation does not create identity of corporate interests between the two corporations so as to render acts by one to be the acts of another.
Document Preview: Worker who was injured when his leg became entangled in a grain auger brought action, along with his wife, against property owner that owned the grain auger, and a parent corporation, alleging the parent was successor corporation to manufacturer of the auger.  Following a jury trial, the District Court for Pottawattamie County, Charles L. Smith, III, J., entered judgment against each defendant after determining damages and apportioning fault.  Defendants appealed.  The Supreme Court, Schultz, J., held that: (1) parent corporation could not be held liable for products liability claims against manufacturer; (2) parent corporation would not be estopped from asserting that it was not corporate entity which was responsible for products liability claims of manufacturer; and (3) owner owed no duty of care to worker. Reversed. Lavorato, J., dissented and issued an opinion in which Larson, J., joined.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Satellite Broadcasting Cable, Inc. v. Telefonica de Espana
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Ownership of all stock of subsidiary, interlocking directorates, common shareholders and similar names will not suffice, by themselves, to pierce corporate veil under Puerto Rico law; rather, factors such as inadequate financing, comingling of assets and control of day-to-day operation of subsidiary are considered crucial in removing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Signatory to joint venture agreement and related entities brought suit against subsidiary and its parent on various theories after joint venture for creation of television project did not close.  Parent and its subsidiary moved to dismiss various claims for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, J., held that: (1) no contract existed between parties as result of joint venture agreement until such time as condition precedent was complied with; (2) parties' negotiations were, thus, at all times precontractual in nature and subject to implied duty of good faith as well as duty to exert best efforts as set forth in agreement; (3) precontractual obligations contained in agreement did not extend to third parties, such that third parties who were not signatories to agreement but who were allegedly aggrieved by venture were not entitled to recover; (4) corporation to be created as result of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Satellite Broadcasting Cable, Inc. v. Telefonica de Espana
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, where parent uses independent subsidiary for sole purpose of signing joint venture agreement fully negotiated by its parent, corporate veil can be pierced for purpose of that particular transaction; that subsidiary may be instrumentality for purposes of single transaction does not make it less of instrument of parent corporation, even if subsidiary is fully independent otherwise.
Document Preview: Signatory to joint venture agreement and related entities brought suit against subsidiary and its parent on various theories after joint venture for creation of television project did not close.  Parent and its subsidiary moved to dismiss various claims for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, J., held that: (1) no contract existed between parties as result of joint venture agreement until such time as condition precedent was complied with; (2) parties' negotiations were, thus, at all times precontractual in nature and subject to implied duty of good faith as well as duty to exert best efforts as set forth in agreement; (3) precontractual obligations contained in agreement did not extend to third parties, such that third parties who were not signatories to agreement but who were allegedly aggrieved by venture were not entitled to recover; (4) corporation to be created as result of...

Title: Satellite Broadcasting Cable, Inc. v. Telefonica de Espana
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Parent corporation will not, absent clear evidence of alter ego or mere instrumentality, be held liable for contractual obligations of its subsidiary; however, where strong showing of control by parent over subsidiary renders latter mere instrumentality of former, corporate veil can be lifted.
Document Preview: Signatory to joint venture agreement and related entities brought suit against subsidiary and its parent on various theories after joint venture for creation of television project did not close.  Parent and its subsidiary moved to dismiss various claims for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, J., held that: (1) no contract existed between parties as result of joint venture agreement until such time as condition precedent was complied with; (2) parties' negotiations were, thus, at all times precontractual in nature and subject to implied duty of good faith as well as duty to exert best efforts as set forth in agreement; (3) precontractual obligations contained in agreement did not extend to third parties, such that third parties who were not signatories to agreement but who were allegedly aggrieved by venture were not entitled to recover; (4) corporation to be created as result of...
