Title: Satellite Broadcasting Cable, Inc. v. Telefonica de Espana
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Plaintiff bears heavy burden of establishing, in order to pierce corporate veil, that subsidiary is mere instrumentality of parent corporation, that such control has been used to commit fraud or other wrong, and that fraud resulted in injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: Signatory to joint venture agreement and related entities brought suit against subsidiary and its parent on various theories after joint venture for creation of television project did not close.  Parent and its subsidiary moved to dismiss various claims for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, J., held that: (1) no contract existed between parties as result of joint venture agreement until such time as condition precedent was complied with; (2) parties' negotiations were, thus, at all times precontractual in nature and subject to implied duty of good faith as well as duty to exert best efforts as set forth in agreement; (3) precontractual obligations contained in agreement did not extend to third parties, such that third parties who were not signatories to agreement but who were allegedly aggrieved by venture were not entitled to recover; (4) corporation to be created as result of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Satellite Broadcasting Cable, Inc. v. Telefonica de Espana
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, corporate veil is subject to piercing if, following investigation of existing corporate structure, it is determined that one or more of certain criteria exist, including that subsidiary shares are wholly owned by parent, that nature of relationship between parent and subsidiary is such that control is obvious, that directors and officials are shared, that nexus exists between shareholders, or that any other strong proof exists justifying piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: Signatory to joint venture agreement and related entities brought suit against subsidiary and its parent on various theories after joint venture for creation of television project did not close.  Parent and its subsidiary moved to dismiss various claims for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, J., held that: (1) no contract existed between parties as result of joint venture agreement until such time as condition precedent was complied with; (2) parties' negotiations were, thus, at all times precontractual in nature and subject to implied duty of good faith as well as duty to exert best efforts as set forth in agreement; (3) precontractual obligations contained in agreement did not extend to third parties, such that third parties who were not signatories to agreement but who were allegedly aggrieved by venture were not entitled to recover; (4) corporation to be created as result of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Satellite Broadcasting Cable, Inc. v. Telefonica de Espana
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, where parent corporation utilizes its subsidiary as agent for particular transaction, exercising strict control insofar as that particular transaction is concerned, otherwise existent corporate veil is dissolved and parent is rendered liable, for that particular transaction, pursuant to theory of alter ego or mere instrumentality and/or principles of agency law.
Document Preview: Signatory to joint venture agreement and related entities brought suit against subsidiary and its parent on various theories after joint venture for creation of television project did not close.  Parent and its subsidiary moved to dismiss various claims for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, J., held that: (1) no contract existed between parties as result of joint venture agreement until such time as condition precedent was complied with; (2) parties' negotiations were, thus, at all times precontractual in nature and subject to implied duty of good faith as well as duty to exert best efforts as set forth in agreement; (3) precontractual obligations contained in agreement did not extend to third parties, such that third parties who were not signatories to agreement but who were allegedly aggrieved by venture were not entitled to recover; (4) corporation to be created as result of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Sunamerica Financial, Inc. v. 260 Peachtree Street, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: As general principle of corporate law, great caution should be exercised in disregarding or going behind corporate entity; it may be done when subsidiary is shown to be alter ego or business conduit of parent but it must appear that subsidiary is mere instrumentality of parent. O.C.G.A. §§ 9-11-12(b), 9-11-56.
Document Preview: Lessor sought payment of rent from lessee and from guarantor of lease.  The Superior Court, Fulton County, Sears-Collins, J., granted summary judgment for lessor, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Birdsong, P.J., held that genuine issues of material fact existed, precluding summary judgment, as to whether parent corporation or its officers acted on behalf of parent corporation or merely as agents of subsidiary and whether parent acted with improper purpose to terminate lease. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Local 397, Intern. Union of Electronic, Elec. Salaried Mach. and Furniture Workers, AFL-CIO v. Midwest Fasteners, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Mere existence of parent-subsidiary relationship does not provide basis for holding parent liable under piercing the corporate veil doctrine.
Document Preview: Local union brought action against subsidiary and parent corporations alleging violation of Workers' Adjustment and Retraining Acts of 1988 (WARN).  Parent corporations moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Clarkson S. Fisher, J., held that parent corporations and subsidiary were a single enterprise so that parents could be held liable for subsidiary's violation of Act. Motion denied. See also 763 F.Supp. 78.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Local 397, Intern. Union of Electronic, Elec. Salaried Mach. and Furniture Workers, AFL-CIO v. Midwest Fasteners, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Simply because parent controls subsidiary's stock and participates in subsidiary's management, personal liability is not created.
Document Preview: Local union brought action against subsidiary and parent corporations alleging violation of Workers' Adjustment and Retraining Acts of 1988 (WARN).  Parent corporations moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Clarkson S. Fisher, J., held that parent corporations and subsidiary were a single enterprise so that parents could be held liable for subsidiary's violation of Act. Motion denied. See also 763 F.Supp. 78.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gatecliff v. Great Republic Life Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Arizona, In Banc.
Headnote: Under alter ego theory parent corporation's "substantially total control" may be proved by showing, among other things: stock ownership by parent; common officers or directors; financing of subsidiary by parent; payment of salaries and other expenses of subsidiary by parent; failure of subsidiary to maintain formalities of separate corporate existence; similarity of logo; and plaintiff's lack of knowledge of subsidiary's separate existence.
Document Preview: Insureds brought action against parent insurer for breach of contract and bad faith in connection with cancellation of group health policy.  The Superior Court, Maricopa County, Cause No. C555986, John Foreman, J., dismissed complaint, and insureds appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 154 Ariz. 502, 744 P.2d 29, reversed and remanded.  On remand, the Superior Court, Stephen A. Gerst, J., entered summary judgment in favor of insurer.  Appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals affirmed in memorandum decision.  Review was accepted. The Supreme Court, Cameron, J., held that questions of fact precluded summary judgment as to parent insurer's liability under alter ego theory, instrumentality theory, and direct liability theory. Decision of Court of Appeals vacated, decision of trial court reversed, and case remanded. Corcoran, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Las Palmas Associates v. Las Palmas Center Associates
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Generally, alter ego liability is reserved for parent-subsidiary relationship; however, under single-enterprise rule, liability can be found between sister companies.
Document Preview: Shopping center vendors sought declaratory relief concerning their duty to guarantee rents, and purchasers filed cross complaint for fraud and breach of contract.  The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, No. C575906, Arthur Baldonaldo, J., entered judgment on jury verdict for purchasers, and vendors appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Nott, J., held that: (1) evidence supported finding of fraud; (2) compensatory and punitive damage awards were excessive; and (3) purchasers were not entitled to contractual attorney fees on their fraud claim, but were entitled to recover fees incurred in defending vendors' contract action. Affirmed as modified; remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Holborn Oil Trading Ltd. and Interpetrol Bermuda Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In admiralty cases decided under federal common law plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must show fraud or domination by parent, but is not required to establish both.
Document Preview: Owner of vessel intervened in arbitration proceeding involving parent of its charterer, and unrelated party, seeking to pursue directly against parent its claim under charter party agreement.  The District Court, Leisure, J., held that: (1) in order to pierce corporate veil in admiralty case, showing of fraud or domination of subsidiary by parent was required, but not both, and (2) material issues of fact, precluding summary judgment, existed in support of claim that parent of charterer had stripped charterer of its assets, so as to show commission of fraud, or exhibit domination over charterer, sufficient to support piercing of corporate veil. Summary judgment motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Air Disaster Near Cove Neck, N.Y., on Jan. 25, 1990
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Although corporations are generally presumed to be separate from their subsidiaries, federal courts sitting in diversity will ignore such distinctions where parent exercises sufficient control over subsidiary; where such control is exercised, two corporations will be deemed alter egos of one another and treated as single consolidated entity.
Document Preview: In action arising out of air disaster, Colombian airline moved to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.  The District Court, Platt, Chief Judge, held that American subsidiary and sales agent of Colombian airline could not be considered to be alter ego of airlines so as to confer jurisdiction under Warsaw Convention. Motion granted. See also 774 F.Supp. 725, 774 F.Supp. 732.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: CPC Intern., Inc. v. Aerojet-General Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, piercing corporate veil to reach parent corporation or their investor is equitable doctrine that is applied to prevent fraud, illegality, or injustice, with decision whether to disregard corporate entity turning on unique factual circumstances of each case.
Document Preview: Series of claims were brought under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA), regarding responsibility for past and future costs incurred in environmental cleanup of soil, surface water, and groundwater surrounding dormant chemical manufacturing plant. After trial on issue of liability, the District Court, Hillman, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent corporation of former owner of site was liable as operator; (2) Michigan Department of Natural Resources was not liable as either operator or arranger; (3) parent corporation of present owner was liable as owner and operator; and (4) innocent owner defense was not available to present owner and its corporation parents. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: CPC Intern., Inc. v. Aerojet-General Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, corporate veil may be pierced to reach parent corporation after finding that subsidiary has been instrumentality of parent, that separateness between corporations has been used to commit fraud or wrong, and that unjust loss or injury to plaintiff has occurred.
Document Preview: Series of claims were brought under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA), regarding responsibility for past and future costs incurred in environmental cleanup of soil, surface water, and groundwater surrounding dormant chemical manufacturing plant. After trial on issue of liability, the District Court, Hillman, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent corporation of former owner of site was liable as operator; (2) Michigan Department of Natural Resources was not liable as either operator or arranger; (3) parent corporation of present owner was liable as owner and operator; and (4) innocent owner defense was not available to present owner and its corporation parents. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: CPC Intern., Inc. v. Aerojet-General Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, it may be appropriate under some circumstances to pierce veil of separate corporate entity to serve interest of justice when individual is sole shareholder of corporation, as in case of parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary; for example, fiction of corporate form may be disregarded when complete identity of interests exists between two corporate individuals so as to suggest that one was simply alter ego of other.
Document Preview: Series of claims were brought under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA), regarding responsibility for past and future costs incurred in environmental cleanup of soil, surface water, and groundwater surrounding dormant chemical manufacturing plant. After trial on issue of liability, the District Court, Hillman, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent corporation of former owner of site was liable as operator; (2) Michigan Department of Natural Resources was not liable as either operator or arranger; (3) parent corporation of present owner was liable as owner and operator; and (4) innocent owner defense was not available to present owner and its corporation parents. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: First Health, Inc. v. Blanton
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Fact that individual or another corporation owns all or majority of stock of corporation does not of itself destroy separate corporate entity.
Document Preview: Physician filed action against hospital and the corporate owner of all stock in hospital after hospital ceased paying his salary.  The Circuit Court, Lawrence County, No. CV89109, A. Philip Reich, II, J., entered judgment for physician, and corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Kennedy, J., held that absent any showing that corporation which controlled stock in hospital misused its control, or that physician's loss of wages resulted from misuse of that control, corporate entity would not be disregarded. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Chase Manhattan Bank (Nat. Ass'n) v. 264 Water Street Associates
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Court may pierce corporate veil to reach controlling parent, shareholder or director, upon showing that said party exercised complete domination in respect to transaction attacked so that subsidiary had at time no separate will of its own.
Document Preview: Mortgagee brought action to foreclose two mortgages and to enforce guarantees executed in connection with them.  Subsequently, mortgagee served amended complaint, adding as defendants parent of one of the guarantors and president of both corporations.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Preminger, J., denied additional defendants' motion to dismiss, and they appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that mortgagee's allegation that subsidiary and its parent masterminded scheme to denude subsidiary of its assets in order to render it unable to honor its obligations, resulting in loss to mortgagee was sufficient to sustain cause of action to pierce corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Chase Manhattan Bank (Nat. Ass'n) v. 264 Water Street Associates
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: It was unnecessary that unsatisfied judgment first be obtained against subsidiary to pierce parent's corporate veil.
Document Preview: Mortgagee brought action to foreclose two mortgages and to enforce guarantees executed in connection with them.  Subsequently, mortgagee served amended complaint, adding as defendants parent of one of the guarantors and president of both corporations.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Preminger, J., denied additional defendants' motion to dismiss, and they appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that mortgagee's allegation that subsidiary and its parent masterminded scheme to denude subsidiary of its assets in order to render it unable to honor its obligations, resulting in loss to mortgagee was sufficient to sustain cause of action to pierce corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Pritchard Services (NY) Inc. v. First Winthrop Properties, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation over which parent corporation exercises control in everyday operations may be deemed instrumentality or agent of parent, and determinative factor is whether or not subsidiary corporation is dummy for parent corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from an order of the Supreme Court, New York County, Shainswit, J., which, inter alia, deemed proposed amended complaint served. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that although plaintiff was entitled to leave to replead cause of action for breach of contract as against parent corporation, plaintiff was not entitled to leave to replead cause of action for account stated. Modified, and as modified, affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Pritchard Services (NY) Inc. v. First Winthrop Properties, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced either to achieve equity, where officers and employees of parent corporation exercise control over daily operations of subsidiary and act as true prime movers behind subsidiary's action, or on theory that parent conducts business through subsidiary, which exists solely to serve parent.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from an order of the Supreme Court, New York County, Shainswit, J., which, inter alia, deemed proposed amended complaint served. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that although plaintiff was entitled to leave to replead cause of action for breach of contract as against parent corporation, plaintiff was not entitled to leave to replead cause of action for account stated. Modified, and as modified, affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Southwestern Bell Telephone Co. v. Vollmer
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Under alter ego doctrine, courts disregard corporate entity when there exists such a unity between parent corporation and subsidiary that parent ceases to be separate, and holding only the subsidiary liable would promote injustice, and generally court will not disregard corporate fiction and hold corporation liable for obligations of subsidiary except when it appears that subsidiary is being used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, to avoid liability, to avoid the effect of a statute, or in other exceptional circumstances.
Document Preview: Customer sued telephone company, related entities, and telephone company employee as a result of omission from directory listings of customer's new business trade name.  The 94th District Court, Nueces County, Jack Hunter, J., entered judgment against telephone company for violation of Deceptive Trade Practices Act and against employee for negligence, and granted judgment n.o.v. on behalf of parent corporation, and telephone company, employee, and customer appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Kennedy, J., held that: (1) evidence supported finding that telephone company's tariff limiting liability was reasonable; (2) apart from employer's contract with state, employee had no independent legal duty to provide customer with directory listing, and thus could not be found negligent; (3) jury's findings of no gross negligence or willful misconduct were not against the great weight and preponderance of the evidence; (4) liability under the Deceptive...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Logal v. Inland Steel Industries, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: Subsidiary was not mere alter ego of parent corporation despite corporations' shared officers and office space, issuance of parent corporation's stock on subsidiary's old certificates, parent corporation's issuance of stock under subsidiary's employee stock purchase plan, and corporations' use of same trademark.
Document Preview: Shareholder of parent corporation, employee of subsidiary corporation, sought to inspect corporate records concerning closing of plant.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, Albert Green, J., dismissed petition.  Shareholder appealed. The Appellate Court, Buckley, J., held that: (1) proposed examination was not for proper purpose, and (2) subsidiary was not alter ego of parent corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mason v. Burkett
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Subsidiary's corporate veil could not be pierced under Connecticut law, even though subsidiary and parent corporation were known for a time by single name, and even though subsidiary's publications normally featured parent's logo and referred to subsidiary as company of parent; officers, directors, and employees of subsidiary were separate from officers, directors, and employees of parent, and parent did not conduct day-to-day business of subsidiary or formulate policies of subsidiary's employees.
Document Preview: Investors brought action against financial planners, financial management firm, and firm's parent corporation to recover for breach of fiduciary responsibility, fraud, and negligent misrepresentation.  Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Eginton, J., held that: (1) whether planner was fiduciary of one investor was question of fact precluding summary judgment; (2) planner did not aid and abet securities fraud by other planner; (3) planner did not commit fraud or negligent misrepresentation; and (4) corporate veil of subsidiary firm could not be pierced. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Fidelity Capital Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation's practice of lending money as "private lender" to its subsidiaries with few formalities did not show that corporation's president abused corporate form under Georgia law.
Document Preview: As receiver of firm designated a Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) under Small Business Investment Act, Small Business Administration (SBA) began nonjudicial proceedings to foreclose mortgage which company held on parcel of real estate by exercising power of sale contained in mortgage.  Mortgage company which claimed that it owned property moved for leave to intervene in receivership action and to declare investment company's mortgage, which had not been satisfied of record, null and void.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, No. C862033A, granted mortgage company leave to intervene and declaratory relief it sought.  SBA appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 888 F.2d 1344, vacated and remanded with directions.  On remand, the District Court, Richard C. Freeman, J., made supplemental findings of fact.  The Court of Appeals, Tjoflat, Chief Judge, held that facts as found by district court were...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Fidelity Capital Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: That subsidiary's payment of loan incidentally benefited parent corporation did not constitute evidence of abuse of corporate form under Georgia law.
Document Preview: As receiver of firm designated a Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) under Small Business Investment Act, Small Business Administration (SBA) began nonjudicial proceedings to foreclose mortgage which company held on parcel of real estate by exercising power of sale contained in mortgage. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Fidelity Capital Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: That corporation shared offices, stationary, and employees with its parent, which was owned by corporation's president, did not, by itself, compel conclusion that corporation and its president were one and the same under Georgia law.
Document Preview: As receiver of firm designated a Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) under Small Business Investment Act, Small Business Administration (SBA) began nonjudicial proceedings to foreclose mortgage which company held on parcel of real estate by exercising power of sale contained in mortgage.  Mortgage company which claimed that it owned property moved for leave to intervene in receivership action and to declare investment company's mortgage, which had not been satisfied of record, null and void.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, No. C862033A, granted mortgage company leave to intervene and declaratory relief it sought.  SBA appealed. The Court of Appeals, Tjoflat, Chief Judge, held that facts as found by district court were...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: USP Real Estate Inv. Trust v. Discount Auto Parts, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil, it must be shown not only that wholly-owned subsidiary was mere instrumentality of parent corporation, but also that subsidiary was organized or used by parent to mislead creditors or to perpetrate fraud upon them.
Document Preview: After obtaining judgment against wholly-owned subsidiary to which retail lease had ostensibly been assigned, lessor obtained court order impleading parent corporation as third-party defendant and sought to have parent held liable for judgment against subsidiary.  The Circuit Court for Clay County, William A. Wilkes, J., refused to pierce corporate veil, and lessor appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Zehmer, J., held that evidence established that parent used subsidiary to mislead creditors or perpetrate fraud upon them, thus justifying piercing corporate veil. Reversed and remanded. Barfield, J., dissented with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Jarax Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Law of alter ego with respect to parent-subsidiary relationships in Florida is not identical to general law regarding piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Trustee in Chapter 7 case of debtor client of subsidiary brought action against parent bank and subsidiary, seeking to pierce corporate veil. The Bankruptcy Court, A. Jay Cristol, J., held that evidence established that wholly owned subsidiary of parent bank was mere instrumentality of parent and that there was improper conduct by parent, thus permitting piercing of corporate veil, assuming conduct alleged proximately caused injury to client. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Jarax Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Showing of "improper conduct" as required for piercing of corporate veil in parent/subsidiary relationship can be made by evidence demonstrating that subsidiary was organized or maintained to mislead creditors, or to circumvent statute or to fraudulently avoid liability.
Document Preview: Trustee in Chapter 7 case of debtor client of subsidiary brought action against parent bank and subsidiary, seeking to pierce corporate veil. The Bankruptcy Court, A. Jay Cristol, J., held that evidence established that wholly owned subsidiary of parent bank was mere instrumentality of parent and that there was improper conduct by parent, thus permitting piercing of corporate veil, assuming conduct alleged proximately caused injury to client. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Stinson v. GAF Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To recover from parent corporation under "mere instrumentality" test under Pennsylvania law, plaintiffs must prove that parent controlled subsidiary to such a degree that subsidiary is mere instrumentality; that parent is perpetrating fraud or wrong through its subsidiary; and unjust loss or injury to claimant such as insolvency of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Products liability action was brought against asbestos manufacturer.  Manufacturer moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Lee, J., held that manufacturer's wholly owned subsidiary was not mere instrumentality of manufacturer and, therefore, under Pennsylvania law manufacturer was not liable for acts of its subsidiary. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Stinson v. GAF Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To find parent corporation liable for acts of its subsidiaries, Pennsylvania law requires threshold showing that controlled corporation acted robot or puppet-like in mechanical response to controller's strings or pressure on its buttons.
Document Preview: Products liability action was brought against asbestos manufacturer.  Manufacturer moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Lee, J., held that manufacturer's wholly owned subsidiary was not mere instrumentality of manufacturer and, therefore, under Pennsylvania law manufacturer was not liable for acts of its subsidiary. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Poulos v. NAAS Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, mere fact that corporate parent controls policies of subsidiary is not, in itself, sufficient to permit piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: Dealer brought suit under the Wisconsin Fair Dealership Act for grantor's alleged wrongful termination of dealership. Following removal of action to federal court, dealer moved to remand, and grantor moved to compel production of documents and answers to deposition questions. The District Court, Warren, Chief Judge, held that: (1) addition of grantor's corporate parent as additional defendant in suit under the Wisconsin Fair Dealership Act was fraudulently undertaken to defeat diversity and to preclude removal of case, and (2) grantor was entitled to production of tax records and other financial information of dealer. Motions denied in part and granted in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Holywell Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, fact that parent company owns all of stock of subsidiary does not permit court to disregard their separate entities unless there are other aggravating circumstances, such as showing that one corporation is mere instrumentality of the other and that corporation is device or sham to mislead creditors or exists for fraudulent purposes.
Document Preview: Liquidating trustee brought adversarial complaint against discharged Chapter 11 debtors seeking to locate and recover stock and assets of 50 nondebtor subsidiaries of debtors.  The United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of Florida struck debtors' answer and affirmative defenses, entered default, imposed fine, and found debtors in contempt.  Debtors appealed.  The District Court, Aronovitz, J., held that adversary proceeding was not shown to concern property of debtors' estate, on present record, and thus was not within subject matter jurisdiction of bankruptcy court. Vacated and remanded. See also, D.C., 93 B.R. 780.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Skidmore, Owings & Merrill v. Canada Life Assur. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Absent circumstances justifying disregard of corporate form, parent company is treated under Colorado law as legal entity separate from subsidiary.
Document Preview: Architectural firm, judgment creditor of subsidiary corporations, brought action to collect debt from parent corporations.  The United States District Court for the District of Colorado, 706 F.Supp. 758, Lewis T. Babcock, J., entered summary judgment in favor of parent corporations.  Firm appealed. The Court of Appeals held that firm was not entitled to pierce subsidiaries' corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Trailways, Inc. v. Clark
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Generally, court will not disregard corporate fiction and hold corporation liable for obligations of its subsidiary except where it appears the corporate entity of subsidiary is being used as sham to perpetrate fraud, to avoid liability, to avoid effect of statute, or in other exceptional circumstances when corporate form has been used as part of basically unfair device to achieve inequitable result.
Document Preview: In wrongful death action against United States and Mexican bus lines arising out of Mexican bus accident, the 138th District Court, Cameron County, Robert Garza, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs.  On appeal, the Court of Appeals, 756 S.W.2d 786,reversed and remanded, and plaintiffs brought error.  The Supreme Court, 774 S.W.2d 644, reversed and remanded.  On remand, the Court of Appeals, Kennedy, J., held that: (1) supervisor for Mexican federal police was qualified to testify as expert on speed of bus and its contribution to cause of accident; (2) there was some evidence to support finding that bus driver exceeded rate of speed at which person using high degree of care would have driven; (3) Texas had the most significant contacts, for choice of law purposes; and (4) United States bus line was not liable for actions of its subsidiary. Affirmed in part and reversed and rendered in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Trailways, Inc. v. Clark
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: There must be something more than mere unity of financial interest, ownership, and control for court to treat subsidiary as alter ego of parent and make parent liable for subsidiary's actions; merely showing blending of activities between parent and subsidiary such that they may have had some or all of the same directors or officers, filed consolidated income tax returns, shared the same corporate logo, conducted inter-corporate business, or officed in the same building is not alone sufficient.
Document Preview: In wrongful death action against United States and Mexican bus lines arising out of Mexican bus accident, the 138th District Court, Cameron County, Robert Garza, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs.  On appeal, the Court of Appeals, 756 S.W.2d 786,reversed and remanded, and plaintiffs brought error.  The Supreme Court, 774 S.W.2d 644, reversed and remanded.  On remand, the Court of Appeals, Kennedy, J., held that: (1) supervisor for Mexican federal police was qualified to testify as expert on speed of bus and its contribution to cause of accident; (2) there was some evidence to support finding that bus driver exceeded rate of speed at which person using high degree of care would have driven; (3) Texas had the most significant contacts, for choice of law purposes; and (4) United States bus line was not liable for actions of its subsidiary. Affirmed in part and reversed and rendered in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Key v. Liquid Energy Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: In order to hold a parent corporation liable for acts of a subsidiary, it must be established that the subsidiary was a mere instrumentality or alter ego of the parent, and/or, show that the use of the separate corporate structures resulted in fraud, illegality or inequity, and it is not sufficient to show that the parent wholly owned the subsidiary, or that the corporations shared some personnel.
Document Preview: Truck drivers who were injured during an explosion that occurred in connection with hauling butane condensate brought action against, inter alia, their employer, and employer's parent corporation.  Following a jury trial, the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, James O. Ellison, J., entered a judgment finding negligence on all parties and awarding damages to the drivers.  Thereafter, court denied defendant's motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict, or in alternative, for a new trial. Defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Conway, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) plaintiffs failed to offer evidence sufficient to hold parent liable on theory that subsidiary was mere instrumentality or alter ego, and failed to offer sufficient evidence of fraud, illegality or inequity; (2) the peculiar risk doctrine would not be applied to the parent subsidiary relationship;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Dutoit v. Strategic Minerals Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: A parent-subsidiary relationship is by itself insufficient reason to pierce corporate veil in jurisdictional context.
Document Preview: Employee brought personal injury action against employer, a Delaware corporation whose principal place of business was in South Africa, for injuries arising out of industrial accident that took place in South Africa.  Employer moved for dismissal.  The District Court, Katz, J., held that it lacked personal jurisdiction over employer. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Meshel v. Resorts Intern. of New York, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In absence of a clear indication of dominion and control, parent, subsidiary or affiliated corporations are treated separately and independently for purposes of assigning legal responsibility.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against a tour operator seeking to hold it liable for alleged negligence of hotel employees in responding to an emergency with defective oxygen equipment and spent or inadequate oxygen cylinders.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Fingerhood, J., denied the defendant's cross motion for summary judgment, and defendant appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that subsidiary corporation, which operated tour business which provided customers to hotel indirectly owned by parent corporation and which did not share employees, assets, or business of parent corporation, could not be held liable for alleged negligence of hotel's agents or employees. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Long v. AT & T Information Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Relationship between parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary is insufficient in itself to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Black disabled former employee brought action against former employer for discriminatory employment practices and retaliatory actions in violation of federal civil rights statutes and New York Human Rights Law.  Former employer moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, William C. Conner, J., held that: (1) employee's allegations of discriminatory termination and retaliation for filing civil rights claims did not state claims under federal civil rights statute; (2) District Court would not consider employee's pendent state law discrimination claims, as employee's conduct in reopening administrative proceedings effectively amounted to election to proceed before State Division of Human Rights; (3) genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether employer engaged in discriminatory termination in violation of Civil Rights Act, where employee presented evidence of racially derogatory references to him by supervisors who fired him; (4)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Brown v. Advantage Engineering, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, there is a "two-prong" test for determining whether subsidiary corporation is alter ego of parent: subsidiary must be mere instrumentality of parent so that separate personalities no longer exist; and to adhere to the doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: Personal injury action was brought arising from explosion of oil heating machine.  On motion of two defendants for summary judgment and on motions to bifurcate or for separate trial on certain issues, the District Court, Robert H. Hall, J., held that: (1) there were fact issues precluding summary judgment as to whether a defendant which, through an intermediate subsidiary, owned all of the stock of plaintiff's employer was alter ego of the employer so as to be entitled to tort immunity under Georgia workers' compensation law; (2) such defendant did not have tort immunity as plaintiff's statutory employer; (3) separate trials on issues of liability and damages, or on alter ego question, were not warranted; and (4) there were issues of fact precluding summary judgment as to whether pump on the machine had design defects and as to proximate cause. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re D.R.L., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Judgment in contract action between corporate subsidiary and third party did not constitute judgment against subsidiary's unjoined parent corporation; fact that many of the same principals were involved in both parent and subsidiary was alone insufficient to warrant ignoring separate corporate entities.
Document Preview: Developer requested that debtor be required to release liens on developer's property, and debtor counterclaimed to recover for additional services performed at request of developer.  The United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Rhode Island, 103 B.R. 379, entered judgment for debtor, and developer moved for clarification.  The Bankruptcy Court, Arthur N. Votolato, Jr., J., held that judgment in contract action between developer and debtor did not constitute judgment against developer's unjoined parent corporation. Judgment clarified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re ContiCommodity Services, Inc., Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Texas and Illinois law, corporate veil can be pierced where parent so controls the subsidiary that subsidiary is a mere instrument or tool and adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Multidistrict litigation was brought in which customers of futures commission merchant sued the merchant and others, and various claims and counterclaims were asserted by other parties.  On motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Hart, J., held that: (1) customers would not be allowed to rely at trial on specific trades not already identified; (2) there were issues of fact with respect to piercing the corporate veil, precluding summary judgment for merchant's corporate parent; (3) there were issues of fact precluding summary judgment on RICO claim; (4) customers had claim against parent corporation and merchant's officers under the Commodity Exchange Act; (5) merchant could be liable for interfering with its contract with its customers to extent it conspired with its parent and parent's acts were not privileged; (6) Texas law controlled on issue of whether tort of conversion exists for conversion of intangible property;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Pebble Cove Homeowners' Ass'n, Inc. v. Fidelity New York FSB
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil between parent corporation and subsidiary, parent must exercise complete domination and control; stock control, interlocking directors and interlocking officers are in and of themselves insufficient to justify imposition of liability on parent, but control by parent of subsidiary's everyday operations will render parent liable for subsidiary's acts.
Document Preview: Breach of contract action was brought against, inter alia, wholly owned subsidiary's corporate parent.  The Supreme Court, Nassau County, DiNoto, J., granted summary judgment for parent, and appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that corporate veil between parent corporation and subsidiary would not be pierced where complaint failed to adequately allege means by which parent controlled its wholly owned subsidiary, and documentation submitted in opposition to summary judgment motion was devoid of evidentiary facts to support allegations that parent totally controlled everyday operation of subsidiary. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Johnson & Johnson v. Coopervision, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Wholly owned subsidiary was not alter ego of parent corporation for purposes of determining whether subsidiary was indispensable party to lawsuit, on theory that parent could be viewed as surrogate for subsidiary in suing another corporation over sale of business assets, where corporate formalities had been observed; moreover, alter ego doctrine, which was typically employed by claimants against defendant corporation as vehicle for holding corporation's shareholders or its parent company liable, could not be used by parent as means of benefitting from its own inattention to corporate formalities, so as to permit it to bring diversity action in federal court, without joinder of subsidiary, which would have destroyed diversity jurisdiction.
Document Preview: Parent corporation brought breach of contract and fraud suit arising from a purchase of pharmaceutical business.  Seller moved to dismiss for failure to join indispensable party.  The District Court,Latchum, Senior District Judge, held that plaintiff subsidiary was indispensable party to litigation where it had played important role in negotiation of agreement and had been assigned assets and liabilities over which dispute arose. Motion to dismiss granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mobil Oil Corp. v. Linear Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation may be deemed alter ego of its corporate parent where there is lack of attention to corporate formalities, such as where assets of two entities are commingled and their operations intertwined.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against, among others, parent corporation of subsidiary which manufactured allegedly infringing product. Parent moved for summary judgment and patent holder moved to substitute subsidiary for parent as party defendant.  The District Court, Latchum, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent was not liable for any direct infringement; (2) parent could not be held liable under alter ego theory for infringement of its subsidiary; (3) parent could not be held liable under pure agency theory for infringement of its subsidiary; and (4) subsidiary could not be substituted for parent. Parent's motion granted and patent holder's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mobil Oil Corp. v. Linear Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Alter ego relationship might also lie between subsidiary corporation and corporate parent where parent exercises complete domination and control over subsidiary.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against, among others, parent corporation of subsidiary which manufactured allegedly infringing product. Parent moved for summary judgment and patent holder moved to substitute subsidiary for parent as party defendant.  The District Court, Latchum, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent was not liable for any direct infringement; (2) parent could not be held liable under alter ego theory for infringement of its subsidiary; (3) parent could not be held liable under pure agency theory for infringement of its subsidiary; and (4) subsidiary could not be substituted for parent. Parent's motion granted and patent holder's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mobil Oil Corp. v. Linear Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Where agency or alter ego relationship is premised upon parent's domination and control of subsidiary, such domination and control may be general in nature and need not have any particular relationship to cause of action being asserted; in contrast, plaintiff wishing to hold parent corporation liable for the acts of its subsidiary under pure agency theory must demonstrate a close connection between the relationship of the two corporations and the cause of action.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against, among others, parent corporation of subsidiary which manufactured allegedly infringing product. Parent moved for summary judgment and patent holder moved to substitute subsidiary for parent as party defendant.  The District Court, Latchum, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent was not liable for any direct infringement; (2) parent could not be held liable under alter ego theory for infringement of its subsidiary; (3) parent could not be held liable under pure agency theory for infringement of its subsidiary; and (4) subsidiary could not be substituted for parent. Parent's motion granted and patent holder's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mobil Oil Corp. v. Linear Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Fraud or injustice warranting holding parent corporation liable for acts of its subsidiary under alter ego theory must be found in corporations' use of corporate form.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against, among others, parent corporation of subsidiary which manufactured allegedly infringing product. Parent moved for summary judgment and patent holder moved to substitute subsidiary for parent as party defendant.  The District Court, Latchum, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent was not liable for any direct infringement; (2) parent could not be held liable under alter ego theory for infringement of its subsidiary; (3) parent could not be held liable under pure agency theory for infringement of its subsidiary; and (4) subsidiary could not be substituted for parent. Parent's motion granted and patent holder's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Lowell Staats Min. Co., Inc. v. Pioneer Uravan, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Fact that corporation's sole shareholder consolidated financial reports with its subsidiary did not warrant piercing corporate veil under Colorado law given that Internal Revenue Code allows parent corporation to file consolidated tax returns with subsidiaries when parent owns at least 80% of subsidiary. 26 U.S.C.A. § 1501.
Document Preview: Independent mining contractor brought breach of contract action against corporate owner of mining property.  Property owner brought action against contractor to recover overpayments for ore deliveries under contract and contractor brought third-party claim against sole shareholder of property owner and against shareholder's subsidiary.  Actions were consolidated and removed to federal court.  The United States District Court for the District of Colorado, John L. Kane, Jr., J., granted directed verdict motions of sole shareholder and subsidiary on claims in third-party complaint, jury returned verdict against property owner on counterclaim and on breach of contract claim awarded damages.  The District Court, 645 F.Supp. 254, denied contractor's motion for prejudgment interest.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Brorby, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate veil of mining property owner could not be pierced to render sole...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Frazier v. Bryan Memorial Hosp. Authority
Court: Supreme Court of Oklahoma.
Headnote: Question of whether allegedly dominant corporation may be held liable for subservient entity's tort hinges primarily on control; factors which may be considered at trial include whether parent corporation owns all or most of subsidiary's stock, corporations have common directors or officers, parent provides financing to subsidiary, dominant corporation subscribes to all the other's stock, subordinate corporation is grossly undercapitalized, parent pays salaries, expenses or losses of subsidiary, almost all of subsidiary's business is with parent or assets of former were conveyed from latter, parent refers to its subsidiary as division or department, subsidiary's officers or directors follow directions from parent corporation, and legal formalities for keeping entities separate and independent are observed.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from orders of the District Court, Bryan County, Joe C. Taylor, J., entered in wrongful death action.  The Supreme Court, Opala, V.C.J., held that: (1) order dismissing action against hospital for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted due to absence of statutorily required notice of claim was a nonappealable interlocutory order, and (2) fact issue as to whether hospital management corporation's wholly owned subsidiary was instrumentality or agent of corporation precluded summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Pennsylvania Engineering Corp. v. Islip Resource Recovery Agency
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation cannot create subsidiary and then ignore its separate corporation existence whenever it would be advantageous to parent.
Document Preview: Action was brought on contract to construct and operate solid waste disposal facility for resource recovery agency.  Agency and the other defendants moved for partial summary judgment and requested confirmation of arbitrator's decision and dismissal of the entire case.  The District Court, Wexler, J., held that: (1) arbitration agreement in the contract was subject to the Federal Arbitration Act; (2) objections to confirmation could not be raised after time limit to vacation of award had passed; (3) arbitrator's decision barred under collateral estoppel and res judicata claim that contractor did not default on the contract; and (4) no claim for tortious interference with either contractual or precontractual relation was stated. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hando v. PPG Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Two general factors must be present before a court will disregard separate corporate entity and treat subsidiary and parent as one corporation: corporation must be a mere agent or alter ego of parent company; and corporate cloak must have been used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, perpetrate fraud, or to defend a crime.
Document Preview: Employee of wholly owned subsidiary brought suit against subsidiary, its parent corporation, and a paint manufacturer seeking damages resulting from her exposure to paint used by the subsidiary.  A Thirteenth Judicial District Court, Yellowstone County, Russell Fillner, J., granted parent corporation's motion for summary judgment on issue of its duty to provide a safe workplace for employee, and denied motions for summary judgment by paint manufacturer and parent corporation on statute of limitations grounds, and cross appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Gulbrandson, J., held that: (1) parent corporation did not have a duty to provide a safe workplace for employee, and (2) three-year statute of limitations was tolled until a medical diagnosis causally connected employee's exposure to toxic paint fumes with her various continuing ailments where employee's initial failure to learn cause of her ongoing injuries was not due to a lack of diligence on her part...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hando v. PPG Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation may be mere agent of parent company, for purposes of disregarding separate corporate entity and treating subsidiary and parent as one corporation, if parent company exercises control over conduct and activities of subsidiary so that in effect subsidiary is merely acting on behalf of parent; furthermore, subsidiary is alter ego of parent corporation if corporate affairs of both are so intertwined that, in effect, each no longer has a separate identity.
Document Preview: Employee of wholly owned subsidiary brought suit against subsidiary, its parent corporation, and a paint manufacturer seeking damages resulting from her exposure to paint used by the subsidiary.  A Thirteenth Judicial District Court, Yellowstone County, Russell Fillner, J., granted parent corporation's motion for summary judgment on issue of its duty to provide a safe workplace for employee, and denied motions for summary judgment by paint manufacturer and parent corporation on statute of limitations grounds, and cross appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Gulbrandson, J., held that: (1) parent corporation did not have a duty to provide a safe workplace for employee, and (2) three-year statute of limitations was tolled until a medical diagnosis causally connected employee's exposure to toxic paint fumes with her various continuing ailments where employee's initial failure to learn cause of her ongoing injuries was not due to a lack of diligence on her part...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Lubrizol Corp. v. Cardinal Const. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Controlling corporation could not be held liable for wrongdoing of another corporate entity which was alleged to be a "mere instrumentality" of controlling corporation, absent finding of fault or wrongdoing on the part of the controlling corporation.
Document Preview: Facility owner filed action for breach of contract, interference with contract and fraud against contractors, their bonding company and financial monitor. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, Lynn N. Hughes, J., granted judgment for plaintiff against construction companies for $5,000,000 and $250,000 in attorney fees, but found other defendants not liable.  Plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Gee, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) trial court properly refused to give instruction on agency requested by plaintiff absent showing of improper behavior by controlling corporation, and (2) prejudgment interest rate used by trial court was appropriate. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Glanzer v. St. Joseph Indian School
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Parent corporation is liable for acts of its subsidiary under instrumentality exception to separateness of entities when parent controlled subsidiary to such an extent as to render latter mere instrumentality of former and adherence to rule of corporate separateness would produce injustices and inequities.
Document Preview: Limited partner sued general partner and general partner's parent corporation for breach of partnership agreement, negligent and intentional infliction of emotional distress, fraudulent and negligent misrepresentation, guaranty and breach of fiduciary duty.  The Circuit Court, Fourth Judicial Circuit, Brule County, Marshall M. Gerken, J., granted summary judgment in favor of parent, and entered judgment on jury verdict on behalf of limited partner against general partner.  Limited and general partner appealed.  The Supreme Court, Timm, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) summary judgment on question of whether parent was liable for acts of its subsidiary as general partner in fishing tackle venture was improper; (2) trial court erred in refusing to instruct jury on lost salary and research and development income as element of damage; (3) trial court adequately instructed jury on general partner's fiduciary duty to limited partner; and (4)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Horowitz v. Schneider Nat., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Mere ownership of subsidiary's stock by parent corporation does not establish control required under mere instrumentality rule, nor is identity of directors sufficient.
Document Preview: Parent corporation, joined by subsidiaries, moved for partial summary judgment in suit against them.  The District Court, Johnson, J., held that: (1) genuine issue of material fact precluded summary judgment as to parent corporation's liability under Wyoming law for negligence of subsidiary under theory of retained control, and (2) subsidiary was not mere instrumentality of parent. Motion granted in part and denied in part. See also 708 F.Supp. 1573.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Horowitz v. Schneider Nat., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Subsidiary was not mere instrumentality of parent corporation, even though president of parent owned capital stock of subsidiary, parent handled subsidiary's revenues and paid subsidiary's expenses from them, parent caused subsidiary's incorporation through merger of other companies, and president of subsidiary reported to employee of parent; parent did not itself own stock of subsidiary, parent and subsidiary did not have common officers or directors, parent did not finance subsidiary with its funds, subsidiary did not have grossly inadequate capital, parent did not pay salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary with its funds, subsidiary did not do substantially all its business with parent, papers of parent did not refer to subsidiary as department or division, and subsidiary observed formal legal requirements of incorporation.
Document Preview: Parent corporation, joined by subsidiaries, moved for partial summary judgment in suit against them.  The District Court, Johnson, J., held that: (1) genuine issue of material fact precluded summary judgment as to parent corporation's liability under Wyoming law for negligence of subsidiary under theory of retained control, and (2) subsidiary was not mere instrumentality of parent. Motion granted in part and denied in part. See also 708 F.Supp. 1573.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: El Paso Development Co. v. Berryman
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Generally, court will not disregard corporate fiction and hold corporation liable for obligations of its subsidiary except where it appears that corporate entity of subsidiary is being used as sham to perpetrate fraud, to avoid liability, to avoid effect of statute, or in other exceptional circumstances.
Document Preview: Development company and gas company appealed from adverse judgment of the 148th District Court, Nueces County, Margarito C. Garza, J., in usury case arising out of credit contract for purchase of real estate.  The Court of Appeals, Utter, J., held that: (1) time price differential defense was unavailable, and evidence supported jury's finding that difference between amount of expired cash contract and credit contract represented interest rather than increase in land value; (2) prejudgment interest was not recoverable on usury penalty damages; and (3) whether gas company was alter ego of development company was for jury. Affirmed in part and reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Wilcox v. Kerr-McGee Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced to hold parent corporation liable for damage award against its subsidiary, notwithstanding great deal of control exercised by parent over subsidiary, absent showing that parent failed to observe formalities of separate incorporation or that its control amounted to total domination of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Jones Act seaman employed as driller on offshore rig brought action against his employer, its parent corporation and insurer as result of allegedly work-related wrist injury.  The District Court, Mitchell, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) seaman's disabilities were the direct result of employer's negligence and unseaworthy condition of draw works on rig; (2) seaman was not entitled to punitive damages; and (3) seaman was entitled to $600,000 in compensatory damages, representing past and future wage loss, past and future disability, past and future physical pain and suffering, and past and future loss of consortium by seaman's wife. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Federated Title Insurers, Inc. v. Ward
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: A parent corporation will not be held liable for actions of its subsidiary unless subsidiary is deemed to be a mere instrumentality of the parent.
Document Preview: Former president of employer demanded arbitration and sought to include in proceedings corporate shareholder of employer and parent of corporate shareholder's parent.  The corporate shareholder and parent of the parent requested injunctive relief.  The Circuit Court, Broward County, Stephen R. Booher, J., held that corporate shareholder and parent of parent were required to submit to arbitration because they were parties to employment agreement by way of involvement in stockholder's agreement.  Appeal was taken.  The District Court of Appeal held that corporate shareholder and parent of parent were not bound by arbitration provision. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Federated Title Insurers, Inc. v. Ward
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
