Headnote: For a subsidiary to be considered "mere instrumentality" of parent corporation such that parent corporation can be held liable for actions of subsidiary, there must be control of parent over subsidiary to the degree that subsidiary is a mere instrumentality, parent must have committed fraud or wrongdoing through its subsidiary, and unjust loss or injury to claimant must occur such as when subsidiary is insolvent.
Document Preview: Former president of employer demanded arbitration and sought to include in proceedings corporate shareholder of employer and parent of corporate shareholder's parent.  The corporate shareholder and parent of the parent requested injunctive relief.  The Circuit Court, Broward County, Stephen R. Booher, J., held that corporate shareholder and parent of parent were required to submit to arbitration because they were parties to employment agreement by way of involvement in stockholder's agreement.  Appeal was taken.  The District Court of Appeal held that corporate shareholder and parent of parent were not bound by arbitration provision. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Reflectone, Inc. v. Farrand Optical Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that the parent corporation used the subsidiary as a mere instrumentality and that that was done for an improper purpose.
Document Preview: Plaintiff in action for breach of contract appealed from order of the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, No. 87427CIV T15B, William J. Castagna, J., which granted summary judgment for parent corporation after ordering arbitration as to subsidiary.  The Court of Appeals held that: (1) it was not an abuse of discretion to grant motion for summary judgment prior to discovery; (2) plaintiff was not entitled to respond to prior summary judgment motion in light of its amended complaint where amended complaint presented no genuine issues of material fact; and (3) there was no basis for piercing corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Metropolitan Life Ins. Co. v. La Mansion Hotels & Resorts, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Notwithstanding fact that parent corporation owns entire capital stock of subsidiary corporation, two corporations are separate legal entities, and, whatever may have been motive leading to their separate existence, they can only be regarded as separate entities for purpose of legal proceedings.
Document Preview: The beneficiary under a deed of trust which secured a note representing money lent to construct a hotel, posted a notice setting the hotel's foreclosure sale.  The founder of the hotel chain, the current owner of the hotel and principal debtor under loan documents, and the management company which operated the hotel sued the beneficiary, certain employees of beneficiary, and others, and requested a temporary injunction to enjoin the trustee's sale of the hotel.  The 288th District Court, Bexar County, Carol R. Haberman, J., issued an order temporarily enjoining the trustee's sale, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cadena, C.J., held that: (1) the actions of nonappealing defendants could be considered in determining plaintiffs' right to temporary injunctive relief; (2) wholly owned subsidiaries of beneficiary could be guilty of conspiring with their parent company; and (3) the trial court did not act unreasonably in setting the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Blum v. Airport Terminal Services, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Three.
Headnote: Two different corporations are in eyes of law, two different persons, even if one corporation is sole shareholder of other, and exception exists only when there is such domination and control that controlled corporation has no separate mind, will or existence of its own and is but an alter ego for principal.
Document Preview: Wrongful death action was brought on behalf of copilot who died in airplane crash caused be improper refueling of plane against refueling service, its parent corporation, city, as owner and operator of airport, and owner of aircraft and employer of copilot.  The Circuit Court, St. Louis County, Floyd McBride, J., dismissed owner of aircraft from action, directed verdict in favor of parent corporation of refueling service and entered judgment against city and refueling service on wrongful death claim.  Appeals followed.  The Court of Appeals, Smith, J., held that: (1) wrongful death action could not be maintained against copilot's employer as workers' compensation law provided exclusive remedy; (2) parent corporation of refueling service was not liable for breach of duty committed by its subsidiary as there was no evidence that parent was alter ego of subsidiary; (3) trial court properly permitted jury to consider aggravating circumstances...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Stacey-Rand, Inc. v. J.J. Holman, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, First District.
Headnote: Where corporation is wholly owned subsidiary with identical principal corporate officers, these facts alone might provide sufficient evidence for piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Franchise owners filed breach of contract action against corporation and two individuals associated with the corporation.  The Montgomery Circuit Court, Thomas K. Milligan, J., held the corporation liable on three counts, and submitted to the jury the remaining two counts, which requested the court to pierce the corporate veil and hold the two individuals liable.  The jury held that one individual could be held personally liable but that the other could not.  Corporation and individual appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ratliff, C.J., held that: (1) the trial court did not err in submitting the plaintiff's request to pierce the corporate veil to the jury, and (2) the jury's decision with respect to piercing the corporate veil was neither contrary to law nor inadequately supported by evidence. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Oldenburger v. Del E. Webb Development Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1, Department A.
Headnote: Parent corporation will be responsible for actions of its subsidiary when subsidiary has become mere instrumentality.
Document Preview: Purchasers brought action against builder/vendor to recover damages for breach of contract and breach of duty of good faith and fair dealing.  The Superior Court, Maricopa County, Cause No. C551214, William P. Sargeant, J., granted vendor's motion for summary judgment, and purchasers appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Jacobson, P.J., held that: (1) material issue of fact as to whether purchasers anticipatorily repudiated sales agreement precluded summary judgment in favor of vendor on breach of contract claim; (2) there were no fiduciary duties between vendor and purchasers to justify cause of action for bad faith breach of contract; and (3) dismissal of purchasers' prior action without prejudice did not preclude them from bringing same cause of action subsequently. Affirmed in part, reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Arkwright, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: In determining whether parent's control is pervasive enough for corporate entity of subsidiary to be disregarded, following factors must be considered: intermingling of corporations' properties, accounts and records, employees, and business transactions; failure to observe corporate formalities; inadequate capitalization of subsidiary; enterprises not held out to public as separate entities; policies of subsidiary directed primarily to parent; and parent's control over day-to-day operations of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Environmental Protection Agency brought action against parent and subsidiary, which was plastic film surface coating plant, to obtain injunctive relief and civil penalties under the Clean Air Act.  Parent and subsidiary moved for dismissal and the EPA cross-moved for partial summary judgment.  The District Court, Devine, Chief Judge, held that: (1) facts as alleged established prima facie case of personal jurisdiction over parent; (2) genuine issues of fact, concerning amount of control parent exercised over subsidiary, precluded summary judgment as to parent; (3) consent agreement, which was negotiated between Rhode Island and subsidiary and which incorporated exceptions to Rhode Island's original state implementation plan, had to approved by the EPA as matter of law; and (4) failure of the EPA to approve or disapprove the proposed consent agreement within four months did not bar simultaneous EPA noncompliance enforcement proceedings. So...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Scott v. AZL Resources, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: Only under special circumstances will courts disregard corporate entity to pierce corporate veil, holding individual shareholders or parent corporation liable; this is done where corporation was set up for fraudulent purposes or where to recognize corporation would result in injustice.
Document Preview: Former chairman and chief executive officer of subsidiary corporation brought action against subsidiary, its parent corporation, and other subsidiaries of parent corporation for breach of employment contract.  The District Court of Santa Fe County, Bruce E. Kaufman, D.J., found breach of employment agreement and found each corporation jointly and severally liable under theory of piercing corporate veil, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that there was insufficient showing of improper purpose to warrant piercing corporate veil. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Scott v. AZL Resources, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: Mere control by parent corporation is not enough to warrant piercing corporate veil; some form of moral culpability attributable to parent, such as use of subsidiary to perpetrate fraud, is required.
Document Preview: Former chairman and chief executive officer of subsidiary corporation brought action against subsidiary, its parent corporation, and other subsidiaries of parent corporation for breach of employment contract.  The District Court of Santa Fe County, Bruce E. Kaufman, D.J., found breach of employment agreement and found each corporation jointly and severally liable under theory of piercing corporate veil, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that there was insufficient showing of improper purpose to warrant piercing corporate veil. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Scott v. AZL Resources, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: Undercapitalization of subsidiary is factor to be considered in determining whether there was improper purpose such as would warrant piercing corporate veil; thus, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that financial setup of corporation is sham and causes injustice; mere proof that corporation is now insolvent is insufficient.
Document Preview: Former chairman and chief executive officer of subsidiary corporation brought action against subsidiary, its parent corporation, and other subsidiaries of parent corporation for breach of employment contract.  The District Court of Santa Fe County, Bruce E. Kaufman, D.J., found breach of employment agreement and found each corporation jointly and severally liable under theory of piercing corporate veil, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that there was insufficient showing of improper purpose to warrant piercing corporate veil. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: A/S Apothekernes Laboratorium for Specialpraeparater v. I.M.C. Chemical Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation cannot refuse to recognize binding effect of legal obligation entered into by subsidiary simply because parent did not acquiesce.
Document Preview: In action growing out of unsuccessful negotiations for sale of corporation's biochemicals division, the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, granted summary judgment for corporation on three of five counts against it and certified its dismissal of those counts for immediate appeal. The Court of Appeals, 725 F.2d 1140, dismissed. Following trial on remaining counts, the District Court, Moran, J., held that preliminary oral agreement into which parties entered for sale of corporate assets was not in itself binding contract enforceable by would-be purchaser. Corporations' motion for summary judgment granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Reynolds Metals Co. v. Columbia Gas System, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division. .
Headnote: Although courts may pierce corporate veil to reach parent, such power is to be exercised reluctantly, and burden of establishing basis for such action rests on party asserting claim.
Document Preview: Aluminum producer brought antitrust action against interstate gas transmission line operator and parent company of affiliates and subsidiaries which explore, produce and sell natural gas.  On motion to dismiss by defendants, the District Court, Merhige, J., held that: (1) venue was improper against both defendants; (2) aluminum producer failed to state antitrust claim against parent corporation of natural gas companies; and (3) producer was entitled to maintain antitrust action against operator of interstate gas transmission line. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Federal Deposit Ins. Corp. v. Martinez Almodovar
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Corporate existence will be disregarded when the corporation is an "instrumentality" or "adjunct" of parent, or is merely a "agency" or "alter ego" of parent or individual, or generally when required in the interest of justice.
Document Preview: The FDIC brought an action in its corporate capacity seeking to collect certain assets acquired from receiver of closed bank.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, Chief Judge, held that: (1) FDIC's action on note was not time barred; (2) borrower's former wife was not released from liability she might have had on borrower's indebtedness to bank absent suggestion in letters by and between bank and borrower of intention to substitute or extinguish obligation; (3) family corporations were alter egos of defendant; (4) daughter and son-in-law of a borrower were liable to FDIC for damages; and (5) former wife's transfer of her shares of preferred stock of family corporation to her granddaughters would be rescinded. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Porter v. Beloit Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, parent and subsidiary corporations are recognized as separate entities and, absent exceptional circumstances, corporate veil will be pierced only to avoid fraud or to avoid subversion of justice.
Document Preview: Wholly-owned subsidiary of decedent's employer moved for summary judgment that subsidiary was entitled to exclusivity protection of Mississippi's workers' compensation law in wrongful death action arising out of accident wherein platform installed by subsidiary above paper machine gave way, causing death of decedent when he fell into paper machine. The District Court, Barbour, J., held that wholly owned subsidiary was not the same as decedent's employer under Mississippi law so as to be entitled to invoke protection of exclusivity provision of workers' compensation law. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Environmental Tectonics Corp., Intern. v. W.S. Kirkpatrick & Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: In determining whether the subsidiary is instrumentality of parent corporation so that two should be treated as one, factors to be examined include ownership of subsidiary's stock, identity of officers and directors of corporations, financial arrangements of corporations, responsibility over day-to-day operations of subsidiary and payment of subsidiary's salaries and expenses.
Document Preview: Corporation engaged in manufacture and sale of aircraft equipment and facilities brought action against corporate competitors and individuals, seeking damages in connection with award of contract with government of Nigeria, which was allegedly procured in violation of antitrust and racketeering laws.  Defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Lechner, J., held that: (1) allegations that competitors engaged in mail and wire fraud and committed bribery were insufficient to establish pattern of racketeering activity, and (2) act of state doctrine precluded action. Dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Phoenix Canada Oil Co. Ltd. v. Texaco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Parent corporation will be held liable under Delaware law for activities of subsidiary only if parent dominates those activities.
Document Preview: Canadian corporation brought action against international oil companies for breach of contract and unjust enrichment in connection with contract assigning two oil companies right to develop petroleum concession in Ecuador. The District Court, Roth, J., held that: (1) corporation could not recover under theory of unjust enrichment under Ecuadorian law for future production rights under assignment contract from oil companies who sold their interests to Ecuadorian government at net book value; (2) oil companies were required to pay royalties in accordance with official Ecuadorian government tax reference price in effect at time production was commenced, and not government royalty valuation in effect at time assignment contract was executed; and (3) Canadian corporation was entitled to prejudgment interest from date of service at legal rate of interest in effect in Ecuador during pendency of action. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Phoenix Canada Oil Co. Ltd. v. Texaco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Fact that subsidiary is wholly owned by parent corporation does not alone make subsidiary agent of its parent under Delaware law.
Document Preview: Canadian corporation brought action against international oil companies for breach of contract and unjust enrichment in connection with contract assigning two oil companies right to develop petroleum concession in Ecuador. The District Court, Roth, J., held that: (1) corporation could not recover under theory of unjust enrichment under Ecuadorian law for future production rights under assignment contract from oil companies who sold their interests to Ecuadorian government at net book value; (2) oil companies were required to pay royalties in accordance with official Ecuadorian government tax reference price in effect at time production was commenced, and not government royalty valuation in effect at time assignment contract was executed; and (3) Canadian corporation was entitled to prejudgment interest from date of service at legal rate of interest in effect in Ecuador during pendency of action. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Alvarado Morales v. Digital Equipment Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Mere fact that parent corporation may assert authority to approve or reject plans of its subsidiary does not establish that parent plans, implements, or in any way controls subsidiary's policies.
Document Preview: Employees brought putative class action against nonresident parent corporation for physical and emotional damages arising from work place conditions at wholly owned subsidiary.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, Chief Judge, held that: (1) parent corporation and its directors were not subject to personal jurisdiction under Puerto Rico long-arm statute for acts of wholly owned subsidiary, where subsidiary was separate legal entity; (2) employees' complaint was barred by Puerto Rico Workmens' Accident Compensation Act; and (3) employees and their attorney who alleged that parent corporation tortured and brainwashed employees with concentration camp tactics were liable for sanctions under Rule 11. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Dempsey v. Intercontinental Hotel Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: As a general rule, parent corporation is not liable for acts of subsidiary, but separate legal identities of parent and subsidiary are disregarded if parent intervenes in subsidiary's management so thoroughly as to ignore subsidiary's paraphernalia of incorporation, directors and officers.
Document Preview: Personal injury action was brought against, inter alia, parent corporations of subsidiary which maintained escalator involved in accident.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Evans, J., granted parents' motion for summary judgment, and plaintiff appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that whether parents were liable for acts of subsidiary presented factual question precluding summary judgment in personal injury action where parents' affidavits denying extensive interrelationship lacked probative value. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Federal Deposit Ins. Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: It is appropriate to go behind the corporate entity when subsidiary corporation is shown to be alter ego or business conduit of the parent, but it must be shown that the subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of the parent, that the separate personalities of the subsidiary and parent no longer exist, and that to adhere to the doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: In interpleader action, the United States, former wife of debtor, and others claimed surplus cash proceeds from foreclosure sale of property on which second mortgage had been transferred to trust to secure alimony. The District Court, Harold L. Murphy, J., held that record established that transfer to trust of mortgage, and other transactions, were fraudulent conveyances and that neither trustee nor the wife, as contingent beneficiary of the trust, were subsequent purchasers entitled to the protections of the Georgia innocent purchaser statute. Transaction set aside and claims of former wife denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Federal Deposit Ins. Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Seller's business associate and corporate entity which she used for acquisition of seller's corporation and subsidiaries were alter egos of the seller, for purposes of disregarding the corporate entity, where no stock was ever formally issued to associate in the purchasing entity, seller remained in communication with business even though in prison, and later effectively terminated associate as president of the entity, corporate formalities were not observed, payments were made to associates and relative of seller who did not perform any work for the corporate entity, and seller told other associates that the transaction was a front or sham.
Document Preview: In interpleader action, the United States, former wife of debtor, and others claimed surplus cash proceeds from foreclosure sale of property on which second mortgage had been transferred to trust to secure alimony. The District Court, Harold L. Murphy, J., held that record established that transfer to trust of mortgage, and other transactions, were fraudulent conveyances and that neither trustee nor the wife, as contingent beneficiary of the trust, were subsequent purchasers entitled to the protections of the Georgia innocent purchaser statute. Transaction set aside and claims of former wife denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Duff v. Southern Ry. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: A parent corporation which owns all the stock of a subsidiary corporation is not liable for acts of its subsidiary unless parent so controls operation of subsidiary as to make it a mere adjunct, instrumentality, or alter ego of parent corporation.
Document Preview: Employee of alleged instrumentality of railroad brought action under Federal Employers' Liability Act to recover for injuries allegedly sustained during course of employment.  The Circuit Court, Jefferson County, C. W. Callaway, J., granted railroad's motion for summary judgment, and employee appealed. The Supreme Court, Shores, J., held that question whether employer was an instrumentality of railroad so as to make injured individual an employee of railroad for purposes of Federal Employers Liability Act because railroad owned all of employer's stock and paid salaries of its workers and because employer did over 99 percent of its business with railroad and had a director who was an officer of railroad was a question of fact precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Duff v. Southern Ry. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: A subsidiary is an instrumentality of parent corporation if parent corporation holds all or most of capital stock of subsidiary, finances subsidiary, subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, pays salaries and other expenses or losses of subsidiary, and uses property of subsidiary as its own, both corporations share common directors or officers, and subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, has substantially no business except with parent corporation, is described as a department or division of parent, and has directors or executives who take their orders from parent corporation.
Document Preview: Employee of alleged instrumentality of railroad brought action under Federal Employers' Liability Act to recover for injuries allegedly sustained during course of employment.  The Circuit Court, Jefferson County, C. W. Callaway, J., granted railroad's motion for summary judgment, and employee appealed. The Supreme Court, Shores, J., held that question whether employer was an instrumentality of railroad so as to make injured individual an employee of railroad for purposes of Federal Employers Liability Act because railroad owned all of employer's stock and paid salaries of its workers and because employer did over 99 percent of its business with railroad and had a director who was an officer of railroad was a question of fact precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Najran Co. for General Contracting and Trading v. Fleetwood Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Savannah Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation was alter ego of two subsidiary corporations, where parent controlled operations of subsidiaries, subsidiaries had no employees or office space, parent corporation's money was spent in transporting subsidiaries' employees to and from job site, and stationery of parent and subsidiary were used interchangeably except in dealings with bank which was to distribute proceeds from letters of credit; additionally, where parent corporation profited from subsidiaries' transactions by virtue of substantial favorable publicity that accompanied and followed consummation of contract between subsidiaries and commercial purchaser of mobile homes it would be offensive to public policy to permit parent corporation to maintain fiction of corporate separateness to evade liability.
Document Preview: Commercial purchaser of 600 mobile homes brought action against corporation which manufactured and sold homes and its subsidiaries for resolution of certain issues with respect to arbitration proceedings being conducted before International Chamber of Commerce involving corporation and subsidiaries. Commercial purchaser moved for partial summary judgment, and corporations moved to dismiss.  The District Court, Edenfield, J., held that: (1) purchaser's claim that corporation and its subsidiaries served as alter egos for one another was ripe for issuance of declaratory judgment; (2) three subsidiaries of parent corporation had separate corporate autonomy; (3) corporation and two other subsidiaries were alter egos of one another and purchaser was entitled to pierce corporate veil; (4) purchaser stated cause of action against corporate manufacturer of mobile homes under Magnuson-Moss Act; and (5) whether volume commercial purchaser can...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Miller v. Dixon Industries Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Standards for piercing the corporate veil vary with the circumstances; generally, where a parent-subsidiary relationship is involved, it must be demonstrated that the parent dominated the finances, policies, and practices of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against the employer and its parent corporation for breach of an employment contract.  The Superior Court, Providence County, Lagueux, J., entered judgment in favor of the plaintiff, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Weisberger, J., held that: (1) stock-option benefits that were available to another executive during the term of the plaintiff's employment agreement were additional fringe benefits to which the plaintiff was entitled under his employment contract; (2) for purposes of applying interest-on-judgment statute, plaintiff's claim for breach of employment contract, which was based on the employer's failure to offer him stock-option benefits, accrued on the dates on which he first could have exercised the stock options rather than on the dates the stock options were granted; (3) cash-bonus program offered by the employer to its other executives was an additional fringe benefit as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Miller v. Dixon Industries Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Absent a showing of inequity, fraud, undercapitalization, or domination of the subsidiary by the parent corporation, separate corporate identities must be observed.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against the employer and its parent corporation for breach of an employment contract. The Supreme Court, Weisberger, J., held that: (1) stock-option benefits that were available to another executive during the term of the plaintiff's employment agreement were additional fringe benefits to which the plaintiff was entitled under his employment contract; (2) for purposes of applying interest-on-judgment statute, plaintiff's claim for breach of employment contract, which was based on the employer's failure to offer him stock-option benefits, accrued on the dates on which he first could have exercised the stock options rather than on the dates the stock options were granted; (3) cash-bonus program offered by the employer to its other executives was an additional fringe benefit as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Peoples Energy Corp. v. Illinois Commerce Com'n
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Although dominant characteristic of "holding company" is ownership of securities by which it is possible to control or substantially influence policies and management of one or more operating companies in a particular enterprise, general rule is that holding companies and their subsidiaries are separate legal entities, and such separate corporate entity is not destroyed by fact that holding company, through its stock ownership, has power to control subsidiary.
Document Preview: Holding company which owned 100% of stock of two operating utilities and other plaintiffs brought action for injunctive relief in seeking declaratory judgment that the Public Utilities Commission lacked jurisdiction over proposed reorganization of holding company.  Action was consolidated with separate action filed by the Commission, and various organizations and government entities were permitted to intervene.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, George J. Schaller, J., determined that the Commission lacked jurisdiction, and the Commission appealed.  The Appellate Court, Rizzi, P.J., held that: (1) evidence established that holding company was not a public utility, and thus holding company was not subject to Commission jurisdiction in regard to proposed reorganization unless it was an affiliated interest; (2) proposed reorganization was not a transaction involving a public utility, and thus, the Commission did not have...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Coral Petroleum, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil is appropriate only when separate legal identities of parent and subsidiary have ceased and corporate fiction is utilized to achieve an inequitable result, or to conceal fraud or illegality.
Document Preview: Proponents of proposed plan of reorganization objected to vote of certain contingent claims, and former subsidiary of debtor moved for continuance of confirmation hearing based on administrative expense claim.  The Bankruptcy Court, R.F. Wheless, Jr., Chief Judge, held that: (1) claims of creditors who received allegedly void or voidable preferential transfers would be disallowed for purposes of voting on approval of proposed reorganization plan to extent of claims subject to preference allegations, but, upon surrender to estate of funds transferred, disallowance would be vacated to extent of payment, upon motion; (2) subsidiary had no reasonable expectation that it would ever be compensated by Chapter 11 debtor, its parent corporation, for use of subsidiary's net operating loss by debtor for income tax purposes, and debtor's bookkeeping alone was insufficient to establish contractual duty to compensate former subsidiary for use of losses; and (3)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re S I Acquisition, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Alter ego theory of piercing corporate veil can apply to corporations dominated by affiliate corporations; veil is pierced between affiliated corporations, whether to create enterprise liability for aggregate corporations or to treat parent-subsidiary as if one entity existed.
Document Preview: Debtor in possession filed motion to show cause of why creditor should not be held in contempt for serving interrogatories on debtor's nonbankruptcy codefendants, its parent corporation and principal, in state court action based on piercing the corporate veil theory. The Bankruptcy Court, R. Glen Ayers, Jr., J., held that creditor's action against debtor's parent corporation and principal of both corporations seeking to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory was not property of the bankruptcy estate and was not a claim assertable by debtor or trustee, so that automatic stay provision did not apply to prevent creditor bringing such action from filing and serving interrogatories upon nonbankruptcy codefendants of debtor in action to pierce corporate veil. Motion to show cause denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re S I Acquisition, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Although no single circumstance or factor is generally conclusive on issue of separate existence between parent corporation and its subsidiaries or sister corporations, for purposes of piercing corporate veil, general checklist of circumstances and facts tending to show that one corporation exercised substantial or total domination over subsidiary or affiliate include payment of expenses by one for the other, common officers and/or directors, stock ownership by parent, and failure of subsidiary to maintain formalities of separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: Debtor in possession filed motion to show cause of why creditor should not be held in contempt for serving interrogatories on debtor's nonbankruptcy codefendants, its parent corporation and principal, in state court action based on piercing the corporate veil theory. The Bankruptcy Court, R. Glen Ayers, Jr., J., held that creditor's action against debtor's parent corporation and principal of both corporations seeking to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory was not property of the bankruptcy estate and was not a claim assertable by debtor or trustee, so that automatic stay provision did not apply to prevent creditor bringing such action from filing and serving interrogatories upon nonbankruptcy codefendants of debtor in action to pierce corporate veil. Motion to show cause denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kashfi v. Phibro-Salomon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil between parent and subsidiary corporations, plaintiff must show that subsidiary is "mere instrumentality" of parent, and that subsidiary is being used by parent to commit or conceal a fraud.
Document Preview: Iranian citizen brought action to recover payment for services he claimed to have rendered in Iran for Delaware corporation.  On corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Tenney, J., held that: (1) written personal services contract, under which citizen arranged meetings between corporation and key officials of Iranian Government in connection with oil barter transaction, was between citizen and British subsidiary of corporation; (2) British subsidiary was not subservient to corporation so as to permit piercing of corporate veil between the corporations; (3) citizen's quantum meruit claim for finder's fee for having introduced corporation to Iranian officials was barred by New York six-year limitations period; and (4) contract violated Iranian penal statute and contravened public policy of United States and, thus, was unenforceable. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: 3-D Elec. Co., Inc. v. Barnett Const. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: In determining whether subsidiary is mere adjunct of parent, important factors to consider are whether two file consolidated income tax returns, whether operating capital is financed by parent, extent to which separate books and accounts are kept, whether entities have common departments or businesses, whether they have separate meetings of shareholders and directors, whether officer or director of one corporation is permitted to determine policies of other, and whether there are any facts which indicate that subsidiary is mere conduit.
Document Preview: Texas electrical contractor brought breach of contract action against Tennessee general contractor based on construction work done on motel in Colorado.  The Fourteenth Judicial District Court, Dallas County, John McClellan Marshall, J., sustained Tennessee general contractor's special appearance and dismissed suit for lack of jurisdiction, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Maloney, J., held that: (1) commonality of officers of two general contractors, evidence that they officed in same building, and showing that general contractors were related in some way was not enough to establish degree of control necessary for one general contractor's activities in Texas to be attributable to defendant general contractor; (2) mere fact that same individual owned stock in both general contractors was not enough to hold two corporations acted as one; and (3) defendant general contractor did not have minimum contacts needed to assert personal...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Greenslate v. Tenneco Oil Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Parent and subsidiary companies are separately blended unless the latter exists as a mere tool or front for the parent or the corporation fiction is utilized to achieve an inequitable result or to conceal fraud or illegality.
Document Preview: Subsidiary of charterer sought indemnity from owner pursuant to terms of charter.  The District Court, Mentz, J., held that: (1) subsidiary was third-party beneficiary of indemnity agreement, and (2) where charterer's waiver of the indemnity provision came after subsidiary had asserted its rights and where release was by an agent of the charterer not acting on behalf of the subsidiary, the waiver was ineffective as to the subsidiary. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Conan Properties, Inc. v. Mattel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Among factors court should consider in determining whether to "pierce the corporate veil" are whether parent corporation owns all or most of capital stock of subsidiary, parent and subsidiary corporations have common directors or officers, parent corporation finances subsidiary, parent corporation subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, parent corporation pays salaries and other expenses or losses of subsidiary, and directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary, but take their orders from parent corporation in latter's interest.
Document Preview: In trademark infringement action plaintiff sought leave to file third amended complaint, and defendant sought leave to amend answer to filing counterclaim. The District Court, Kevin Thomas Duffy, J., held that: (1) defendant was entitled to join certain additional counterclaim defendants; (2) defendant sufficiently pled cause of action under Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act; and (3) plaintiff was entitled to file third amended complaint to state RICO cause of action. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Institutional Laundry, Inc. v. Utah State Tax Com'n
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: Corporation, be it parent or subsidiary, has its own legal identity and existence, and common ownership or control does not automatically destroy that separate identity.
Document Preview: Subsidiary corporation brought action challenging sales tax assessment for laundry services provided by it to parent corporation.  The Third District Court, Salt Lake County, Timothy R. Hanson, J., upheld sales tax assessment, and subsidiary appealed.  The Supreme Court held that subsidiary, with separate corporate existence, was liable for sales tax in regard to laundry services provided for parent corporation on nonprofit basis. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: United Nat. Records, Inc. v. MCA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under California law, liability may be imposed upon parent corporation for acts of its subsidiary only where parent controls subsidiary to such a degree as to render the latter a mere instrumentality of the former.
Document Preview: Defendant, a former parent corporation, moved for summary judgment in antitrust action.  The District Court, Bua, J., held that former parent corporation of record and tape producer could not be held liable under California law for any alleged antitrust violations of former subsidiary. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Jon-T Chemicals, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where parent corporation totally dominates and controls subsidiary, operating subsidiary as its business conduit or agent, subsidiary is considered alter ego, or agent, or instrumentality, of parent company, and district court, acting in its equitable capacity, is entitled to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: After obtaining criminal conviction against corporation and individuals in connection with fraudulent misrepresentations to obtain agricultural subsidies under upland cotton program, Government brought action to recover erroneously paid subsidies.  When corporation went into bankruptcy, and further proceedings were stayed, Government sought to hold corporation's parent company liable on ground that subsidiary was its alter ego or agent.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, Halbert O. Woodward, Chief Judge, sitting without jury, found that parent exercised total domination and control over subsidiary and that consequently subsidiary was alter ego of parent, and entered judgment against parent in amount of $4,787,604.20, and parent appealed. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Jon-T Chemicals, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors to be used in determining whether subsidiary is alter ego of its parent include whether parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership, common directors or officers, and common business departments; whether parent and subsidiary filed consolidated financial statements and tax returns; whether parent finances subsidiary; whether parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; whether subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital; whether parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; whether subsidiary receives no business except that given to it by parent; whether parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; whether daily operations of two are kept separate; and whether subsidiary does not observe basic corporate formalities.

Title: U.S. v. Jon-T Chemicals, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where parent establishes subsidiary, undercapitalizes it, and dominates it to such extent that subsidiary is mere conduit for parent's business, parent should not be able to shift risk of loss due to subsidiary's tortious acts to innocent third parties.

Title: U.S. v. Jon-T Chemicals, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Whether corporate formalities were observed is only one factor considered by court in determining if subsidiary is alter ego of parent, it is not determinative.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mesler v. Bragg Management Co.
Court: Supreme Court of California, In Bank.
Headnote: When it is claimed that parent corporation should be liable because it is alter ego of subsidiary, equity commands that corporate wall be breached, yet wall remains and parent is liable through acts of subsidiary but as a separate entity.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought personal injury action.  The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, John A. Shidler, J., granted defendant's motion for summary judgment, and plaintiff appealed.  The Supreme Court, Mosk, J., held that: (1) trial court should have allowed plaintiff to amend pleading to plead alter-ego theory, and (2) plaintiff's settlement with corporation did not bar plaintiff from proceeding against alter ego of corporation. Reversed. Lucas, J., filed a dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Panalpina Welttransport GmBh v. Geosource, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Alter-ego doctrine cannot be used to preserve diversity jurisdiction by ignoring place of incorporation of subsidiary and treating subsidiary as if it were only a citizen of the state of incorporation of the dominant corporation. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1332.
Document Preview: A suit by two alien corporations against two defendants, one of which was a Texas corporation, a subsidiary of which had been incorporated in the Cayman Islands, was dismissed for lack of diversity jurisdiction by the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas at Houston, Gabrielle K. McDonald, J. The Court of Appeals, Politz, Circuit Judge, held that where it was not alleged nor did it appear that the corporate subsidiary of the Texas corporation was incorporated in the Cayman Islands solely for purposes of destroying diversity jurisdiction, and before the court was merely a suit initiated by two alien corporations against two defendants, one of whom was an alien corporation, there was not the required complete diversity of citizenship. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Instrumentality rule is not limited to factual situations or resulting legal analysis afforded by cases dealing with corporate "domination and control" as evidenced in parent-subsidiary or sole dominant shareholder situation.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Rule with regard to piercing corporate veil is broad enough to encompass both situations where there is direct stock ownership of subsidiary corporation by parent, and stock control exercised through mutual shareholder.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Parker v. Bell Asbestos Mines, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In Pennsylvania, it is permissible to disregard corporate formalities only in exceptional circumstances, and the corporate entity being disregarded must be so controlled as to have no "mind" of its own and there must also be a showing that the corporate entity is being used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud or defend crime; test is the same when the corporate relationship involves a parent and subsidiary.
Document Preview: Certain defendants in asbestos litigation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Fullam, J., held that material fact issues existed precluding summary judgment on issue of whether movants, which had never themselves mined, sold or supplied asbestos or asbestos products, could be held liable for plaintiffs' or their decedents' exposure to asbestos in course of employment, precluding summary judgment. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Parker v. Bell Asbestos Mines, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: As indicia of control of a subsidiary by the parent, courts tend to look to such matters as shared officers and directors and the extent of the parent's domination of the subsidiary's policies, practices, and finances, and no one factor is alone dispositive.
Document Preview: Certain defendants in asbestos litigation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Fullam, J., held that material fact issues existed precluding summary judgment on issue of whether movants, which had never themselves mined, sold or supplied asbestos or asbestos products, could be held liable for plaintiffs' or their decedents' exposure to asbestos in course of employment, precluding summary judgment. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Beckwith v. International Mill Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Mere instrumentality test is used to determine extent a parent has assumed control over a subsidiary when parent controls a subsidiary to such a degree that it is but a mere instrumentality of parent, parent is perpetuating a wrong through subsidiary and unjust result will occur if parent is allowed to be shielded by its separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: Age discrimination suits brought by discharged employees against employer's parent corporation and others were consolidated.  The District Court, 595 F.Supp. 166, granted summary judgment in favor of defendants and against one plaintiff on one count.  On defendants' summary judgment motions on remaining counts, the District Court, James McGirr Kelly, J., held that: (1) discharged employees failed to meet their burden of showing that parent corporation was not independent of subsidiary employer and thus parent corporation was not an employer subject to liability of its subsidiary under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act; (2) claims under the Pennsylvania Human Relations Act were barred; and (3) discharged employees failed to state a cause of action under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. Motions granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Nobers v. Crucible, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: A parent company, like any stockholder, is not normally liable for contractual obligations of subsidiary, even if that corporation is its wholly owned subsidiary; such liability occurs only by application of the "alter ego" theory to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Former steel mill supervisors and managers brought action in state court against steel mill's successor in interest and successor's parent corporation for breach of employment contracts, and the action was removed to federal court.  The District Court, Ziegler, J., held that: (1) no contract of employment existed between plaintiffs and parent corporation; (2) plaintiffs' allegations were insufficient to support treatment of parent and subsidiary as alter egos; (3) single wrong was alleged, and thus, there was no separate and independent claim or cause of action on which defendants could rely to support removal despite lack of complete diversity; and (4) ancillary jurisdiction was not available. Motion to remand granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Matter of Midwestern Companies, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Missouri, Southwestern Division.
Headnote: Ordinarily, subsidiary corporations are recognized as entities separate and apart from parent or other allied corporations; it is only after evidentiary demonstration that two entities have same debts and assets or that their affairs are inextricably intertwined that they can be considered as one and accordingly amenable to consolidation in bankruptcy proceedings.
Document Preview: On motion seeking leave to appeal Bankruptcy Court's judgment interlocutory, the Bankruptcy Court, Dennis J. Stewart, J., held that: (1) no evidentiary showing had been made to justify treating property rights of debtors' subsidiaries as property rights of debtor corporations, and (2) even if debtors had successfully raised factual issues concerning jurisdiction over ethanol plants, those plants, for that very reason, remained outside jurisdiction of bankruptcy court for reason that they were outside its actual and constructive possession. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Tennessee Valley Authority v. Exxon Nuclear Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: A parent corporation and a subsidiary are in law separate and distinct entities, and under ordinary circumstances a contract in terms and in name with one corporation cannot be treated as that of both, and a parent corporation will not be liable for the obligations of its subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Supplier of uranium fuel and its parent company appealed from order entered by the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee, Robert L. Taylor, Chief Judge, 570 F.Supp. 462, granting summary judgment in favor of Tennessee Valley Authority, reversing decision of the TVA Board of Contract Appeals, which held TVA liable on contract for one half of parent company's increased costs in producing uranium fuel.  The Court of Appeals, Gilmore, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that parent company was not entitled to compensation for increased production costs in accordance with special conditions contained in contract. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Tennessee Valley Authority v. Exxon Nuclear Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil is generally done to impose liability on parent corporation, and only after a strong showing of such control of the subsidiary by the parent to effectively render the subsidiary a mere instrumentality of parent, and of some fraud connected with use of the parent/subsidiary corporate form.
Document Preview: Supplier of uranium fuel and its parent company appealed from order entered by the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee, Robert L. Taylor, Chief Judge, 570 F.Supp. 462, granting summary judgment in favor of Tennessee Valley Authority, reversing decision of the TVA Board of Contract Appeals, which held TVA liable on contract for one half of parent company's increased costs in producing uranium fuel.  The Court of Appeals, Gilmore, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that parent company was not entitled to compensation for increased production costs in accordance with special conditions contained in contract. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Daugherty
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, the "instrumentality rule" is adopted to pierce the corporate veil where a subsidiary company is a mere instrumentality for the parent company; corporate veil will be pierced where there is parental domination of the finances, policy, and business practices, use of the domination to commit fraud or other wrong, and proximate cause connecting the wrong with injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: Government brought action to assess civil penalties under the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act against two corporations and their individual owners.  Following grant of summary judgment in favor of Government against corporations, cross motions for summary judgment were filed as to individual liability.  The District Court, Hull, J., held that: (1) fact that one corporation was not qualified to do business in Tennessee did not provide basis for holding individual shareholder and officer liable, and (2) there was no basis for piercing the corporate veil or applying the alter ego theory to hold individual shareholders and officers liable for the civil penalties. Judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Vuitch v. Furr
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: Where privilege of transacting business in corporate form granted by legislature is used contrary to law and separate incorporation of subsidiary is consistent only with establishing double layer of insulation for parent corporation and its sole shareholders, total organization should not be allowed to be artificially subdivided for sole purpose of limiting liability.
Document Preview: Patient brought medical malpractice action against physician, physician's wife, and incorporated clinic and hospital owned by physician and wife.  The Superior Court, District of Columbia, Sylvia Bacon, J., denied defendants' motion for directed verdict and entered judgment on jury verdict for patient, and defendant appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Rogers, J., held that: (1) evidence created question for jury as to whether corporate veils of clinic and hospital should be pierced; (2) evidence created question for jury as to physician's wife's individual liability as corporate officer; and (3) evidence created question for jury as to physician's malpractice. Affirmed.

Title: Akzona Inc. v. E.I. Du Pont De Nemours & Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Whether a subsidiary is agent of parent corporation involves a determination that separate corporate identities of subsidiary and parent are a fiction and that subsidiary is, in fact, being operated as a department of parent.

Headnote: Parent corporation must have actual, participatory and total control of subsidiary in order for subsidiary to be found to be agent of parent.

Title: Texas Oil & Gas Corp. v. Hagen
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Mere fact that subsidiary is wholly owned by parent and there is identity of management does not justify disregarding the corporate entity of the subsidiary, but where management and operations are assimilated to the extent that subsidiary is simply a name or a conduit through which parent conducts its business, corporate fiction may be disregarded in order to prevent fraud and injustice.
Document Preview: Royalty owners brought action against gas lessee, based on breach of contract, failure to market gas with good faith and reasonable diligence, and fraud by misrepresentation and concealment.  Judgment for royalty owners was rendered by the 276th District Court, Camp County, William R. Porter, J., and lessee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cornelius, C.J., held that: (1) lessee breached contract by virtue of sham sales transactions with its wholly owned subsidiary, used to deprive owners of their rightful royalties, and purported sale at the wells could therefore be disregarded and true sale taken as being off premises at plants of third parties; (2) data proffered by royalty owners was sufficient to allow the trial court to find market value of the gas, though remand was required to determine whether the market value exceeded the maximum price allowable by the Natural Gas Policy Act; (3) gas lessor's breach of confidential relationship with...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: North American Plastics, Inc. v. Inland Shoe Mfg. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Factors relevant to determining whether corporation constitutes an instrumentality of another are: (1) parent corporations owns all or a majority of the capital stock of the subsidiary; (2) parent and subsidiary corporations have common directors or officers; (3) parent corporation finances the subsidiary; (4) parent corporation subscribes to all the capital stock of the subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) parent corporation pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary has substantially no business except with the parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent corporation; (8) a subsidiary is referred to as such or as a department or division in the papers of the parent corporation and in the statements of its officers; (9) directors or executives of the subsidiary do not act independently in the interests of the subsidiary but take direction from the parent corporation; and (10) formal legal requirements of subsidiary as a separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: Upon defendant's motion to dismiss or for summary judgment in suit seeking to recover balance due from subsidiary on an open account, the District Court, Biggers, J., held that commonality of ownership and officers of parent and subsidiary corporations was not sufficient for application of the piercing doctrine for purposes of establishing long-arm jurisdiction against New York parent corporation. Motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Lucas v. Texas Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Generally, court will not disregard corporate fiction and hold a corporation liable for obligations of its subsidiary except where it appears that the corporate entity of the subsidiary is being used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, to avoid liability, to avoid effect of a statute, or in other exceptional circumstances.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action to recover damages for personal injuries allegedly sustained on construction site when concrete beam which was being lifted from truck fell on plaintiff's leg. Heard, J., rendered judgment against defendants jointly and severally for $2,000,000, and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Campbell, J., held that: (1) evidence introduced by plaintiff was insufficient to pierce corporate veil to hold parent liable for alleged negligence of subsidiary in construction of concrete beam, and (2) from testimony of president of subcontractor, jury was entitled to conclude that advising that only one and a quarter-inch lifting equipment was necessary at job...

Title: Lucas v. Texas Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Financial strength or weakness of a subsidiary is an important consideration in determining whether subsidiary is merely a shell through which parent is conducting its business without taking any of the risks for liabilities incurred.

Title: Nelson v. International Paint Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, question whether parent corporation can be held responsible for subsidiary's acts rests in large part on whether plaintiff seeks to hold parent liable for tort or contract claim.
Document Preview: Plaintiff, who was injured using allegedly defective paint, and his wife, brought products liability action against paint company.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, H.F. Garcia, J., granted company's motion for summary judgment, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Randall, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) there was no evidence that paint company was manufacturer of paint in question; (2) even if paint company's wholly owned subsidiary was selling paint in question as a paint company product, paint company was not liable for plaintiff's injuries as manufacturer; (3) paint company was not estopped from denying liability on basis of mislabeling; and (4) subsidiary was not alter ego of paint company so as to render latter liable to plaintiff. Affirmed.
