Title: U.S. v. ACB Sales & Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Actions of a subsidiary may be attributed to the parent corporation where subsidiary is merely an instrumentality of the parent, indicated by such facts as inadequate capitalization, absence of independent activity, action in the interest of the parent rather than the subsidiary, and failure to observe the legal requirements of separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: The United States brought civil action against debt collectors for penalties under the Federal Trade Commission Act, alleging violations of Federal Trade Commission order and of Fair Debt Collections Practices Act.  The District Court, Hardy, J., held that: (1) letters by debt collectors violated statute and FTC order by threatening legal action where at time letters were sent collectors did not intend to bring such action; (2) individual collectors violated statute and order in telephone conversations with debtors; (3) local agencies who employed individual collectors who violated the order were liable under doctrine of respondeat superior; (4) corporate directors of debt collection companies were liable for employees' violations of order; (5) parent companies were liable for subsidiaries' violations of order and violations of statute; (6) corporate directors were not liable for employees' violations of statute; and (7) Fair...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Securities Industry Ass'n v. Federal Home Loan Bank Bd.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Except in unusual circumstances, courts will not disregard separate identities of parent and its subsidiary, even wholly owned subsidiary.
Document Preview: Securities association which represented securities brokers, dealers, and underwriters brought action against Federal Home Loan Bank Board, seeking declaration of illegality as to its approval of applications by three federal savings and loan associations to permit service corporation owned by them to invest in second corporation formed to offer limited brokerage and investment advisory services.  On cross motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Harold H. Greene, J., held that: (1) securities association had standing to bring action, but (2) service corporation's investment in corporation formed to offer limited brokerage and investment advisory services violated neither Home Owners' Loan Act nor Glass-Steagall Act. Judgment for defendants.

Title: Securities Industry Ass'n v. Federal Home Loan Bank Bd.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Separate identities of parent corporation and its subsidiary will not be disregarded merely because corporate arrangement allows affiliate or subsidiary to engage in activities which affiliate or parent corporation is statutorily prohibited from doing.

Title: Edwards Co., Inc. v. Monogram Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: For purpose of piercing corporate veil, wholly owned subsidiary could not be properly characterized as nothing more than a piece of paper lying in file cabinet where although all directors and officers of subsidiary were directors and officers of parent the subsidiary was infused with $1.8 million cash which was used primarily to acquire stock of another corporation, record was replete with resolutions passed by subsidiary's board of directors, financial records of subsidiary were separate from those of parent and intercompany loans were carefully recorded on books of each, subsidiary's president regularly received and reviewed financial information relating to partnership business and hired and fired general managers, notwithstanding that such actions were not reflected in corporate minutes, although such would have been preferable as would have been recording of other critical decisions.
Document Preview: Creditor of partnership in which wholly owned subsidiary was general partner sued the parent corporation to recover amount due and unpaid for supplies furnished the partnership.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, Walter Ely, J., sitting by designation, rendered judgment against creditor, and it appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 700 F.2d 994, reversed and remanded.  On petition for rehearing, the Court of Appeals, 713 F.2d 139, held that subsidiary was a mere sham entity.  Rehearing en banc was granted, 715 F.2d 157.  The Court of Appeals, en banc, Randall, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Texas law, a showing of fraud or injustice is required to pierce the corporate veil in a contract action and that no such showing was made, and (2) in any event, subsidiary could not be properly characterized as nothing more than a piece of paper lying in a file cabinet. Judgment of District Court affirmed. Alvin B....

Title: Liberty Financial Management Corp. v. Beneficial Data Processing Corp.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division One.
Headnote: Mere fact of ownership and control of subsidiary corporation by parent corporation does not of itself authorize piercing subsidiary corporate veil.
Document Preview: Action for breach of data processing contract and misrepresentation was commenced by subscriber against data processing company.  The Circuit Court, St. Louis County, Franklin Ferriss, J., entered judgment in favor of subscriber, and company appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Stephan, J., held that: (1) trial court erred in removing from jury's consideration the contract's limitation on liability clause; (2) subscriber could properly seek to recover, in a representative capacity, damages caused by company's breach of the contract that were suffered by subscriber's parent corporation and parent's other subsidiaries; (3) financial statement of company's parent should not have been admitted; (4) results of survey, though hearsay, were admissible to provide foundation for expert opinion; (5) affidavit of witness, who testified under oath to truth of affidavit and was available to company for cross-examination, was admissible; (6)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Community Title Co. v. Roosevelt Federal Sav. & Loan Ass'n
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Eight.
Headnote: With regard to tort liability, full ownership is not enough to find a parent corporation identical to its subsidiary.
Document Preview: Title companies brought action for injunctive relief, alleging savings and loan association's tortious interference with the title companies' business relations.  The savings and loan counterclaimed, seeking injunctive relief and alleging tortious interference with mortgage contracts.  The Circuit Court, City of St. Louis, George Adolf, J., denied each claim, and both sides appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Karohl, J., held that: (1) even if title companies proved that savings and loan tortiously interfered with title companies' business relations by rejecting their title policies, injunctive relief requested by title companies was inappropriate, since it would require an undue burden of supervision by state courts and would involve interference with area preempted by federal law; (2) savings and loan failed to prove causal relationship between title company's conduct regarding contracts for deed executed by savings and loan's borrowers and breach...

Title: Community Title Co. v. Roosevelt Federal Sav. & Loan Ass'n
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Eight.
Headnote: Even if a party establishes that a subsidiary is no more than a parent corporation's alter ego, the party must establish that equity requires that the two corporations be treated as one.

Title: Application of Crespo
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term, Part I.
Headnote: Except in exceptional circumstances, the law respects separate corporate identities, even where one corporation may wholly own another or share the same principals.
Document Preview: Proceeding, denoted by injured bus passenger as a motion to amend a notice of claim, ostensibly sought to change in the original notice of claim the designation of the corner at which passenger was allegedly injured.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Special Term, Martin Evans, J., held that: (1) passenger's application to change the corner designation would not be granted upon mere unsubstantiated allegation of no prejudice to public corporations; (2) application, sub silentio, to add borough transit authority as an additional party, whether viewed as a motion or a special proceeding, had to be dismissed; and (3) passenger, who presented no evidence of excusable delay to justify her failure to give reasonable and timely notice of her claim to borough transit authority, would not be entitled to serve late notice of claim upon borough transit authority by placing name of borough transit authority into proposed amended notice of claim. Proceeding...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: NCR Credit Corp. v. Underground Camera, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Corporate disregard doctrine is normally used to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholders, including parent corporations of wholly owned subsidiaries, liable for torts of the corporation, and the doctrine is equitable in nature and should be applied on a case-by-case basis.
Document Preview: In a suit for money allegedly due and unpaid on a computer sales contract, and on various motions, the District Court, Caffrey, Chief Judge, held that: (1) point charging that defendants conspired to defraud plaintiff to its great harm and detriment was insufficient to inform opposing party of nature of the conspiracy charged; (2) case was not appropriate one in which to apply equitable doctrine of corporate disregard; (3) court having declined to treat parent manufacturer and financing subsidiary corporation as same entity, it was found that subsidiary did not waive parent's right to arbitrate by filing suit in federal court, and where outcome of arbitration might dispose of some or all claims outstanding, proceedings in the court between plaintiff buyer and financing subsidiary would also be stayed pending outcome of arbitration; and (4) description of pending case in news weekly was unlikely to interfere with any litigant's right to fair...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Farrell v. Farrell
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Fact that parent corporation operated in the United States and Canada while subsidiary operated outside North America provided no basis for inferring that the subsidiary was a mere agency or instrumentality of the parent. LSA-C.C. arts. 435, 437; LSA-R.S. 12:93, subd. B.
Document Preview: The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Melvin J. Duran, J., found garnishee corporation liable for not withholding funds from garnishor's husband's wages after husband began working for a corporate subsidiary of the garnishee, and the garnishee appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Barry, J., held that absent showing that debtor's employment was not terminated as of date he went to work for garnishee or that garnishee was a mere instrumentality or that employment was changed to avoid the garnishment, liability could not be imposed on the parent. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hoffman v. United Telecommunications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Fact that one corporation may own all stock of another and may further select from its own directors and officers majority of all directors of other corporation, or fact that parent finances subsidiary, is not sufficient, standing alone, to warrant disregard of corporations as separate entities; however, where from all facts and circumstances it is apparent that relationship between parent and its subsidiary is so intimate, parent's control over subsidiary so dominating, and business and assets of two so mingled, that recognition of distinct entity would result in injustice to third-parties, courts will look through legal fiction of separate entity and treat them as justice requires.
Document Preview: Employment discrimination action was filed against plaintiff's former employer, its holding company parent corporation, and 38 other subsidiaries of parent which were located throughout country, and subsidiaries filed motion to dismiss.  The District Court, Saffels, J., held that: (1) prima facie case that constitutional and statutory requirements for assumption of personal jurisdiction over subsidiaries were satisfied; (2) parent corporation exerted such dominion and control over subsidiaries that they were not in reality separate and distinct corporate entities, but one and same under alter ego analysis, so that service of process on chief executive officer of parent was appropriate service on subsidiaries; and (3) venue was proper in district of Kansas. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hoffman v. United Telecommunications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Important factors in determining whether subsidiary is such instrumentality of parent that treating two as one is necessary include: that parent owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary; that parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; that parent corporation finances subsidiary; that parent corporation subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; that subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; that parent corporation pays salaries, expenses, or losses of subsidiary; that subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or assets except those conveyed to it by parent; that subsidiary is referred to by parent as subsidiary or as department or division; that directors of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary; and that formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: Employment discrimination action was filed against plaintiff's former employer, its holding company parent corporation, and 38 other subsidiaries of parent which were located throughout country, and subsidiaries filed motion to dismiss.  The District Court, Saffels, J., held that: (1) prima facie case that constitutional and statutory requirements for assumption of personal jurisdiction over subsidiaries were satisfied; (2) parent corporation exerted such dominion and control over subsidiaries that they were not in reality separate and distinct corporate entities, but one and same under alter ego analysis, so that service of process on chief executive officer of parent was appropriate service on subsidiaries; and (3) venue was proper in district of Kansas. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Hoffman v. United Telecommunications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Where it is shown that decisions made by subsidiary are made under domination of parent, as dictated by mandatory policies and procedures, such showing is sufficient to establish alter ego relationship.
Document Preview: Employment discrimination action was filed against plaintiff's former employer, its holding company parent corporation, and 38 other subsidiaries of parent which were located throughout country, and subsidiaries filed motion to dismiss.  The District Court, Saffels, J., held that: (1) prima facie case that constitutional and statutory requirements for assumption of personal jurisdiction over subsidiaries were satisfied; (2) parent corporation exerted such dominion and control over subsidiaries that they were not in reality separate and distinct corporate entities, but one and same under alter ego analysis, so that service of process on chief executive officer of parent was appropriate service on subsidiaries; and (3) venue was proper in district of Kansas. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hoffman v. United Telecommunications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Parent corporation exerted such dominion and control over subsidiaries that they did not in reality constitute separate and distinct corporate entities, but were one and same under alter ego analysis, and therefore service of process on a chief executive officer of parent was appropriate service on subsidiaries, where parent corporation owned all of majority of capital stock of subsidiaries, several individuals were simultaneously officers of parent and subsidiaries, parent exercised significant financial control over subsidiaries, parent and subsidiaries attempted to project unified public image; and parent's exercise of control over personnel policies of all corporation subsidiaries was so substantial that to treat corporate entities separately would amount to injustice.
Document Preview: Employment discrimination action was filed against plaintiff's former employer, its holding company parent corporation, and 38 other subsidiaries of parent which were located throughout country, and subsidiaries filed motion to dismiss.  The District Court, Saffels, J., held that: (1) prima facie case that constitutional and statutory requirements for assumption of personal jurisdiction over subsidiaries were satisfied; (2) parent corporation exerted such dominion and control over subsidiaries that they were not in reality separate and distinct corporate entities, but one and same under alter ego analysis, so that service of process on chief executive officer of parent was appropriate service on subsidiaries; and (3) venue was proper in district of Kansas. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Sabine Towing & Transp. Co., Inc. v. Merit Ventures, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: In light of other factors indicating corporate domination, whether parent and subsidiary filed consolidated income tax returns becomes factor in proving alter ego relationship. 26 U.S.C.A. § 1501.
Document Preview: In action by tug and barge owners for breach of maritime charter agreements, the District Court, Joe J. Fisher, J., held that: (1) defendant corporation was alter ego of its subsidiary which entered into agreements and thus would be primarily liable for subsidiary's debts; (2) interest charge assessed on late payments would be applied each month that payments remained unpaid; (3) barge owner was entitled to damages sustained as foreseeable consequence of breach, including those for idled personal barge; and (4) pursuant to terms of charter agreement, individual plaintiffs were entitled to reasonable attorney fees. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: North Pacific S.S. Co. v. Pyramid Ventures Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Control of corporation is not equivalent of "mere instrumentality"; to rise to such level, control must amount to total domination of subservient corporation, to extent that subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its own and functions solely to achieve purposes of dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor sought to pierce corporate veil to find others liable for corporate debt.  The District Court, Cassibry, J., held that: (1) in view of controlling parties' shifting of operations among companies as if they were one, interest of justice required piercing of corporate veil to reach dominant corporation; (2) requisite degree of commingling of individual and corporate assets did not exist so as to hold controlling individual personally responsible, and (3) shareholder's redemption of stock constituted partial liquidation and was, under Louisiana law, unlawful distribution of assets. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Edwards Co., Inc. v. Monogram Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where parent corporation creates sham subsidiary corporation which exists only on paper and attempts to erect that corporation between it and its creditors, Texas courts will not give cognizance or effect to subsidiary.
Document Preview: Creditor brought suit attempting to pierce corporate veil of subsidiary in order to hold parent corporation liable for debt owed to creditor.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, Walter Ely, J., sitting by designation, entered judgment in favor of parent and subsidiary, and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, E. Grady Jolly, Circuit Judge, 700 F.2d 994, reversed and remanded, holding that subsidiary had no separate corporate existence.  On petition for rehearing, the Circuit Court, E. Grady Jolly, Circuit Judge, held that subsidiary was mere sham entity with no existence except as piece of paper, and thus could not serve to shield parent corporation. Rehearing denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Edwards Co., Inc. v. Monogram Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, subsidiary corporation acting as general partner in limited partnership can shield parent from liability, if subsidiary exists in more than name only.

Title: Sisk v. General Builders Corp. of Fort Lauderdale, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Criteria to be considered in determining whether subsidiary is mere instrumentality or alter ego of parent corporation listed.
Document Preview: Personal representative of fatally injured worker filed suit against two sister corporations, one a general contractor of record while the other was the owner of record.  Summary final judgment of the Circuit Court, Broward County, Barbara Bridge, J., found that the general contractor of record was immune from suit.  An appeal was taken by the personal representative.  The District Court of Appeal, Hurley, J., held that the personal representative by submitting documents and depositions to support his contention of total domination of the general contractor of record and the owner of record by the corporate parent of both raised genuine issue of material fact concerning corporate status of the defendant subsidiary and availability of immunity. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rose Hall, Ltd. v. Chase Manhattan Overseas Banking Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Disregard of the corporate entity is merely a method to hold the parent liable for the actions of its subsidiary and the theory does not, of itself, confer any additional substantive right on a plaintiff and, hence, if underlying reasons or facts are not actionable against the subsidiary they are likewise not actionable against the parent through the device of ignoring existence of separate corporate entities.
Document Preview: Mortgagor sued lessee of hotel, which was located on mortgaged property, charging that it conspired with mortgagee to sell collateral at unreasonably low price and to prevent mortgagor from suing lessee for alleged interference with more lucrative sale and also sought to hold mortgagee's parent corporation, a federally chartered Edge Act corporation, liable on a control theory. Title: McKibben v. Mohawk Oil Co., Ltd.

Headnote: Parent corporation may be held liable for wrongful conduct of its subsidiary when parent uses separate corporate form to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, commit fraud or defend crime.

Title: State, Dept. of Environmental Protection v. Ventron Corp.

Headnote: Application of principle that courts may pierce corporate veil by finding that subsidiary was mere instrumentality of parent corporation depends on finding that parent so dominated subsidiary that it had no separate existence but was merely conduit for parent.

Title: Ex parte Baker
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: A parent corporation which owns all stock of a subsidiary corporation is not liable for acts of its subsidiary corporation, unless parent corporation so controls operation of subsidiary corporation as to make it a mere adjunct, instrumentality, or alter ego of parent corporation.
Document Preview: Petition for writ of mandamus was brought seeking vacation of judicial order dismissing medical malpractice action against parent corporation of subsidiary hospital corporation and transferring venue as to all other defendants.  The Supreme Court held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that business affairs of subsidiary corporation were conducted in a manner that was appropriate to its separate purposes and functions, without nomination or any excessive degree of control by parent corporation, and that subsidiary corporation could not properly be regarded as alter ego or mere instrumentality of parent corporation, and (2) failure to show awareness of brochure, in which it was alleged that holding out to public fact that corporations were subsidiaries of a parent corporation clothed corporations with apparent authority to act on behalf of parent corporation as agents, belief in what brochure said, or detrimental reliance on brochure precluded finding...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Moffett v. Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in showing that management and operations of subsidiary and parent corporation are so assimilated that subsidiary is simply conduit through which parent conducts its business include whether the two file consolidated income tax returns; whether operating capital is financed by parent or borrowed from other sources; extent to which separate books and accounts are kept; whether they both have common departments of businesses; whether they have separate meetings of shareholders and directors; whether an officer or director of one corporation is permitted to determine policies of the other; and whether there are any other facts which also indicate that subsidiary is a mere conduit.
Document Preview: Products liability action was brought against tire company for damages sustained when pickup truck overturned, allegedly from failure of right rear tire.  The 261st District Court, Travis County, Pete Lowry, J., entered judgment in favor of defendant company, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Brady, J., held that: (1) where plaintiffs' objections to jury charge were based on refusal of trial judge to submit plaintiffs' requested special issues to jury, objections did not preserve error based on such refusal since failure, to submit requests separately from objections to trial court's charge resulted in requests being waived; (2) where there was no endorsement of Refused by the trial court of any of three requested special issues, none were signed officially by trial judge, and there was no formal bill of exceptions in the record, error based on trial court's refusal to submit special issues was not preserved; and (3)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Engel v. Teleprompter Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation is a legal entity separate and apart from its shareholders, notwithstanding fact that its principal shareholder is another corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from a judgment of the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Lucius Desha Bunton, III, J., finding that merger of corporate owner of stock and defendant corporation's wholly owned subsidiary required corporate defendants to honor first-refusal option in cable television corporation's stock subscription agreement.  The Court of Appeals, E. Grady Jolly, Circuit Judge, held that merger of defendant corporation's wholly owned subsidiary with parent corporation of corporate owner of cable television corporation's stock was not a sale, transfer, assignment, or other disposition of that stock within meaning of stock transfer restriction in cable television corporation's stock subscription agreement so as to give remaining shareholders of that corporation right to purchase cable television corporation's stock. Reversed. Jerre S. Williams, Circuit Judge, concurred specially and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Engel v. Teleprompter Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: A parent corporation possesses a separate existence and is treated separately from subsidiary unless there are circumstances justifying disregard of corporate entity.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from a judgment of the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Lucius Desha Bunton, III, J., finding that merger of corporate owner of stock and defendant corporation's wholly owned subsidiary required corporate defendants to honor first-refusal option in cable television corporation's stock subscription agreement.  The Court of Appeals, E. Grady Jolly, Circuit Judge, held that merger of defendant corporation's wholly owned subsidiary with parent corporation of corporate owner of cable television corporation's stock was not a sale, transfer, assignment, or other disposition of that stock within meaning of stock transfer restriction in cable television corporation's stock subscription agreement so as to give remaining shareholders of that corporation right to purchase cable television corporation's stock. Reversed. Jerre S. Williams, Circuit Judge, concurred specially and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Baker v. Caravan Moving Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine, courts will "pierce the corporate veil" and hold a defendant liable when there is control by the parent to such a degree that the subsidiary has become its mere instrumentality.
Document Preview: Pension fund trustees brought suit to satisfy a judgment obtained against corporate judgment debtor for failure to make monthly health and welfare contributions as required by a collective bargaining agreement and multiemployer plan under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. On motion of the trustees for summary judgment to enforce their judgment against a holding company and against the president and sole shareholder of both the holding company and the judgment debtor, the District Court, Aspen, J., held that: (1) corporate judgment debtor's affiliate, which held the only asset of value of the judgment debtor, was liable for the judgment, since both corporations functioned as a common enterprise, and (2) the Illinois Wage Payment Collection Act, insofar as it applies to employer contributions to employee benefit plans, is preempted by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Baker v. Caravan Moving Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine applies to affiliated corporations owned by the same individual, as well as parent/subsidiary corporations.
Document Preview: Pension fund trustees brought suit to satisfy a judgment obtained against corporate judgment debtor for failure to make monthly health and welfare contributions as required by a collective bargaining agreement and multiemployer plan under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. On motion of the trustees for summary judgment to enforce their judgment against a holding company and against the president and sole shareholder of both the holding company and the judgment debtor, the District Court, Aspen, J., held that: (1) corporate judgment debtor's affiliate, which held the only asset of value of the judgment debtor, was liable for the judgment, since both corporations functioned as a common enterprise, and (2) the Illinois Wage Payment Collection Act, insofar as it applies to employer contributions to employee benefit plans, is preempted by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Edwards Co., Inc. v. Monogram Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, a finding of fraud, injustice or some form of bad-faith dealing is not required before a court may pierce corporate veil; it is sufficient to show that subsidiary existed as mere agent or conduit of parent.
Document Preview: Creditor brought suit attempting to pierce corporate veil of subsidiary in order to hold parent corporation liable for debts owed to creditor.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, Walter Ely, J., sitting by designation, rendered judgment in favor of parent and subsidiary, and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, E. Grady Jolly, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Texas law, a finding of fraud, injustice or some form of bad-faith dealing is not required before a court may pierce corporate veil; it is sufficient to show that subsidiary existed as mere agent or conduit of parent, and (2) subsidiary had no separate corporate existence, and therefore creditor was entitled to pierce corporate veil in order to hold parent corporation liable for debts owed creditor. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cole v. City of Las Cruces
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: Generally, a subsidiary and its parent are viewed as independent corporations.
Document Preview: Action was brought against city, natural gas association and construction company to recover for injuries which plaintiff sustained as result of natural gas explosion occurring about ten miles beyond city limits.  The District Court, Dona Ana County, Garnett R. Burks, D.J., entered judgment for defendants, and plaintiff was granted interlocutory appeal.  The Supreme Court, Federici, J., held that: (1) city was a governmental entity under Tort Claims Act; (2) city was not excluded from Act because it was operating natural gas transmission and distribution pipeline outside of the five-mile statutory limit; and (3) although association entered into cooperative services agreement with city, which was approved by the Public Service Commission, the association was a private corporation and not within the Act. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: D.L. Auld Co. v. Park Electrochemical Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to prevail on piercing the corporate veil theory, a plaintiff must establish that a subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of corporation and requires showing that corporation actually dominated subsidiary such that subsidiary had no existence of its own and corporation used corporate existence of subsidiary to perpetrate a fraud, resulting in unjust loss to a claimant.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against parent corporation and subsidiary. The District Court, Glasser, J., held that: (1) facts were insufficient to warrant disregarding corporate entity of subsidiary, and (2) genuine issue of material fact existed with respect to whether parent corporation, primarily through its president, played such a major role in business discussions with plaintiff in attempting to resolve patent dispute that it became an actor directly in transaction and was therefore jointly liable with subsidiary, precluding summary judgment. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Matter of Sbarro Holding, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, where officers and employees of parent corporation exercise control over daily operations of subsidiary corporation and act as true prime movers behind subsidiary's actions and/or where parent corporation conducts business through subsidiary which exists solely to serve parent.
Document Preview: Holding company brought proceeding to stay arbitration on ground that sole agreement which provided for arbitration was between franchisee and franchisor, which was subsidiary of holding company.  The Supreme Court, Kings County, Arthur S. Hirsch, J., 111 Misc.2d 910, 445 N.Y.S.2d 911, denied application to stay arbitration and granted application of franchisees for order joining other related corporations, and holding company and others appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that in light of thorough integration of entire franchising operation, subsidiary corporations of holding company would be required to participate in arbitration. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Maki v. Copper Range Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation must become mere instrumentality of parent before its corporate entity will be disregarded.
Document Preview: Injured employees of subsidiary brought negligence action against parent corporation.  The Circuit Court, Ontonagon County, Donald L. Munro, J., granted summary judgment to parent corporation, and employees appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that evidence was insufficient to show sufficient control by parent of subsidiary to pierce subsidiary's corporate entity. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Maki v. Copper Range Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: To establish cause of action because subsidiary is mere instrumentality of its parents, following must be proved: control by parent to such degree that subsidiary has become its mere instrumentality, fraud or wrong by parent through its subsidiary, and unjust loss or injury to claimant.
Document Preview: Injured employees of subsidiary brought negligence action against parent corporation.  The Circuit Court, Ontonagon County, Donald L. Munro, J., granted summary judgment to parent corporation, and employees appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that evidence was insufficient to show sufficient control by parent of subsidiary to pierce subsidiary's corporate entity. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Williams Plaza, Inc. v. Sedgefield Sportswear Div. of Blue Bell, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Facts that corporations had common ownership and that one was a wholly owned subsidiary of the other were not alone sufficient to allow a jury to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Unsecured creditor of subsidiary corporation brought action to reach the assets of the parent corporation to satisfy the subsidiary's debt on its account with the creditor.  The State Court, Houston County, Paul C. Armitage, J., entered judgment in favor of the creditor, and the parent corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Shulman, P.J., held that, evidence that corporations had common ownership, that one was a subsidiary of the other, that acquisition of the subsidiary corporation may have been in the interest of the parent corporation, and that the two corporations had a joint obligation on a bank note was insufficient to raise a jury question as to whether the corporate veil should be pierced to hold the parent corporation liable for the unsecured debt of the subsidiary corporation, absent proof that funds of the subsidiary corporation were misappropriated or misused. Judgment reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Vantage View, Inc. v. Bali East Development Corp.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: For a parent corporation to be liable for its subsidiary's acts under alter ego or agency theory, parent must exercise control to extent that subsidiary manifests no separate interests of its own and functions solely to achieve purposes of the parent.
Document Preview: Condominium association brought action to recover against developers for breach of implied warranty, negligence and strict liability arising out of construction defects and deficiencies.  The Circuit Court, Broward County, Robert C. Abel, Jr., J., dismissed association's second amended complaint with prejudice, and association appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Glickstein, J., held that: (1) complaint stated cause of action for breach of implied warranty; (2) complaint stated cause of action for negligence in designing, constructing, supervising, inspecting and approving the condominium building and improvements; and (3) complaint, in which it was alleged that defendant parent corporation established defendant subsidiary as a mere instrumentality and a sham and did so to mislead creditors and to avoid liability, stated cause of action against parent for acts of subsidiary. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Sooner Oil & Gas Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Notion of corporate existence of parent and subsidiary or affiliated corporations will not be recognized where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its business conducted in such manner as to make it merely agency, instrumentality, adjunct, or alter ego of another corporation.
Document Preview: Matter was before court on motions for partial summary judgment submitted by trustee in bankruptcy, and by a party that asserted security interest in perforating truck against bank whih asserted similar interest. The Bankruptcy Court, Robert L. Berry, J., held that: (1) bank held security interest in truck; (2) bank's security interest was unperfected; and (3) bank's interest would be subordinate to any security interest held by other party holding security interest if such interest was perfected, or if not, to bankruptcy trustee. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hughey v. Hoffman Rosner Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fifth Division.
Headnote: Holding companies and subsidiaries are separate legal entities.
Document Preview: The Circuit Court, Cook County, Myron Gomberg, J., granted motion to dismiss action for damages sustained in course of plaintiff's employment, and plaintiff appealed.  The Appellate Court, Wilson, J., held that defendant corporation and plaintiff's employer were not separate corporate entities and plaintiff was therefore barred by workmen's compensation statute from bringing instant cause of action. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Eagle Air, Inc. v. Corroon and Black/Dawson and Co. of Alaska, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: In general, subsidiary corporation is considered an entity separate and distinct from its parent.
Document Preview: Suit was brought by insurance broker on promissory note and open account to recover for premiums advanced. The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Sitka, Duane Craske, J., entered judgment against corporations for which premiums had been advanced and against parent corporation and shareholder, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Connor, J., held that: (1) trial court was correct in piercing the corporate veil to hold parent corporation and shareholder jointly and severally liable with other defendants in light of finding that shareholder drained the corporations of their assets; (2) finding that defendants had failed to prove that broker contracted to obtain insurance at the lowest rates in the state was not clearly erroneous; (3) there was no abuse of discretion in award of costs in connection with prejudgment attachment; (4) award of expert witness fees should have been based only on time expert was actually testifying, as opposed to time spent in court observing;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Brock v. Alaska Intern. Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be held liable for conduct of its subsidiary where parent uses corporate form for fraudulent or criminal purpose or where subsidiary is mere instrument of parent.
Document Preview: Employee brought negligence action arising from on-the-job injury. The Superior Court, Fourth Judicial District, Fairbanks, James R. Blair, J., granted summary judgment as to employer's corporate parent, and employee appealed. The Supreme Court held that: (1) employee failed to make showing sufficient to create issue of fact regarding whether corporate parent assumed safety duties or retained control as to employees of employer, and (2) Superior Court did not abuse its discretion in awarding attorney fees to corporate parent. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Chicken Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: While full ownership alone would be insufficient to show that a subsidiary was not independent of its parent, it is a factor highly indicative of control by the parent.
Document Preview: Subsidiaries of a defendant in chicken antitrust litigation filed a motion for clarification, asking the court to rule that they were entitled to recover as members of settlement classes, and asking the court to rule that they had opted out of the class settlement in the event court found them not entitled to class membership because of affiliation with or ownership by their parent.  The District Court, O'Kelley, J., held that three subsidiaries of a defendant were not entitled to participate in the settlement fund, since they were not sufficiently independent of their parent to warrant participation; they shared officers and directors, raising a strong inference of parental domination, and they were completely owned by their parent. Order in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cruttenden v. Mantura
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: A subsidiary and its parent corporation are viewed as independent corporations.
Document Preview: Parent corporation appealed from a judgment of the District Court, Bernalillo County, James A. Maloney, D.J., in favor of judgment creditor in suit to garnish wages of employee of subsidiary corporation. The Supreme Court, Riordan, J., held that evidence that all agreements formerly between parent corporation and overseas entities were assigned to and operated by subsidiary corporation, and that management agreement between parent corporation and Saudi Arabian company was assigned to subsidiary corporation was insufficient to support finding that subsidiary corporation was the alter ego of parent corporation; therefore, judgment creditor could not garnish wages payable by subsidiary corporation to its employee by serving writ of garnishment on parent corporation. Reversed. Payne, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cruttenden v. Mantura
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: To find that a subsidiary is the alter ego of the parent corporation, it must be established that the parent control is so complete as to render the subsidiary an instrumentality of the parent.
Document Preview: Parent corporation appealed from a judgment of the District Court, Bernalillo County, James A. Maloney, D.J., in favor of judgment creditor in suit to garnish wages of employee of subsidiary corporation. The Supreme Court, Riordan, J., held that evidence that all agreements formerly between parent corporation and overseas entities were assigned to and operated by subsidiary corporation, and that management agreement between parent corporation and Saudi Arabian company was assigned to subsidiary corporation was insufficient to support finding that subsidiary corporation was the alter ego of parent corporation; therefore, judgment creditor could not garnish wages payable by subsidiary corporation to its employee by serving writ of garnishment on parent corporation. Reversed. Payne, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cruttenden v. Mantura
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: Some guidelines to be followed in determining if the alter ego theory is appropriate are, whether: parent corporation owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary; the corporations have common directors or officers; parent finances subsidiary; parent subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; parent pays salaries, expenses or losses of subsidiary; subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; subsidiary is referred to as such or as a department or division; directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently but take direction from parent; and formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: Parent corporation appealed from a judgment of the District Court, Bernalillo County, James A. Maloney, D.J., in favor of judgment creditor in suit to garnish wages of employee of subsidiary corporation. The Supreme Court, Riordan, J., held that evidence that all agreements formerly between parent corporation and overseas entities were assigned to and operated by subsidiary corporation, and that management agreement between parent corporation and Saudi Arabian company was assigned to subsidiary corporation was insufficient to support finding that subsidiary corporation was the alter ego of parent corporation; therefore, judgment creditor could not garnish wages payable by subsidiary corporation to its employee by serving writ of garnishment on parent corporation. Reversed. Payne, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Alsted Automotive Warehouse, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E. D. New York, at Westbury.
Headnote: Under New York law, in order to pierce corporate veil, it must be established that subsidiary has no independent existence, but, rather, is in reality, a mere instrumentality or department of parent. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: Trustee for debtor corporation instituted proceedings in which he sought to invalidate creditors' claimed security interest in debtor's inventory based on creditors' alleged failure to properly perfect those interests under New York law. The Bankruptcy Court, Robert John Hall, J., held that debtor, whose warehouse and office was located in certain county, had a place of business in only that county, for purposes of statute providing that if debtor has place of business in only one county, a financing statement had to be filed in such county in order to perfect security interest, in view of fact that, though persons controlling debtor also controlled two other affiliated enterprises, such enterprises were profit motivated and maintained their own inventories, clientele and books and records, and in light of fact that piercing the corporate veil so as to permit a finding that debtor had place of business in more than one county was not warranted. Judgment entered...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Russell v. Birmingham Oxygen Service, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Even though single individual wholly owned both corporations and it was him with whom defendants dealt, it did make a difference whether parent corporation or its wholly owned subsidiary enforced noncompetition agreement with defendants, in that parent corporation, which entered agreement with defendants, must enforce its own rights and privileges. Const. § 240; Code 1975, § 10–2A–20(2).
Document Preview: Suit was brought in which plaintiffs sought damages for breach of contract and injunctive relief. The Circuit Court, Madison County, Thomas N. Younger, J., granted injunction restraining defendants from engaging in respiratory therapy care business or competing with plaintiffs for seven years, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Torbert, C. J., held that: (1) where parent corporation was not engaged in respiratory care business, plaintiffs could not be in competition with it and thus they did not violate contract not to compete; (2) where it was apparent from face of contract that wholly owned subsidiary was not a third-party beneficiary, it had no standing to enforce contract in court; and (3) where there was no act or statement by parent corporation, which did not engage in respiratory care business, evidencing intention to assign noncompete agreement to its wholly owned subsidiary, which did engage in such business, there was no assignment of agreement and thus...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Application of Sbarro Holding, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York.
Headnote: When parent corporation becomes prime mover or actor in business of its subsidiaries, parent will be held liable for conduct of subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Holding company brought proceeding to stay arbitration on ground that the only agreement which provided for arbitration was between franchisees and franchisor, a subsidiary of plaintiff. The Supreme Court, Arthur S. Hirsch, J., held that: (1) contract requiring arbitration of disputes between subsidiary and its franchisees applied to parent, where parent controlled business which had grown out of family business, family members were still active real principals, and funds were transferred from one entity to another, and (2) showing of fraud was not necessary to require parent corporation to submit to arbitration, although it had not signed arbitration executed by subsidiary. Application to stay arbitration denied and application of franchisees for order joining other related corporations granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Application of Sbarro Holding, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York.
Headnote: Where parent corporation's interference in subsidiaries' business is obtrusive, subsidiaries will be deemed mere instrumentality or agent of parent.
Document Preview: Holding company brought proceeding to stay arbitration on ground that the only agreement which provided for arbitration was between franchisees and franchisor, a subsidiary of plaintiff. The Supreme Court, Arthur S. Hirsch, J., held that: (1) contract requiring arbitration of disputes between subsidiary and its franchisees applied to parent, where parent controlled business which had grown out of family business, family members were still active real principals, and funds were transferred from one entity to another, and (2) showing of fraud was not necessary to require parent corporation to submit to arbitration, although it had not signed arbitration executed by subsidiary. Application to stay arbitration denied and application of franchisees for order joining other related corporations granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Pearl-Wick Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Existence of a single shareholder parent corporation is by itself insufficient to support piercing of the parent subsidiary corporate veil; there must be a showing of fraud, misrepresentation, or illegality in their structure.
Document Preview: Debtor commenced adversary proceeding against, among others, sellers and prior owners of its corporate parent to recover the proceeds of a policy on the life of one of its directors and officers. On cross motions for summary judgment, the Bankruptcy Court, Burton R. Lifland, J., held that provision of agreement, in which corporation acquiring all the outstanding common stock of debtor's corporate parent agreed to maintain in force and effect a policy on the life of a director and officer of the debtor payable to the debtor's corporate parent to secure any unpaid balance owed the owners and sellers of debtor's corporate parent, did not constitute an assignment of the policy, which was solely owned by the debtor; thus, the policy was the property of debtor's estate and debtor, the designated beneficiary, was entitled to the proceeds therefrom as debtor in possession. Summary judgment for debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Main Bank of Chicago v. Baker
Court: Supreme Court of Illinois.
Headnote: Doctrine of piercing corporate veil is not limited to parent and subsidiary relationship; separate corporate identities of corporations owned by same parent will likewise be disregarded in appropriate case.
Document Preview: Corporate obligee sued obligors on a note and obligors counterclaimed against a subsidiary of the obligee and against the obligee itself seeking recovery on the lease with the subsidiary. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Walter J. Kowalski, J., rendered judgments on directed verdicts for the obligee and obligors appealed. The Appellate Court, 88 Ill.App.3d 28, 43 Ill.Dec. 681, 410 N.E.2d 681, affirmed in part and reversed in part. Obligors appealed. The Supreme Court, Underwood, J., held that: (1) parol evidence was inadmissible to establish an oral agreement to make payment on the note contingent on the subsidiary's obligations under the lease; (2) the corporate veil could not be pierced so as to hold obligee liable on the lease; (3) a jury question existed as to the amount due under the lease; and (4) the obligee was entitled to recover from obligors the portion of the attorney fees attributable to recovering on the note itself, but not that portion attributable to the balance...

Title: General Finance Corp. v. Skinner
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, First District.
Headnote: Although parent corporation and subsidiary were separate legal entities, only one commonly owned enterprise existed where all business of subsidiary was transmitted and processed by parent, parent issued binding instructions to subsidiary regarding issuance of credit disability insurance to customer, names of parent and subsidiary were used interchangeably on many written particulars mailed and handed to customers, subsidiary frequently represented itself on business letters, advertising and mailings to customers as "[parent]," and general supervisor of subsidiary was salaried executive of parent.
Document Preview: In action against finance corporation for recovery of benefits under credit disability insurance on loan balance, the Superior Court, Vigo County, Charles K. McCrory, J., awarded default judgment in favor of insured, and finance corporation appealed denial of its amended motion for relief from judgment, alleging insufficient service of process. The Court of Appeals, Neal, P. J., held that since subsidiary corporation did not conduct its own business as independent entity, but was maintained as instrument of finance corporation, service of process on registered agent of subsidiary was sufficiently served notice of action. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Baker v. Raymond Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit. Unit A
Headnote: A parent corporation may be held liable for debts of a subsidiary if parent fails to observe formalities of separate incorporation, including adequate capitalization of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Seaman brought action against barge owner to recover for injuries sustained while working on barge. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, Morey L. Sear, J., Judge, awarded seaman compensatory damages, and barge owner appealed. The Court of Appeals, Alvin B. Rubin, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) seaman failed to establish barge owner's liability under borrowed servant doctrine; (2) charge did not provide jury with an adequate understanding of factors to be considered in reaching finding holding barge owner liable as seaman's actual Jones Act employer; (3) fact that seaman's nominal employer had complete possession and control of the barge did not absolve barge owner of liability; (4) even if there had been a bareboat charter to the nominal employer, it would not have absolved barge owner of liability for the barge's unseaworthiness; and (5) new trial was granted on issue of seaman's right to maintenance, cure and wages to end of the voyage. Affirmed...

Title: Southern States Co-op., Inc. v. Dailey
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: Mere showing that one corporation is owned by another or that they share common officers is not a sufficient justification for a court to disregard the separate corporate structure, nor is mutuality of interest, without the countermingling of funds or property interest, or prejudice to creditors, sufficient.
Document Preview: Tax commissioner appealed from the Circuit Court, Kanawha County, Thomas E. McHugh, J., which reversed in part an administrative decision of the State Tax Commissioner, in which assessment of business and occupation tax against agricultural cooperative association was affirmed in part. The Supreme Court of Appeals, McGraw, J., held that: (1) agricultural cooperative association and its affiliated cooperatives were each persons within meaning of definitional section of chapter governing business and occupation tax, and as such gross receipts from transfers between them were subject to business and occupation tax, and (2) transfer of goods from agricultural cooperative association to its local associated cooperatives was an activity engaged in or caused to be engaged in with the object of gain or economic benefit, either direct or indirect, within meaning of business and occupation tax. Reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U. S. v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: As general proposition, corporate entity will not be disregarded, but strict adherence to common-law principle is not required in determination of whether parent should be held liable for acts of its subsidiary, where strict adherence would enable corporate device to be used to circumvent policy of statute.
Document Preview: United States sued American corporation alleging that it, through a wholly owned foreign subsidiary, acquired and held gold in violation of regulations promulgated pursuant to the Gold Act. The District Court, Contie, J., held that: (1) the regulation prohibiting Americans from dealing in gold was applicable extraterritorially; (2) it was not constitutionally impermissible to enforce the penalty provision of the Gold Act through a civil action; (3) the doctrine of fraudulent concealment was not applicable to toll the five-year statute of limitations; (4) the actions of the subsidiary, a Swiss bank, in purchasing and selling gold claims did not result in the actual or constructive transfer of physical custody or possession of any gold and did not violate the regulation; and (5) the corporate entity could not be disregarded so as to hold the American corporation liable for the acts of its subsidiary. Judgment for defendant.

Title: Gulf & Western Corp. v. New York Times Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Parent or affiliated corporation will not be held liable for contractual obligation of subsidiary or affiliate, unless it is exercising complete domination and control in the matter.

Title: In re Washington Medical Center, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Where debtor's subsidiary was incorporated and maintained as separate corporate entity, had its own board of directors and officers, maintained separate books and records, functions were distinct and separate from those of its parent and separate identity was clear to public at large, subsidiary was not mere instrumentality and thus alter ego of debtor notwithstanding that there were instances of some intervention by debtor in affairs of subsidiary. Title: Anderson v. Section 11, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Mere subsidiary status does not permit disregard of corporate entity.
Document Preview: When developer lessor demanded from sublessee substantial increase in lease payments, sublessees brought action against lessor, lessee, and corporation which had acquired all of shares of lessor. The Court of Appeals, Corbett, J., held that: (1) it was within equitable power of trial court to find lease to be ambiguous and to apply equitable principles to determine intent of parties and thereafter fix reasonable sum as rental to be paid; (2) trial court did not err in admitting evidence presented by plaintiffs with respect to new issue and in considering it in reaching its judgment, although new issue was introduced after parties had entered into pretrial order; (3) trial court erred in finding that if corporation, which had acquired shares of lessor acquired title to leased property as contemplated, that would have effect of merging lessor's interest with lessee's interest of master...

Title: Parrillo v. Giroux Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Absent proof that a parent corporation dominates the finances, policies and practices of a subsidiary, courts will generally respect the independent character of each corporation.
Document Preview: Bartender, who was assertedly injured when bottle of grenadine exploded, brought action to recover against manufacturer and its parent company and local distributor on theories of negligence, strict liability, res ipsa loquitur and breach of implied warranty. The Supreme Court, Kelleher, J., held that: (1) failure to instruct jury that doctrine of strict liability was applicable even though manufacturer or distributor might have demonstrated that they used all reasonable care in preparation and distribution of the bottled grenadine was not error; (2) evidence failed to establish that bartender had given manufacturer and the other defendants notice of the...

Title: Soanes v. Baltimore & O. R. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E. D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, facts that there were interlocking directorates and executive officers between subsidiary and parent railroad corporation, that both accepted service at the same address, and that train master of subsidiary used business cards naming parent but not subsidiary did not warrant piercing the corporate veil, particularly in light of fact that subsidiary had its own employees, separate labor agreements, its own tax status, and several corporate directors who were unaffiliated with parent.
Document Preview: In personal injury action arising when child was struck by train, plaintiff moved to strike affirmative defense of failure to join indispensable party. The District Court, Bramwell, J., held that: (1) under New York law, facts that were interlocking directorates and executive officers between subsidiary and parent railroad corporation, that both accepted service at the same address, and that train master of subsidiary used business cards naming parent but not subsidiary did not warrant piercing the corporate veil, particularly in light of fact that subsidiary had its own employees, separate labor agreements, its own tax status, and several corporate directors who were unaffiliated with parent, and (2) thus, since judgment rendered without presence of subsidiary would be inadequate, subsidiary was an indispensable party, and it was necessary that action be dismissed where subsidiary could not be joined without destroying diversity jurisdiction. Motion to strike denied; and dismissed.
