Title: Pasco Intern. (London) Ltd. v. Stenograph Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: In order to hold parent corporation liable for acts of subsidiary, subsidiary must be "mere instrumentality" of parent corporation; determination of vicarious liability of parent depends upon degree of control exercised by parent over subsidiary.
Document Preview: Plaintiff filed action against corporations with which plaintiff's former chief engineer entered into an exclusive agency agreement and with which the chief engineer allegedly conspired to induce a foreign government to bypass plaintiff and deal directly with defendants. Defendants filed a motion to dismiss based on plaintiff's failure to sue an allegedly indispensable party, the former chief engineer. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division, Joel M. Flaum, J., dismissed the action, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that plaintiff's former chief engineer was not an indispensable party to a suit brought against corporations where the possibility of injunctive relief did not result in any impermissible prejudice to the chief engineer, the possibility of monetary relief could not prejudice the chief engineer, any prejudicial impact of the suit upon the engineer's business reputation in the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: FMC Finance Corp. v. Murphree
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate disregard doctrine may apply to attempts to make the subsidiary liable for the parent's acts.
Document Preview: Suit was brought to enforce an unconditional personal guaranty contract of payment which covered payment of monies that a closely held Georgia corporation owed to plaintiff under an equipment lease agreement. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi, at Clarksdale, Orma R. Smith, J., directed a verdict for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Sam D. Johnson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) warranty disclaimer language was conspicuous and thus validly negated any implied warranties on the part of plaintiff; (2) warranty disclaimer clause was not unconscionable; and (3) there was sufficient evidence to create a jury question on the corporate disregard issue raised by defendants, who attempted to assert against plaintiff the affirmative defense of its parent corporation's breach of manufacturer's warranty of repair or replacement of the leased buses. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: FMC Finance Corp. v. Murphree
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: To find a parent corporation liable for acts of its subsidiary, it must be shown that there is control by the parent to such degree that the subsidiary has become a mere "alter ego" or "instrumentality."
Document Preview: Suit was brought to enforce an unconditional personal guaranty contract of payment which covered payment of monies that a closely held Georgia corporation owed to plaintiff under an equipment lease agreement. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi, at Clarksdale, Orma R. Smith, J., directed a verdict for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Sam D. Johnson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) warranty disclaimer language was conspicuous and thus validly negated any implied warranties on the part of plaintiff; (2) warranty disclaimer clause was not unconscionable; and (3) there was sufficient evidence to create a jury question on the corporate disregard issue raised by defendants, who attempted to assert against plaintiff the affirmative defense of its parent corporation's breach of manufacturer's warranty of repair or replacement of the leased buses. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Northern Illinois Gas Co. v. Total Energy Leasing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Each of the three Turner elements must be established before the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil will be imposed, i. e., sufficient control by the parent, fraud or wrongdoing by the parent through the subsidiary and unjust loss or injury to claimant.
Document Preview: Utility which had furnished natural gas to subsidiary sued parent corporation seeking to pierce the corporate veil. Utility moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Flaum, J., held that: (1) applicable Turner factors were present in proper combination to conclude that subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of parent, and (2) the two remaining elements necessary to pierce corporate veil were present, i. e., fraud or wrong by the parent through the subsidiary in stripping subsidiary of its assets and unjust loss or injury to the utility in view of insolvence of the subsidiary. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Northern Illinois Gas Co. v. Total Energy Leasing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Fact that subsidiary's capital was established by original incorporators was not determinative of whether defendant parent corporation exercised requisite amount of control over the subsidiary for purpose of piercing the corporate veil; parent could not rely on original capitalization where it acquires subsidiary nine years after the latter's incorporation and subsidiary's already poor financial position continued to decline after the acquisition.
Document Preview: Utility which had furnished natural gas to subsidiary sued parent corporation seeking to pierce the corporate veil. Utility moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Flaum, J., held that: (1) applicable Turner factors were present in proper combination to conclude that subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of parent, and (2) the two remaining elements necessary to pierce corporate veil were present, i. e., fraud or wrong by the parent through the subsidiary in stripping subsidiary of its assets and unjust loss or injury to the utility in view of insolvence of the subsidiary. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Northern Illinois Gas Co. v. Total Energy Leasing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Each of the 11 Turner factors determinative of whether a parent corporation has exercised requisite amount of control over subsidiary to be liable for the latter's obligations need not be met, but, rather, presence of such factors in the proper combination is controlling.
Document Preview: Utility which had furnished natural gas to subsidiary sued parent corporation seeking to pierce the corporate veil. Utility moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Flaum, J., held that: (1) applicable Turner factors were present in proper combination to conclude that subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of parent, and (2) the two remaining elements necessary to pierce corporate veil were present, i. e., fraud or wrong by the parent through the subsidiary in stripping subsidiary of its assets and unjust loss or injury to the utility in view of insolvence of the subsidiary. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Matter of Typhoon Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E. D. New York.
Headnote: Under the "instrumentality rule," used as a guide in determining whether it is appropriate to disregard the corporate form, court looks to whether there is control by the parent to such a degree that the subsidiary has become its mere instrumentality, whether there is fraud or wrong by the parent to its subsidiary, and whether there is unjust loss or injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: Trustee objected to claim of district director of Internal Revenue Service for priority claim for unpaid federal insurance contributions, withholding, and unemployment taxes. The Bankruptcy Court, Boris Radoyevich, J., held that: (1) court would pierce the corporate veil and hold bankrupt liable for tax obligations of its affiliates, but (2) three-year time limit on taxes began to run at the end of the quarter or month in which the FICA and FUTA taxes were due, not from the following April 15 when the period for assessment began to run. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Matter of Typhoon Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E. D. New York.
Headnote: Under the "alter ego theory," corporate veil may be pierced if the subsidiary does not trade under its own name, the subsidiary does not have separate assets, creditors or obligations, the subsidiary has not held itself out to the general public and trade creditors as a business separate and distinct from parent, there has been a commingling of assets between subsidiary and parent, the subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, the parent pays the debts of the subsidiary, the subsidiary's source of business is dependent upon that of its parent, and the subsidiary disregards its separate and independent corporate entity.
Document Preview: Trustee objected to claim of district director of Internal Revenue Service for priority claim for unpaid federal insurance contributions, withholding, and unemployment taxes. The Bankruptcy Court, Boris Radoyevich, J., held that: (1) court would pierce the corporate veil and hold bankrupt liable for tax obligations of its affiliates, but (2) three-year time limit on taxes began to run at the end of the quarter or month in which the FICA and FUTA taxes were due, not from the following April 15 when the period for assessment began to run. Order accordingly.

Headnote: Texas, like Kentucky, follows general rule of corporation law that, absent exceptional circumstances, parent and subsidiary corporations shall be recognized as separate entities, and same is true, under Texas law, even where parent corporation owns all stock of subsidiary or has same directors or officers or exercises control over subsidiary.

Title: Luckett v. Bethlehem Steel Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors determinative of whether a subsidiary is a mere alter ego of a parent corporation include whether parent owns all the stock, commonality of directors and officers, whether parent finances subsidiary, whether parent causes subsidiary's incorporation, whether subsidiary is inadequately capitalized, who pays salaries or expenses, whether subsidiary has business dealings with others, independence of officers and directors, compliance with legal requirements such as record keeping, whether subsidiary has full board of directors and whether subsidiary has any assets other than those transferred by the parent.
Document Preview: Action was brought against United States corporation and its subsidiary, a Singapore corporation, to recover for injuries which plaintiff sustained when crane cable snapped on board a drilling rig on which he was employed in Singapore. The United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, Ralph G. Thompson, J., granted summary judgment as to parent and granted subsidiary's motion to dismiss, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Holloway, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) although parent furnished management team for subsidiary it could not be said that subsidiary was a mere alter ego of the parent so as to hold parent liable for any negligence of subsidiary employee, especially absent showing of fraud or inequitable conduct in use of separate corporate structures; (2) material fact issue existed as to liability of parent based on doctrines of respondeat superior and loaned servant; and (3) in personam jurisdiction could not be asserted over subsidiary...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Luckett v. Bethlehem Steel Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oklahoma law, it is necessary to establish something more than ownership of virtually all of the subsidiary stock by the parent or identity of directors in order to treat the parent and subsidiary as one.
Document Preview: Action was brought against United States corporation and its subsidiary, a Singapore corporation, to recover for injuries which plaintiff sustained when crane cable snapped on board a drilling rig on which he was employed in Singapore. The United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, Ralph G. Thompson, J., granted summary judgment as to parent and granted subsidiary's motion to dismiss, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Holloway, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) although parent furnished management team for subsidiary it could not be said that subsidiary was a mere alter ego of the parent so as to hold parent liable for any negligence of subsidiary employee, especially absent showing of fraud or inequitable conduct in use of separate corporate structures; (2) material fact issue existed as to liability of parent based on doctrines of respondeat superior and loaned servant; and (3) in personam jurisdiction could not be asserted over subsidiary...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Woodyard v. Arkansas Diversified Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: Courts will ignore corporate form of subsidiary where fairness demands it; usually, this will be where it is necessary to prevent wrongdoing and where subsidiary is mere tool of parent.
Document Preview: Insurance commissioner appealed from judgment of the Circuit Court, Pulaski County, Third Division, Tom F. Digby, J., reversing his decision to deny to wholly owned subsidiary of Blue Cross a certificate which would grant authority to such subsidiary to sell group life insurance to Blue Cross and Blue Shield subscriber groups. The Supreme Court, Hickman, J., held that: (1) substantial evidence supported insurance commissioner's ruling that Blue Cross, a tax-exempt, nonprofit corporation enjoying financial advantage over conventional insurers, could not market its own life insurance policies through wholly owned subsidiary, and (2) commissioner did not err in piercing corporate veil of subsidiary. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Matter of Maple Contractors, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Probate Part, Essex County.
Headnote: Parent and its wholly owned subsidiary are two separate and distinct legal entities.
Document Preview: Alleged secured creditor made application to restrain sale of personal property of creditor. The Superior Court, Law Division, Probate Part, Essex County, Villanueva, J. S. C., held that secured creditor which had filed a financing statement which was deficient for lack of debtor's signature did not perfect its security interest even if it did have a valid security agreement; furthermore, creditor's action of attaching to financing statement alleged security agreement with creditor's parent corporation which was signed by debtor was no substitute for required signature of debtor. Sale confirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: A. W. Fiur Co., Inc. v. Ataka & Co., Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation over which parent corporation exercises control in everyday operations may be deemed instrumentality or agent of parent; determinative factor is whether subsidiary corporation is dummy for parent.
Document Preview: Suit was brought by a firm acting as a sales agent or representative for the sale of fabrics manufactured by a Japanese corporation, alleging that the Japanese corporation had breached a sales agency contract. The Supreme Court, New York County, Louis Grossman, J., entered summary judgment against plaintiff, and it appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, Fein, J., held, inter alia, that triable issues of fact remained with respect to whether the Japanese corporation could be held liable for a contract technically executed by its American subsidiary. Modified and affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Beary v. Norton-Simon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Although Delaware parent corporation owned all of stock in Pennsylvania subsidiary and received half of the earnings, there was no basis for applying the alter ego theory and ignoring the corporate structure; thus, Pennsylvania long-arm statute did not authorize the exercise of jurisdiction over Delaware parent on basis of its subsidiary's activities. 42 Pa.C.S.A. § 5301 et seq.
Document Preview: Delaware corporation, which was named as a defendant in an action to recover for injuries sustained in an accident which occurred on premises of its Pennsylvania subsidiary, moved for summary judgment on ground that court lacked in personam jurisdiction. The District Court, Knox, J., held that: (1) although Delaware parent corporation owned all of stock in Pennsylvania subsidiary and received half of earnings, there was no basis for treating the subsidiary as an agent of the parent, which directed the subsidiary's activities to some extent but which did not control the day to day operations, so as to permit exercise of in personam jurisdiction under Pennsylvania long-arm statute, and (2) there was no basis for treating subsidiary as an alter ego of parent so as to permit exercise of long-arm jurisdiction. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Dernick v. Bralorne Resources Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: To justify piercing corporate veil, it was not enough to allege that parent company owned all stock of its subsidiary and even dominated its affairs, but, rather, plaintiff had to allege that such domination was for purpose of defrauding third party, avoiding liability or defeating public convenience, and absent such allegation, federal district court was bound to respect separate identity of subsidiary which had been lawfully incorporated and had been functioning, at least in formal sense, as distinct corporation. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1332(a).
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action to recover moneys allegedly due him for his efforts in locating a company to be purchased by corporate defendant. The District Court, McDonald, J., held that: (1) in order to justify piercing corporate veil for purpose of establishing diversity jurisdiction, it was not enough to allege that parent company owned all stock of its subsidiary and even dominated its affairs, but, rather, plaintiff had to allege that such domination was for purpose of defrauding third party, avoiding liability or defeating public convenience, and absent such allegation, court was bound to respect separate identity of subsidiary which had been lawfully incorporated and had been functioning, at least in formal sense, as distinct corporation, and (2) under circumstances, subsidiary was indispensable party, which necessitated dismissal, since there was no diversity between plaintiff and subsidiary. Corporate defendant's motion for summary judgment granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: United Rubber, Cork, Linoleum and Plastic Workers of America, AFL-CIO v. Great Am. Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: Separate corporations will not generally be regarded as a single entity so as to hold one responsible for acts and obligations of other even where parent has ability to control wholly owned subsidiary.
Document Preview: Action was instituted for alleged violations of collective bargaining agreement. The District Court, Kevin Thomas Duffy, J., held that: (1) subsidiary corporation as employer breached bargaining agreement and, hence, was liable to members of union for its obligations under agreement with respect to 1966 vacation pay totaling $52,000, 1967 vacation pay totaling $55,803.20, 1966 and 1967 supplemental unemployment benefits totaling $12,400.72, hospitalization benefits totaling $310,000, medical insurance totaling $2,652, pension funds totaling $49,427.02, and pension claims, and (2) corporate veil of subsidiary corporation as employer was simply being pierced and assets of parent corporation and its other subsidiaries applied to satisfy employer's obligations to members of union under bargaining agreement where, aside from facts and circumstances establishing a complete domination of parent and its other subsidiaries over corporate employer, parent and its other subsidiaries, by...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: United Rubber, Cork, Linoleum and Plastic Workers of America, AFL-CIO v. Great Am. Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: It is only where parent chooses to exploit its dominant position over its subsidiary and becomes so involved and intertwined in its activities that a court will disregard corporate formalities and hold parent liable for obligations of its subsidiary.
Document Preview: Action was instituted for alleged violations of collective bargaining agreement. The District Court, Kevin Thomas Duffy, J., held that: (1) subsidiary corporation as employer breached bargaining agreement and, hence, was liable to members of union for its obligations under agreement with respect to 1966 vacation pay totaling $52,000, 1967 vacation pay totaling $55,803.20, 1966 and 1967 supplemental unemployment benefits totaling $12,400.72, hospitalization benefits totaling $310,000, medical insurance totaling $2,652, pension funds totaling $49,427.02, and pension claims, and (2) corporate veil of subsidiary corporation as employer was simply being pierced and assets of parent corporation and its other subsidiaries applied to satisfy employer's obligations to members of union under bargaining agreement where, aside from facts and circumstances establishing a complete domination of parent and its other subsidiaries over corporate employer, parent and its other subsidiaries, by...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bonanza Hotel Gift Shop, Inc. v. Bonanza No. 2
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Mere showing that one corporation is owned by another, or that the two share interlocking officers or directors, is insufficient to support a finding of alter ego; it must further be shown that the subsidiary corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs are so conducted that it is in fact a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation; nor is mere mutuality of interests sufficient to make such a showing without evidence of a commingling of funds or property interests, or of prejudice to creditors.
Document Preview: In action seeking to hold parent corporations liable for obligations of subsidiary, the Eighth Judicial District Court, Clark County, Michael J. Wendell, J., entered judgment in favor of defendants, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Mowbray, C. J., held that doctrine of alter ego was not applicable to hold corporations liable for obligations of their subsidiary where separate corporate books and accounts were kept, separate directors' meetings were held with full corporate formalities observed, corporations had independent headquarters and separate business responsibilities and operations, and there was no showing that the parent companies had in any way impaired the assets of the subsidiary. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Florida Shade Tobacco Growers, Inc. v. Duncan
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Although great caution should be exercised in disregarding or going behind corporate entity, it may be done when subsidiary is shown to be alter ego or business conduit of parent; however, it must appear that subsidiary is mere instrumentality of parent, that separate personalities of corporation and owners no longer exist, and to adhere to doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: Farmer brought action to recover for damages allegedly done to his unharvested soybean crop by uninvited cows owned by corporation. The Grady Superior Court, Culpepper, J., entered judgment against corporation which owned cows and its parent corporation, and parent corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, Banke, P. J., held that where there was no evidence that subsidiary corporation was a sham, or that it was used to defeat a public convenience, to justify wrong, protect fraud, defend crime, or any other reason which in equity and good conscience would justify disregard of its separate entity, trial court erred in denying motion to dismiss parent corporation as defendant. Judgment affirmed as to subsidiary corporation; judgment reversed as to parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Florida Shade Tobacco Growers, Inc. v. Duncan
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Where there was no evidence that subsidiary corporation was a sham, or that it was used to defeat a public convenience, to justify wrong, protect fraud, defend crime, or any other reason which in equity and good conscience would justify disregard of its separate entity, trial court erred in denying motion to dismiss parent corporation as defendant in property damage suit arising out of activities of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Farmer brought action to recover for damages allegedly done to his unharvested soybean crop by uninvited cows owned by corporation. The Grady Superior Court, Culpepper, J., entered judgment against corporation which owned cows and its parent corporation, and parent corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, Banke, P. J., held that where there was no evidence that subsidiary corporation was a sham, or that it was used to defeat a public convenience, to justify wrong, protect fraud, defend crime, or any other reason which in equity and good conscience would justify disregard of its separate entity, trial court erred in denying motion to dismiss parent corporation as defendant. Judgment affirmed as to subsidiary corporation; judgment reversed as to parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Continental Bankers Life Ins. Co. of the South v. Bank of Alamo
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee.
Headnote: Generally, corporate entities will be recognized as separate and distinct from their stockholders and in order to disregard the corporate entities requires, in case of parent and subsidiary, more than showing that they have similar corporate names and locations and exercise of dominion through common officers and directors.
Document Preview: Life insurance corporation brought action against bank for payment of certificate of deposit deposited in connection with loan to former parent of the life insurance corporation. The Equity Court, Crockett County, Robert S. Thomas, Chancellor, entered judgment in favor of the bank, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals affirmed and remanded, and certiorari was sought. The Supreme Court, Fones, J., held that: (1) there was no material evidence to support finding that the certificate represented additional security for the loan, and thus bank had no security interest in the certificate, where assertion that it was understanding of the bank that the certificate was security for the loan was incompetent and inadmissible, and (2) the control that the former parent exercised over the insurance corporation was not used to commit fraud, misrepresentation or dishonest or unjust act upon the bank in transactions involved and the bank could not invoke...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Continental Bankers Life Ins. Co. of the South v. Bank of Alamo
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee.
Headnote: For subsidiary's action to create liability for parent corporation requires proof: that the parent corporation, at time of transaction complained of, exercises complete dominion over its subsidiary, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction under attack, so that the corporate entity, as to that transaction, had no separate mind, will or existence of its own; that such control must have been used to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of third parties' rights; that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: Life insurance corporation brought action against bank for payment of certificate of deposit deposited in connection with loan to former parent of the life insurance corporation. The Equity Court, Crockett County, Robert S. Thomas, Chancellor, entered judgment in favor of the bank, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals affirmed and remanded, and certiorari was sought. The Supreme Court, Fones, J., held that: (1) there was no material evidence to support finding that the certificate represented additional security for the loan, and thus bank had no security interest in the certificate, where assertion that it was understanding of the bank that the certificate was security for the loan was incompetent and inadmissible, and (2) the control that the former parent exercised over the insurance corporation was not used to commit fraud, misrepresentation or dishonest or unjust act upon the bank in transactions involved and the bank could not invoke...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Murphy Tugboat Co. v. Shipowners & Merchants Towboat Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N. D. California.
Headnote: A parent corporation is not liable for its subsidiaries' acts simply because the parent owns all the stock of the subsidiaries and shares common officers and directors.
Document Preview: A Sherman Act suit was brought against San Francisco Bay tugboat companies by a former competitor. Following a jury verdict for plaintiff, defendants moved for judgment notwithstanding that verdict or, alternatively, for a new trial. The District Court, William W Schwarzer, J., held, inter alia, that: (1) there was, given the 70 to 80 percent size of defendants' market share, substantial evidence to sustain a finding that defendants together possessed the power to exclude competition or control prices and hence monopoly power in the relevant market; further, there was substantial evidence that defendants willfully acquired or maintained that power, thus justifying the jury's verdict for plaintiff on the monopolization issue; (2) evidence of defendants' practice of refusing to work on vessels with competitors, coupled with other evidence raising an inference of intent to exclude competitors, was sufficient to support the jury verdict of an attempt to monopolize; (3) individual who...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Else v. Inflight Cinema Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Although parent corporation is not generally liable for acts of its subsidiary, it may become liable where subsidiary acts as its mere instrumentality; whether subsidiary acted as instrumentality of its parent is question of fact.
Document Preview: Pennsylvania resident franchisee sued New York corporate franchisor and its parent corporation, alleging fraudulent misrepresentation and inducement to purchase the franchise in violation of the California Franchise Investment Law. On the defendant's motion to dismiss, the District Court, Cohill, J., held that: (1) the franchisee would be allowed to go forward with his proof where it did not appear a certainty that he would not be entitled to relief under any state of facts offered in support of his claims; (2) Pennsylvania long-arm statute conferred personal jurisdiction over both defendants; (3) an arbitration clause in the franchise agreement merely limited the scope of federal court review rather than depriving the district court of its constitutionally based diversity jurisdiction, and (4) the claims were subject to arbitration. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Boggs v. Blue Diamond Coal Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, owners may elect to divide their business into parent and subsidiary corporations entitled to respect as separate legal entities in absence of improper purposes.
Document Preview: Widows of coal miners who worked for subsidiary corporation and were killed in mining disaster brought wrongful death action against parent corporation. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky, Howard David Hermansdorfer, J., ruled that parent corporation was exempt from tort liability under Kentucky's Workmen's Compensation Act, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Merritt, Circuit Judge, held that under Kentucky's Workmen's Compensation Act a parent corporation is not immune from tort liability to its subsidiary employees for its own, independent acts of negligence. Reversed and remanded. John W. Peck, Senior Circuit Judge, dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Service Iron Foundry, Inc. v. M. A. Bell Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: A holding or parent company has a separate corporate existence and is treated separately from its subsidiary in absence of circumstances justifying disregard of corporate entity.
Document Preview: Plaintiff buyer brought action against manufacturer and its selling agent to recover damages for breach of warranty arising from purchase of a pollution control unit for use at its foundry. The Sedgwick District Court, B. Mack Bryant, J., directed verdict in favor of defendant selling agent and entered judgment against defendant manufacturer, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Abbott, J., held that: (1) trial court erred in excluding evidence tending to show an independent warranty by selling agent; (2) evidence as to alleged independent warranty by selling agent and as to whether selling agent was alter ego of manufacturer was sufficient for jury, and (3) trial court correctly instructed jury concerning damages which included damages for special circumstances as well as incidental and consequential damages. Judgment affirmed as to plaintiff and reversed as to defendant selling agent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Walker v. Newgent
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, fact that parent corporation owns 100 percent of subsidiary's stock is not sufficient to fuse subsidiary into parent corporation for purpose of establishing an agency relationship.
Document Preview: A passenger injured in an automobile collision in Germany brought an action, inter alia, against manufacturer of automobile, alleging that vehicle was defectively manufactured and unsafe and that such defects were proximate cause of the injuries. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, John V. Singleton, Jr., J., 442 F.Supp. 38, dismissed case, and passenger appealed. The Court of Appeals, Gee, Circuit Judge, held that the manufacturer, which was a wholly owned German subsidiary of an American automobile manufacturer doing business in the district, was not amenable to service of process under the Texas long-arm statute. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Energy Reserves Group, Inc. v. Superior Oil Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining when a subsidiary corporation and its parent or owner may be treated as one for purposes of liability include undercapitalization, misuse or intermingling of corporate funds, absence of separate corporate record and the use of corporation as facade for operations of dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: In a diversity declaratory judgment action, nonresident corporation that had been served in Texas pursuant to the Kansas long-arm statute moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction. The District Court, Theis, Chief Judge, held that: (1) personal jurisdiction over the nonresident corporation, which was a wholly owned subsidiary of a corporation that was doing business in Kansas and which had transacted business in Kansas through the instrumentality of its parent corporation and had contracted with a Kansas resident for partial performance in Kansas, was both authorized by statute and sanctioned by the due process clause; (2) the Kansas long-arm statute did not evidence a legislative intent to authorize service only on those nonresidents who are called into Kansas on claims for breach of contract that arise in Kansas, and (3) there was subject matter jurisdiction. Motion to dismiss denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Ricker v. American Zinser Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E. D. Tennessee, Northeastern Division.
Headnote: Mere existence of subsidiary-parent relationship did not suffice to hold subsidiary liable, in products liability suit, for injuries which plaintiff worker sustained because of defect in machine manufactured and sold by the parent, there being no showing that subsidiary was involved in any transaction involving the machine.
Document Preview: Products liability suit was brought to recover for personal injuries and loss of consortium. One defendant moved for summary judgment and, following grant thereof, plaintiffs sought relief from such judgment. The District Court, Neese, J., held that mere existence of subsidiary-parent relationship did not suffice to hold subsidiary liable, for injuries which plaintiff worker sustained because of defect in machine manufactured and sold by the parent, there being no showing that subsidiary was involved in any transaction involving the machine. Defendant's motion granted; plaintiffs' motion denied. Affirmed, 6 Cir., 633 F.2d 218. See also, D.C., 506 F.Supp. 3.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Mortgage and Trust, Inc. v. Bonner & Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi.
Headnote: In some circumstances one corporation may be regarded as "alter ego" of another where management and operations are assimilated to extent that subsidiary is simply a name or a conduit through which parent conducts its business.
Document Preview: Contractor brought suit against a number of defendants to establish and foreclose a constitutional and a statutory mechanic's and materialman's lien. The 156th District Court, San Patricio County, Rachel Littlejohn, J., entered joint and several judgment against deed of trust lienholder and purchaser of land at foreclosure sale for outstanding amount found to be due plaintiff under its construction contract, and entered judgment foreclosing plaintiff's mechanic's and materialman's lien on a portion of land secured under deed of trust and defendants perfected appeal. The Court of Civil Appeals, Nye, C. J., held that: (1) evidence that two corporations had overlapping officers and directors and that their offices were in same building did not invoke alter ego theory so as to permit disregard of corporate entities and result in priority of mechanic's lien over deed of trust held by defendant corporation; (2) where plaintiff contractor's mechanic's and materialman's...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: McDaniel v. Johns-Manville Sales Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Generally, holding companies or subsidiaries of a corporation are separate legal entities.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs brought suit against their employer, various related companies and other defendants alleging intentional and felonious asbestos poisoning, fraud, misrepresentation, and conspiracy to deceive. Upon motions to dismiss and motion to quash service of summons, the District Court, Kirkland, J., held that: (1) court would not accede to corporate employer's request to pierce its corporate veil so as to hold that its holding companies and subsidiaries were also employers of plaintiffs and thus seek to limit plaintiffs, remedy to an action under Illinois Workmen's Compensation Act; (2) Illinois Workmen's Compensation Act did not bar suit alleging the plaintiffs' employer's intentional and felonious asbestos poisoning of plaintiffs, fraud, misrepresentation, and conspiracy to deceive; and (3) although Canadian corporation had no office or agents in Illinois, corporation had sufficient contacts with Illinois for constitutional assertion of jurisdiction over...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Astrocom Electronics, Inc. v. Lafayette Radio Electronics Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: When a parent corporation uses a subsidiary corporation for the transaction of the parent's business, as distinct from the subsidiary's business, the parent may be held liable for the acts of the subsidiary in accordance with the general principles of agency.
Document Preview: In two actions, plaintiff appealed from orders of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Otsego county, which denied motion by defendant corporation to dismiss complaints for failure to state a cause of action on defendant corporation's claim that it was not a party to purchase contract. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that opposing affidavits on defendant corporation's motion to dismiss presented issue of fact as to whether codefendant corporation was an instrumentality or an agent of defendant corporation in transaction in question, thus precluding dismissal. Orders affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Skouras v. Admiralty Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware,New Castle County.
Headnote: Absent a showing of fraud or that a subsidiary is in fact the mere alter ego of a parent, common central management alone is not proper basis for disregarding separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: Stockholder sought order granting him the right to inspect certain books and records of closely held family corporation as well as books of corporation's affiliates. The Court of Chancery, in and for New Castle County, Marvel, Chancellor, held that: (1) technical defect in stockholder's demand could not be permitted to defeat his claim, and (2) where stockholder's primary purpose in obtaining inspection was not to compel a buy-out of his holdings but was to rally support to his battle against what he believed to be corporate acts detrimental to corporation and consequently to himself as minority stockholder of such corporation, he would be granted right to inspect books and records. Order to be entered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rea v. An-Son Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Notion of separate corporate existence of parent and subsidiary or affiliated corporations will not be recognized, where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its business conducted in such a manner as to make it merely an agency, instrumentality, adjunct, or alter ego of another corporation and the separate corporate identity of two corporations will not be extended to permit one of corporations to evade its just obligations or to promote fraud or illegality or injustice.
Document Preview: Texas citizen, who was injured while working aboard a drilling tender vessel in Venezuela, brought suits against an American parent corporation and a subsidiary, which had their principal places of business in Oklahoma, and against Venezuelan subsidiary which moved for dismissal. The District Court, Thompson, J., held that, for purposes of determining its personal jurisdiction over Venezuelan subsidiary, record disclosed that both of the other corporations had exercised sufficient control over Venezuelan corporation to enable court to disregard separate identities of each and to find that their acts might be imputed to Venezuelan corporation to give court jurisdiction under Oklahoma long-arm statute over that corporation which could be said to be doing business in Oklahoma. Motions to dismiss denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rea v. An-Son Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Upon disregard of corporate entity, parent corporation may be held liable for acts of subsidiary and acts of parent corporation may be imputed to subsidiary for purposes of personal jurisdiction.
Document Preview: Texas citizen, who was injured while working aboard a drilling tender vessel in Venezuela, brought suits against an American parent corporation and a subsidiary, which had their principal places of business in Oklahoma, and against Venezuelan subsidiary which moved for dismissal. The District Court, Thompson, J., held that, for purposes of determining its personal jurisdiction over Venezuelan subsidiary, record disclosed that both of the other corporations had exercised sufficient control over Venezuelan corporation to enable court to disregard separate identities of each and to find that their acts might be imputed to Venezuelan corporation to give court jurisdiction under Oklahoma long-arm statute over that corporation which could be said to be doing business in Oklahoma. Motions to dismiss denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Briggs Transp. Co., Inc. v. Starr Sales Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: In parent-subsidiary context, corporate entity should be disregarded where doing so would prevent parent from perpetuating a fraud or injustice, evading just responsibility or defeating public convenience.
Document Preview: Carrier, as seller's assignee, brought action against corporation and its officer-owners, alleging that defendant corporation fraudulently breached contract for sale of goods with plaintiff's assignor, that individual defendants were individually liable for breach as principals of a sham corporation and committed fraud individually and in conspiracy, for which plaintiff sought actual and punitive damages. The Linn District Court, Louis W. Schultz, J., rendered judgment against defendant corporation and two of corporate officers, but found that third corporate officer and stockholder, who had no active part in corporate business, was not personally liable, and defendants appealed and plaintiff cross-appealed. The Supreme Court, Reynoldson, J., held that: (1) there was ample evidence to support finding that individual defendant was officer, director and owner of corporation; (2) trial court was justified in piercing corporate veil to find officer personally liable; (3) because of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Dixon v. Process Corp.
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: That parent corporation owns subsidiary or that stock is held by one person, does not justify disregard of corporate entity.
Document Preview: Action was brought to obtain decree that properties and assets of subsidiary were those of parent so that judgment lien against parent would be collectible from the subsidiary. The Circuit Court, Prince George's County, William B. Bowie, J., entered judgment adverse to plaintiffs and they appealed. The Court of Special Appeals, Gilbert, C. J., held that: (1) evidence supported finding that there was no fraud and no paramount equity such as would justify disregard of corporate identities, and (2) plaintiffs seeking disregard of corporate identities on basis of fraud was properly required to demonstrate by clear and satisfactory proof that there was fraud, rather than being allowed to show fraud by preponderance of evidence. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Sun First Nat. Bank of Orlando v. Miller
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: In making determination as to whether a subsidiary is really an independent entity or a mere department courts look to number of factors including common directors, movement of key personnel from company to company, policy conferences involving top executives of different companies, training of employees of subsidiary by parent, consolidated earning statements and preparation of literature for subsidiary by the parent.
Document Preview: A bank, which had been party to a repurchase agreement involving treasury bills, brought action against firm which had acted as broker for both parties and against particular foreign defendants located in England allegedly related to the agent, on allegations of numerous federal and state causes of action concerning securities violations. The foreign defendants filed motion to dismiss for lack of in personam jurisdiction. The District Court, Robert L. Carter, J., held that to justify court's exercise of in personam jurisdiction over foreign defendants as controlling persons and corporations, or on other basis, bank was required to clarify causal nexus between acts alleged and its proposed theories of recovery under federal securities laws and that bank would be permitted further discovery to attempt such clarification. Defendants' motion to dismiss denied with leave to renew upon plaintiff's completion of discovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Duplan Corp. v. Deering Milliken, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Spartanburg Division.
Headnote: Fact that parent corporation owns all of corporate stock of its subsidiary does not destroy identity of latter as distinct legal entity; however, where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its business is conducted in such manner as to make it merely agency, instrumentality, adjunct or alter ego of another corporation, separate corporate existence of parent and subsidiary may not be recognized.
Document Preview: In consolidated suits for recovery of patent royalties alleged to be due from patent sublicensees on patents involving textile machinery, the District Court, Dupree, J., held inter alia, that the defendants had been guilty of horizontal, but not vertical, antitrust conspiracy. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Duplan Corp. v. Deering Milliken, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Spartanburg Division.
Headnote: Factors listed relevant to determining whether there has been such domination of finances, policy and practices of subsidiary that it has no separate mind, will or existence of its own but is simply business conduit for parent corporation.
Document Preview: In consolidated suits for recovery of patent royalties alleged to be due from patent sublicensees on patents involving textile machinery, the District Court, Dupree, J., held inter alia, that the defendants had been guilty of horizontal, but not vertical, antitrust conspiracy. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fehl v. S. W. C. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, a separate corporate entity may be disregarded where it would otherwise shield a parent or alter ego corporation from liability for acts attributable to it. 8 Del.C. § 382.
Document Preview: Action was brought against, among others, purchaser of assets of manufacturer of allegedly defective ice-cubing machine to recover for injuries which workman sustained while operating the machine. The purchaser, a New York corporation, moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction. The District Court, Caleb M. Wright, Senior Judge, held that (1) under Delaware long-arm statute a foreign corporation must both transact business in Delaware and the cause of action must arise or grow out of specific business transacted in the state; (2) jurisdiction could not be founded on the corporate continuation theory absent showing that movant was the present-day embodiment of the manufacturer and (3) jurisdiction could not be based on the tort theory absent showing that cause of action arose out of any particular business transacted by movant in Delaware. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rimes v. Club Corp. of America
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Notwithstanding fact that parent corporation owns entire capital stock of subsidiary corporation, two corporations are separate legal entities and, whatever may have been motive leading to their separate existence, they can only be regarded as separate entities for purpose of legal proceedings.
Document Preview: Suit was brought to enforce noncompetitive provisions of employment contracts. The 44th District Court, Dallas County, Joe Bailey Humphreys, J., issued preliminary injunction enjoining defendants from operating business in violation of restrictive covenants contained in previous employment contracts, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Claude Williams, C.J., held that trial court erred in issuing injunctive order which expanded time period restricting competition beyond time expressly contained in employment contracts and in finding that certain information was confidential and therefore within plaintiff employer's protectible interests. Reversed and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Boise Cascade Corp. v. Wheeler
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: A corporation is a creature of the law, endowed with a personality separate and distinct from that of its owners, and the dual personality of parent and subsidiary is not lightly disregarded.
Document Preview: A suit for compensatory and punitive damages, arising out of a hospital construction project, was brought against architectural partnership by corporation which, from 1969 to 1973, was the sole stockholder of the project's corporate general contractor. On a defense motion to dismiss the complaint for failure of plaintiff to join an indispensable party plaintiff, viz., the contractor, the District Court, MacMahon, J., held that the contractor appeared to have rights in the matter inextricably intertwined with those asserted by plaintiff such that any disposition on the merits in the contractor's absence might impair its ability to protect its own interests and/or subject the architect to multiple liability; thus, the contractor was shown to be an indispensable party whose joinder, however, would destroy diversity jurisdiction. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Edwin K. Williams & Co., Inc. v. Edwin K. Williams & Co.-East
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: There are no inflexible tests by which courts determine when to hold corporations liable for acts of their subsidiaries; generally, corporate separateness is respected unless to do so would work an injustice upon innocent third parties, but each case must be considered on its own facts.
Document Preview: Licensor brought action against licensee and corporate owner of licensee seeking, inter alia, damages and injunctive relief for breach of agreement between parties, interference with contractual business relations, and copyright and trademark infringement, and licensee counterclaimed, alleging antitrust violations and invalidity of licensor's copyrights. The action was instituted in state court and removed to federal district court. The United States District Court for the Central District of California, David W. Williams, 377 F.Supp. 418, entered judgment for licensors, and defendants appealed and plaintiff cross-appealed. The Court of Appeals, Solomon, District Judge, held that agreement between parties created relationship of trade name licensee and licensor; that licensee could not assert lack of quality control to invalidate trade name license; that account books containing several pages of instructions were entitled to copyright protections; that licensee was guilty of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hayes v. Sanitary and Imp. Dist. No. 194 of Douglas County
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Where Nebraska corporation was wholly owned subsidiary of Minnesota corporation, where employees of Nebraska corporation were paid out of payroll account of Minnesota corporation with Nebraska corporation then reimbursing parent company, and where there was almost total interlocking of officers and directors of the two corporations which did maintain separate books and file separate income tax returns, corporate shell would be pierced and separate legal identities dissipated.
Document Preview: Individual and municipal corporation brought suit to recover money paid by annexed sanitary and improvement district to fiscal agent as underwriter of warrants and bonds of district claiming that payments made by district to agent resulted in illegal discounting of price of warrants and bonds. The District Court, Douglas County, Murphy, J., entered judgment against fiscal agents, and agents, et al., appealed. The Supreme Court, McCown, J., held that municipal corporation was not equitably estopped from bringing suit; that where fiscal agent for sale of bonds purchased bonds privately from district at par, district's payment of fee for fiscal services to such purchaser constituted sale of bonds at less than par in violation of statute; and that district could contract to pay fiscal agent's fee for agent's purchase and handling of warrants where warrants were purchased exclusively from contractors to whom district had issued warrants and where warrants issued directly to fiscal...

Title: Hayes v. Sanitary and Imp. Dist. No. 194 of Douglas County
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Separate corporate existence of parent and subsidiary or affiliated corporations will not be recognized by corporation so organized and controlled and its business conducted in such a manner as to make it merely an agency, instrumentality, adjunct or alter ego of another corporation.
