Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: International Union, United Auto., Aerospace and Agr. Implement Workers of America (UAW) v. Cardwell Mfg. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Ordinarily, several corporations retain their distinct identities notwithstanding that they have stockholders and officers in common or that one corporation owns stock in others, creating subsidiary or affiliated corporations, but concept or fiction of distinct identity will not be recognized where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its business conducted in such a manner as to make it a mere agency, instrumentality, agent or alter ego of other corporation.
Document Preview: International and local unions and bargaining unit employees brought action against employer and its parent corporation following failure of employer to meet its pension plan obligations under agreements with unions. The District Court, Theis, J., held that corporate veil would be pierced and parent as well as subsidiary employer would be held liable for the pension fund obligations where subsidiary employer was a mere agent, instrumentality and alter ego of parent, parent's directors, officers and employees, acting within the scope of their employment and authority, intentionally interfered with known contractual rights of unions and directly caused violations of contracts within meaning of the Labor Management Relations Act, and where, in causing such violation, officers and employees of parent and subsidiary acted in concert in manner constituting civil conspiracy; and that where, inter alia, considered conduct of the two corporations was carried on in bad faith and for...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: International Union, United Auto., Aerospace and Agr. Implement Workers of America (UAW) v. Cardwell Mfg. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Fact that one corporation owns all the stock of another and thereby selects from its own directors and officers a majority of all the directors of the other, or that parent finances subsidiary, is without more not sufficient to warrant disregarding the separate entities and treating them as the one, but where from all the facts and circumstances it is apparent that relationship between parent and subsidiary is so intimate the parent's control over the subsidiary is so dominating, and the business and assets of the two so mingled that recognition of distinct entities would result in injustice to third persons, courts will look through the legal fiction of separate entities and treat them as justice requires.
Document Preview: International and local unions and bargaining unit employees brought action against employer and its parent corporation following failure of employer to meet its pension plan obligations under agreements with unions. The District Court, Theis, J., held that corporate veil would be pierced and parent as well as subsidiary employer would be held liable for the pension fund obligations where subsidiary employer was a mere agent, instrumentality and alter ego of parent, parent's directors, officers and employees, acting within the scope of their employment and authority, intentionally interfered with known contractual rights of unions and directly caused violations of contracts within meaning of the Labor Management Relations Act, and where, in causing such violation, officers and employees of parent and subsidiary acted in concert in manner constituting civil conspiracy; and that where, inter alia, considered conduct of the two corporations was carried on in bad faith and for...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. Dean Van Lines, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, in order to hold a parent corporation liable for the acts of its subsidiary, it is not enough that observance of separate corporate identities would be unjust or inequitable; as a condition to liability, it must also be shown that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality of the subsidiary as a distinct entity has ceased.
Document Preview: United States brought suit against Belgian subsidiary's American corporate parent, seeking an accounting and collection of overcharges made by the subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, at Jacksonville, Charles R. Scott, J., entered judgment for the Government on a theory of unjust enrichment, and parent corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, Dyer, Circuit Judge, held that while the Belgian subsidiary, which from 1965 to 1967 acted as freight forwarder for a federal agency, overcharged the United States by the amount of certain undisclosed rebates it received from steamship lines, the overcharge could not be recovered from the subsidiary's American parent on a theory of unjust enrichment, even though, after the overcharge occurred, the parent sold the subsidiary's stock and, in the Government's view, allegedly received a price inflated by the amount of the overcharge, where the parent was admittedly not the alter ego of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Omaha Pollution Control Corp. v. Carver-Greenfield Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nebraska.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil on theory that one corporation is an instrumentality of another, it must be proved that control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked is such that the corporate entity, as to the transaction attacked, had no separate mind, will or existence of its own, that such control was used to commit fraud or wrong, and that the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: City and its pollution control corporation brought action against contractor seller of sewage treatment plant which was designed to remove certain packinghouse waste from the city sewer system so as to permit the sewage to be handled by city's already extant sewage treatment plant and which was also designed to convert the materials removed from the system into marketable products and against a related corporation for breach of warranties with respect to the construction and sale of the treatment plant. The District Court, Van Sickle, J., held that the contractor seller impliedly warranted the merchantability and fitness for particular purpose of the plant; that the warranties were breached; that the city could recover for the breaches as a third-party beneficiary of the implied warranties; that the contractor seller was entitled to recover on its counterclaim for amounts not paid for work pursuant to change orders and was also entitled to recover insurance loss proceeds resulting...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Unijax, Inc. v. Factory Ins. Ass'n
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District.
Headnote: Neither ownership of all of the stock of a subsidiary, nor common officers and directors, nor both combined, are sufficient per se to justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Parent corporation brought action to recover on business interruption policy for fire loss to paper mill owned by subsidiaries. The Circuit Court, Duval County, Marion W. Gooding, J., entered final summary judgment for insurer and for agent engaged to procure business interruption policy for plaintiff and plaintiff appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Boyer, C.J., held that the parent and its two subsidiaries being separate entities, and each separately insured under the same policy, each corporation was required to maintain its own action to recover for its own loss; that parent corporation was not doing business through its subsidiaries which were not the mere instrumentality of parent; that parent corporation was not the real party in interest; that insurer's agreement for prelitigation payment would not support parent's claim of estoppel in view of specific provision in the agreement against waiver or modification of any conditions or requirements of policy...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Musman v. Modern Deb, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: There must be complete domination and control of subsidiary before parent's corporate veil can be pierced; stock control, interlocking directors and officers and the like are in and of themselves insufficient, and the control must actually be used to commit wrong against the plaintiff and must be the proximate cause of the plaintiff's loss.
Document Preview: Action was brought by a discharged general manager-designer for breach of employment contract. Judgment in the amount of $59,187.03 was awarded against the employer and a parent corporation of the employer by the Supreme Court, New York County, Louis I. Kaplan, J. Appeals were taken by the manager-designer and by the employer and its parent. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that where the employment contract contained a provision that, should the manager be discharged without cause, the employer undertook to pay him full compensation and bonuses to the end of term and exonerated him from any obligation to perform services for the employer, such provision fixed exposure of the employer following discharge without cause and removed the case from the ordinary rule requiring mitigation of damages. The mere fact that the contract required the general manager-designer, in the apparel business, to perform reasonable responsibilities and duties for his employer's parent...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Johnson & Higgins of Mississippi, Inc. v. Commissioner of Ins. of Mississippi
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Piercing the veil of a subsidiary in order to deal with its parent corporation should not be lightly undertaken.
Document Preview: Corporation and its resident agent appealed from Commissioner of Insurance's refusal to issue domestic corporate insurance agency license to corporation and to issue a license to agent. The Circuit Court, Hinds County, Leon F. Hendrick, J., affirmed, and applicants appealed. The Supreme Court, Broom, J., held that corporations are eligible for licensing as insurance agencies, that Commissioner erred in piercing the veil of applicant-corporation and requiring disclosure of the shareholders of New York corporation, which owned the applicant-corporation, that even if applicant-corporation's president, who was a licensed nonresident agent, had a pecuniary interest in corporation, such would not place a license of corporation into jeopardy, that even if applicant-corporation would pay dividends to New York corporation from earnings derived from commissions paid to applicant-corporation, such would not violate statute prohibiting payment of commissions to unauthorized insurance agents,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Edgar v. Fred Jones Lincoln-Mercury of Oklahoma City, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: It is necessary under law of Oklahoma to establish something more than ownership of virtually all of the subsidiary stock by the parent or identity of directors in order to treat the parent and subsidiary as one.
Document Preview: Diversity action was instituted by plaintiff to obtain actual and punitive damages from corporate defendant for alleged common-law fraud. The United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, Stephen S. Chandler, J., 383 F.Supp. 583, awarded plaintiff actual damages of $1,500, but denied exemplary damages and, after awarding $1,000 in attorney's fees, assessed costs against plaintiff because amount of recovery had not satisfied jurisdictional amount, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, William E. Doyle, Circuit Judge, held that federal statute creating private federal claim in favor of person defrauded by wrongful odometer rollback did not supersede common-law remedy in fraud available to plaintiff under law of Oklahoma and was improperly employed as a measure of damages and as a limitation on damages in action; further, awarding costs to defendant was error where exemplary damages could have easily reached $10,000 statutory amount, that plaintiff was...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Edgar v. Fred Jones Lincoln-Mercury of Oklahoma City, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under law of Oklahoma, in order to establish that a subsidiary corporation is the alter ego or agent of the parent, evidence must establish that the parent's control is so complete as to render the subsidiary an instrumentality of the parent.
Document Preview: Diversity action was instituted by plaintiff to obtain actual and punitive damages from corporate defendant for alleged common-law fraud. The United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, Stephen S. Chandler, J., 383 F.Supp. 583, awarded plaintiff actual damages of $1,500, but denied exemplary damages and, after awarding $1,000 in attorney's fees, assessed costs against plaintiff because amount of recovery had not satisfied jurisdictional amount, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, William E. Doyle, Circuit Judge, held that federal statute creating private federal claim in favor of person defrauded by wrongful odometer rollback did not supersede common-law remedy in fraud available to plaintiff under law of Oklahoma and was improperly employed as a measure of damages and as a limitation on damages in action; further, awarding costs to defendant was error where exemplary damages could have easily reached $10,000 statutory amount, that plaintiff was...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gentry v. Credit Plan Corp. of Houston
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: A subsidiary corporation will not be regarded as the alter ego of its parent merely because of stock ownership, because of duplication of some or all of the directors or officers, or because of exercise of control that stock ownership gives to the stockholders; on the other hand, where management and operations are assimilated to the extent that the subsidiary is simply a name or conduit through which the parent conducts its business, the corporate fiction may be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Action was brought against credit company, two of its employees, and two corporations allegedly controlling credit company, seeking to recover damages for unreasonable collection efforts. The Fourteenth Judicial District Court, Harris County, William N. Blanton, Jr., J., entered judgment for plaintiffs, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals affirmed in part and reversed and rendered in part, 516 S.W.2d 471, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Walker, J., held that defendant credit company was, as a matter of law, the alter ego of its parent, the second corporate defendant, and that filing of suit against defendant credit company stopped the running of two-year statute of limitations in favor of defendant parent, which had been joined as a defendant more than two years after the alleged cause of action accrued. Judgment of Court of Civil Appeals reversed, that of trial court affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Diamond Paint Co. of Houston v. Embry
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.)
Headnote: Even though corporation owned 100% of outstanding stock of second corporation, it was, in absence of proof of alter ego, a separate entity.
Document Preview: Actions and cross actions were filed as to liabilities pertaining to promissory note and contemporaneous guaranties. The District Court, Harris County, Shearn Smith, J., entered judgment on verdict against maker and guarantor and refused injunctive relief sought by intervenor, and an appeal was taken. The Court of Civil Appeals, Curtiss Brown, J., held that so-called take-out letters were not guaranties' and settlement of contractual dispute between payee and writers did not extinguish debt; that package relied upon by payee afforded sufficient consideration for note and guaranty; that evidence established that corporation ratified guaranty executed by its officers; that corporate guaranty was not illegal and unenforceable; and that trial court did not abuse its discretion as matter of law in refusing injunction sought by acquiring corporation, as sole outstanding shareholder, to restrain payment of guaranty as being ultra vires. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Schlecht v. Equitable Builders, Inc., A. E. C. G.
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, En Banc.
Headnote: Corporate entity of a subsidiary corporation should be disregarded only to prevent fraud or injustice and to protect persons whose rights have been jeopardized by conduct of the parent corporation.
Document Preview: Judgment creditors of wholly owned subsidiary brought action to require parent corporation to pay those judgments. The Circuit Court, Washington County, Hollie Pihl, J., entered judgment from which plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, McAllister, J., held that in absence of any evidence that control exercised by parent corporation over its wholly owned subsidiary was used to perpetrate a fraud on judgment creditors of subsidiary, in view of fact that, though parent might have caused subsidiary to guaranty certain loans, there was no evidence that the rights of creditors were jeopardized thereby, and in light of fact that there was no evidence that parent caused subsidiary to transfer to parent any funds or other assets, subsidiary's corporate veil would not be pierced for purpose of requiring parent to pay judgments against subsidiary. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Siboney Corp. v. Dresser Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Where subsidiary is not operated as bona fide separate entity but as mere agency or instrumentality of owning company, courts will look beyond corporate form to determine companies' true business relationship.
Document Preview: Seller brought suit against corporate buyer and buyer's former parent corporation to recover for merchandise sold and delivered on account to buyer. The District Court, Harris County, W. Ervin James, J., entered judgment in seller's favor and parent corporation appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Evans, J., held that where seller had had no prior dealings with buyer, a wholly owned subsidiary, which previously had been division of parent corporation, and there was no indication that, at time seller furnished merchandise to buyer, it was misled as to buyer's incorporated status, parent was not liable to seller for the merchandise on basis of failure of parent to give statutory notice of incorporation of buyer and that, even though someone in seller's offices prepared invoice showing that corporate buyer was a division of parent and that information generally came from the buyer, in absence of showing that parent had authorized or knowingly permitted anyone at buyer to represent...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Trans-American Communications, Inc. v. Nolle
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia, Division No. 3.
Headnote: The separate identity of a subservient corporation is not destroyed merely by the fact that it is used by the parent for the parent's ends, nor even by fact that they have the same officers and offices.
Document Preview: The plaintiff commenced an action for unpaid salary against his corporate employer and its parent which was a holding company for the employer and other subsidiaries. From a judgment of the Superior Court, DeKalb County, Clyde W. Henley, J., an appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Deen, P.J., held, inter alia, that the separate identity of a subservient corporation is not destroyed merely by fact that it is used by the parent for the parent's ends, nor even by fact that they have the same officers and offices; and that the questions of whether through its excessive control and financial policies the parent had blurred corporate lines between it and the corporate employer so as to render both liable to plaintiff for the employer's breach of contract were for jury. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Call Carl, Inc. v. BP Oil Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Notwithstanding the fact that the parent corporation may own all of a subsidiary's stock, and interlocking directorships may exist between the two corporations, if a subsidiary maintains its own books and accounts, and makes its own marketing, purchasing, management and other policy decisions, it cannot be held to be acting as an agent of the parent.
Document Preview: Retail gasoline dealers who had franchise agreements with subsidiary of oil company brought action against the subsidiary and the oil company to recover for alleged violations of federal antitrust laws, alleged breach of contract, alleged fraud and misrepresentation in the execution of franchise agreements, and refusal to allocate gasoline as required by federal regulations. On oil company's motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, improper venue, and improper service of process, the District Court, Joseph H. Young, J., held that oil company exercised sufficient control over subsidiary to be subject to venue and jurisdiction under the antitrust claims in state in which subsidiary transacted business; that oil company exercised sufficient control over the subsidiary to be subject to jurisdiction with respect to the state claims; and that service of process upon the subsidiary was sufficient to effect service on the oil company. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Call Carl, Inc. v. BP Oil Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil in a case where interlocking directorships exist and there is complete stock ownership of the subsidiary by the parent, it is necessary to find some evidence of conscious control by the parent of a major aspect of the subsidiary's operation.
Document Preview: Retail gasoline dealers who had franchise agreements with subsidiary of oil company brought action against the subsidiary and the oil company to recover for alleged violations of federal antitrust laws, alleged breach of contract, alleged fraud and misrepresentation in the execution of franchise agreements, and refusal to allocate gasoline as required by federal regulations. On oil company's motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, improper venue, and improper service of process, the District Court, Joseph H. Young, J., held that oil company exercised sufficient control over subsidiary to be subject to venue and jurisdiction under the antitrust claims in state in which subsidiary transacted business; that oil company exercised sufficient control over the subsidiary to be subject to jurisdiction with respect to the state claims; and that service of process upon the subsidiary was sufficient to effect service on the oil company. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Lehigh Valley Industries, Inc. v. Birenbaum
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, there can be no piercing of the corporate veil solely because there is only one shareholder; rather, it is necessary to show that there is fraud, misrepresentation or illegality involved in the designation of parent and subsidiary which would make it inequitable for the courts to ignore the true relationship between the two entities.
Document Preview: Corporations brought suit against two brothers and against two foreign corporations, charging breach of employment contract with plaintiffs' predecessor in interest, conspiracy to divert assets and business opportunities, and misappropriation of a business opportunity. On the motion of one brother to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, the District Court, Stewart, J., held that the various provisions of New York's long-arm statute would not allow service of process to be made on the movant in Massachusetts. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Chengelis v. Cenco Instruments Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Absent the element of fraud or injustice akin to fraud, corporate structure of a subsidiary could not be disregarded to impose liability on parent corporation.
Document Preview: Action against a parent corporation for breach of a royalty contract entered into by plaintiff with a subsidiary corporation. The United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania, Weber, J., held that where parties deal at arm's length, represented by counsel, corporate veil cannot be removed merely to give a litigant an advantage at law; the court also held that parent corporation could not be held liable for breach of royalty payment contract entered into by plaintiff with subsidiary corporation where plaintiff entered into the contract which bound only the subsidiary notwithstanding knowledge of interrelation of the two corporations, and where there was no proof that corporate form of subsidiary was used by parent corporation to perpetrate a fraud or promote an injustice akin to fraud. Judgments for defendant in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: U.S. v. State Tax Commission of State of Miss.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Fact that one entity owns all stock in the other is not determinative of whether corporate fiction may be disregarded.
Document Preview: The United States brought suit on behalf of Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians to enjoin the Mississippi State Tax Commission from assessing, collecting, and attempting to collect sales taxes from a construction company which was formed at request of tribal council. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi, at Jackson, William Harold Cox, J., entered judgment granting a permanent injunction, and the Commission and the sheriff of Neshoba County appealed. The Court of Appeals, Coleman, Circuit Judge, held that the construction company was an entity separate and distinct from the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians, the group named as beneficiary of the exemption in Mississippi's sales tax statutes, that the United States was attempting to lend its name to a suit on behalf of a private corporation and was not the real party in interest, and that tribal character of Choctaw Indians in Mississippi came to an end when the United States Senate ratified...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Quarles v. Fuqua Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: A holding or parent company has a separate corporate existence and is treated separately from the subsidiary in absence of circumstances justifying disregard of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: Class action was brought against a nonresident corporation and others to recover compensatory and punitive damages for fraudulently inducing plaintiffs to enter into training course contracts and enroll in vocational training schools. The United States District Court for the District of Kansas, George Templar, J., sustained nonresident corporation's motion to quash and dismiss, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Hill, Circuit Judge, held that district court had no jurisdiction over nonresident corporation, notwithstanding alter ego and agency theories relied upon by plaintiffs. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Quarles v. Fuqua Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Facts that nonresident parent corporation received monthly financial reports from subsidiary and consulted with its officers, that parent provided financial support, that employment contracts of officers of subsidiary required them to be available in an advisory capacity to parent, that two of parent's staff members were on subsidiary's board of directors, that parent's employee stock purchase plan was available to employees of subsidiary, and that subsidiary was sold as an unprofitable investment did not warrant application of alter ego doctrine for jurisdiction over parent which, unlike subsidiary, had not engaged in any business transactions in the state, where total participation of parent in affairs of subsidiary did not amount to a domination of day to day business decisions of subsidiary. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(d)(7), (e), 28 U.S.C.A.; K.S.A. 60–308, 60–308(b).
Document Preview: Class action was brought against a nonresident corporation and others to recover compensatory and punitive damages for fraudulently inducing plaintiffs to enter into training course contracts and enroll in vocational training schools. The United States District Court for the District of Kansas, George Templar, J., sustained nonresident corporation's motion to quash and dismiss, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Hill, Circuit Judge, held that district court had no jurisdiction over nonresident corporation, notwithstanding alter ego and agency theories relied upon by plaintiffs. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Latham v. Technar, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee, Northern Division.
Headnote: Presence of a common insurer as between holding company and wholly owned subsidiary does not automatically establish a single employer nor does identity of management create identity for workmen's compensation purposes.
Document Preview: Administrator of estate of individual killed in test chamber explosion brought wrongful death action. On corporate defendant's motion to set aside verdict awarding administrator $300,000 or, alternatively, for a new trial, the District Court, Robert L. Taylor, J., held that corporate defendant that was engaged in automobile air bag operation dissimilar from seat belt operations of its wholly owned subsidiary, that hired its own employees and paid them on its own payroll checks was not the employer of individual who was hired by subsidiary and paid by subsidiary and thus was not immune from wrongful death action; and that award of $300,000 was excessive where only damage established was decedent's loss of earnings and thus should be reduced to $214,000, amount of decedent's projected earnings. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Allegheny Airlines, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: In establishing fact that a subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of its parent, the following elements must be proved: control by parent to such a degree that the subsidiary has become its mere instrumentality; fraud or wrong by parent through its subsidiary; and an unjust loss or injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: Airline and owner of one of engines which was mounted on airline's aircraft that was destroyed in mid-air collision with small aircraft appealed from final judgments which were entered by the United States District Court for the Southern District of Indiana, Indianapolis Division, Cale J. Holder, J., in favor of corporate owner of small aircraft, its parent corporation, the United States, and estate of student pilot who was operating small aircraft. The Court of Appeals, Swygert, Chief Judge held that district court's implicit finding as to altitude of clouds was clearly erroneous, that owner of engine was a real party in interest and should have not been dismissed from action as party plaintiff, that parent corporation was not a mere instrumentality of subsidiary and directed verdict was properly granted in favor of parent corporation, and that under Indiana aeronautical statutes, an absentee owner is financially responsible for negligent acts of a student pilot to whom he had...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gladding Corp. v. Register
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Fact that one corporation owns all of the stock of a subsidiary company does not erase subsidiary's identity as a legal entity or create any conclusion that the subsidiary is only the alter ego of the parent.
Document Preview: Interpleader action brought by escrow agent with respect to parent and subsidiary corporation involved in acquisition of business and the seller of business on ground that there were conflicting claims to funds held by escrow agent. Counterclaims and third-party complaints were filed. The Circuit Court for Dade County, Rhea Pincus Grossman, J., held on trial on equitable issues, entered order denying with prejudice counterclaim seeking rescission of contract and set case down for jury trial on issue of damages. An interlocutory appeal was taken. The District Court of Appeal held that buyer by delay had waived right to rescind, that parent corporation was not liable to sellers of business to newly created subsidiary and that both sellers and buyer had right to prove amount of damages each party incurred. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Reul v. Sahara Hotel
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Ownership of all stock and presence of common directors will not alone fuse subsidiary into parent corporation, either for purposes of liability or for purpose of establishing some sort of agency relationship.
Document Preview: Products liability action arising from explosion of chlorine tank. On motion of one defendant to dismiss, the District Court, Singleton, J., held that where defendant California corporation was completely integrated subsidiary of defendant New York corporation, and New York corporation clearly did business in Texas within contemplation of long-arm statute, activities of New York corporation in Texas could be imputed to California corporation and California corporation could be said to be doing business' in Texas for purpose of in personam jurisdiction. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Jackson v. General Elec. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be held liable for its subsidiary's conduct when parent uses separate corporate form to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, commit fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: Action against manufacturer of electical appliance by purchaser who claimed he was damaged by defamatory letter sent by finance company which was wholly owned subsidiary of manufacturer and through which purchaser financed purchase. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eben H. Lewis, J., found for manufacturer and purchaser appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that evidence sustained trial court's finding that manufacturer was not liable for actions of subsidiary. Affirmed. Erwin, J., did not participate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fanfan v. Berwind Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: For instrumentality rule to be applicable, it must be shown that parent controls subsidiary to such degree that subsidiary is a mere instrumentality, that parent is perpetrating fraud or wrong through its subsidiary, and that an unjust loss or injury to claimant exists.
Document Preview: Puerto Rican seaman injured in the territorial waters of Puerto Rico while working for a Puerto Rico corporate employer brought suit against employer's parent corporation for the alleged Jones Act negligence and unseaworthiness of tug owned and operated by the employer. On parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Broderick, J., held that court would not pierce the corporate veil of the employer, an insured employer under the Puerto Rico Workmen's Accident Compensation Law, and hold the parent company which was uninsured under the Puerto Rico statute liable in absence of showing that the employer was the mere instrumentality of the parent corporation. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fanfan v. Berwind Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Generally, a parent corporation is not liable for the acts of its subsidiary unless the subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of the parent.
Document Preview: Puerto Rican seaman injured in the territorial waters of Puerto Rico while working for a Puerto Rico corporate employer brought suit against employer's parent corporation for the alleged Jones Act negligence and unseaworthiness of tug owned and operated by the employer. On parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Broderick, J., held that court would not pierce the corporate veil of the employer, an insured employer under the Puerto Rico Workmen's Accident Compensation Law, and hold the parent company which was uninsured under the Puerto Rico statute liable in absence of showing that the employer was the mere instrumentality of the parent corporation. Motion granted.

Title: In re Beck Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Where parent corporation desires legal benefits to be derived from organization of subsidiary that will function separately and autonomously in conduct of its own distinct business, parent must accept the legal consequences, including its inability later to treat subsidiary as its alter ego because of certain advantages that might thereby be gained; parent cannot "have it both ways."
Document Preview: From an order of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, John M. Cannella, J., affirming an order of a bankruptcy referee, Asa S. Herzog, J., restraining state court plaintiffs from continuing their action directed at a wholly owned subsidiary of the debtor in a Chapter X proceeding, the state court plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Mansfield, Circuit Judge, held that though the subsidiary corporation was perhaps a mere shell when, immediately prior to merger, it was formed, and the transaction was structured to conform to a hybrid Type A form of corporate reorganization for purposes of Internal Revenue Code, conclusions that the subsidiary, which was a vital and viable independent entity was devious * * * legal rigamarole and independent entity by the sheerest fiction and an adjunct or instrumentality of the parent were, under evidence showing an arm's length transaction, clearly...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Home Tel. Co. v. Darley
Court: United States District Court, N. D. Mississippi, Delta Division.
Headnote: Fact that corporation was sole owner of common stock in second corporation did not constitute basis for refusing to recognize second corporation as an active and viable corporate entity with separate and distinct legal identity.
Document Preview: Corporation's action against former officers for breach of fiduciary duties. The District Court, Keady, Chief Judge, held that officers who were in control of corporation owed fiduciary duty to it which they violated by causing it to breach merger agreement for no corporate business purpose and solely for their own personal gain. Judgment for plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Scott-Douglas Corp. v. Greyhound Corp.
Court: Superior Court of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Generally, corporation is entity distinct from its shareholders even if its stock is wholly owned by one person or corporation.
Document Preview: Actioin for breach of franchise contract and for fraud in inducement of contract. On motion by defendants for dismissal of action as to one defendant and on defendants' motion for summary judgment, the Superior Court, Wright, J., held that where there was no evidence in any way tending to show fraud by a parent corporation except evidence of ownership and common directors and officers, there was a failure to make a case against the parent corporation. The Court also held that the question whether franchisees were justified in their reliance upon representations was a question of fact precluding summary judgment. Motion of defendant parent corporation for dismissal granted; motion of remaining defendant for summary judgment denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Scott-Douglas Corp. v. Greyhound Corp.
Court: Superior Court of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Sole ownership of stock and common directors and officers between parent and subsidiary are only some of factors to be considered in determining whether or not the corporate fiction should be disregarded and shareholders held liable.
Document Preview: Actioin for breach of franchise contract and for fraud in inducement of contract. On motion by defendants for dismissal of action as to one defendant and on defendants' motion for summary judgment, the Superior Court, Wright, J., held that where there was no evidence in any way tending to show fraud by a parent corporation except evidence of ownership and common directors and officers, there was a failure to make a case against the parent corporation. The Court also held that the question whether franchisees were justified in their reliance upon representations was a question of fact precluding summary judgment. Motion of defendant parent corporation for dismissal granted; motion of remaining defendant for summary judgment denied.

Title: Scott-Douglas Corp. v. Greyhound Corp.
Court: Superior Court of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: It requires strong case to induce court to consider two corporations as one on account of one owning all capital stock of the other.
Document Preview: Actioin for breach of franchise contract and for fraud in inducement of contract. On motion by defendants for dismissal of action as to one defendant and on defendants' motion for summary judgment, the Superior Court, Wright, J., held that where there was no evidence in any way tending to show fraud by a parent corporation except evidence of ownership and common directors and officers, there was a failure to make a case against the parent corporation. The Court also held that the question whether franchisees were justified in their reliance upon representations was a question of fact precluding summary judgment. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: C. J. Tower & Sons of Niagara, Inc. v. U. S.
Court: United States Customs Court, First Division, Appellate Term.
Headnote: Merely because a majority of second corporation's voting shares are held by first corporation does not mean that second corporation is the agent of first corporation.
Document Preview: Application for review of a decision of the trial court affirming appraisement by United States of certain vulcanizing equipment for the repair of passenger and truck tires. The Customs Court, Maletz, J., held that finding that United States corporation was not a selected purchaser of imported merchandise, that such merchandise was not sold to United States corporation, but that such corporation was a selling agent of Canadian company, and that proper dutiable values were thus represented by the appraised values, was supported by evidence that, inter alia, the Canadian company handled the accounting and bookkeeping functions of United States corporation, Canadian company printed and distributed price lists and sent them directly to jobbers in the United States, majority of sales promotion work was handled in Canada, and Canadian company corresponded directly with United States jobbers with regard to sales. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bay Sound Transp. Co. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: In determining if a subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of the parent corporation, factors generally to be considered include, common stock ownership, common directors or officers, financing of subsidiary by parent, incorporation of subsidiary being caused by parent, grossly inadequate capital for subsidiary, payment by parent of salaries and other expenses or losses of subsidiary, subsidiary's receiving no business except that given by parent, parent's using subsidiary's property as its own and directors or officers of subsidiary not acting independently in interest of subsidiary but taking their orders from parent in the latter's interest.
Document Preview: Income tax refund actions. On remand, 410 F.2d 505, the District Court, Hannay, J., held that evidence failed to establish that evasion or avoidance of federal income taxes, by securing benefit of multiple surtax exemptions, was not the principal purpose motivating separate incorporation of 20 barges and vessels acquired by shipping fleet, with one individual being major stockholder and chief executive officer of all but two of such corporations, with two partnerships and corporations using same office address, with one individual personally soliciting all business and directing services to be performed, with records governing all transactions being maintained by partnerships and intercorporate affairs handled as accounts payable and accounts receivable and only evidence that tax evasion or avoidance was not principal motive being unsupported statements of stockholders and others. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fisher v. First Nat. Bank of Omaha
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Iowa.
Headnote: A corporation is not doing business in a state, for purpose of subjecting corporation to in personam jurisdiction under state long-arm statute, merely by presence of its wholly owned subsidiary; however, the fiction of corporate entity may be disregarded where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs are so conducted that it is, in fact, a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: Action charging national bank with violating certain provision of Federal Truth in Lending Act in connection with operation of credit card program. On defendant's motion to dismiss, the District Court, Stuart, J., held that where wholly owned service corporation had been organized by Nebraska national bank for purpose of promoting and expanding credit card plan, corporation solicited participation on part of merchants and solicited applications for cards subject to bank's approval, bank kept books and records and paid corporation monthly compensation and card holders were required to pay their accounts to bank in Nebraska, service corporation was merely an adjunct of bank and, thus, making of contract to be performed in whole or in part in Iowa by corporation constituted doing of business in Iowa by bank subjecting bank to service under Iowa long-arm statute, notwithstanding that agreement between bank and corporation provided that each party acted as principal and not as agent....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Berger v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: The dual personality of parent and subsidiary corporation is not to be lightly disregarded.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover from parent corporation, as alleged alter ego of subsidiary, for breach of contract entered into with subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John V. Singleton, J., awarded damages to plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus, parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Berger v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: To justify judicial derogation of the separateness of a corporate creature, an aggrieved party must, under New York law, prove something more than a parent's mere ownership of a majority or even all of the capital stock and parent's use of its power as an incident of its stock ownership to elect officers and directors of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover from parent corporation, as alleged alter ego of subsidiary, for breach of contract entered into with subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John V. Singleton, J., awarded damages to plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus, parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Berger v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, a parent corporation's immunity from liability for acts of a subsidiary will be toppled where the subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of the parent.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover from parent corporation, as alleged alter ego of subsidiary, for breach of contract entered into with subsidiary. The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus, parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another.
