Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Berger v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Mere labeling of a subsidiary corporation as a "division" of the parent corporation is not, under New York law, sufficient to establish that subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of parent.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover from parent corporation, as alleged alter ego of subsidiary, for breach of contract entered into with subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John V. Singleton, J., awarded damages to plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus, parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Berger v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under the substantive law of New York, a parent corporation's potential to dominate its subsidiary is insufficient to justify application of the instrumentality rule; New York law respects corporate identity, and its destruction by piercing or surrogation requires substantiation of facts, not just organizational charts and labels.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover from parent corporation, as alleged alter ego of subsidiary, for breach of contract entered into with subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John V. Singleton, J., awarded damages to plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus, parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Berger v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Complete stock ownership, common officers and directors, and the use of organizational charts illustrating lines of authority are business practices common to most parent-subsidiary relationships, and such proof of a parent corporation's potential to dominate its subsidiary is not, under New York law, sufficient to prove a community of management between the corporations.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover from parent corporation, as alleged alter ego of subsidiary, for breach of contract entered into with subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John V. Singleton, J., awarded damages to plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus, parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Berger v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Just as siamesing is a biological fact, so must corporate umbilication be anatomically demonstrated under New York law before a subsidiary can be found to be a mere instrumentality of a parent corporation.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover from parent corporation, as alleged alter ego of subsidiary, for breach of contract entered into with subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John V. Singleton, J., awarded damages to plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus, parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Berger v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, unlawful control sufficient to establish that a subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of a parent corporation must be shown to have been exercised at time that acts complained of took place.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover from parent corporation, as alleged alter ego of subsidiary, for breach of contract entered into with subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John V. Singleton, J., awarded damages to plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus, parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Milwaukee Motor Transp. Co. v. Commissioner of Taxation
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Fact that parent corporation allocates to its subsidiary a part of its business does not alter the corporate character of either.
Document Preview: Proceeding by railroad's wholly owned subsidiary trucking company for refund of corporate income taxes paid. The District Court, Ramsey County, J. Jerome Plunkett, J., entered summary judgment for plaintiff, and State Commissioner of Taxation appealed. The Supreme Court, Murphy, J., held that plaintiff, which, although it had authority to perform auxiliary railroad service, was not prevented from engaging in trucking services unrelated to railroad business, was separate and distinct corporate entity from the railroad; thus, imposition of corporate income tax on plaintiff on the same income on which the parent railroad had paid gross earnings tax for the same years did not constitute double taxation. Reversed. Otis and Kelly, JJ., dissented and filed opinions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: La Chemise Lacoste v. General Mills, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: That one corporation is wholly owned subsidiary of another and that there may be common directors does not justify piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Action involving rights to certain trademark. Certain defendants moved for dismissal or to be dropped as parties, principal defendant moved for production of documents, and plaintiff moved for protective order and injunction pendente lite. The District Court, Latchum, J., held, inter alia, that defendant corporation's parent corporation and sibling corporations were improperly joined, where complete relief on original pleadings could be granted without them and they were strangers to dispute, despite claimed agreements and relations between them and defendant. Defendants' motion granted and plaintiff's motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Trans-Amazonica Iquitos, S. A. v. Georgia S. S. Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Savannah Division.
Headnote: Ordinarily, corporations are to be treated as separate entities even though parent corporation owns all stock in subsidiary.
Document Preview: Action was brought for the hire of a vessel, the action for hire was settled, and, on the counterclaim of the consignee against the subcharterer-carrier and the charterer for loss of cargo, the District Court, Lawrence, Chief Judge, held that the subcharterer-carrier and charterer failed to prove navigational error which would have brought them within an exemption of the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act. The Court also held that to bring the loss of cargo within the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act exemption relating to loss resulting from unseaworthiness not caused by want of due diligence on the part of the carrier to make the ship seaworthy, the burden was on the carrier and charterer to show unseaworthiness and exercise of due diligence to make the vessel seaworthy, and the burden was not sustained. Subcharterer-carrier and charterer held jointly liable for loss of cargo; other decisions reserved.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Com. v. Beneficial Finance Co.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Parent's ownership of entire stock of its subsidiary as well as control over latter's affairs do not, without more, warrant treating separate and distinct corporate entities identically.
Document Preview: Prosecutions of various small loan companies and individuals on charges of bribery and conspiracy. The Superior Court, Quirico, J., found defendants guilty and appeals were taken. The Supreme Judicial Court, Spiegel, J., held that indictments were not invalid because of use of material developed during legislative investigation by grand jury or because of presence of number of prosecutors while grand jury was deliberating and that evidence sustained convictions of corporate and individual defendants. Affirmed. See also 355 Mass. 373, 244 N.E.2d 586.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Thomas v. Maigo Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Wholly owned subsidiaries which were controlled, dominated and financed by parent were separate and distinct legal entities.
Document Preview: Proceedings on motion to strike affirmative defenses. The Erie Special Term, James O. Moore, J., granted the motion and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that subsidiary corporations may not be considered as employees' of parent and therefore fellow-employees of plaintiff in negligence action. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Roman Catholic Archbishop v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: "Alter ego" theory makes "parent" liable for actions of "subsidiary" which it controls, but it does not mean that where "parent" controls several subsidiaries each subsidiary then becomes liable for actions of all other subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Mandamus proceeding to compel the Superior Court of Alameda County to enter summary judgment in favor of petitioner, a corporation sole, in suit against petitioner to recover amount deposited with European monastery of same religious faith for purchase of dog which was not delivered and to recover additional amount expended for similar dog. The Court of Appeal, David, J., held that uncontroverted affidavit that corporation sole had no dealings with European monastery negated any possibility that corporation so controlled and dominated the monastery as to be liable for its actions under alter ego doctrine; thus, plaintiff was not entitled to recover. Peremptory writ issued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: State ex rel. Utilities Commission v. Morgan
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: To prevent defeat of public interest and circumvention of public policy, parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary may be treated as one.
Document Preview: Proceeding on telephone company's application for authority to increase rates. The Utilities Commission entered order approving rate increases, and the Court of Appeals affirmed, 7 N.C.App. 576, 173 S.E.2d 479. The Attorney General appealed. The Supreme Court, Lake, J., held, inter alia, that Utilities Commission's finding as to fair value of telephone company's properties at end of test period was without substantial evidentiary support. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: P.F. Collier & Son Corp. v. F.T.C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Generally, absent highly unusual circumstances, corporate entity will not be disregarded; but where stock ownership is resorted to for purpose of controlling subsidiary so that it may be used as mere agency or instrumentality of the parent, courts will deal with substance of transaction involved as if corporate agency did not exist and as the justice of the case may require.
Document Preview: Petition to review order of Federal Trade Commission requiring corporations to cease and desist from unfair and deceptive trade practices allegedly employed in door-to-door sales of encyclopedias. The Court of Appeals, Celebrezze, Circuit Judge, held that findings that dissolved subsidiary corporation had engaged in various illegal trade practices was supported by substantial evidence, as was finding that such subsidiary was so dominated and controlled by parent that latter might be held vicariously responsible for its acts; and that, where successor subsidiary was merely disguised continuance of dissolved subsidiary, it was subject to cease and desist order issued against dissolved subsidiary. Order enforced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: American Trading & Production Corp. v. Fischbach & Moore, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: That parent corporation shows concern about subsidiary's affairs, asks for reports and consults with subsidiary's officers does not amount to domination of day-to-day business decisions and disregard of the corporate entity necessary to impose liability on parent.
Document Preview: Action against parent and subsidiary corporations for damages from fire allegedly caused by faulty electrical wiring installed by subsidiary. The District Court, Decker, J., held that where corporate parent of subsidiary which installed allegedly defective wiring which caused fire resulting in damage to plaintiffs exercised supervision over general performance of subsidiary but separate corporate identities were scrupulously maintained and subsidiary was not operated as an undercapitalized dummy and no fraud, injustice or unfairness was disclosed which would justify ignoring separate identities of the corporations, parent was not liable for allegedly negligent acts of subsidiary. Parent's motion for summary judgment granted. See also D.C., 47 F.R.D. 155.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: American Trading & Production Corp. v. Fischbach & Moore, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Significant factor in applying instrumentality test is the extent to which corporate formalities are observed by parent and subsidiary corporations.
Document Preview: Action against parent and subsidiary corporations for damages from fire allegedly caused by faulty electrical wiring installed by subsidiary. The District Court, Decker, J., held that where corporate parent of subsidiary which installed allegedly defective wiring which caused fire resulting in damage to plaintiffs exercised supervision over general performance of subsidiary but separate corporate identities were scrupulously maintained and subsidiary was not operated as an undercapitalized dummy and no fraud, injustice or unfairness was disclosed which would justify ignoring separate identities of the corporations, parent was not liable for allegedly negligent acts of subsidiary. Parent's motion for summary judgment granted. See also D.C., 47 F.R.D. 155.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: American Trading & Production Corp. v. Fischbach & Moore, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Even if subsidiary is the mere instrumentality of the parent, that circumstance by itself will not justify imposition of liability; the corporate entity is ignored only when ends of justice require it.
Document Preview: Action against parent and subsidiary corporations for damages from fire allegedly caused by faulty electrical wiring installed by subsidiary. The District Court, Decker, J., held that where corporate parent of subsidiary which installed allegedly defective wiring which caused fire resulting in damage to plaintiffs exercised supervision over general performance of subsidiary but separate corporate identities were scrupulously maintained and subsidiary was not operated as an undercapitalized dummy and no fraud, injustice or unfairness was disclosed which would justify ignoring separate identities of the corporations, parent was not liable for allegedly negligent acts of subsidiary. Parent's motion for summary judgment granted. See also D.C., 47 F.R.D. 155.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Acme Precision Products, Inc. v. American Alloys Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Where subsidiary corporation acts as direct instrumentality of and in direct cooperation with its parent corporation, and where properties and affairs of the two are so inextricably confused as to a particular transaction, the corporate structures cannot exist separate one from the other.
Document Preview: Patent infringement suit wherein defendant counterclaimed for treble damages under Sherman Anti-Trust Act. The United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri, William R. Collinson, J., found that patent was invalid and dismissed claim for infringement and counterclaim and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Lay, Circuit Judge, held that finding that assignee and licensee of patent obtained by assignee's subsidiary and licensee's predecessor had no knowledge of any fraud in procurement of patent upon which to ground claim for treble damages based upon monopoly in violation of Sherman Anti-Trust Act was clearly erroneous. Dismissal of counterclaim vacated and case remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Royal Industries v. St. Regis Paper Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Separate identities of parent corporation and its subsidiary, even wholly owned subsidiary, would not be disregarded unless recognition of their separateness, under the circumstances, would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Action against patent licensee for infringement and unfair competition on basis that the license had been terminated by plaintiff for breach by defendant of oral condition to written license, wherein defendant moved for summary judgment. The United States District Court for the Central District of California, Francis C. Whelan, J., granted defendant's motion for summary judgment and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Hufstedler, Circuit Judge, held that where plaintiff parent corporation and its subsidiary were colicensors of patent and there was no showing that refusal to permit plaintiff to disregard separate identity of its subsidiary would sanction a fraud or work injustice, subsidiary would not be treated as plaintiff's alter ego and plaintiff could not terminate licensing agreement on basis of alleged breach of oral condition by licensee without joinder or consent of the subsidiary. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: A & I Realty Corp. v. Kent Dry Cleaners, Inc.
Court: District Court, Nassau County, New York, Second District.
Headnote: Where corporation is so dominated and the interference with its activities so obtrusive that when there is attempt separation between parent and subsidiary, such attempt will work fraud, parent company is considered principal and subsidiary the agent.
Document Preview: Action by landlord against corporate tenant for breach of lease. The District Court of Nassau County, Second District, Harold Fertig, J., held that where lease provided that, in event of default and reentry of landlord, damages would be difference between rent reserved and rent collected and received and such deficiency would be due and payable in monthly payments during remainder of unexpired term, landlord had separate cause of action for each month's rent as it became due. Judgment for plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Broenen v. Beaunit Corp.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Corporation's wholly owned subsidiary was corporation separate from its parent.
Document Preview: Class action by holder of corporate debentures, for herself and others similarly situated, for damages and equitable relief on account of a corporate merger allegedly violating the obligations of a trust indenture executed by a party to the merger. The District Court, Myron L. Gordon, J., on motion to quash service of process and for dismissal for lack of jurisdiction over the person of one defendant held that grounds for exercise of personal jurisdiction by Wisconsin courts were shown. On motion to dismiss for failure to meet monetary jurisdictional requirements the court held that the action was a true class action permitting aggregation of claims. On motions to dismiss and for summary judgment the court held that in the trust indenture protecting the rights of holders of a corporation's debentures, a specific provision for conversion of the debentures controlled over a general provision and that the merger did not violate the rights of debenture holders. Defendants'...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Ira Haupt & Co.
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to maintain suit against corporation on theory that corporation and its subsidiary are one and the same, corporation must be shown to have had not mere majority or complete stock control but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to the transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own and that such control had been used to perpetrate violation of legal duty and that such breach of duty proximately caused injury or loss complained of.
Document Preview: Petition to review order and decision of referee in bankruptcy authorizing trustee for bankrupt to compromise two controversies. The District Court, Motley, J., held that referee was justified in approving settlement of claims of bankrupt against corporation arising out of losses sustained by bankrupt's taking as collateral for loans to vegetable oil company warehouse receipts stolen from corporation's subsidiary and forged by officer of oil company, on theory that outcome of litigation was in doubt. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cameron Equipment Corp. v. People
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: For subsidiary corporation to become mere instrumentality of parent corporation's business, parent's control of subsidiary must, as to transactions involved, preclude subsidiary from having separate mind, will, or existence and must be used to commit fraud or wrong or to violate a legal duty in violation of complaining party's rights, and the control or breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: Action in which the Supreme Court, Trial Term, Erie County, Frank J. Kronenberg, J., awarded sub-sub-subcontractor, under contract with state for elimination of railroad grade crossings, $23,742.73 on its cross claim, and defendants, which included prime contractor and indemnity company, appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Marsh, J., held that sub-sub-subcontractor was too remote from prime contractor to file a valid lien under the Lien Law, and that corporate entity of sub-subcontractor under contract with state for elimination of railroad crossings would not be disregarded to permit sub-sub-subcontractor to come within ambit of lien law provision applicable only to prime contractors, subcontractors, and sub-subcontractors. Judgment, insofar as appealed from, reversed, and cross claim dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: ACS Industries, Inc. v. Keller Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Where alleged agency or alter ego claim is based on an agreement whereby one corporate entity is made subordinate to the other, the corporate veil will be pierced; however, although the officers and directors of the two corporations are the same, the corporate veil will not be pierced so long as the officers and directors can be said to wear two hats and operate in theoretically distinct capacities for each corporate entity.
Document Preview: On motion to dismiss for lack of in personam jurisdiction, the District Court, Timbers, C.J., held that, notwithstanding fact that cause of action did not arise out of transaction between plaintiff and defendant's subsidiary, and no aspects of disputed transaction occurred within jurisdictional forum, service in Connecticut on defendant's subsidiary was sufficient to confer jurisdiction over defendant where plaintiff made threshold demonstration that defendant and its subsidiary failed to maintain sufficient formal separateness; that it necessarily followed, from disposition of jurisdictional issue, that for venue purposes defendant constructively did business in Connecticut through a subsidiary; and that there was not controlling question of law as to which there is a substantial ground for difference of opinion justifying an immediate appeal. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Ira Haupt & Co.
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil is pierced to permit assertion against parent of liability incurred by dominated subsidiary when the parent has taken over management and direction of the subsidiary's affairs.
Document Preview: Petitions by creditor for review and reversal of order of bankruptcy court sustaining its summary jurisdiction to adjudicate controversy between trustee and creditor. The District Court, Pollack, J., held that creditor which intervened in proceedings in bankruptcy in opposition to motion of limited partners in bankrupt to dismiss petition for arrangement and which proclaimed its status as creditor and stated intention of filing claim submitted to summary jurisdiction of bankruptcy court even though it did not file formal written proof of claim. Petitions for review denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Ira Haupt & Co.
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: Status of subsidiary corporation as separate entity should be disregarded when that is required to avoid fraud and injustice.
Document Preview: Petitions by creditor for review and reversal of order of bankruptcy court sustaining its summary jurisdiction to adjudicate controversy between trustee and creditor. The District Court, Pollack, J., held that creditor which intervened in proceedings in bankruptcy in opposition to motion of limited partners in bankrupt to dismiss petition for arrangement and which proclaimed its status as creditor and stated intention of filing claim submitted to summary jurisdiction of bankruptcy court even though it did not file formal written proof of claim. Petitions for review denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Brown v. Margrande Compania Naviera, S. A.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Extent of stock ownership and potential control possessed by a holding company is not determining factor when its liability for subsidiary's acts and obligations are in question; corporate entity will stand unless fraud, illegality, or wrongdoing which produces injury or complaint exists.
Document Preview: Action against parent corporation and its subsidiaries for salvage services in towing and saving tanker chartered by one subsidiary and carrying other subsidiary's cargo. Upon parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Kellam, J., held that instrumentality rule would not be invoked to make parent corporation liable, even though corporations had interlocking directors and officers, and though subsidiaries were wholly owned by parent corporation, where there was no injustice, fraud, or wrong, public convenience was not affected, and no illicit act was committed. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Beneficial Finance Co. of Midland v. Miskell
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. Austin.
Headnote: A court is authorized to disregard corporate fiction separating parent and its subsidiaries when a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation and where corporate fiction is used to circumvent a statute.
Document Preview: Subsidiary's application for a license to engage in loan business under the regulatory loan act was denied by the commissioner on ground that parent held either directly or through subsidiaries 60 Texas regulatory loan licenses previously issued. The 53rd District Court, Travis County, Herman Jones, J., sustained denial, and appeal was taken. The Court of Civil Appeals, Hughes, J., held that parent Delaware corporation, by accepting 60 licenses, through wholly-owned subsidiaries under the regulatory loan act had in effect agreed to be bound by 60 license limitation provision of the act and was in no position to question constitutionality of that provision. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Pauley Petroleum Inc. v. Continental Oil Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Delaware.
Headnote: Corporate entities as between parent and subsidiary may be disregarded and parent regarded in law and fact as sole party in particular transaction where interest of justice so requires, when such matters as fraud, contravention of law or contract or public wrong are involved, or where equitable considerations among members of the corporation require it.
Document Preview: Action by Delaware corporations and Mexican corporation for injunction which would require defendant Delaware corporation to cause its wholly owned Mexican subsidiary to cease prosecution of action filed in Mexico. The Court of Chancery, New Castle County, 231 A.2d 450, denied the preliminary injunction and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Wolcott, C.J., held that where plaintiffs failed to show fraud or other elements which would authorize disregard of separate corporate entities of defendant Delaware corporation and its Mexican subsidiary, injunction was properly denied. Affirmed. See also Del., 235 A.2d 284.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Perlman v. Great States Life Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, In Department.
Headnote: Where parent and subsidiary corporations maintain separate identities and charge each other for services performed corporations will be treated as separate entities.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought suit against foreign corporation for failure or refusal to re-issue stock to plaintiff. The District Court, City and County of Denver, George M. McNamara, J., quashed service and dismissed the complaint, and the plaintiff brought error. The Supreme Court, Sutton, J., held that foreign corporation reinsurance treaties with domestic insurers, stock ownership in domestic insurer and common directors did not establish the minimal status of doing business within state necessary to give court jurisdiction over corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Dobyns-Taylor Hardware Co. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Tennessee, Northeastern Division.
Headnote: Where parent corporation controls subsidiary so that it may be used as mere agency or instrumentality of parent corporation, courts will deal with substance of transaction involved as if corporate agency did not exist and as justice of case may require, or may disregard the separate corporate entities and treat the two corporations as one.
Document Preview: Action for refund of federal income taxes based on claimed operating loss carryback. The District Court, Neese, J., held that where officials of parent corporation exercised complete dominion over manager of subsidiary, manager was agent and employee of parent which paid sum to bank in exchange for release of both corporations from liability for loss resulting from criminal machinations of manager who had discounted spurious conditional sales contracts of fictitious makers and parent was entitled to deduct such payments as loss arising from theft in fiscal year theft was discovered. Judgment for taxpayer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Huski-Bilt, Inc. v. First-Citizens Bank & Trust Co.
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Ordinarily, corporation retains its separate and distinct entity where its stock is owned partly or entirely by another corporation.
Document Preview: Action by borrower against lending bank for determination that loan was usurious and for other relief. The Superior Court, Mecklenburg County, H. L. Riddle, Special Judge, entered judgment adverse to plaintiff which appealed. The Supreme Court, Pless, J., held that evidence supported finding that bank and insurer were separate corporations, although bank and three of its principal officers owned 90% Of insurer, and that requirement by bank that borrower take credit life policies upon debtors was not a form of usury. No error.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Huski-Bilt, Inc. v. First-Citizens Bank & Trust Co.
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Under "instrumentality rule" except in event of express agency, estoppel or direct tort, for parent corporation to be liable for contracts of its subsidiary it must be proved that parent completely dominated policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that subsidiary as to transaction had no separate mind, will or existence of its own, that control was used by parent to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of legal rights and the control and breach of duty must proximately cause injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: Action by borrower against lending bank for determination that loan was usurious and for other relief. The Superior Court, Mecklenburg County, H. L. Riddle, Special Judge, entered judgment adverse to plaintiff which appealed. The Supreme Court, Pless, J., held that evidence supported finding that bank and insurer were separate corporations, although bank and three of its principal officers owned 90% Of insurer, and that requirement by bank that borrower take credit life policies upon debtors was not a form of usury. No error.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hermetic Seal Corp. v. Savoy Electronics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court S.D. Florida.
Headnote: If a principal officer of parent corporation maintains an office in Florida from which he directs and controls the business operations of the Florida subsidiary, and parent's board meetings, corporate records, and shareholders are in Florida, then subsidiary may be considered the alter ego or instrumentality of the parent so that the parent may thereby be doing business in Florida. F.S.A. § 48.081.
Document Preview: Judgment affirmed, 5 Cir., 401 F.2d 775. On motion to dismiss suit for lack of jurisdiction over the person the District Court, Fulton, Chief Judge, held that plaintiff who sought to sue parent corporation by serving its Florida subsidiary with process failed to sustain its burden of proving that the parent had, either by itself or through its subsidiary, the requisite contact with Florida to justify service under Florida long arm statute. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Wirtz v. Mercantile Stores Co.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Fact that defendant corporation exercised certain supervision over employment policies and practices and that there was an interrelationship of certain officers with second corporation, upon which process was served, did not render second corporation the agent of defendant corporation or destroy presumption of a subsidiary with a separate corporate entity. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(d) (3), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: On motion by defendant corporation to quash process and to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction, the District Court, Daugherty, J., held that evidence adduced by plaintiff United States was insufficient to show that party served with process, who was store manager of second corporation, had any legal relationship with defendant corporation other than through parent-subsidiary corporate structure of the stores, so that service of process upon the manager was not effective as to defendant corporation. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Wallach v. Williams
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey Appellate Division.
Headnote: Use of subsidiary corporation for purpose of holding title to property leased to parent corporation was not per se fraudulent.
Document Preview: Action for injuries sustained by business invitee at service station when he was struck by automobile. The Superior Court, Law Division, entered judgment for lessor, lessee and sublessee of service station and against owner of automobile which struck plaintiff and plaintiff appealed. The Superior Court, Appellate Division, Labrecque, J.A.D., held that where sublease of service station gave sublessee right to exercise control over conduct of business, sublessor had no duty to plaintiff invitee who was struck by automobile which had been left with motor running even though sublessor routinely had sent its agent to inspect premises and even if sublessee habitually failed to require that motors be shut off before customers were served. Affirmed. Affirmed 52 N.J. 503, 246 A.2d 713.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Pauley Petroleum, Inc. v. Continental Oil Co.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Mexican subsidiary of defendant Delaware corporation which had its own directors, officers and records and which had some officers and personnel in common with parent corporation was not mere instrumentality of parent and parent would not be enjoined from prosecuting suits filed by subsidiary in Mexico against plaintiff Delaware corporation and plaintiff Mexican corporation on theory that defendant subsidiary was responsive to defendant's wishes.
Document Preview: Action by Delaware corporation and Mexican corporation to enjoin defendant Delaware corporation and its agents and associates from prosecuting lawsuits pending in Mexico. The Court of Chancery, New Castle County, Duffy, Chancellor, held that Mexican subsidiary of defendant Delaware corporation which had its own directors, officers and records and which had some officers and personnel in common with parent corporation was not mere instrumentality of parent and parent would not be enjoined from prosecuting suits filed by subsidiary in Mexico against plaintiff Delaware corporation and plaintiff Mexican corporation on theory that defendant subsidiary was responsive to defendant's wishes. Temporary restraining order dissolved and motion for preliminary injunction denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Pauley Petroleum, Inc. v. Continental Oil Co.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Corporation is entity distinct from its stockholders even if its stock is wholly owned by one corporation.
Document Preview: Action by Delaware corporation and Mexican corporation to enjoin defendant Delaware corporation and its agents and associates from prosecuting lawsuits pending in Mexico. The Court of Chancery, New Castle County, Duffy, Chancellor, held that Mexican subsidiary of defendant Delaware corporation which had its own directors, officers and records and which had some officers and personnel in common with parent corporation was not mere instrumentality of parent and parent would not be enjoined from prosecuting suits filed by subsidiary in Mexico against plaintiff Delaware corporation and plaintiff Mexican corporation on theory that defendant subsidiary was responsive to defendant's wishes. Temporary restraining order dissolved and motion for preliminary injunction denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Washington and Old Dominion Users Ass'n v. Washington and Old Dominion R. R.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia.
Headnote: Before the corporate entity may be properly disregarded and the parent corporation held liable for the acts of its subsidiary, it must be shown not only that undue domination and control were exercised by the parent over the subsidiary but also that this control was exercised in such a manner as to defraud and wrong a party dealing with the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Appeal from order of State Corporation Commission authorizing railroad to abandon the intrastate operation of its entire line. The Supreme Court of Appeals, Eggleston, Chief Justice, held that evidence that operation of intrastate freight railroad was conducted at a loss, that there was no continued public use for railroad and no reasonable prospect that its operation would become profitable, and that other public facilities were reasonably available to users of railroad sustained order of State Corporation Commission that railroad might abandon its operation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Walkovszky v. Carlton
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Although either the circumstance that a corporation is a fragment of a larger corporate combine which actually conducts a business, or that a corporation is a dummy for its individual stockholders who in reality are carrying on a business in their own personal capacities for purely personal rather than corporate ends would justify treating the corporation as an agent and piercing the corporate veil to reach the principal, in the first circumstance only a larger corporate entity could be held financially responsible, while in the other circumstance the stockholders would be personally liable.
Document Preview: Action against corporation in name of which a taxicab was registered, driver of the taxicab, nine other corporations in whose names other taxicabs were registered, two additional corporations, and three individuals for injuries sustained by plaintiff when struck by the taxicab. The Supreme Court, Edward G. Baker, J., granted motion of an individual defendant who was claimed to be a stockholder of ten corporations, including corporation in name of which taxicab was registered, to dismiss the complaint as to him for failure to state a cause of action, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, 24 A.D.2d 582, 262 N.Y.S.2d 334, reversed and denied the motion and individual defendant appealed by leave of the Appellate Division on a certified question. The Court of Appeals, Fuld, J., held that complaint containing allegations that individual defendant organized, managed, dominated and controlled a fragmented corporate entity and that fleet ownership of taxicabs had...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Sylvia Martin Foundation, Inc. v. Swearingen
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: Though corporation was wholly owned subsidiary, it was separate entity from parent.
Document Preview: Derivative action by stockholder of Indiana parent on behalf of parent and its stockholders and derivatively on behalf of wholly owned Maryland and Luxembourg subsidiaries for breach of trust duties of officers and directors of parent by authorizing Luxembourg subsidiary to float bond issue outside United States, thus necessitating payment of higher interest rates. The case was removed. The District Court, Ryan, J., held that parent-subsidiary relationship between Indiana and Maryland corporations provided no basis for keeping the Maryland subsidiary in the suit, that parent, which did no business in New York and was thus not subject to process there and which had not been served by service on Maryland subsidiary, was entitled to dismissal of the complaint as to itself, and that failure to join indispensable parties necessitated dismissal of complaint as to all defendants. Complaint dismissed as to all defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kueckelhan v. Federal Old Line Ins. Co. (Mut.)
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: Principle requiring that corporate entity on occasion be disregarded is especially applicable in cases involving parent or principal corporation and subsidiary corporations which merely acquiesce in registered decrees of principal.
Document Preview: Proceeding by insurance commissioner for rehabilitation of mutual insurer. The Superior Court, King County, George H. Revelle, J., appointed commissioner as rehabilitator, and insurer appealed. The Supreme Court, Hamilton, J., held that the insurance code provisions in question were constitutional and that under circumstances, court did not err in directing rehabilitation, on ground that mutual insurer's operations were hazardous, in view of excessive concentration of investments in single project, dubious security of mortgage guarantees, insufficient return for mortgage property, practice of periodically increasing face amount of mortgages to effect amounts of unpaid interest, deferment of interest payments, and failure to consider mortgages in default, despite insurer's solvency in ordinary business sense and despite its good record of payment. Affirmed and remanded. Hunter, J., dissented in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: B-W Acceptance Corp. v. Spencer
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Ordinarily corporation retains its separate and distinct identity where its stock is owned partly or entirely by another corporation.
Document Preview: Action to recover on note wherein defendants filed counterclaims. The Superior Court, Mecklenburg County, G. L. Houk, J., entered judgment adverse to defendants and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Parker, C.J., held that where counterclaim filed by purchasers of dry cleaners and washers failed to allege facts to show that parent corporation had complete domination of policy and business practice of purchaser of note, issued in connection with purchase of machines or of manufacturer of machines, corporate structure would not be disregarded and institution of action did not toll running of statute against plaintiff finance company's alleged alter ego manufacturer or alleged alter ego parent corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: B-W Acceptance Corp. v. Spencer
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: To invoke "instrumentality rule" whereby parent is held liable for conduct of subsidiary, in any case, except express agency, estoppel or direct tort, it must be proved that there is complete domination of finances, policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that, as to transaction, subsidiary had no separate mind, will or existence of its own, the control must have been used to commit fraud or wrong, and control and breach of duty must have proximately caused injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: Action to recover on note wherein defendants filed counterclaims. The Superior Court, Mecklenburg County, G. L. Houk, J., entered judgment adverse to defendants and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Parker, C.J., held that where counterclaim filed by purchasers of dry cleaners and washers failed to allege facts to show that parent corporation had complete domination of policy and business practice of purchaser of note, issued in connection with purchase of machines or of manufacturer of machines, corporate structure would not be disregarded and institution of action did not toll running of statute against plaintiff finance company's alleged alter ego manufacturer or alleged alter ego parent corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Palmer v. Stokely
Court: United States District Court W.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation is mere instrumentality of parent when (1) parent owns all stock; (2) both have common directors and officers; (3) parent finances subsidiary; (4) parent causes subsidiary's incorporation; (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) parent pays salaries or expenses of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary has no business except with its parent or subsidiary corporation or no assets except those transferred by its parent or subsidiary; (8) directors and officers do not act independently in interests of subsidiary; (9) formal legal requirements of subsidiary such as keeping corporate minutes are not observed; (10) distinctions between parent and subsidiary and subsidiary and its subsidiary are disregarded or confused; (11) subsidiary does not have full board of directors.
Document Preview: Action by trustee in bankruptcy against individuals and company owned by them to recover amounts allegedly fraudulently transferred to defendants. The District Court, Daugherty, J., held, inter alia, that cancellation of amount owed bankrupt by corporation controlled by persons who controlled bankrupt was void where it occurred within one year prior to bankruptcy, there were creditors of bankrupt existing at time of cancellation, there were others who subsequently became creditors of bankrupt, bankrupt was insolvent at time of cancellation and was engaged in business for which property remaining in its hands after cancellation was unreasonably small capital, cancellation was made by owners in behalf of bankrupt and they believed it would incur debts beyond its ability to pay as debts matured, and was also made with actual intent to hinder, delay or defraud existing creditors and particularly premium stamp holders. Judgment for trustee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Whayne v. Transportation Management Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: For instrumentality rule to be applicable, it must be shown that parent controls subsidiary to such degree that subsidiary is mere instrumentality, that parent is perpetrating fraud or wrong through its subsidiary, for example, torts, violation of statute, or stripping subsidiary of its assets, and that an unjust loss or injury to claimant, such as insolvency of the subsidiary, exists.
Document Preview: Action for injuries sustained by cook aboard vessel owned by one corporation trict Court, on defendant's motion to disagainst a second corporation. The Dismiss, Van Dusen, J., held that where defendant corporation owned no stock in corporate owner of vessel, the two corporations had only one common director and officer, corporate vessel owner regularly paid defendant for bookkeeping and other services that defendant performed, directors meetings of corporations were held at different times and in different places, defendant did not direct movement of vessel, purchase any equipment or supplies used on it, finance building of it or hire or fire personnel on board, corporate vessel owner was not mere instrumentality of defendant and defendant was not liable for cook's injuries. Action dismissed with prejudice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Whayne v. Transportation Management Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In determining whether parent controls subsidiary to such a degree that subsidiary is mere instrumentality so as to make parent liable for wrongful conduct of subsidiary, court must weigh many factors and it is not the opportunity to control but actual control which is determinative.
Document Preview: Action for injuries sustained by cook aboard vessel owned by one corporation trict Court, on defendant's motion to disagainst a second corporation. The Dismiss, Van Dusen, J., held that where defendant corporation owned no stock in corporate owner of vessel, the two corporations had only one common director and officer, corporate vessel owner regularly paid defendant for bookkeeping and other services that defendant performed, directors meetings of corporations were held at different times and in different places, defendant did not direct movement of vessel, purchase any equipment or supplies used on it, finance building of it or hire or fire personnel on board, corporate vessel owner was not mere instrumentality of defendant and defendant was not liable for cook's injuries. Action dismissed with prejudice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Markow v. Alcock
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors in determining whether to disregard corporate fiction include: (1) are formal legal requirements observed; (2) is subsidiary adequately financed or does parent furnish capitalization; (3) by whom are salaries and expenses paid; (4) do subsidiary's directors act in independent and primary interest of parents; (5) are operations so integrated through commingling of funds, interactivities and common direction and supervision that they should be considered as one enterprise; and (6) generally, is one corporation so organized and controlled and its business conducted in such a manner as to make it merely an agency, instrumentality, adjunct, or alter ego of the other.
Document Preview: Action by corporation's bankruptcy trustee claiming a mortgage to be invalid as in fraud of general creditors. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, Emett C. Choate, J., rendered judgment for defendants, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Benjamin C. Dawkins, Jr., District Judge, held that evidence did not establish that corporate mortgagor was a wholly owned subsidiary of bankrupt corporation, nor that such mortgagor was not a legally constituted separate corporate entity. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hughes v. Kaiser Jeep Corp.
Court: United States District Court E.D. South Carolina, Orangeburg Division.
Headnote: Where automobile sales corporation was subsidiary sales organization of automobile manufacturing corporation, and relationship of corporations was interrelated and entwined, acts of one corporation were acts of other corporation.
Document Preview: Diversity action for wrongful death was brought in the District Court of the United States for the Eastern District of South Carolina, Orangeburg Division, by administrator of deceased against Nevada automobile manufacturing corporation and Michigan automobile sales corporation for death of deceased. The corporations made a motion to quash return of service of summons and to dismiss the action. The District Court, Simons, J., held that automobile manufacturing corporation and its subsidiary Michigan sales corporation were doing business' in South Carolina and had such contracts with South Carolina that they were subject to jurisdiction of District Court and subject to service of process statutes of South Carolina, so that they could be legally served with process by service of summons and complaint on South Carolina Secretary of State, personal service in South Carolina on executive assistant to general sales manager of manufacturing corporation, and by personal service...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Botwinick v. Credit Exchange, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Neither similarity of names between parent and subsidiary corporations nor total ownership of stock of subsidiary by parent nor fact that single individual is active chief executive of both corporations will per se justify a court in piercing the corporate veil if each corporation maintains a bonafide separate and distinct corporate existence.
Document Preview: Business libel case. The Court of Common Pleas No. 3 (heard in Court of Common Pleas No. 5) of the County of Philadelphia, No. 729 December Term, 1963, Lee Weinrott, J., dismissed the preliminary objections. The order was entered on January 7, 1965. The defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, No. 163 January Term, 1965, Jones, J., held that New York corporation was not doing business' within Pennsylvania even though it had a subsidiary which was a Pennsylvania corporation. Order reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: National Dairy Products Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Courts may disregard the legal fiction of corporate entity where the relationship between parent and subsidiary is not one of stock ownership alone and the subsidiary is run by the parent in accordance with the parent's policies and objectives, and with independent existence in form only.
Document Preview: The defendant was convicted of conspiring to fix prices and eliminate competition in violation of the Sherman Act and of selling milk at unreasonably low prices for the purpose of destroying competition in violation of the Robinson-Patman Act. The United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri, John W. Oliver, J., 231 F.Supp. 663, rendered judgment, and the defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Matthes, Circuit Judge, held that the evidence sustained the conviction and that there was no error in respect to the rulings on the evidence or the instructions to the jury or the use of grand jury minutes for refreshment purposes. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Chase Manhattan Bank v. Nissho Pacific Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In view of course of dealings between domestic wholly owned subsidiary corporation, which purchased goods for shipment to Japan, and its Japanese parent corporation and between seller and subsidiary corporation as buyer, subsidiary corporation and parent corporation could be considered as one to extent that subsidiary corporation did not usurp its authority or wrongfully preempt space on vessel reserved by parent corporation for shipment of such goods.
Document Preview: The bank which financed acquisition by borrower of goods sold to one of the defendants sued the buyer and carrier for breach of contract and conversion. From an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term, New York County, Edgar J. Nathan, J., which denied motion by plaintiff and cross motions by defendants for summary judgment, the plaintiff and the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Stevens, J., held, inter alia, that buyer's claim against seller for damages for default on prior contracts constituted a proper setoff against bank's demand for payment of draft for purchase price of goods and that the carrier was justified in delivering goods to buyer upon presentation of negotiable bill of lading issued to buyer as shipper. Order reversed on the law, complaint dismissed and summary judgment granted to defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fooshee v. Interstate Vending Co.
Court: United States District Court D. Kansas.
Headnote: Separate entities of parent and subsidiary bodies corporation are usually entitled to be so treated, but court has power to pierce the corporate veil where the facts warrant.
Document Preview: Suit under Clayton Act for treble damages for alleged violations of Sherman Act. The Illinois corporate parent defendant moved to quash service and dismiss. The District Court, Wesley E. Brown, J., held that parent on which checks for salaries and purchases of machines were drawn and from which approval was necessary before officials of Kansas subsidiaries might purchase machines and which sent personnel to Kansas to give subsidiaries assistance on bookkeeping and accounting procedures and maintenance problems and to help solicit new locations for machines was found in Kansas within venue section of Clayton Act. Motion denied.

Title: Consolidated Sun Ray, Inc. v. Oppenstein
Court: United States Court of Appeals Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Where there was no reasonable doubt but that parent corporation did completely control and use subsidiary corporation which executed agreement as a mere conduit or adjunct of parent corporation itself, ultimate fact question for determination was whether parent corporation's purpose in so doing was unlawful or improper.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Consolidated Sun Ray, Inc. v. Oppenstein
Court: United States Court of Appeals Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, where subsidiary is a mere conduit, instrumentality, or adjunct through which parent corporation achieves some improper end, subsidiary's own corporate identity will be disregarded.
Document Preview: Suit by landlord to recover damages for breach of lease against tenant corporation and parent corporation. The United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri, Floyd R. Gibson, Chief Judge, 216 F.Supp. 268, entered judgment adverse to tenant and parent corporation and the parent corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, Vogel, Circuit Judge, held that the parent corporation's complete and absolute control over subsidiary, making subsidiary a supplemental part of parent corporation's economic unit, and parent corporation's operation of subsidiary without sufficient funds to meet its obligations to creditors was circumstantial evidence from which advisory jury and court, as finders of facts, could reasonably draw inference that parent corporation's purpose was improper and detrimental to landlord who had signed lease with subsidiary, but there was error in refusing to admit certain evidence on issues of mitigation of damages. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, Inc. v. Atlas
Court: Supreme Court, Nassau County, New York, Part III.
Headnote: Exception to concept of corporate entity exists when business is carried on by individual stockholder or a partnership of stockholders or by parent corporation which so wholly dominates its subsidiary as in fact to operate its business.
Document Preview: Action by judgment creditor to recover the amount of the judgment from defendants. The Supreme Court, Special Term, Nassau County, Part III, Bernard S. Meyer, J., held, inter alia, that where corporate purchaser of realty had been dormant prior to contract to purchase, it had no regularly elected officers or directors and it had no assets, liabilities or income, and vendor did not rely upon third party's credit, vendor which obtained judgment against corporate purchaser could collect such judgment from corporation's president. Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fawcett v. Missouri Pac. R. Co.
Court: United States District Court W.D. Louisiana, Lake Charles Division.
Headnote: If ownership of stock of one corporation by another is resorted to only for purpose of normally participating in affairs of subsidiary corporation in manner usual to stockholders, and not for purpose of taking some unfair advantage of subsidiary or using it as mere adjunct to main corporation or as subterfuge to justify wrongdoing, their identity as separate corporations will not be disregarded and their respective rights when dealing with each other with respect to separate property will be recognized and maintained.
Document Preview: Action against railroad under Federal Employers' Liability Act. The District Court, Hunter, J., held that freight company employee, who died as result of being crushed between truck tractors on flatcar being loaded on siding owned by defendant railroad, who was not on railroad payroll, who was not doing work that railroad was required to do, and who was not under supervision of railroad employees was not employee of railroad within coverage of Federal Employers' Liability Act at time that he met his death, and his administratrix had no cause of action against railroad where freight company was not alter ego of railroad even though railroad owned all outstanding stock of freight company and five officers of freight company were also officers of railroad. Summary judgment for defendant. Judgment affirmed, 347 F.2d 233.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fawcett v. Missouri Pac. R. Co.
Court: United States District Court W.D. Louisiana, Lake Charles Division.
Headnote: Extent of stock ownership and the mere potential control of one company over another is not controlling factor in determining whether to disregard corporate entity, and something must be disclosed to indicate exercise of undue domination or influence resulting in infringement on rights of subservient corporation for benefit of dominant one; otherwise, rights of separate corporations with respect to their corporate property will be governed by rules applicable in ordinary cases.
Document Preview: Action against railroad under Federal Employers' Liability Act. The District Court, Hunter, J., held that freight company employee, who died as result of being crushed between truck tractors on flatcar being loaded on siding owned by defendant railroad, who was not on railroad payroll, who was not doing work that railroad was required to do, and who was not under supervision of railroad employees was not employee of railroad within coverage of Federal Employers' Liability Act at time that he met his death, and his administratrix had no cause of action against railroad where freight company was not alter ego of railroad even though railroad owned all outstanding stock of freight company and five officers of freight company were also officers of railroad. Summary judgment for defendant. Judgment affirmed, 347 F.2d 233.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Acton Plumbing & Heating Co. v. Jared Builders, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Before corporate entity may be properly disregarded and parent corporation held liable for acts of its subsidiary, it must be shown not only that undue domination was exercised by parent corporation over subsidiary, but also that such control was exercised in manner as to defraud complainant, and that unjust loss or injury will be suffered by complainant as result of such domination unless parent corporation is held liable.
Document Preview: Action by plumbing contractor to recover balance due on work and materials furnished by plaintiff. From a judgment of the Circuit Court, Wayne County, Horace W. Gilmore, J., in favor of the plaintiff, the defendants appealed.
