The Supreme Court, Kavanagh, J., held that where evidence preponderated in favor of findings of trial court sitting without jury that building corporations had been formed for purpose of trying to limit liability and for tax purposes, that they all had common directors, that capital stock was not paid until profits were made, that all corporations were agents of each other and that they were manipulated by individuals for sole purpose of evading their responsibility, trial court correctly held that plumbing contractor was entitled to judgment against all of defendants, jointly and severally. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: G. E. J. Corp. v. Uranium Aire, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Generally a corporation which owns and controls another is not responsible for liabilities of latter; however, this rule is not without exception, and if subsidiary is alter-ego of parent the fact of separate corporate existence will be disregarded.
Document Preview: Suit to recover on an option for the sale of mining claims. The United States District Court for the District of Arizona, James A. Walsh, Chief Judge, gave judgment for the plaintiffs, and the defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Koelsch, Circuit Judge, held that none of the assigned errors could be sustained. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: G. E. J. Corp. v. Uranium Aire, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: California law establishes two requirements for an alter-ego relationship: first, that subsidiary corporation is not only influenced and governed by parent corporation, but that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that their individuality or separateness has ceased; second, that the facts are such that adherence to normal attributes of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Suit to recover on an option for the sale of mining claims. The United States District Court for the District of Arizona, James A. Walsh, Chief Judge, gave judgment for the plaintiffs, and the defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Koelsch, Circuit Judge, held that none of the assigned errors could be sustained. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Coclin Tobacco Co. v. British Am. Tobacco Co.
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: There are situations where a wholly-owned subsidiary may be considered as merely a branch or an agency of parent company; however the fact of this agency relationship must depend upon something more than a mere parent-subsidiary relationship.
Document Preview: A defendant filed a motion to quash the return of service of summons and to dismiss the action as against it. The District Court, Dawson, J., held that wholly-owned subsidiary was not agent of parent corporation and parent corporation was not served by delivering summons and complaint to subsidiary's employee at subsidiary's branch sales office in New York, where parent and subsidiary were two separate corporations, each of which conducted its own business, maintained its own affairs and had its own officers and directors, and subsidiary's employees in New York devoted their time solely to promoting sale of subsidiary's products in New York and did not sell or promote products of parent. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Luis v. Orcutt Town Water Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Corporate entity of wholly-owned subsidiary will be disregarded only when recognition of separate entities of parent and subsidiary would produce fraud or injustice, and bad faith in one form or another must be shown before court may disregard fiction of separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: Action against water distributor and producer, in contract and tort, for failure to supply water under sufficient pressure for fire protection purposes. The Superior Court of Santa Barbara County, Percy C. Heckendorf, J., rendered judgment for the defendants after demurrer sustained, and the plaintiffs appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Balthis, J., held, inter alia, that contract between water producer and water distributor obligating producer to furnish water from separate high pressure line in case of emergency when distributor would be prevented from or unable to take water at its regular connection did not make water distributor's customer third party beneficiary or clothe customer with right to recover damages predicated upon failure to furnish water under sufficient pressure for fire protection. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Luis v. Orcutt Town Water Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Any recognition of subsidiary as alter ego of parent corporation would cause contract between them asserted as basis for recovery to go out of existence. West's Ann.Civ.Code, § 1550.
Document Preview: Action against water distributor and producer, in contract and tort, for failure to supply water under sufficient pressure for fire protection purposes. The Superior Court of Santa Barbara County, Percy C. Heckendorf, J., rendered judgment for the defendants after demurrer sustained, and the plaintiffs appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Balthis, J., held, inter alia, that contract between water producer and water distributor obligating producer to furnish water from separate high pressure line in case of emergency when distributor would be prevented from or unable to take water at its regular connection did not make water distributor's customer third party beneficiary or clothe customer with right to recover damages predicated upon failure to furnish water under sufficient pressure for fire protection. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bowater S. S. Co. v. Patterson
Court: United States Court of Appeals Second Circuit.
Headnote: Whether a subsidiary corporation is to be considered a separate entity cannot be answered in vacuo and issues in each case must be resolved in light of policy underlying applicable legal rule, whether statute or common law.
Document Preview: Action by employer seeking temporary and permanent injunctive relief and damages against union. From an order of the United States District Court for the western District of New York, Harold P. Burke, Chief Judge, declining a temporary injunction for lack of jurisdiction, the employer appealed. The Court of Appeals, Friendly, Circuit Judge, held that Norris-LaGuardia Act deprived district court of jurisdiction to issue a temporary injunction restraining picketing by American and possibly Canadian members of woodworkers union of a foreign vessel in American waters in endeavor to force foreign owner of vessel to recognize their union to represent Newfoundland woodworkers on foreign owner's land so that union presumably thereafter could get higher wages for foreign laborers and reduce adverse competitive effects on American workers from lower wages or harder working conditions abroad. Affirmed. Lumbard, Chief Judge, dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Murdock Acceptance Corp. v. Adcox
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: A corporation may retain its separate identity although its stock is owned partly or entirely by another corporation, rather than by natural persons.
Document Preview: Action by seller's assignee to replevy trucks under conditional sales contracts. The Circuit Court, Simpson County, Homer Currie, J., rendered judgment for defendant, and the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Kyle, J., held, inter alia, that assignee could bring replevin action, although assignee had reassigned contracts to bank, as security for loan, under agreement that assignee should continue to exercise right to receive payments and to repossess property. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Stauffer v. Standard Brands Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Absent showing of fraud in merger of Pennsylvania corporation into Delaware subsidiary corporation, this merger would not be disregarded in determining validity of subsequent merger of Delaware subsidiary into Delaware parent. 8 Del.C. §§ 252, 253.
Document Preview: Action by stockholders in subsidiary corporation to set aside merger with parent corporation. The Court of Chancery, Short, Vice Chancellor, held that under circumstances, exclusive remedy of minority stockholders in subsidiary corporation, which was merged with parent in short merger proceeding, was appraisal, and alleged undervaluation of shares would not permit setting merger aside. Dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Charles Keeshin, Inc. v. Farmers & Merchants Bank of Rogers
Court: United States District Court W.D. Arkansas, Fayetteville Division.
Headnote: Under Arkansas law, where there is no need to pierce corporate veil to prevent fraud on third parties, corporate entity of Arkansas corporation transacting business in Arkansas will be preserved, even where there has been intermingling of assets between parent and subsidiary corporation, as well as interlocking directorates.
Document Preview: Diversity action by Illinois corporation against Arkansas residents to recover on account of third parties' alleged seizure of property belonging to the plaintiff's subsidiary. Defendants moved to dismiss. The United States District Court, John E. Miller, Chief Judge, held that, under the circumstances, the plaintiff's subsidiary was an indispensable party plaintiff, and that joining it would destroy the necessary diversity of citizenship. Motion sustained.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Gibraltor Amusements, Limited
Court: United States Court of Appeals Second Circuit.
Headnote: That parent corporation handled most of collections for wholly owned subsidiary which operated as parent corporation's financing corporation was insufficient to warrant inference of internal disregard of subsidiary's separate entity.
Document Preview: Proceeding to review an order of Hon. Louis J. Castellano, Referee in Bankruptcy, adjudicating a debtor a bankrupt on the petition of creditors. From an order of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, John R. Bartels, J., 187 F.Supp. 931, partially sustaining and partially denying the petition, and confirming the referee's adjudication, the bankrupt appealed. The Court of Appeals, J. Joseph Smith, Circuit Judge, held that a creditor corporation's wholly owned subsidiary, to which the corporation had assigned claims against the debtor long before the filing of the petition, could be counted as one of the required number of petitioning creditors where the corporation and the subsidiary had strictly honored the corporate form as to assets and in intercorporate transactions, and there was no showing of attempted subversion of the Bankruptcy Act. Affirmed. Friendly, Circuit Judge, dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fitz-Patrick v. Commonwealth Oil Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: When a parent corporation dominates a subsidiary so that the subsidiary is an instrumentality or agent of the parent, the corporate fiction will frequently be disregarded.
Document Preview: Action for specific performance of a contract or in the alternative for damages. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, T. Whitfield Davidson, J., dismissed the suit and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Wisdom, Circuit Judge, held that complaint of former owner of a fifty-year oil and gas concession alleging that it assigned the concession to defendant by assignment of the concession to a wholly owned subsidiary of defendant, subject to consent of Haiti, with a reserved royalty to be held in trust for former owner, and that consent to the assignment was obtained, stated a cause of action for specific performance or for damages, and sufficiently alleged happening of condition precedent to existence of the contract, namely, consent of Haiti to the assignment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Abbott v. Bob's U-Drive
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, Department 2.
Headnote: Where corporate affairs are confused with those stockholders, a subsidiary or an affiliate corporation, the corporate veil may be lifted to protect persons whose rights have been jeopardized by corporate device.
Document Preview: Action to compel parties to arbitrate pursuant to a provision contained in a lease. From a judgment for the plaintiff in the Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Charles W. Redding, J., the defendants appeal. The Supreme Court, O'Connell, J., held that a defendant by participation in subsequent proceedings submitted itself to jurisdiction of the board of arbitrators and to the Circuit Court though there was no order directing arbitration, and that where plaintiff leased premises to lessees under a provision for arbitration of any controversy arising out of the lease and the lessee incorporated two corporations, one to make short term rentals of automobiles and the other leasing automobiles for 12 months or longer, and the lessee assigned all his interests in the lease to the first corporation and the second corporation continued to carry on its business as before and the operations of the two corporations were not strictly segregated, possession of the corporations made them...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fitzgerald v. Hilton Hotels Corp.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Every corporation, even those bearing a relationship to each other of parent and wholly-owned subsidiary, has the status of a separate legal person.
Document Preview: Action to recover for personal injuries suffered at hotel in Mexico, where plaintiff allegedly drank a glass of what apparently was water but which turned out to be carbon tetrachloride. The District Court, Grim, J., held that mere fact that hotel was owned and operated by foreign corporation which was a wholly-owned subsidiary of a corporation licensed to do business in Pennsylvania did not permit service upon foreign corporation by serving parent corporation in Pennsylvania and that where it had not been shown that foreign corporation was doing business in Pennsylvania or that plaintiff's injuries occurred in Pennsylvania, foreign corporation could not be served under doing business' provision of Pennsylvania Business Corporation Law. Motion to quash return of service and to dismiss action granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Buechner v. Farbenfabriken Bayer Aktiengesellschaft
Court: Supreme Court of Delaware.
Headnote: The corporate fiction may be disregarded to prevent fraud, and a wholly-owned subsidiary may sometimes be treated as an instrumentality of the parent.
Document Preview: Action against a nonresident German corporation for damages based on its alleged failure to compensate plaintiff properly while he was in its employ, for failure to make promised payments upon termination of his employment, and for damages based on its action in preventing plaintiff from taking a position in the United States upon his leaving its employ in Germany. The Court of Chancery, 151 A.2d 125, granted defendant's motion to vacate a sequestration order, and subsequently entered an order dismissing the action, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Southerland, C. J., held that ownership of shares of a Delaware corporation by a wholly-owned subsidiary of defendant corporation did not mean that plaintiff, as an alleged creditor of defendant could, in the absence of fraud, disregard the separate existence of the subsidiary corporation and look directly to its specific assets for satisfaction of his claim against defendant, and therefore the sequestration order and seizure...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Buechner v. Farbenfabriken Bayer Aktiengesellschaft
Court: Supreme Court of Delaware.
Headnote: A creditor of a parent corporation may not, in the absence of fraud, disregard the separate existence of a subsidiary corporation and look directly to specific assets of a subsidiary for satisfaction of his claim against the parent.
Document Preview: Action against a nonresident German corporation for damages based on its alleged failure to compensate plaintiff properly while he was in its employ, for failure to make promised payments upon termination of his employment, and for damages based on its action in preventing plaintiff from taking a position in the United States upon his leaving its employ in Germany. The Court of Chancery, 151 A.2d 125, granted defendant's motion to vacate a sequestration order, and subsequently entered an order dismissing the action, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Southerland, C. J., held that ownership of shares of a Delaware corporation by a wholly-owned subsidiary of defendant corporation did not mean that plaintiff, as an alleged creditor of defendant could, in the absence of fraud, disregard the separate existence of the subsidiary corporation and look directly to its specific assets for satisfaction of his claim against defendant, and therefore the sequestration order and seizure...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Buechner v. Farbenfabriken Bayer Aktiengesellschaft
Court: Supreme Court of Delaware.
Headnote: Ownership of shares of a Delaware corporation by a wholly-owned subsidiary of a foreign corporation did not mean that plaintiff, as an alleged creditor of the foreign corporation, could, in the absence of fraud, disregard the separate existence of the subsidiary corporation and look directly to its specific assets for satisfaction of his claim against the foreign corporation and therefore a sequestration order issued in an action against the foreign corporation and seizure thereunder of stock in the Delaware corporation was properly vacated.
Document Preview: Action against a nonresident German corporation for damages based on its alleged failure to compensate plaintiff properly while he was in its employ, for failure to make promised payments upon termination of his employment, and for damages based on its action in preventing plaintiff from taking a position in the United States upon his leaving its employ in Germany. The Court of Chancery, 151 A.2d 125, granted defendant's motion to vacate a sequestration order, and subsequently entered an order dismissing the action, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Southerland, C. J., held that ownership of shares of a Delaware corporation by a wholly-owned subsidiary of defendant corporation did not mean that plaintiff, as an alleged creditor of defendant could, in the absence of fraud, disregard the separate existence of the subsidiary corporation and look directly to its specific assets for satisfaction of his claim against defendant, and therefore the sequestration order and seizure...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Garrett v. Southern Ry. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee, Northern Division.
Headnote: Whether subsidiary corporation is instrumentality of owner corporation is question to be determined from all surrounding circumstances.
Document Preview: Action under Federal Employers' Liability Act against railroad, by injured employee of car company in which railroad held all but five qualifying shares of stock. The District Court, Robert L. Taylor, J., held that even though railroad owned all but five qualifying shares of car company's stock, all directors and officers of car company were employees of railroad and car company sold majority of its products to railroad or its affiliates, where car company did not sell products exclusively to railroad, car company's manager was in full control of its operations, and company paid local taxes, had local counsel at seat of its operations and maintained workmen's compensation, under the circumstances, car company and railroad were separate operations, car company was not a common carrier by railroad for purposes of Federal employers' Liability Act, and injured car company employee was not entitled to bring action for his injuries against railroad under...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Teller v. Clear Service Co.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Pre Trial Term, Part I.
Headnote: Although person owning capital stock of corporation is ordinarily not liable for debts and liabilities of corporation, such principle is not applicable where stock ownership has been resorted to, not for purpose of participating in affairs of corporation in normal or usual manner, but for purpose of controlling a subsidiary corporation so that it may be used as a mere agency or instrumentality of owning company or where dominion is so complete and interference so obtrusive that by general rules of agency parent will be a principal and subsidiary agent.
Document Preview: Proceeding on application for preference at a pretrial hearing. The Supreme Court, Saul S. Streit, J., held that where 39 year old housewife alleged she had expended $1,400 for serious and permanent injuries sustained when she was struck by taxicab owned by defendant corporation, which had only two taxicabs and which carried no insurance but had filed bond for each cab guaranteeing payment up to $5,000 for injury to one person, and which was only one of 150 such corporations owned by members of family, and principal stockholder sought to conceal assets from public and there was a possibility that housewife might succeed in piercing corporate entity, defendants' offer of $3,500 did not represent a bona fide attempt to settle case, and housewife was entitled to a preference. Application granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Wescott & Winks Hatcheries v. F. M. Stamper Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: In cases involving question of claimed liability of parent for acts or commitments of subsidiary corporation, corporate existence of subsidiary may be ignored in order to circumvent fraud, restraint of trade, creation of monopolistic combination or other violation of law by the parent corporation or by an individual in control of both corporations.
Document Preview: Action for damages for breach of alleged written contract to sell and deliver turkey poults. The District Court, Johnson County, James P. Gaffney, J., directed verdict for supplier and buyer appealed. The Supreme Court, Smith, J., held that where buyer had solicited tenders on turkey poults for delivery on July 17, 1953 and agent of supplier, a subsidiary corporation, had telephoned buyer and had stated that they could take care of order and had prepared unsigned written order blank reciting date wanted week of July 17, and buyer had written letter correcting order blank by requiring delivery on July 17, 1953, and thereafter manager of supplier's parent company had written letter advising buyer that they would be unable to fill order, memorandum signed by parent company did not constitute compliance with statute of frauds sufficient to render subsidiary corporation liable on its oral contract. Affirmed. Oliver, J., dissented in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Wescott & Winks Hatcheries v. F. M. Stamper Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: Disregard of separation of identity between parent and subsidiary corporations is equitable prerogative to circumvent improper use.
Document Preview: Action for damages for breach of alleged written contract to sell and deliver turkey poults. The District Court, Johnson County, James P. Gaffney, J., directed verdict for supplier and buyer appealed. The Supreme Court, Smith, J., held that where buyer had solicited tenders on turkey poults for delivery on July 17, 1953 and agent of supplier, a subsidiary corporation, had telephoned buyer and had stated that they could take care of order and had prepared unsigned written order blank reciting date wanted week of July 17, and buyer had written letter correcting order blank by requiring delivery on July 17, 1953, and thereafter manager of supplier's parent company had written letter advising buyer that they would be unable to fill order, memorandum signed by parent company did not constitute compliance with statute of frauds sufficient to render subsidiary corporation liable on its oral contract. Affirmed. Oliver, J., dissented in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Austad v. U.S. Steel Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, Southern Division.
Headnote: Absent a showing of a relationship of agency between parent and subsidiary, separate corporate entities of parent and subsidiary are entitled to be treated as separate entities for purposes of anti-trust law as for other purposes.
Document Preview: Civil antitrust action. On a corporate defendant's motion to quash purported service of summons and to dismiss for lack of venue and jurisdiction, the District Court, Edward P. Murphy, J., held that the purported service of summons had not been shown to have been made on an agent authorized to receive service of process for movant, and that the movant, a Delaware corporation whose sole contact with California was filling of orders sent to it by independent steel sales firm and which shipped into Northern District of California only 6/100th of 1% of tonnage produced by it, could not be held to have been transacting business' in that district, for purposes of Clayton Act section permitting civil antitrust action to be brought in judicial district where defendant corporation transacts business. Motions granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kraft Foods Co. v. C.I.R.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Second Circuit.
Headnote: Where parent and subsidiary are true corporations conducting their respective businesses as holding company and as operating company, their intercorporate transactions must be accorded recognition unless in some way tainted.
Document Preview: Petitions for review of decision of Tax Court of the United States, 1954, 21 T.C. 513, denying petitioner any deduction on its income and excess profits taxes for the years 1934 to 1938, inclusive, for payments of alleged interest of $30,000,000 of 6% debentures held by petitioner's sole stockholder. The Court of Appeals, Waterman, Circuit Judge, held, inter alia, that where in 1934, when Congress abolished consolidated federal tax returns, Delaware corporate taxpayer declared dividend out of surplus payable to taxpayer's parent corporation and sole stockholders in 6% debentures which were unambiguous and contained all characteristics of a debt instrument, the debenture interest payments were deductible as interest on indebtedness'. Order of Tax Court reversed. Clark, Chief Judge, dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Spears v. Transcontinental Bus System
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Generally, a corporation and its stockholders are deemed separate legal entities, and stock ownership, in itself, is not sufficient to charge parent company with responsibility for acts of subsidiary, but rule is subject to qualification that separate entities may be disregarded in exceptional situations, where it would otherwise present an obstacle to due protection or enforcement of public or private rights.
Document Preview: Negro bus passenger, who was segregated from white passengers on bus of subsidiary bus company, brought action against parent bus company, which had sold him bus ticket, to recover damages for alleged violation of his civil rights. The United States District Court for the Southern District of California, Central Division, Leon R. Yankwich, Chief Judge, entered judgment adverse to Negro passenger, and he appealed. The Court of Appeals, Wiig, District Judge, held that parent company was not liable merely because it sold bus ticket, and that, in absence of any showing that parent company had any direct operating control over rules, regulations, or policies of subsidiary company, parent company was not liable on ground that act of subsidiary company was the act of the parent company. Judgement affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Castle Hill Beach Club v. Arbury
Court: Supreme Court, Bronx County, New York, Special Term, Part I.
Headnote: Equity will disregard corporate entities even when subsidiaries are not mere instrumentalities of the parent.
Document Preview: Proceeding in the matter of the application to annul an order of the State Commission Against Discrimination and by the Commission seeking to enforce an order. The Supreme Court, Special Term, Martin M. Frank, J., held that the evidence sustained the charge of discrimination against an applicant because of color, that the petitioner was a place of public accommodation, resort or amusement, and that the real parties in interest had employed the device of a membership corporation to facilitate the exclusion of Negroes. Motion of the petitioner denied. Cross motion of the Commission granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: S.O.S. Co. v. Bolta Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Where ownership by a corporation of stock in a second corporation has been resorted to, not for purpose of participating in the affairs of second corporation in the normal and usual manner, but for purpose of controlling it as a subsidiary in order that it may be used as a mere agency or instrumentality of its corporate parent, the fiction of corporate entity is not controlling, but court will cut through the maze of corporate appearances to arrive at the true status and relationship between the corporations.
Document Preview: Suit for patent infringement and unfair competition. On motions to dismiss the action on jurisdictional grounds, and to transfer the case to Massachusetts, the District Court, Hoffman, J., held inter alia, that where individual owned majority of stock in first corporation, and second and third corporations were entirely owned by such individual's family, and majority of stock in fourth corporation was owned by such other three corporations and the individual's family, fiction of corporate entity was not controlling, and service on agent of third corporation, which was qualified in Illinois, was sufficient service on all four corporations. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Condenser Service & Engineering Co. v. Brunswick Port Authority
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia, Division No. 1.
Headnote: The corporate entity of a subsidiary or one-man corporation should not be disregarded merely because a parent corporation or other sole owner controls the subservient corporation and uses it to promote owner's ends.
Document Preview: Suit for damage to gantry crane leased to defendant corporation's wholly owned subsidiary. The Superior Court, Glynn County, Douglas F. Thomas, J., overruled demurrers to complaint and defendant's motion for new trial after verdict for plaintiff, and defendant brought error. The Court of Appeals, Felton, J., held that second count of complaint did not allege facts sufficient to authorize the disregard of separate corporate entity of subsidiary corporation for the purpose of rendering defendant corporation liable for subsidiary's negligence. Judgments affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Investigation of World Arrangements with Relation to Production, Transp., Refining & Distribution of Petroleum
Court: United States District Court District of Columbia.
Headnote: When parent corporation has control over affairs of subsidiary and manages subsidiary primarily for interest of parent, courts will look through corporate entity.
Document Preview: Proceeding in the matter of investigation of world arrangements with relation to production, transportation, refining and distribution of petroleum in possible violation of statute, wherein various oil companies moved to quash or modify subpoenas duces tecum served on them. The District Court, James R. Kirkland, J., held that provision of Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure authorizing court to quash or modify subpoenas duces tecum if compliance would be unreasonable or oppressive is applicable after an information or indictment has been returned and not prior to indictment. Order in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: McComb v. Aibel
Court: United States District Court E.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts are hesitant to destroy corporate separateness of parent and subsidiary corporations when there is no evidence of evasion of law or where it is clear that both parent and subsidiary have a legitimate separate existence.
Document Preview: Action by William R. McComb, administrator of the Wage and Hour Division, United States Department of Labor, against Samuel H. Aibel and Harryette L. Aibel, co-partners, doing business under the trade name and style of French Textile Company, to enjoin defendants from violating the Fair Labor Standards Act. On plaintiff's motions for summary judgment and to vacate defendants' notice for taking depositions, and defendants' request to add a name to the notice, the District Court, Galston, J., held that the plaintiff was not entitled to a summary judgment where there was a genuine issue as to whether the corporation supplying defendants with materials and in which defendants owned 52 per cent of the stock conducted a substantial and separate business of its own, and as to whether defendants violated the recordkeeping requirements of the Fair Labor Standards Act. Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment denied; motion to vacate notice of taking depositions granted in part, and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Beale v. Kappa Alpha Order
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia
Headnote: Before the corporate entity may be properly disregarded and the parent corporation held liable for the acts of its subsidiary, it must be shown not only that undue domination and control was exercised by the parent over subsidiary, but also that this control was exercised in such a manner as to defraud and wrong the party dealing with subsidiary, and that unjust loss or injury will be suffered by party dealing with subsidiary as the result of such domination unless the parent corporation be held liable.
Document Preview: Action by C. W. Beale against the Kappa Alpha Order and the Kappa Alpha Alumni Foundation to compel the Kappa Alpha Order to pay an obligation contracted by the Kappa Alpha Holding Corporation. The Law and Equity Court of the City of Richmond, Part Two, Haskins Hobson, J., entered an order dismissing the case, and the plaintiff brought error. The Supreme Court of Appeals, Hudgins, C. J., held that under the facts of the case the separate corporate entity of the two corporations could not be disregarded so as to hold one corporation liable for the obligation of the other. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Garden City Co. v. Burden
Court: United States Court of Appeals Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Where the relationship between the parent and subsidiary corporation is so intimate, parent's control over subsidiary is so dominating, and business and assets of two are so commingled, that recognition of distinct entity would result in injustice to third persons, courts should look through legal fiction of separate entity and treat them as justice requires.
Document Preview: Action by J. L. Burden agasinst the Garden City Company, a corporation, and another for damages to plaintiff's land caused by the negligence of defendants in the operatinon of an irrigation canal crossing plaintiff's land. The United States District Court for the District of Kansas, Delmas C. Hill, J., entered judgment for plaintiff after jury verdict and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Huxman, Circuit Judge, held that the evidence was sufficient to sustain finding that defendants were negligent in the maintenance and operation of the irrigation ditch and that such negligence was the proximate cause of damage to plaintiff's land. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Continental Distilling Corp. v. Old Charter Distillery Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: A court of equity to do justice does not hesitate to disregard a corporate entity and to recognize that all the assets of a solvent wholly owned subsidiary are equitably owned by the parent corporation.
Document Preview: Action by the Old Charter Distillery Co. against John A. Marzall, Commissioner of Patents and the Continental Distilling Corporation to enjoin the Commissioner from cancelling the trade-mark Old Charter as applied to whiskey. Judgment for plaintiff in the District Court of the United States for the District of Columbia (now the United States District Court for the District of Columbia), Holtzoff, J., 73 F.Supp. 539 and the defendant Continental Distilling Corporation appealed. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, Wilbur K. Miller, Circuit Judge, held that service of process upon the defendant, a Delaware corporation, brought it before the District Court and that plaintiff under the circumstances, was entitled to relief. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: In re Belt-Modes, Inc.
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: A court of equity may disregard the corporate entity in cases where corporation concerned in suit is a front or mere conduit for carrying on business of parent corporation; but test is whether purpose of using subsidiary corporation as a cloak was to commit a fraud or illegal purpose.
Document Preview: Proceeding in the matter of Belt-Modes, Inc., bankrupt, brought by the trustee to review an order of the referee allowing wage claims of the employees of Danin, Inc. The District Court, Irving R. Kaufman, J., held that the court would not ignore a corporate entity so as to permit claimants to assert their claims against the bankrupt on the theory that two corporations were in fact the same. Petition sustained, order of referee reversed and wage claims disallowed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rounds & Porter Lumber Co. v. Burns
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: A parent corporation is not liable for the debts of its subsidiary merely because parent corporation holds the controlling interest or because the two are managed by the same officers.
Document Preview: Suit by Homer Burns and wife against Rounds & Porter Lumber Company to hold defendant liable for lumber which defendants' subsidiary corporation was to process and sell as agent for plaintiffs, and for which subsidiary corporation had not accounted. The Chancery Court of Bradley County, D. A. Bradham, Chancellor, entered judgment for plaintiffs, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, George Rose Smith, J., held that the evidence warranted finding that defendant had wrongfully manipulated subsidiary corporation to its own advantage at expense of plaintiffs so as to entitle plaintiffs to a judgment directly against parent corporation, and affirmed the judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rounds & Porter Lumber Co. v. Burns
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: The corporate entities should be disregarded and parent corporation held liable for debts of its subsidiary only where the privilege of transacting business in corporate form has been illegally abused to the injury of a third person.
Document Preview: Suit by Homer Burns and wife against Rounds & Porter Lumber Company to hold defendant liable for lumber which defendants' subsidiary corporation was to process and sell as agent for plaintiffs, and for which subsidiary corporation had not accounted. The Chancery Court of Bradley County, D. A. Bradham, Chancellor, entered judgment for plaintiffs, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, George Rose Smith, J., held that the evidence warranted finding that defendant had wrongfully manipulated subsidiary corporation to its own advantage at expense of plaintiffs so as to entitle plaintiffs to a judgment directly against parent corporation, and affirmed the judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Rounds & Porter Lumber Co. v. Burns
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: That executives of subsidiary corporation, instead of acting independently in its interest, take their orders from parent corporation in the latter's interest is one of the surest indications of abuse of the privilege of transacting business in corporate form so as to justify disregarding the corporate entities and holding parent corporation liable for debts of its subsidiary.
Document Preview: Suit by Homer Burns and wife against Rounds & Porter Lumber Company to hold defendant liable for lumber which defendants' subsidiary corporation was to process and sell as agent for plaintiffs, and for which subsidiary corporation had not accounted. The Chancery Court of Bradley County, D. A. Bradham, Chancellor, entered judgment for plaintiffs, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, George Rose Smith, J., held that the evidence warranted finding that defendant had wrongfully manipulated subsidiary corporation to its own advantage at expense of plaintiffs so as to entitle plaintiffs to a judgment directly against parent corporation, and affirmed the judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Duryee v. Erie R. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: The domination by a corporation of its subsidiary is not of itself fraudulent.
Document Preview: Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, Eastern Division; Robert N. Wilkin, Judge. Suit by Peter Duryee, Trustee of the property of the New Jersey & New York Railroad Company, against Erie Railroad Company, for a judgment that all the obligations and debts of the New Jersey & New York Railroad Company were obligations of the defendant. From a summary judgment, 76 F.Supp. 635, the plaintiff appeals and the defendant cross-appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Superior Portland Cement v. Pacific Coast Cement Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, en Banc.
Headnote: The rule that the corporate veil may be pierced when necessary to do justice in particular cases is especially applicable in cases involving a parent or principal corporation and subsidiary corporations which merely acquiesce in and register the decrees of their principal.
Document Preview: Action by Superior Portland Cement, Inc., against Pacific Coast Cement Company, for specific performance of provision in lease giving the plaintiff the first right to purchase the property or in the alternative for damages on account of breach thereof. From a judgment for the defendant, the plaintiff appeals. Judgment reversed and cause remanded for further proceedings in conformity with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Nagl v. Northam Warren Corp.
Court: District Court, D. Nebraska, Omaha Division.
Headnote: The transaction of business within a state by a corporation whose stock is owned by a foreign corporation is not necessarily or usually the doing of business within the state by the latter even though it dominates the operating domestic subsidiary through stock ownership.
Document Preview: Action by Carl J. Nagl against Northam Warren Corporation for conversion of certain shares of stock formerly owned by plaintiff. On defendant's motion to dismiss. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Nagl v. Northam Warren Corp.
Court: District Court, D. Nebraska, Omaha Division.
Headnote: Interorganizational activity by the parent corporation in respect to its operating subsidiary is not alone ground for conclusion that the former is doing business in the state of the latter's incorporation.
Document Preview: Action by Carl J. Nagl against Northam Warren Corporation for conversion of certain shares of stock formerly owned by plaintiff. On defendant's motion to dismiss. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Warren v. Fitzgerald
Court: Court of Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: A corporation is a real legal personality and there is a real difference between ownership of stock of a subsidiary and ownership of its property.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court for Baltimore City; John T. Tucker, Judge. Stockholders' suit by Wilson C. Warren and others against E. Roy Fitzgerald and others to enjoin the Baltimore Transit Company from abandoning almost 50 per cent. of its track mileage and substituting, for trolley cars, motorbuses to be owned by a wholly owned subsidiary, wherein the City of Baltimore intervened as a party defendant. From a decree of dismissal, plaintiffs appeal. Decree affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Ginas v. Loew's, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term, Part III.
Headnote: A subsidiary corporation is an entity independent and apart from its parent corporation and is not its alter ego.
Document Preview: Action by Ellen Ginas and Christ Ginas against Loew's, Inc., and 45th & Broadway Corporation to recover for personal injury allegedly sustained because of alleged negligence of 45th & Broadway Corporation. On motion by 45th & Broadway Corporation to dismiss the complaint. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Constitution Pub. Co. v. Dale
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, generally the fact that a corporation owns controlling stock of another does not destroy identity of latter as a distinct legal entity unless such separate corporate existence is a mere sham or where organization and control of subsidiary are such that it is but an instrumentality of dominant corporation and question of relationship is one of law and not of fact.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Northern District of Alabama; Seybourn H. Lynne, Judge. Action by J. T. Dale, who sues as administrator of the estate of Neoma Dale, deceased, against the Constitution Publishing Company and others to recover for decedent's wrongful death. From a judgment for plaintiff, defendants Constitution Publishing Company and Theatre Service Company appeal. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Portland Trust & Sav. Bank v. Lincoln Realty Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon En Banc.
Headnote: Where subsidiary corporation was formed by parent to make subsidiary an agency of parent and same persons were officers of each corporation, the two corporations were to be deemed a single entity.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Multnomah County; James W. Crawford, Judge. Suit by the Portland Trust & Savings Bank against the Lincoln Realty Company, George A. McFaul, individually and as trustee, Ada McFaul, Earl Goss, LaVerna Goss, O. C. Roehr, and Virgil Crum and others to foreclose a mortgage, wherein some of the defendants filed a counter-claim seeking the cancellation of a lease. Decree for the plaintiff, and the named defendants other than the Lincoln Realty Company appeal. Decree set aside and cause remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Randolph Laboratories v. Specialties Development Corp.
Court: District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: The existence of an ordinary parent-subsidiary relationship between two corporations does not of itself justify disregarding the corporate entities.
Document Preview: Action by Randolph Laboratories, Inc., against Specialties Development Corporation and Walter Kidde & Company, Incorporated, for a declaratory judgment of invalidity and noninfringement by plaintiff of a certain patent and for injunctive relief, charging unfair competition by both defendants.  On defendants' motions to dismiss action as to defendant Walter Kidde & Company, Incorporated, and to strike certain allegations from complaint. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hordin v. City of Cleveland
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: The separate corporate entities of a parent and subsidiary corporation will not be disregarded in the absence of proof that subsidiary was formed for fraudulent purposes, and the fact that the stock of a company is owned by a municipal corporation does not change the rule.
Document Preview: MORGAN, J., dissenting in part. Action by Philip Hordin, as taxpayer, against City of Cleveland and others to enjoin carrying out provisions of certain contracts allegedly entered into contrary to law. From a judgment for plaintiff, the defendants appeal.[Editorial Statement.] Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bowles v. American Distilling Co.
Court: District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: That one corporation is parent of another does not make the former the agent of the latter.
Document Preview: Action by Chester Bowles, Administrator, Office of Price Administration, against American Distilling Company, Inc., Russell R. Brown and others, individually and as copartners doing business as Foster & Company, Country Distillers Products, Inc., Ben Burk, Inc., Arthur C. Sullivan, Joseph J. Sands, and others for injunction to restrain alleged violation of maximum price regulations, for treble damages arising out of alleged sales of distilled spirits by defendants at prices in excess of maximum prices permitted by regulations, and to recover for fraud and deceit. On motions of the defendants Arthur C. Sullivan, Ben Burk, Inc., Country Distillers Products Corporation, and Joseph J. Sands to dismiss the action because of improper venue and improper service of process. Complaint dismissed as to moving defendants. See also 62 F.Supp. 20.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: State v. Swift & Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Ownership of capital stock in one corporation by another or interlocking directorship does not create an identity of corporate interests or create relation of principal and agent or representative, unless such ownership has been resorted to, not for purpose of participating in affairs of corporation in normal and usual manner, but for purpose of controlling a subsidiary company so that it may be used as a mere agency or instrumentality of owning company or companies.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Travis County; J. D. Moore, Judge. Suit by the State of Texas against Swift & Company and Consumers Cotton Oil Company to recover from first-named defendant statutory penalties for doing business in the state without a permit, to cancel first-named defendant's permit to do business in the state, and to forfeit the corporate charter of the other defendant. From a judgment that it take nothing by its suit against either defendant, plaitiff appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: State v. Swift & Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Courts will not disregard the separate corporate entities of parent and subsidiary corporations if a separate adequate financial unit is set up for each, day to day business of each unit is kept separate, formal barriers between the two management structures are maintained, and the two units are not represented as being one unit.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Travis County; J. D. Moore, Judge. Suit by the State of Texas against Swift & Company and Consumers Cotton Oil Company to recover from first-named defendant statutory penalties for doing business in the state without a permit, to cancel first-named defendant's permit to do business in the state, and to forfeit the corporate charter of the other defendant. From a judgment that it take nothing by its suit against either defendant, plaitiff appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Shanik v. Aller
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: When subsidiaries constitute mere instruments or departments of a parent company, or when subsidiaries and parent constitute a single integrated enterprise, or when insistence upon technical joinder of subsidiaries as parties would frustrate justice, a court of equity may disregard corporate entity of the subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Appeal from Supreme Court; John H. McCooey, Jr., Justice. Derivative class action by Joseph Shanik against Howard L. Aller and others, to recover from defendants for the benefit of the American Power & Light Company and the stockholders moneys paid by the operating companies upon alleged unlawful contracts. From an order, plaintiff appeals. Order so far as it relates to the first cause of action reversed and motion to dismiss denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Blaustein v. Pan American Petroleum & Transport Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Equity frequently disregards corporate entities, even where subsidiaries are not mere instrumentalities of parent corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal from Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department. Stockholders' derivative action by Louis Blaustein, Jacob Blaustein, and others, on behalf of themselves and all similarly situated stockholders of the Pan American Petroleum & Transport Company, against such company, the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), and others for an accounting of first-named defendant's assets and profits illegally paid out, wasted, or diverted by defendants' acts, impression of a constructive trust on moneys, oil leases, or property acquired by defendants as the result of acts committed in bad faith and in breach of fiduciary obligations to such corporation, and injunctive relief, in which Jacob Blaustein and others, as executors of the estate of Louis Blaustein, deceased, were substituted for deceased as plaintiffs, and Fred C. Haas and another intervened. From a judgment on an order of the Appellate Division, 263 App.Div. 97, 31 N.Y.S.2d 934, which reversed on the facts and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hirshhorn v. Mine Safety Appliances Co.
Court: District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To effect substantial justice, equity will pierce the corporate veil, especially when the affairs of the parent and its subsidiaries are so interwoven as to dictate the penetration.
Document Preview: Action by Joseph H. Hirshhorn, on his own behalf and on behalf of all other stockholders of Carbon Monoxide Eliminator Corporation, against Mine Safety Appliances Company and others for an accounting, for rescission of a license agreement, and for general equitable relief. On defendants' motions to stay the proceedings and motion to dismiss. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hayman v. Morris
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term.
Headnote: Domination alone of a subsidiary by the parent corporation, primarily a holding company, is not improper, unless improperly and inequitably exercised.
Document Preview: Stockholders' derivative action by Seymour Hayman and another, copartners, doing business under the firm name of Seymour Hayman & Co., individually and as stockholders of the Industrial Finance Corporation, suing on behalf of themselves and all other stockholders similarly situated, and for the benefit of the Industrial Finance Corporation, against Arthur J. Morris and others, and a similar action by George F. Smith and others, suing on behalf of the Industrial Acceptance Corporation, for themselves and all other stockholders similarly situated, against Stanwood G. Bradlee and others, were consolidated and tried jointly. In the course of the trial, motions were made to strike out testimony. Motions denied and complaint in each action dismissed. See, also, 36 N.Y.S.2d 754; 37 N.Y.S.2d 512; 179 Misc. 265, 38 N.Y.S.2d 782.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cargill, Inc. v. Spaeth
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Where the corporate separation is maintained and the subsidiary conducts its own business, the subsidiary, and not the parent, is doing the business.
Document Preview: Three certiorari proceedings by Cargill, Inc., and by Cargill Warehouse Company, against G. Howard Spaeth, as Commissioner of Taxation, to review decisions of the Board of Tax Appeals affirming determinations of the commissioner that taxpayers were liable for deficiency income taxes upon certain dividends and interest for the periods from December 1 to December 31, 1936, the entire year 1937, and from January 1 to November 30, 1936. Writs dismissed and decisions of Board of Tax Appeals affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Roof v. Conway
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: The property and debts of subsidiary must be treated in equity as those of parent corporation where subsidiary is used as parent corporation's mere instrumentality.
Document Preview: Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern District Court for the Southern District of Ohio; Robert R. Nevin, Judge. Action by Thomas Conway, Jr., and another as receivers of the Cincinnati and Lake Erie Railroad Company against Forrest E. Roof and others, in the nature of a suit ancillary to the cause in which the railroad was being operated in receivership, for an injunction to restrain defendants from further prosecuting their complaints before the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio and from acting contrary to contracts.  From an adverse decree, defendants appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Esmond Mills v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Courts will not disregard corporate entities merely because of a parent-subsidiary relationship, but will look behind the intercorporate set-up only if there is evidence of a purpose to evade a statute or to practice fraud upon third persons.
Document Preview: Petition for Review of Decisions of the United States Board of Tax Appeals. Petition by the Esmond Mills and another to review a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals redetermining deficiencies in income taxes and excess profits taxes imposed by the Commission of Internal Revenue. Decision affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kelley, Glover & Vale v. Heitman
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: A "subsidiary" or "auxiliary corporation" which is created by a parent corporation merely as an agency for the latter may sometimes be regarded as identical with the parent corporation, especially if stockholders or officers of the two corporations are substantially the same or their systems of operation unified.
Document Preview: Action by Elmer W. Heitman, receiver of the First National Bank of Gary, Indiana, against Kelley, Glover and Vale, Inc., and others on a note and for foreclosure and sale of pledged collateral, wherein the defendants filed a counterclaim. From an adverse judgment defendants appealed to the Appellate Court and the case was transferred to the Supreme Court under Burns' Ann.St. § 4215. Judgment affirmed. Superseding opinion of the Appellate Court, 40 N.E.2d 408. Roll, J., dissenting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Nichols & Co. v. Secretary of Agriculture
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Courts will look to substance of ownership and control when there is evidence that subsidiary corporation was created by parent corporation for express purpose of violating provisions of statute.
Document Preview: Petition by Nichols & Company and others against the Secretary of Agriculture for review of an order of the Secretary of Agriculture suspending a registration of named petitioner as a commission merchant under the provisions of the Commodity Exchange Act Sec. 1 et seq., 7 U.S.C.A. § 1 et seq. Order set aside and case remanded to the Secretary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Nichols & Co. v. Secretary of Agriculture
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: The courts will not destroy corporate entity merely because there is identity of control in parent and subsidiary corporations.
Document Preview: Petition by Nichols & Company and others against the Secretary of Agriculture for review of an order of the Secretary of Agriculture suspending a registration of named petitioner as a commission merchant under the provisions of the Commodity Exchange Act Sec. 1 et seq., 7 U.S.C.A. § 1 et seq. Order set aside and case remanded to the Secretary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Nichols & Co. v. Secretary of Agriculture
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Courts are hesitant to destroy corporate separateness of parent and subsidiary corporations when there is no evidence of evasion of law or where it is clear that both parent and subsidiary have legitimate, separate existences.
Document Preview: Petition by Nichols & Company and others against the Secretary of Agriculture for review of an order of the Secretary of Agriculture suspending a registration of named petitioner as a commission merchant under the provisions of the Commodity Exchange Act Sec. 1 et seq., 7 U.S.C.A. § 1 et seq. Order set aside and case remanded to the Secretary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Page v. Haverty
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: A parent corporation's ownership of all stock of subsidiary does not warrant disregard of their separate legal entities unless the subsidiary is so controlled that it is in fact a mere instrumentality of the parent, or the separate corporate structure is used to promote fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Middle District of Georgia; Bascom S. Deaver, Judge. Action by Clarence Haverty and others, executors of the estate of J. J. Haverty, against W. E. Page, Jr., and another, as executors of the estate of W. E. Page, Collector of Internal Revenue, to compel refund of income taxes paid. From a judgment for plaintiffs, defendants appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Beneficial Industrial Loan Corporation v. Kline
Court: District Court, N.D. Iowa, Western Division.
Headnote: A foreign holding corporation is not "doing business" in a state through a subsidiary but the two entities are distinct and only the subsidiary does business.
Document Preview: Action by Beneficial Industrial Loan Corporation and another against Earl L. Kline, doing business under the name and style of Personal Finance Company, and others to enjoin defendants except Melvin W. Ellis, Superintendent of Banking of the State of Iowa, from using the name Personal Finance Company and for accounting for profits derived by defendants except defendant Ellis for using such name because of alleged unfair competition. Case dismissed without prejudice. See, also, 41 F.Supp. 854.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hamblen v. Horwitz-Texan Theatres Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Galveston.
Headnote: Where one corporation owns all stock of another corporation, and uses the other corporation as a mere agency or instrumentality for perpetrating fraud, or for the purpose of evading the law, the corporate fiction will be disregarded to prevent the attainment of either objective.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Harris County; Roy F. Campbell, Judge. Suit by Horwitz-Texas Theatres Company, Incorporated, against W. P. Hamblen, individually, and as independent executor and trustee under the will of Will Horwitz, deceased, to enjoin the defendant from interfering with the management and control of the plaintiff's conduct of its own business affairs, by and through its acting directors and officers. From a judgment temporarily enjoining the defendant, the defendant appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: State ex rel. Monarch Fire Ins. Co. v. Holmes
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: The two general theories on which courts proceed when they go back of the corporate fiction are the "agency theory", that the corporation whose corporate identity is disregarded is under control of parent corporation and acted as its agent in the particular transaction, and the "identity theory", that the corporation whose identity is disregarded is so identified with corporation sought to be charged as, in effect, to make the two corporations one.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, First District, Lewis and Clark County; Geo. W. Padbury, Jr., Judge. Prohibition proceedings by the State of Montana, on relation of Monarch Fire Insurance Company, a corporation, against John J. Holmes, as State Auditor and ex officio Commissioner of Insurance of the State of Montana; and by the State of Montana, on relation of Eureka-Security Fire & Marine Insurance Company, a corporation, against John J. Holmes, as State Auditor and ex officio Commissioner of Insurance of the State of Montana. From orders granting motions to quash a writ of prohibition in each case, relators appeal. Writs of prohibition issued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: State ex rel. Monarch Fire Ins. Co. v. Holmes
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: To invoke the "agency theory" with respect to when the corporate entity of parent and subsidiary corporations may be disregarded, the act giving rise to the action must be the act of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, First District, Lewis and Clark County; Geo. W. Padbury, Jr., Judge. Prohibition proceedings by the State of Montana, on relation of Monarch Fire Insurance Company, a corporation, against John J. Holmes, as State Auditor and ex officio Commissioner of Insurance of the State of Montana; and by the State of Montana, on relation of Eureka-Security Fire & Marine Insurance Company, a corporation, against John J. Holmes, as State Auditor and ex officio Commissioner of Insurance of the State of Montana. From orders granting motions to quash a writ of prohibition in each case, relators appeal. Writs of prohibition issued.
