Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Weisser v. Mursam Shoe Corporation
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: A representation that liability of a subsidiary corporation is same as that of its parent or affiliate will result in a piercing of corporate veil of a subsidiary which is in fact undercapitalized, dominated, and used as an instrument of the parent.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Southern District of New York. Action by Rose Weisser and another against Mursam Shoe Corporation, Murray M. Rosenberg, Incorporated, Miles Shoes, Incorporated, Murray M. Rosenberg, and Samuel H. Rosenberg, to recover rent under a lease. From an order granting a motion for summary judgment made by the defendants Murray M. Rosenberg, Incorporated, Miles Shoes, Incorporated, Murray M. Rosenberg, and Samuel H. Rosenberg, and dismissing the complaint as to them, 40 F.Supp. 1007, the plaintiffs appeal. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Cintas v. American Car & Foundry Co.
Court: Court of Chancery of New Jersey.
Headnote: The corporate identity will be disregarded in equity only when it is necessary to do so in order to prevent fraud, deception, evasion or injustice, wherein equity regards the substance and not the form, precluding a contention that separate corporate identities of wholly owned subsidiaries must always be regarded as mere departments of the parent company.
Document Preview: Suit by Oscar B. Cintas against American Car and Foundry Company to restrain the payment of a dividend to common stockholders in violation of complainant's rights as a preferred stockholder. Decree in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Bank of California, N.A. v. American Fruit Growers
Court: District Court, E.D. Washington, Northern Division.
Headnote: The use of wholly-owned subsidiaries and mutual officers and directors is not malum per se.
Document Preview: Action by Bank of California, N.A., a national banking association, against American Fruit Growers, Incorporated, to recover on an alleged agreement and for conversion of mortgaged fruit crops. Judgment in accordance with opinion. See, also, 37 F.Supp. 1017.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Inland Development Co. v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: The fact that a parent corporation owns all of stock of its subsidiary does not of itself warrant disregard of their separateness of corporate entity, but that separateness is disregarded where stock ownership is used to dominate subsidiary to such extent that it becomes a mere agency or instrumentality of the parent, or where maintenance of such apartness would work a fraud or do injustice.
Document Preview: On Petition to Review the Decision of the United States Board of Tax Appeals. Petition by the Inland Development Company to review a decision of the United States Board of Tax Appeals redetermining a deficiency in the tax imposed by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue. Decision reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Heller v. Boylan
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term.
Headnote: Where a subsidiary has been formed for purpose of cheating, defrauding, or accomplishing indirectly or by circumvention a prohibited act, where no fraud or illicit motive is involved in the formation of the subsidiary or its operation, but where some one is attempting to fasten onto the parent a liability for the act of the subsidiary, or where an attempt is made to subject the parent corporation to the service of process or liability under tax statutes, in a jurisdiction where it is allegedly operating through a subsidiary, the court brushes aside the fictional-though legal-separate existence of the subsidiary and reaches out for the answerable offender.
Document Preview: Derivative action by Esther Heller and others, suing on behalf of themselves and all other stockholders of the American Tobacco Company similarly situated, against Richard J. Boylan and others, wherein Minnie Mandelker intervened. Judgment for plaintiffs in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Tennessee Consol. Coal Co. v. Home Ice & Coal Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section.
Headnote: A subsidiary corporation will be regarded as identical with, or as agent of, parent corporation, and parent will be held for subsidiary's liabilities, and parent's claims against subsidiary will be subordinated to claims of other creditors.
Document Preview: Appeal from Chancery Court, Davidson County; R. B. C. Howell, Chancellor. General creditors' proceeding by Tennessee Consolidated Coal Company against Home Ice and Coal Company and others. From the decree the Independent Life Insurance Company, now represented by the Standard Life Insurance Company of the South, and Paul Roberts, separately appeal. Affirmed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Tennessee Consol. Coal Co. v. Home Ice & Coal Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section.
Headnote: The fiction of corporate entity will not be disregarded, as between parent corporation and its subsidiary, except to prevent wrong or injustice.
Document Preview: Appeal from Chancery Court, Davidson County; R. B. C. Howell, Chancellor. General creditors' proceeding by Tennessee Consolidated Coal Company against Home Ice and Coal Company and others. From the decree the Independent Life Insurance Company, now represented by the Standard Life Insurance Company of the South, and Paul Roberts, separately appeal. Affirmed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Tennessee Consol. Coal Co. v. Home Ice & Coal Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section.
Headnote: It is not necessary to show that one has been misled, deceived, or defrauded to enable him to invoke rule that subsidiary corporation will be regarded as identical with, or as agent of parent, but it is enough that parent corporation's domination of subsidiary was so complete as to make them practically indistinguishable or to make subsidiary a mere tool, agency, or instrumentality of parent, and that he will suffer loss unless parent be held.
Document Preview: Appeal from Chancery Court, Davidson County; R. B. C. Howell, Chancellor. General creditors' proceeding by Tennessee Consolidated Coal Company against Home Ice and Coal Company and others. From the decree the Independent Life Insurance Company, now represented by the Standard Life Insurance Company of the South, and Paul Roberts, separately appeal. Affirmed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Press Co. v. National Labor Relations Board
Court: United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
Headnote: Where parent company owns all common stock of subsidiary, and officers are identical, parent company not participating in act of subsidiary is responsible for act of subsidiary if an agency relationship exists between parent and subsidiary.
Document Preview: RUTLEDGE, Associate Justice, dissenting in part. On Petitions for Review of Order of National Labor Relations Board. Proceedings by the Press Company, Inc., and by the Gannett Company, Inc., to review an order of the National Labor Relations Board. In the first case, the Tri-City Newspaper Guild and others intervened. Order enforced as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Press Co. v. National Labor Relations Board
Court: United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
Headnote: A parent corporation's ownership of stock of subsidiary, and identity of officers of parent and subsidiary, do not create agency relation so as to make parent responsible for act of subsidiary, but there must be such control by parent as to show that subsidiary is being used as the instrument of the parent.
Document Preview: RUTLEDGE, Associate Justice, dissenting in part. On Petitions for Review of Order of National Labor Relations Board. Proceedings by the Press Company, Inc., and by the Gannett Company, Inc., to review an order of the National Labor Relations Board. In the first case, the Tri-City Newspaper Guild and others intervened. Order enforced as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Press Co. v. National Labor Relations Board
Court: United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
Headnote: A subsidiary corporation which is legal entity separate from parent corporation, retains its identity for legal proceedings, whatever may have been the motives leading to creation of subsidiary corporation.
Document Preview: RUTLEDGE, Associate Justice, dissenting in part. On Petitions for Review of Order of National Labor Relations Board. Proceedings by the Press Company, Inc., and by the Gannett Company, Inc., to review an order of the National Labor Relations Board. In the first case, the Tri-City Newspaper Guild and others intervened. Order enforced as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: General Acc. Fire & Life Assur. Corp., Limited, of Perth, Scotland, v. Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term.
Headnote: Where parent corporation and subsidiary have maintained a separate corporate existence and it does not appear that the subsidiary is merely a dummy for parent corporation, the courts will recognize the separate entities and will not charge the acts of one against the other on the theory of agency.
Document Preview: Action by the General Accident Fire & Life Assurance Corporation, Limited, of Perth, Scotland, against the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company. On motion to vacate and set aside service of process upon the defendant. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: John A. Parks Co. v. General Discount Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: If corporation was a parent corporation to another corporation, it was required to be shown that the alleged subsidiary was formed for the purpose of perpetrating a fraud in order that the alleged parent corporation be held liable for the acts of the alleged subsidiary.
Document Preview: Actions, which were tried at the same time, by the John A. Parks Company and by the Cadillac Insurance Agency against the General Discount Corporation and the General Finance Corporation to hold the defendants liable for the amounts of judgments previously obtained by the plaintiffs against F. W. Young, Inc., on the theory that the defendants had assets in their possession, custody, or control belonging to F. W. Young, Inc. From an adverse decree, the plaintiffs appeal, and the appeals are consolidated. Decree affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. Timken Silent Automatic Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: A parent corporation may not be treated as one with a wholly owned subsidiary, in absence of proof that control by the parent has wronged or defrauded a third party.
Document Preview: CLARK, Circuit Judge, dissenting in part. Petition by the National Labor Relations Board for enforcement of an order made by the board against the Timken Silent Automatic Company and another. On motion by the last directors of the Timken Silent Automatic Company, and on motion by the Timken-Detroit Axle Company, to dismiss petition. Motion of the Timken Silent Automatic Company denied, and motion of Timken-Detroit Axle Company granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: E. Albrecht & Son v. Landy
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: A parent corporation and its wholly-owned subsidiary may for certain purposes and under proper circumstances be treated as separate entities.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the District of Minnesota; George F. Sullivan, Judge. Action by E. Albrecht & Son, Incorporated, against J. R. Landy, Collector of Internal Revenue of the United States of America in and for the District of Minnesota, to recover payment of excise taxes alleged to have been erroneously exacted. From an adverse judgment, 27 F.Supp. 65, the plaintiff appeals. Reversed and remanded for further proceedings in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Fish v. East
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Whether subsidiary is mere "instrumentality" of parent corporation so as to permit disregarding the corporate entity depends on whether parent corporation owns a majority of the capital stock of subsidiary, the parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers, the parent corporation finances subsidiary, the subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, the parent corporation pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary, the subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent corporation, the subsidiary is referred to as such by parent corporation or as a department or division, the directors or executives of subsidiary do not act in the interests of subsidiary, but take direction from parent corporation, and the formal requirements of the subsidiary as an independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: 37. Bankruptcy 467(4) 4A finding by the referee in bankruptcy upon conflicting evidence, where affirmed by the District Judge and supported by substantial evidence, may not be set aside by the Circuit Court of Appeals on review. Appeals from the District Court of the United States for the District of Colorado; J. Foster Symes, Judge. Proceeding between Erland F. Fish and others and John H. East, Jr., as trustee in bankruptcy of the Royal Tiger Mines Company, bankrupt, involving a turnover order.  Action by Erland F. Fish against John H. East, Jr., as trustee in bankruptcy of the Royal Tiger Mines Company, a bankrupt, to require the trustee to convey certain property to plaintiff, and to quiet title thereto.  Proceeding between Erland F. Fish and others and John H. East, Jr., as trustee in bankruptcy of the Royal Tiger Mines Company, bankrupt, also involving a turnover order.  Proceeding by Harry Cohen, doing business as Samuel Cohen Company, and others...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Blaustein v. Pan Am. Petroleum & Transport Co.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term.
Headnote: Equity frequently disregards separate corporate entities of parent and subsidiary corporations in order to do justice, even where subsidiaries are not mere instrumentalities of the parent.
Document Preview: Derivative action by Louis Blaustein and others, suing on behalf of themselves and on behalf of all stockholders of the Pan American Petroleum & Transport Company, similarly situated, against the Pan American Petroleum & Transport Company and others, for alleged breach of fiduciary obligations, wherein Fred C. Haas and Beatrice P. Barry intervened as plaintiffs. Interlocutory judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: First Huntington Nat. Bank v. Guyan Machinery Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: A parental corporation is not necessarily liable for the acts of its subsidiary because of parental control, but if the control is absolute, and the liquidation of the subsidiary is manipulated by the parent for its own purpose, in such manner as to prejudice a third person, the parent must answer therefor.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Logan County. Suit by the First Huntington National Bank against the Guyan Machinery Company to hold the defendant liable for an indebtedness of a subsidiary corporation. From a decree in favor of the defendant, the plaintiff appeals. Reversed, and cause remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Ledlow v. Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: A parent corporation is not liable for the torts of a subsidiary unless the separate corporate existence is a sham or is used to conceal the truth or perpetrate fraud or unless the subsidiary is used as an agent or instrumentality of the parent corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Jefferson County; Leigh M. Clark, Judge. Action for damages for assault and battery by E. C. Ledlow against the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company of Alabama. From a judgment for defendant, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Walker v. Southwest Mines Development Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Arizona.
Headnote: While in general a corporation is a separate legal entity, where corporation resorts to stock ownership in another to use latter as a mere agency or instrumentality of owning company, court will in a proper case disregard corporate entity and treat corporation as one in interest of justice.
Document Preview: Minority stockholders' suit by Ralph H. Walker, on behalf of the Southwest Mines Development Company, a corporation, himself and all other stockholders similarly situated, against the Southwest Mines Development Company, a corporation, and others to set aside certain conveyances of mining property to the Arizona Consolidated Mining Company and to restore the property to the Southwest Mines Development Company, consolidated for trial with suit by E. C. Locklear to foreclose certain real and chattel mortgages executed by the Arizona Consolidated Mining Company on the property conveyed to it by the Southwest Mines Development Company, wherein Ralph H. Walker intervened. From adverse judgments, Ralph H. Walker appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Kentucky Electric Power Co. v. Norton Coal Mining Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: If ownership of all the stock of one corporation by another is resorted to only for purpose of normally participating in affairs of subsidiary corporation in a manner usual to stockholders, and not for purpose of taking some unfair advantage of subsidiary or using it as a mere adjunct to main corporation or as a subterfuge to justify wrongdoing, the separate identity of main corporation and subsidiary corporation will not be disregarded, but their respective rights when dealing with each other in respect to their separate property will be recognized and maintained.
Document Preview: Appeals from the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Kentucky; Elwood Hamilton, Judge. Consolidated receivership and mortgage foreclosure actions instituted by creditors against the Norton Coal Mining Company and others, wherein the Kentucky Electric Power Company filed an intervening petition.  From the decree, the Kentucky Electric Power Company, the Norton Coal Mining Company and others appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Brown v. Standard Casket Mfg. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama
Headnote: Generally, corporation's ownership of controlling stock of another corporation does not destroy the latter corporation's identity as a distinct legal entity, and the former corporation is not liable for torts of the latter corporation unless separate corporate existence is mere sham, or is an instrument for concealing the truth or perpetrating fraud, or the latter corporation is an instrumentality or adjunct of the former corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Montgomery County; Walter B. Jones, Judge. Action for damages by Irma Lee Brown against the Standard Casket Manufacturing Company and the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company. Judgment for defendants, and plaintiff appeals. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Gledhill v. Fisher & Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Before corporate entity may be properly disregarded and parent corporation held liable for act of its subsidiary, it must be shown not only that undue domination was exercised by parent corporation over subsidiary, but also that such control was exercised in manner as to defraud complainant, and that unjust loss or injury will be suffered by complainant as result of such domination unless parent corporation is held liable.
Document Preview: Suit by George E. Gledhill and another against Fisher & Co. and others. From an adverse decree, defendants appeal and plaintiffs cross-appeal. Decree reversed and bill of complaint dismissed. NELSON SHARPE, J., dissenting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Trustees System of Co. of Pennsylvania v. Payne
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Fiction of corporate entity may be disregarded on question of appointment of receivers, where subsidiary corporations are parts of parent corporation.
Document Preview: Separate suits by George H. Payne and another against the Trustees System Company of Pennsylvania, against the Trustees System Company of Reading, against the Trustees System Company of Philadelphia, against the Trusco Company of Reading, and against the Trusco Company of Philadelphia. From decrees appointing receivers, defendants appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hollywood Cleaning & Pressing Co. v. Hollywood Laundry Service
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: Parent corporation's ownership of all stock of another corporation will not warrant disregarding separate corporate entity unless unity of interest has destroyed individuality of each corporation, and observance of separate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: In Bank. Action by the Hollywood Cleaning & Pressing Company against the Hollywood Laundry Service, Incorporated. From the portion of the judgment adverse to it, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed. For prior opinion, see 12 P.(2d) 145.

Title: La Varre v. International Paper Co.
Court: District Court, E.D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Rule as to disregarding corporate entity and treating subsidiary and parent corporation as one held inapplicable in determining whether latter was subject to jurisdiction of state court.
Document Preview: Action by William La varre against the International Paper Company and another.  On motion by defendants to set aside the service of the summons and complaint and to dissolve the attachment obtained by plaintiff and to dismiss the action.  Motions granted in part, and denied in part.

Title: Bethlehem Steel Co. v. Raymond Concrete Pile Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: That all of railroad company's capital stock was in the name of a steel company with the exception of a few shares held by directors could not make it any the less a corporation.

Title: Martin v. Development Co. of America
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Unless it is a mere sham, etc., a holding company has a distinct corporate existence from the company whose stock it holds.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the District of Arizona. Bill by John H. Martin, as trustee in bankruptcy of the Imperial Copper Company, a corporation, against the Development Company of America, a corporation. From a decree dismissing the bill, complainant appeals. Affirmed.

Title: Seymour v. Woodstock & Sycamore Traction Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: The fact that two corporations have same president, or same president and same secretary, or that one of corporations, a construction corporation, agrees to pay in part for work done by delivering bonds or stock of another corporation, does not prove that the two corporations are the same, nor does fact that one corporation owns majority of stock in another, if it can lawfully hold such stock, prove that they are same, or that one is dummy for the other and that what one corporation does the other really does also.
